column2: Some spotting is normal, but it usually goes away in a few days. A health worker can guide you.

column1: My partner wants me to delay using contraception until marriage.
column2: Your body, your choice. You have the right to protect yourself now.

column1: I feel nervous about taking the pill every day.
column2: Set a reminder on your phone or ask a friend to help. Daily routine makes it easier.

column1: I’m embarrassed to ask for family planning because I’m under 18.
column2: Services for adolescents are confidential and respectful in Nepal.

column1: I’m worried people will find out I’m on contraceptives.
column2: Health staff keep records private. You control who knows.

column1: I feel pressured to use traditional methods instead of modern ones.
column2: Modern methods are more reliable. You can choose what works best for your body.

column1: My partner says side effects are dangerous. Should I stop?
column2: Side effects are usually minor. If serious, consult a health worker before stopping.

column1: I feel anxious about using condoms for the first time.
column2: It’s normal. Practice and communication with your partner help.

column1: I don’t know which method is best for me.
column2: A health worker can guide you based on your age, health, and lifestyle.

column1: I’m scared of getting pregnant even while on birth control.
column2: No method is 100% effective, but correct and consistent use greatly reduces risk.

column1: My partner wants me to rely on withdrawal. Is that safe?
column2: Withdrawal is less reliable. Using modern contraception is safer for preventing pregnancy.

column1: At what age do adolescents in Nepal typically first hear about family planning?
column2: Most adolescents hear about family planning between 13–16 years, often through schools, media, or peers.

column1: How does family planning education reach young people in Nepal?
column2: Through school curricula, youth clubs, FCHV outreach, social media campaigns, and health facility counseling.

column1: What percentage of Nepali adolescents know at least one modern contraceptive method?
column2: Around 70–75% of adolescents aged 15–19 have heard of at least one modern method.

column1: What is the main source of family planning information for young people in Nepal?
column2: Schools (37%), friends/peers (25%), and media campaigns (20%).

column1: Do rural adolescents have the same awareness as urban adolescents?
column2: No — urban youth are more aware, while rural adolescents often rely on community health workers and family for information.

column1: At what stage of schooling is family planning usually introduced in Nepal?
column2: Typically in secondary school (grades 9–10) through health and reproductive education classes.

column1: Why is early curiosity about family planning important?
column2: It encourages responsible decision-making, delays early pregnancies, and reduces unsafe abortions.

column1: How do parents influence adolescent awareness?
column2: Parental communication improves knowledge and attitudes; however, many parents hesitate to discuss sexual health openly.

column1: What role do Female Community Health Volunteers (FCHVs) play for adolescents?
column2: They provide counseling, answer questions, and distribute contraceptives or information to youth and young couples.

column1: How do myths and misconceptions affect early curiosity?
column2: Misbeliefs like “contraceptives cause infertility” can discourage young people from asking questions or seeking information.

column1: How effective are media campaigns for early awareness in Nepal?
column2: Radio, TV, and social media campaigns reach millions, but youth often prefer interactive content like apps or SMS quizzes.

column1: Which social media platforms help increase curiosity about family planning among youth?
column2: Facebook, TikTok, Instagram, and YouTube are widely used for awareness campaigns.

column1: Do community meetings improve early knowledge about family planning?
column2: Yes — community gatherings and youth clubs provide safe spaces to ask questions and learn about methods.

column1: How do peer educators contribute to awareness?
column2: Trained youth share factual information with peers, correcting myths and encouraging safe practices.

column1: Are there differences in curiosity levels between boys and girls?
column2: Yes — girls often ask more questions about health, while boys may focus on method responsibility; gender-targeted programs help balance this.

column1: What motivates early curiosity in adolescents about family planning?
column2: Curiosity often stems from school lessons, peer discussions, media, or observing older siblings and parents.

column1: What percentage of adolescents feel comfortable asking questions about contraception?
column2: Only about 40–45% feel comfortable asking adults or health workers.

column1: How does early curiosity affect later contraceptive use?
column2: Adolescents who are informed early are more likely to use contraception responsibly when sexually active.

column1: What barriers exist to early awareness in Nepal?
column2: Cultural taboos, limited access in rural areas, fear of judgment, and low parental communication.

column1: How can curiosity be encouraged safely in schools?
column2: Through interactive lessons, anonymous question boxes, peer mentoring, and youth-friendly health education programs.

column1: What government programs target adolescent reproductive health in Nepal?
column2: Programs like Adolescent Sexual and Reproductive Health (ASRH) under MoHP focus on awareness and counseling.

column1: How does the National Population Policy of Nepal address youth awareness?
column2: It emphasizes comprehensive education, youth-friendly services, and community involvement in early family planning awareness.

column1: How do NGOs support early curiosity in family planning?
column2: Organizations like FPAN, Marie Stopes, and UNFPA Nepal provide training, school workshops, and youth media campaigns.

column1: What are youth-friendly health services?
column2: Clinics or programs designed to provide confidential, respectful, and accessible contraceptive and reproductive health information for young people.

column1: How can technology support early curiosity?
column2: Mobile apps, hotlines, chatbots, and social media pages provide confidential and interactive platforms for adolescents to ask questions and learn safely.

column1: At what age should family planning education ideally start for adolescents?
column2: Around 10–12 years, focusing on basic reproductive health and body awareness.

column1: What is one early indicator that a young person is curious about family planning?
column2: Asking questions about menstruation, pregnancy, or how to prevent unwanted pregnancies.

column1: How does curiosity about family planning differ between boys and girls?
column2: Girls often ask more about reproductive health and contraception, while boys focus on responsibility and side effects.

column1: Why is it important to address family planning curiosity early?
column2: Early guidance helps prevent teenage pregnancies, reduces health risks, and promotes responsible sexual behavior.

column1: How do schools in Nepal support early awareness of family planning?
column2: Through sexual and reproductive health (SRH) classes, peer clubs, and life skills education.

column1: What percentage of schools include reproductive health education in their curriculum?
column2: About 60–70%, though implementation quality varies across provinces.

column1: How do question-and-answer sessions in classrooms help adolescents?
column2: They allow youth to clarify myths, gain factual knowledge, and build confidence in decision-making.

column1: How do teachers influence early curiosity?
column2: Teachers who provide accurate, non-judgmental information encourage students to ask questions and learn responsibly.

column1: Are extracurricular activities useful for family planning awareness?
column2: Yes — clubs, debates, and workshops create safe spaces for discussion.

column1: How important is parental communication for adolescent awareness?
column2: Very important — adolescents with open parental guidance are more likely to use contraception safely in the future.

column1: How do mobile health apps help with family planning in Nepal?
column2: They provide information, reminders for pills or injectables, location of nearest clinic, and sometimes chat support; but you should verify their reliability.

column1: Are there privacy risks when using digital platforms for contraception or counselling?
column2: Yes—data security, unauthorized sharing, and stigma if someone else sees your phone. Choose apps with strong privacy policies.

column1: How can parents encourage curiosity without shame or fear?
column2: By answering questions honestly, providing age-appropriate information, and creating a trusting environment.

column1: What role do older siblings play in early curiosity?
column2: Siblings often share knowledge or stories, which can influence curiosity positively or negatively depending on accuracy.

column1: How can family-based programs improve early awareness?
column2: Through workshops, community meetings, and counseling sessions aimed at parents and guardians.

column1: How do community health workers raise awareness among adolescents?
column2: By visiting schools, conducting group sessions, and providing brochures or counseling.

column1: How does radio help in promoting early curiosity?
column2: Radio programs are widely accessible in rural areas and can share stories, myths, and correct information.

column1: How do social media platforms affect youth curiosity?
column2: Platforms like Facebook, TikTok, and YouTube provide easy access to information but need fact-checking to avoid misinformation.

column1: What role do peer groups play in early curiosity?
column2: Friends influence knowledge, attitudes, and openness to asking questions; peer-led sessions are effective for learning.

column1: Are awareness campaigns reaching remote areas effectively?
column2: Efforts are increasing via FCHVs and mobile health units, but remote areas still have lower exposure.

column1: What percentage of adolescents feel confident to ask questions about contraception in Nepal?
column2: Around 40–45%, indicating social or cultural hesitation.

column1: How do cultural norms affect early curiosity?
column2: Taboos around discussing sex or contraception can limit curiosity and prevent learning.

column1: What are common misconceptions that affect curiosity in adolescents?
column2: Beliefs like “contraceptives cause infertility” or “only married people should use contraceptives” reduce engagement.

column1: How can programs make curiosity safe and productive?
column2: By creating youth-friendly spaces, anonymous question channels, trained counselors, and accurate media campaigns.

column1: How do young people in Nepal even start learning about family planning?
column2: Many start learning in school health classes, from friends, or through media campaigns, while some learn from parents or health volunteers.

column1: Why do some adolescents feel shy to ask about contraception?
column2: Cultural taboos, fear of judgment, and lack of privacy make young people hesitant to ask questions.

column1: Can boys also learn about contraceptives, or is it mostly for girls?
column2: Boys are included in education programs, and it’s important they learn their role in shared responsibility.

column1: If I’m curious about contraception, who can I trust to give accurate information in Nepal?
column2: FCHVs, trained health workers, school teachers, and reputable NGOs like FPAN or Marie Stopes are trustworthy sources.

column1: Do all adolescents know that pregnancy can happen even after one time of unprotected sex?
column2: Not always — this is a common misconception, and awareness programs emphasize that pregnancy can happen anytime without protection.

column1: What are the easiest contraceptives to use for someone just learning about them?
column2: Condoms, pills, and emergency contraceptives are simple to start with, and FCHVs can explain proper use.

column1: Can using contraceptives affect my future fertility?
column2: Most temporary methods do not affect long-term fertility, while permanent methods like sterilization are irreversible.

column1: How effective are implants and IUDs for long-term protection?
column2: Extremely effective — over 99% when properly inserted, and they last 3–10 years depending on the method.

column1: Are there contraceptives that boys can use besides condoms?
column2: Currently, condoms and vasectomy are the main male options; research is ongoing for more male contraceptives.

column1: Can emergency contraceptive pills be used more than once in a month?
column2: Yes, they can be used multiple times, but they are not meant as a regular method; regular contraception is safer.

column1: . How do I know which method is right for me?
column2: Choosing depends on age, health, future pregnancy plans, convenience, and side effects. A health worker can help decide.

column1: If I live in a rural area, can I still get contraceptives easily?
column2: Yes — through FCHVs, local health posts, mobile clinics, and NGOs, though availability may vary.

column1: Can I discuss contraceptives with my parents without getting into trouble?
column2: Many parents are open if approached respectfully, and schools/NGOs provide confidential counseling.

column1: How soon after giving birth can I start using family planning?
column2: Immediately postpartum, methods like LAM, IUDs, or injectables can be used safely.

column1: What happens if I stop using a contraceptive?
column2: Fertility usually returns quickly, except for permanent methods like sterilization.

column1: Do most people in Nepal approve of family planning?
column2: Awareness is increasing, and most urban and educated populations support it, but some rural or traditional communities may have resistance.

column1: Can young couples access family planning even if they are not married?
column2: Access is sometimes limited by cultural norms, but youth-friendly clinics and NGOs provide confidential services.

column1: How do peers influence curiosity about contraception?
column2: Peer discussion can either increase awareness or spread myths, so programs train peer educators to provide accurate info.

column1: Are there any myths I should be careful about?
column2: Yes — myths like “contraceptives cause permanent infertility” or “you can’t use them before the first child” are false.

column1: How does family planning help families economically?
column2: By spacing births and limiting family size, households can better manage food, education, and healthcare expenses.

column1: How do radio or TV programs help someone curious about contraception?
column2: They explain methods, dispel myths, and provide hotlines or health center information, reaching remote audiences.

column1: Are there apps or websites for learning about family planning in Nepal?
column2: Yes — some apps, NGO websites, and social media pages offer interactive info and counseling.

column1: Can curiosity about family planning in schools influence future behavior?
column2: Definitely — students who learn early are more likely to use contraception responsibly and avoid early pregnancies.

column1: What role do NGOs play for someone curious about contraception?
column2: NGOs organize workshops, school visits, youth clubs, and counseling sessions to provide reliable information.

column1: If I ask questions about contraception, will people judge me?
column2: Awareness programs aim to create safe, non-judgmental environments, but cultural stigma may exist, so confidential services are recommended.

column1: Can I get contraceptives even if I’m not married?
column2: Yes. Some health facilities, youth-friendly clinics, and NGOs provide confidential services to unmarried youth.

column1: What if I forget to take a contraceptive pill one day?
column2: Missing one pill usually doesn’t cause pregnancy, but take it as soon as possible and use a backup method if needed.

column1: Are contraceptives safe for teenagers?
column2: Yes. Most modern methods like condoms, pills, and injectables are safe for adolescents when used correctly.

column1: Can contraceptives cause cancer or permanent health problems?
column2: No, most studies show modern contraceptives are safe, though some hormonal methods may have minor temporary side effects.

column1: What are common side effects I should know about?
column2: Possible effects include irregular bleeding, mild weight changes, or nausea, but these usually pass within a few months.

column1: f I experience side effects, what should I do?
column2: Consult a health worker or FCHV. They can suggest alternative methods or manage side effects safely.

column1: Can contraceptives protect against sexually transmitted infections (STIs)?
column2: Only condoms protect against STIs; other methods prevent pregnancy but not infections.

column1: Do boys have to care about family planning?
column2: Absolutely. Boys play a key role in using condoms, supporting their partner, and making shared decisions.

column1: Is vasectomy safe for men?
column2: Yes. It’s a simple, safe, and permanent method that does not affect sexual performance.

column1: Can both partners decide together which method to use?
column2: Yes. Joint decision-making improves satisfaction and reduces misunderstandings.

column1: What if my partner doesn’t want to use contraception?
column2: Talk openly and seek counseling from a health worker or youth-friendly service to explore options.

column1: Can using contraceptives make sexual life less enjoyable?
column2: Most people do not experience reduced pleasure; condoms may slightly change sensation, but it’s a small adjustment.

column1: Can I get contraceptives without my parents knowing?
column2: Yes, youth-friendly services are confidential, so you can ask questions and get methods safely.

column1: Are emergency contraceptive pills available in Nepal?
column2: Yes, they are available in pharmacies, hospitals, and clinics, to be used within 72 hours of unprotected sex.

column1: How much do contraceptives cost in Nepal?
column2: Many methods are free at government facilities. Private pharmacies may charge a small fee.

column1: Can I ask a health worker questions anonymously?
column2: Yes. Some clinics provide hotlines, online chats, or suggestion boxes for confidential queries.

column1: How do I know which method is most effective?
column2: Implants and IUDs are over 99% effective, pills and injectables around 91–94% with typical use, condoms 85–98%.

column1: Are contraceptives only for married couples?
column2: No. They are for anyone who wants to prevent pregnancy, regardless of marital status.

column1: Can I combine methods for extra protection?
column2: Yes. Using condoms with another method provides pregnancy and STI protection.

column1: How can I learn more safely about family planning online?
column2: Use reliable sources like UNFPA Nepal, FPAN, and MoHP websites, and avoid unverified social media posts.

column1: Why is it important to start asking questions about family planning early?
column2: Early awareness helps you make informed choices, prevent early or unwanted pregnancies, and take control of your reproductive health.

column1: How do I know when I am fertile?
column2: Fertility usually occurs around mid-cycle, roughly 12–16 days before your next period. Contraceptives help prevent pregnancy even if you don’t track it perfectly.

column1: Can I get pregnant the first time I have sex?
column2: Yes. Pregnancy can happen any time you have unprotected sex, even if it’s the first time.

column1: If I am still young, do I really need contraception?
column2: Yes. Contraception is about planning and safety, even for young people who may be sexually active.

column1: Does my health affect which contraceptive I can use?
column2: Yes. Health conditions like high blood pressure or hormonal issues may influence method choice. Health workers can help choose the safest option.

column1: What is the easiest way to start contraception?
column2: Condoms are easy, safe, and available without a prescription. Pills and injectables can also be started with guidance from a health worker.

column1: How has the cost of living and urban stress affected family planning in Nepal?
column2: Economic pressures and insecure jobs lead couples to delay or have fewer children; they may use contraception for planning.

column1: Why do many women stop using contraception within a year in Nepal?
column2: High discontinuation rates (e.g., 64.4% within 12 months) due to side effects, desire to become pregnant, method failure, or service barriers.

column1: What modern methods are Nepal promoting now?
column2: Long-acting reversible contraceptives (LARCs) such as implants or IUDs, and improved outreach for youth and remote populations.

column1: If I live with a disability, can I access family planning services in Nepal?
column2: Yes. You have the right. But physical access, communication and correct counselling may need extra support—ask for accessible services.

column1: What if my preferred method is not available in my area because of supply issues?
column2: Ask the health worker when the next supply is due, or if the method is available at a nearby facility or outreach camp.

column1: How has the COVID-19 pandemic affected family planning services in Nepal?
column2: It disrupted supply chains, reduced outreach, and increased access barriers, especially in remote areas. Recovery is ongoing.

column1: How do younger couples think differently about child-spacing compared to older generations?
column2: They often delay first child due to education, jobs and lifestyle; they may prefer fewer children and use contraception more intentionally.

column1: How does urban versus rural location influence modern contraceptive use in Nepal?
column2: Urban women use contraception at higher rates, have better access to services and information; rural women face geographic, supply and cultural barriers.

column1: What are the environmental or disaster-response challenges for family planning in remote Nepal?
column2: Difficult terrain, poor infrastructure, supply chain disruptions after disasters, and fewer outreach camps can limit services.

column1: Are young unmarried women judged for seeking family planning in Nepal?
column2: Sometimes yes—social stigma persists. Confidential services, peer counselling and youth-friendly platforms help reduce this.

column1: How can I verify if online information about contraception is accurate and safe?
column2: Check if the source is from government, UN agencies, or credible health NGOs; always cross-check with a qualified health provider.

column1: What happens if I change my mind and want to remove a long-acting method early?
column2: You can have it removed—your right. Health workers should explain removal, alternatives and ensure you are informed.

column1: Are there new legal or policy changes about family planning in Nepal that I should know?
column2: Policies emphasise adolescent access, non-discrimination, expansion of youth-friendly services, and strengthening LARC uptake.

column1: How does social media influence people’s perceptions about family planning in Nepal?
column2: It spreads both accurate information and myths; peer-led social media campaigns and influencers can help correct misinformation.

column1: What are the challenges in ensuring equity of access to contraceptives across provinces?
column2: Remote districts, poor infrastructure, ethnic minority groups, poverty, and supply chain gaps create unequal access.

column1: How do service-provider attitudes impact modern couples in Nepal seeking family planning?
column2: Judgmental or uninformed providers reduce trust, delay uptake, increase discontinuation; training in respectful, youth-friendly care is vital.

column1: If I use modern contraception, will I still be able to have children later?
column2: Yes. Most modern methods are reversible. Sterilization is permanent, so choose only if you’re sure you don’t want more children.

column1: How can I talk about contraception with my spouse respectfully if he opposes it?
column2: Invite a health counsellor for joint session, use facts (health, cost, timing), ask about his concerns, and work towards shared goals rather than conflict.

column1: My job is unstable and income uncertain—should we delay having children?
column2: Yes. Delaying children and using contraception until you’re financially stable is a responsible choice and recommended by family welfare programmes.

column1: Are there services for postpartum family planning in Nepal?
column2: Yes. Many facilities offer counselling and method provision within 6 weeks of delivery, but availability varies by location.

column1: Does modern contraceptive use help reduce maternal and infant mortality in Nepal?
column2: Yes. Spacing pregnancies and preventing unintended pregnancies reduces health risks for mother and baby.

column1: What should I ask a provider when I want a method suitable for remote living (hard to reach clinic)?
column2: Ask about long-acting methods, side-effects, removal access, follow-up needs, and what happens if you can’t reach the clinic for a while.

column1: Are contraceptive methods available free of cost in government facilities in Nepal?
column2: Yes—government health posts and hospitals provide many modern methods free of charge or at subsidised cost.

column1: How do myths about side-effects influence method choice in Nepal?
column2: Fear of side-effects (real or perceived) leads to low uptake or high discontinuation; good counselling is needed.

column1: What is “unmet need” for family planning and how does it apply in Nepal?
column2: Unmet need means a woman wants to avoid or delay pregnancy but isn’t using contraception. In Nepal it remains sizeable (~21% of married women) according to NDHS 2022.

column1: If someone experiences serious side-effects from a contraceptive method, what should they do?
column2: Immediately visit a qualified health provider, explain symptoms, stop method if advised, and consider switching to another method under supervision.

column1: Are there community outreach programmes for family planning in Nepal’s remote areas?
column2: Yes. Mobile camps, outreach by FCHVs, and partner NGO programmes reach remote areas with counselling and methods.

column1: How does poverty affect access to family planning methods in Nepal?
column2: Poverty reduces access to clinics, transport, choice of methods and correct follow-up, increasing unmet need and lower method uptake.

column1: Is taking a contraceptive method tied to one’s caste or ethnicity in Nepal?
column2: Not legally—but data show differences: some ethnic groups and poorer/women with less education are less likely to use long-acting methods.

column1: What should I consider if I’m thinking about a permanent method (sterilization)?
column2: Be absolutely sure you don’t want more children, ask about risks, reversibility is limited, and ensure you’re fully informed.

column1: How is gender equality linked to family planning in Nepal?
column2: When women have access to contraception and can decide, it supports gender equality: education, employment, better health outcomes. Cultural norms still limit this in some areas.

column1: Are there services specifically for adolescents in Nepal for family planning?
column2: Yes—adolescent-friendly health services exist, but coverage and quality vary. Youth may still face stigma and confidentiality concerns.

column1: How can remote and digital methods help link people to family planning services when the clinic is far away?
column2: Through tele-counselling, SMS reminders, mobile outreach, digital education and tracking tools. They complement but don’t replace in-person services.

column1: What if I decide later to change my method or stop using contraception entirely?
column2: That is your right. You can switch or stop at any time—just discuss with a provider to ensure safe transition or removal if applicable.

column1: How do younger married couples in Kathmandu approach family planning differently than older generations?
column2: They often delay children for work/education, use modern methods earlier, and consider financial stability and quality of life when planning family size.

column1: What is the link between modern contraception use and reducing unsafe abortion in Nepal?
column2: By preventing unintended pregnancies, modern contraception reduces the number of unsafe abortions and associated health risks. Improved contraceptive access is part of the strategy.

column1: What happens to records of my contraceptive choice—can my husband or family see them?
column2: Health facilities are meant to keep your records confidential under patient rights. If you're concerned, you can ask the provider how the records are stored and who has access.

column1: My culture says that using contraceptives means a woman is “unnatural” or “bad.” How should I respond?
column2: You can explain that contraceptives help protect your health and allow you to plan for the best time to have children—not to avoid motherhood altogether. Also mention that many families use them safely and responsibly.

column1: I’ve heard that in some ethnic communities people believe an IUD can travel to other parts of the body—is that true?
column2: No—that’s a myth. IUDs remain in the uterus and reputable health providers can show how they work, answer your questions and reassure you.

column1: How do socio-economic issues (cost of living, jobs, housing) affect family planning decisions in Nepal?
column2: Rising costs, insecure jobs and big housing expenses make couples delay children or use family planning even when they might want children, showing that planning is linked to economic realities.

column1: My cultural belief is that childbearing is a duty—not a choice. How does family planning fit in?
column2: Family planning doesn’t oppose childbearing, it supports safe timing and spacing of children so both mother and baby can be healthy. It’s about making childbirth positive, not mandatory.

column1: Does caste or ethnicity matter in the choice or access of family planning services in Nepal?
column2: Access and uptake vary by ethnic group and caste. Marginalised and indigenous groups often have lower uptake due to geographic, social and cultural barriers.

column1: Are there cultural rituals or superstitions that stop men from choosing vasectomy in Nepal?
column2: Yes. In some ethnic groups, men fear postoperative constraints on traditional rituals or belief that vasectomy affects ritual purity. Overcoming that requires community dialogue.

column1: Can I refuse a contraceptive method if a health worker pressures me into it?
column2: Yes, you always have freedom of choice and the right to voluntary, informed consent. If you feel pressured, you can request a different provider or complain.

column1: When using digital counselling or chatbots for family planning, how can I trust the information?
column2: Verify that the tool is backed by respected organisations (govt, UNFPA, FPAN). Look for clear references, privacy policy, and check advice with a real health professional.

column1: How do I decide what contraceptive method matches my lifestyle in modern Nepal (jobs, mobility, uncertain income)?
column2: Consider factors: how frequently you can access clinic, side-effects you tolerate, plans for children, partner status, cost/income, and mobility. Discuss these with a provider.

column1: My parents want grandchildren soon after our marriage—how can we plan responsibly while respecting family expectations?
column2: You and your partner can gently explain your plans (education, career, finances), share information about health benefits of spacing births, and propose a method to delay until you’re ready.

column1: If I plan to migrate (for work or study) in the future, what should I know about family planning now?
column2: Choose a method with minimal maintenance, check whether your destination country has compatible services, ensure are set up to get refills/substitute if needed.

column1: Can a husband see his wife’s family planning record without her consent?
column2: No. Only the woman herself has the right to access her reproductive health record unless she authorizes someone else.

column1: How do I avoid being seen at the health post while seeking family planning advice?
column2: Visit at off-peak hours or contact mobile outreach teams who provide home visits discreetly.

column1: Are there apps in Nepal that offer private contraceptive tracking?
column2: Yes. Apps like SafeMotherhood Nepal and international apps like Clue or MySathi allow privacy options and password protection.

column1: How safe is my data when I use online counselling for family planning?
column2: Use only verified government or UNFPA-supported sites that use secure encryption and don’t share personal data.

column1: Can I use a fake name at the clinic to protect privacy?
column2: You can request anonymity, though clinics prefer real data for medical safety. Confidentiality is still guaranteed.

column1: Are conversations with chatbots about contraception private?
column2: Yes, if the chatbot complies with privacy standards and doesn’t store identifiable data.

column1: Can my employer access my reproductive health information?
column2: No. That would violate privacy laws under Nepal’s health regulations.

column1: I’m a teenager. Can I talk to a health worker privately without my parents?
column2: Yes. Adolescents can access confidential counselling under Nepal’s adolescent health policy.

column1: What should I do if a provider shares my private health details publicly?
column2: You can report it to the District Health Office or National Health Rights Commission.

column1: What if my partner checks my phone and sees contraception reminders?
column2: Use apps with disguised notifications or manual tracking instead.

column1: Can I get counselling over a phone call instead of visiting in person?
column2: Yes. FPAN and UNFPA offer telephone and online counselling services for privacy.

column1: Are there laws protecting reproductive privacy in Nepal?
column2: Yes. The Reproductive Health Rights Act 2018 guarantees confidentiality and informed consent.

column1: Can family planning data be shared for research without consent?
column2: Only anonymized data can be shared; personal identifiers are removed.

column1: Is privacy different in rural vs. urban clinics?
column2: Urban clinics often have better facilities for privacy, but outreach programs in rural areas also maintain confidentiality standards.

column1: Can I access contraception secretly if I am in an abusive relationship?
column2: Yes, seek support from women’s shelters or NGOs that provide discreet access to services.

column1: What should I do if I’m filmed or photographed at a clinic?
column2: Report it immediately; photography inside health facilities without consent is illegal.

column1: Can I request a female provider for more privacy?
column2: Yes. Most FP clinics honor gender preference requests.

column1: How long does an implant work?
column2: Implants protect against pregnancy for 3–5 years, depending on the brand.

column1: What if I forget to use a method sometimes?
column2: Occasional missed use may reduce effectiveness, so consider backup methods like emergency pills.

column1: Are contraceptives harmful for teenagers?
column2: No. Most modern methods like pills, condoms, injectables, and implants are safe for adolescents.

column1: What are the common side effects I might notice?
column2: Possible mild effects include spotting, nausea, headaches, or breast tenderness. Most go away in a few months.

column1: Can contraception cause cancer?
column2: No, studies show modern methods are safe. Hormonal methods may slightly affect some risks, but benefits outweigh them.

column1: What if I experience strong side effects?
column2: Talk to a health worker or FCHV. They can suggest alternative methods or help manage side effects safely.

column1: Can contraception affect my mood?
column2: Hormonal methods may cause temporary mood changes, but they usually stabilize after a few months.

column1: Is vasectomy safe?
column2: Yes. It’s a minor, safe, permanent procedure that does not affect sexual performance.

column1: Can I discuss contraception with my partner without arguing?
column2: Open, respectful conversations work best. Health workers can provide counseling for couples.

column1: What if my partner refuses contraception?
column2: Try education and counseling. Some programs provide confidential services for young women to explore options safely.

column1: Can I ask questions anonymously?
column2: Yes. Hotlines, apps, suggestion boxes, and youth-friendly services allow confidential questions.

column1: Can contraceptives fail?
column2: Yes, if used incorrectly. Methods like implants or IUDs are highly effective; pills, condoms, and injectables require consistent use.

column1: Can I start asking about contraception even if I am shy?
column2: Absolutely. Health workers and NGOs provide safe, non-judgmental environments.

column1: How do I know if the information I find online is correct?
column2: Use reliable sources like UNFPA Nepal, FPAN, or Ministry of Health websites, not random social media posts.

column1: Why is it important to start learning about family planning now?
column2: Early awareness helps make informed choices, prevent unwanted pregnancies, avoid unsafe abortions, and plan for the future.

column1: If I’m only 16, do I really need contraception?
column2: Yes. Contraceptives are for safety and planning, no matter your age, if you are sexually active.

column1: What is the easiest contraceptive to start with?
column2: Condoms are easy, safe, and widely available. Pills or injectables can also be started with guidance from a health worker.

column1: I feel ashamed to talk about emergency contraception.
column2: It’s normal to feel shy. Health workers understand and provide confidential help.

column1: I’m afraid to use family planning because of myths in my community.
column2: Many myths are false. Trained health providers give accurate, safe information.

column1: My partner pressures me to skip my pills.
column2: You control your health. Never skip pills because of pressure.

column1: I feel nervous visiting a clinic alone.
column2: Bring a friend, or go at less busy times. Staff are supportive and confidential.

column1: I’m scared of pain from implants or IUDs.
column2: Some minor discomfort is normal during insertion. Health workers ensure it’s safe.

column1: My partner says condoms ruin intimacy.
column2: Protection is responsible, and many condoms are made for comfort.

column1: I feel ashamed to ask about fertility after stopping contraception.
column2: It’s safe to ask. Fertility usually returns quickly after most methods.

column1: I’m worried my partner won’t support me using contraception.
column2: You can use methods that you control independently, like pills or condoms.

column1: I’m afraid of being judged by health workers.
column2: They are trained to treat everyone respectfully and confidentially.

column1: I feel scared about trying contraception for the first time.
column2: Feeling nervous is normal. Ask questions, and start with a method that feels safe.

column1: My partner wants me to get pregnant to prove love.
column2: Love isn’t proven by pregnancy. You decide when and if to have children.

column1: I’m worried about changing my mind after using a method.
column2: Most methods are reversible. You can switch with a health worker’s guidance.

column1: I feel pressured to follow friends’ choices about family planning.
column2: Your choice is personal. What works for others may not be right for you

column1: I’m nervous about side effects changing my period.
column2: Some changes are normal. A nurse can guide you and help manage side effects.

column1: I feel guilty for using contraception secretly.
column2: It’s okay to protect your health. Your safety matters first.

column1: My partner says I don’t need contraception because I’m young.
column2: Age doesn’t prevent pregnancy. Contraception is important if you’re sexually active.

column1: I’m embarrassed to ask about contraceptives at school.
column2: School health workers or FCHVs can help confidentially.

column1: I feel anxious my partner will leave if I use birth control.
column2: A partner should respect your choices. You don’t need to risk your health.

column1: I’m afraid of bleeding after an implant.
column2: Minor spotting is common. Serious problems are rare. Health staff can help.

column1: My partner says natural methods are enough.
column2: Modern methods are more reliable. You can combine with condoms for extra protection.

column1: I feel nervous asking my parent for contraception.
column2: You don’t have to ask anyone. Health facilities provide confidential services for teens.

column1: I’m scared about being judged for taking emergency contraception.
column2: It’s safe and private. Many young people use it responsibly.

column1: My partner refuses condoms because of myths.
column2: Share accurate information. You can also use other methods that protect you both.

column1: I feel pressure to hide contraceptive use from my partner.
column2: You deserve to make safe choices openly or privately.

column1: I’m anxious about remembering to take pills every day.
column2: Set phone reminders or use a daily habit to help.

column1: I’m afraid of needles for injections.
column2: A trained health worker ensures safe and quick administration.

column1: My partner wants me to rely on traditional methods.
column2: Traditional methods are less reliable. Modern methods are safer.

column1: I feel guilty about using contraception before marriage.
column2: Your health and safety are important. It’s responsible, not wrong.

column1: I’m nervous about discussing side effects with a nurse.
column2: They expect questions. You’ll get clear guidance and reassurance.

column1: My partner makes me feel bad for wanting contraception.
column2: You have the right to protect yourself. Seek support if pressured.

column1: I’m scared about changing my method.
column2: Health workers can guide you safely when switching methods.

column1: I feel embarrassed asking about fertility after stopping contraception.
column2: It’s safe to ask. Fertility usually returns quickly.

column1: My partner says birth control is unnatural.
column2: Contraception is safe and medically approved. You decide what’s best for your body.

column1: I’m worried about family planning affecting my weight.
column2: Most changes are minor. Healthy habits matter more than contraceptives.

column1: I feel anxious about first-time condom use.
column2: Practice, patience, and communication help make it easier.

column1: My partner refuses to use condoms with me.
column2: You can insist, use a method you control, or seek support.

column1: I’m scared of being embarrassed at the clinic.
column2: Staff are trained to be discreet and supportive.

column1: I feel pressure to start a family because everyone else is married.
column2: Your timing is personal. Only you decide when you’re ready.

column1: I’m nervous about side effects from injections.
column2: Minor effects like spotting or nausea are common. Consult a health worker if severe.

column1: My partner says pills will ruin my health.
column2: Modern pills are safe. Health workers can explain benefits and risks.

column1: I feel scared talking about contraception with friends.
column2: You can choose whom to trust. Health workers are confidential.

column1: I’m anxious about remembering follow-up visits for IUDs.
column2: Set reminders. Clinics are supportive and flexible.

column1: My partner wants me to stop contraception once we live together.
column2: You control your fertility. Discuss options with a health worker.

column1: I feel ashamed asking for condoms.
column2: It’s normal. Using them shows responsibility and care.

column1: I’m scared about switching contraceptive methods.
column2: Health workers will guide you safely. Reversible methods make switching easy.

column1: My partner pressures me to avoid contraception.
column2: You have the right to use a method safely and privately.

column1: I feel anxious about using contraception while young.
column2: It’s safe and responsible if you’re sexually active.

column1: I’m embarrassed to talk about emergency contraception.
column2: Health staff provide confidential, judgment-free help.

column1: I’m scared of side effects from implants.
column2: Minor side effects are common. Serious complications are rare.

column1: My partner says condoms aren’t needed with birth control pills.
column2: Using both adds extra protection against pregnancy and infections.

column1: I feel nervous talking about my sexual health.
column2: It’s okay to be nervous. Health workers are trained to support you.

column1: I’m scared my friends will laugh if they find out.
column2: Your health is more important than their opinions.

column1: My partner refuses to use contraception because of myths.
column2: Share accurate info, or choose a method you can control.

column1: I feel pressure to hide contraceptive use from family.
column2: Your safety comes first. Services are confidential for youth.

column1: I’m anxious about forgetting pills.
column2: Use reminders like phone alarms or daily routines.

column1: I’m afraid of needles for injections.
column2: Staff are trained to make injections quick and safe.

column1: My partner wants me to rely on withdrawal.
column2: Withdrawal is unreliable. Modern methods are safer.

column1: I feel guilty about using contraception before marriage.
column2: It’s safe, responsible, and your choice.

column1: I’m nervous discussing side effects.
column2: Staff expect questions and provide guidance.

column1: My partner makes me feel bad for wanting contraception.
column2: You have the right to protect yourself.

column1: I’m scared about changing my method.
column2: Switching is safe with guidance.

column1: I feel embarrassed asking about fertility after stopping.
column2: Fertility usually returns quickly; it’s normal to ask.

column1: My partner says birth control is unnatural.
column2: Contraception is safe and medically approved.

column1: I’m scared that my parents will find birth control pills in my bag.
column2: You can keep them in a private pouch or take them at the same time each day without drawing attention. Health services are confidential.

column1: I’m worried my boyfriend will think I don’t trust him if I ask to use condoms.
column2: Using condoms means you care about both your safety and his. Trust and protection go together.

column1: My partner told me not to talk to others about contraception.
column2: You have the right to ask for health information. Health staff keep your talks private.

column1: I’m scared that taking birth control will make me infertile later.
column2: That’s a myth. Most contraceptives are reversible — your fertility returns when you stop using them.

column1: I feel anxious that my boyfriend will break up if I use family planning.
column2: If someone truly cares about you, they’ll respect your health decisions. Don’t risk your safety for fear of losing them.

column1: I’m worried I’ll be judged at the pharmacy for buying condoms.
column2: Pharmacy staff are used to selling them every day. You can ask quietly or buy from clinics for free.

column1: My partner gets angry when I mention contraception.
column2: That’s not okay. You have a right to make decisions about your own body. If you feel unsafe, seek support from a counselor or hotline.

column1: I’m scared of hormonal changes from using contraception.
column2: Some methods affect hormones slightly, but effects are usually temporary and safe. Health workers can help you choose one that fits you.

column1: I feel ashamed because people say contraception is only for married women.
column2: That’s not true. Anyone who is sexually active can use contraception to stay safe and healthy.

column1: My friend said using birth control causes cancer. Is that true?
column2: No. Most modern contraceptives are proven safe and do not cause cancer. Always rely on medical advice, not rumors.

column1: I’m afraid my partner won’t respect me if I refuse unprotected sex.
column2: Respect means caring about your comfort and safety. You have every right to say no to unprotected sex.

column1: My boyfriend says I shouldn’t worry about pregnancy because it’s “God’s plan.”
column2: You can still use family planning — it’s about responsibility, not faith. Protecting yourself doesn’t go against belief.

column1: I feel like I’m doing something wrong for wanting contraception.
column2: You’re not. Wanting to protect yourself shows maturity and self-respect.

column1: My partner hides condoms to stop me from using them.
column2: That’s controlling behavior. You can visit a clinic for other private methods like pills, implants, or injections.

column1: I’m worried about gaining weight from contraception.
column2: Some people notice small changes, but it’s usually temporary. Healthy eating and exercise help.

column1: I feel scared that others will think I’m “spoiled” if I use family planning.
column2: Protecting your health is never wrong. Using contraception is a responsible choice.

column1: My boyfriend says using protection means I don’t trust him.
column2: Protection means you both care about your future. It’s a shared responsibility, not a sign of mistrust.

column1: I’m nervous because my partner doesn’t like talking about contraception.
column2: You can start gently — ask what he knows and share what you’ve learned. Healthy communication builds trust.

column1: I’m afraid of being called “bad” for asking about birth control.
column2: Asking questions shows you care about your body. There’s nothing bad about that.

column1: I feel uncomfortable talking to male health workers.
column2: You can ask for a female health worker or visit youth-friendly clinics that ensure privacy.

column1: My partner says I don’t need birth control because he’ll “be careful.”
column2: Withdrawal is risky. You still need modern contraception to stay safe.

column1: I’m scared I’ll forget to remove my implant or IUD on time.
column2: Health workers track it for you and remind you when it’s time to replace or remove it.

column1: I feel ashamed going to a clinic alone.
column2: Many people go alone. Staff are kind and used to helping youth privately.

column1: I’m scared my family will find out I visited a clinic.
column2: Health services keep all visits private. You can ask staff not to share any information.

column1: My partner says contraception ruins the mood.
column2: You can make protection part of intimacy. There are thin, comfortable condoms available.

column1: I’m afraid to tell my boyfriend I’m using contraception.
column2: You can choose to share or keep it private. Your health decisions are yours.

column1: I feel guilty for using emergency contraception.
column2: It’s meant for unexpected situations. Using it shows you’re acting responsibly.

column1: I’m scared of getting scolded at the clinic because I’m unmarried.
column2: Clinics in Nepal serve everyone respectfully, regardless of age or marital status.

column1: My partner says injections make women sick.
column2: That’s not true. They’re safe and approved. A health worker can explain more.

column1: I’m worried that contraception will change my body shape.
column2: Small changes can happen, but they’re temporary and not harmful.

column1: I feel scared to talk about family planning with my husband.
column2: You can start by discussing your shared goals and needs gently.

column1: I’m afraid using contraception means I’ll never have children.
column2: Only sterilization is permanent. Other methods let you have children later when you’re ready.

column1: My friend said pills make women infertile. Is that true?
column2: No. Pills don’t affect long-term fertility. Once you stop, your body returns to normal.

column1: I feel nervous about asking male partners to use condoms.
column2: You can explain that condoms protect both of you. It’s a shared responsibility.

column1: My partner says contraception makes women unfaithful.
column2: That’s a harmful myth. Contraception lets women make safe, informed choices.

column1: I’m scared I’ll regret using family planning later.
column2: It’s okay to change your mind. Most methods are reversible. You can switch anytime.

column1: I feel ashamed to discuss family planning with elders.
column2: That’s okay. You can talk to a health worker or peer counselor instead.

column1: I’m worried about irregular bleeding from contraceptives.
column2: It’s a common side effect and usually not harmful. It often settles after a few months.

column1: My partner says the pill is unnatural.
column2: Modern pills are safe and based on natural hormones.

column1: I feel scared to go to a clinic where people might know me.
column2: You can visit a clinic in another area or use youth-friendly centers that keep visits private.

column1: I’m afraid my partner will think I don’t trust him if I ask to use condoms.
column2: Using condoms means you care about both of you. Trust includes protection.

column1: I feel like family planning is not meant for young people.
column2: Family planning is for anyone who wants to avoid unplanned pregnancy.

column1: My partner refuses contraception because his friends tease him.
column2: Peer pressure shouldn’t control your health. You both deserve protection.

column1: I’m scared of using the wrong family planning method.
column2: Health workers help you choose the safest method for your body.

column1: My partner says contraception reduces desire.
column2: That’s not true for most people. Some even feel more relaxed knowing they’re protected.

column1: I feel guilty because my religion discourages contraception.
column2: You can still make health choices that are right for your situation and beliefs.

column1: I’m afraid to tell my husband I want to stop having children.
column2: You have the right to discuss and decide family size together. Seek counseling if needed.

column1: My partner says I can’t go to the clinic alone.
column2: You can visit health posts alone. Your privacy and autonomy are protected.

column1: I feel nervous using emergency pills for the first time.
column2: They’re safe if used within 5 days after unprotected sex, but not as a regular method.

column1: I’m scared that family planning will make me weak.
column2: Contraceptives don’t weaken your body. Eating well and resting keeps you healthy.

column1: I feel anxious about what my teacher or community will think.
column2: Your health choices are private. You don’t owe anyone an explanation.

column1: My partner wants to decide my contraception for me.
column2: Decisions about your body should always be shared and respected.

column1: I’m afraid to switch methods because people say it’s dangerous.
column2: It’s safe to switch under a health worker’s advice.

column1: I feel ashamed because I used contraception secretly.
column2: It’s okay. You made a responsible decision for your health.

column1: My partner said pills make women emotional.
column2: Some people notice mood changes, but they’re temporary. You can switch if uncomfortable.

column1: I’m scared my family will see me talking to health workers.
column2: Clinics respect confidentiality. You can go at quiet times.

column1: I feel nervous asking about contraception in my village.
column2: FCHVs are trained to guide you confidentially and respectfully.

column1: My partner doesn’t want me to learn about family planning.
column2: You have every right to learn about your health. Knowledge keeps you safe.

column1: I’m afraid contraception will harm my future baby.
column2: It doesn’t. Once stopped, you can have healthy pregnancies.

column1: I feel worried that using family planning will make others think I’m bad.
column2: You’re not bad for protecting yourself. It’s a sign of responsibility and strength.

column1: Can condoms break easily?
column2: If used properly and not expired, condoms are strong. Store them cool and open gently to avoid damage.

column1: Is it embarrassing if a girl buys condoms?
column2: Not at all. Anyone protecting their health is confident and responsible. Shopkeepers are used to it.

column1: Do birth control pills make me infertile?
column2: No. Fertility returns when you stop taking the pills. Pills help prevent pregnancy while you want to delay it.

column1: I missed my pill, what do I do?
column2: Take it as soon as you remember. If it's over 24 hours late, use condoms for the next 7 days as backup.

column1: Can condoms get stuck inside?
column2: Rarely. Stay calm, relax your muscles, and gently remove it. If difficult, a health worker can assist safely.

column1: Can condoms reduce pleasure?
column2: Some people think so, but many don’t find a big difference. There are also thin or textured types made to feel more natural. The most important thing is comfort and protection.

column1: What should I do if the condom tears?
column2: Use emergency contraception within 72 hours and visit a health provider if you are concerned.

column1: Is emergency contraception an abortion pill?
column2: No. It prevents pregnancy before it starts. It does not affect an existing pregnancy."

column1: What to do if I feel dizzy after taking pills?
column2: Rest and drink water. Mild side-effects improve in few days. If it worries you, switch method with a provider’s help.

column1: What is contraception?
column2: Contraception means using safe methods to prevent pregnancy. It helps people plan when or whether to have children. There’s nothing to feel shy about — it’s just a part of health and planning.

column1: Can I get pregnant from hugging or kissing?
column2: No, pregnancy cannot happen from hugging, kissing, or touching. Pregnancy only happens when a sperm meets an egg during sexual intercourse.

column1: What is a condom used for?
column2: A condom is a thin cover worn on the penis during sex. It stops sperm from reaching the egg and also protects from infections like HIV. It’s safe, cheap, and easy to use.

column1: Are condoms only for men?
column2: Mostly yes, but there are also female condoms. Both work the same way — they prevent pregnancy and protect health. Anyone can choose what feels more comfortable.

column1: Can I use two condoms at once for extra safety?
column2: No, using two condoms together can cause them to tear because of friction. One condom used properly is enough and gives good protection.

column1: Can I reuse a condom?
column2: No, never reuse a condom. It’s for one-time use only. Always use a new one every time you have sex.

column1: What is emergency contraception?
column2: It’s a pill taken after unprotected sex to prevent pregnancy. It works best within 72 hours. It’s safe and available at most pharmacies in Nepal.

column1: What if I forget to take my birth control pill?
column2: If you forget one pill, take it as soon as you remember. If you miss two or more, take one and use a condom for the next 7 days. Don’t worry — just restart your routine calmly.

column1: Do birth control pills make you fat?
column2: Not everyone gains weight. Some people notice small changes, but most stay the same. Eating healthy and staying active keeps your body balanced.

column1: Can birth control harm my fertility later?
column2: No, it doesn’t. Once you stop using pills, injections, or implants, your fertility returns to normal. It may take a few months for your cycle to adjust — that’s normal.

column1: Is family planning only for married people?
column2: No, family planning is for anyone who wants to prevent pregnancy or plan their future. It’s about making responsible and healthy choices.

column1: Is it wrong to talk about contraception?
column2: Not at all. Talking about contraception means you care about your health. It’s better to ask and be safe than stay confused.

column1: What is an IUD?
column2: An IUD (Copper-T or Mirena) is a small device placed in the uterus by a health worker. It prevents pregnancy for 5–10 years and can be removed anytime you want.

column1: Does an IUD hurt?
column2: You may feel slight pain or cramping during placement, but it lasts only a few minutes. After that, you can live normally. Trained nurses and doctors make sure it’s safe.

column1: Are there family planning services for men?
column2: Yes! Men can use condoms, get counseling, or even choose vasectomy — a simple, safe operation that prevents pregnancy permanently without harming strength or desire.

column1: Can a vasectomy affect manhood or sexual performance?
column2: No, not at all. It doesn’t affect erections, pleasure, or masculinity. It only stops sperm from mixing with semen. Everything else remains the same.

column1: What are the side effects of family planning methods?
column2: Some people may notice small changes like irregular periods or mild headaches, but they are temporary. If it continues, a health worker can help switch to another method safely.

column1: What if I want to have a baby later?
column2: That’s totally fine! Most methods are reversible — once you stop, your body will return to normal, and you can plan pregnancy whenever you’re ready.

column1: What should I do if I think I’m pregnant by mistake?
column2: Don’t panic. First, take a pregnancy test. If it’s positive, visit a health post or hospital for safe guidance. You’re not alone — help and counseling are available.

column1: Where can I get family planning help in Nepal?
column2: You can visit government hospitals, health posts, Marie Stopes centers, or pharmacies. Health workers are trained to guide you with privacy and care.

column1: Can I talk to a doctor about contraception without my parents knowing?
column2: Yes, you can. Health workers keep your information private. You have the right to ask for help and advice safely.

column1: Is it safe to take family planning pills bought from any pharmacy?
column2: Only buy from registered pharmacies. Most pills sold in Nepal are safe, but it’s always good to ask the pharmacist or a health worker for the right one.

column1: Can traditional or homemade methods prevent pregnancy?
column2: No, traditional methods like herbs, drinks, or washing after sex don’t work. Always use proven modern methods like condoms, pills, or IUDs.

column1: What if I’m shy to buy condoms?
column2: That’s totally normal! You can buy from any pharmacy, even small ones, or use self-service boxes in some areas. Remember, health workers see it as responsibility, not shame.

column1: Can contraception stop diseases too?
column2: Only condoms protect against both pregnancy and sexually transmitted infections (STIs) like HIV. Other methods only prevent pregnancy.

column1: What if I have health problems and want to use contraception?
column2: Tell your doctor or health worker about your condition. They’ll help choose the safest method for you — there’s always an option for every health situation.

column1: Why is family planning important?
column2: It helps you and your family stay healthy, manage finances, and plan your future. It’s not just about avoiding pregnancy — it’s about living with choice and care.

column1: Can I get pregnant if it’s my first time having sex?
column2: Yes, pregnancy can happen anytime sperm enters the vagina, even the first time. Using protection like a condom is always important.

column1: Can a girl get pregnant during periods?
column2: It’s rare but possible. Sperm can live inside the body for a few days, so it’s better to still use protection every time.

column1: Does drinking water after sex prevent pregnancy?
column2: No, that’s just a myth. Drinking water or washing after sex does not prevent pregnancy.

column1: What if my period doesn’t come after starting birth control?
column2: Sometimes birth control changes your cycle. It’s normal for periods to be lighter or even stop for a while. If you’re unsure, do a pregnancy test.

column1: Can breastfeeding mothers use family planning?
column2: Yes! There are safe methods for breastfeeding mothers, like condoms, implants, or special pills called 'mini pills'.

column1: What age is right to start family planning?
column2: There’s no fixed age. You can use contraception whenever you are sexually active and want to avoid pregnancy safely.

column1: Do I need my husband’s permission for family planning?
column2: No, family planning is your health right. Couples are encouraged to discuss together, but every woman can decide for her own body.

column1: Can I stop using contraception anytime I want?
column2: Yes, you can stop whenever you’re ready. Just remember — once you stop, you can get pregnant again soon.

column1: Do I still need contraception after 40 years?
column2: If your periods are still coming, pregnancy is still possible. Once menopause happens (no periods for 12 months), you can stop using contraception.

column1: Can men take birth control pills too?
column2: No, birth control pills are made for women’s hormones. Men can use condoms or get a vasectomy instead.

column1: What if I’m scared of IUD insertion pain?
column2: It’s normal to feel nervous. The process takes only a few minutes, and health workers give medicine to reduce pain. Most women say it’s easier than expected.

column1: Can I take family planning pills secretly?
column2: It’s always better if your partner understands, but yes — pills can be taken privately if needed. Your health is your right.

column1: Is it safe to have sex during periods?
column2: Yes, it’s safe if both partners are comfortable. Using a condom is still good to prevent infections.

column1: What should I do if I miss my period after using contraception?
column2: Sometimes it’s due to hormones. First, take a pregnancy test. If it’s negative, wait a few days — cycles can vary with stress or diet too.

column1: Is it true that family planning makes women weak?
column2: No, that’s a myth. Family planning keeps women healthier by spacing births and giving the body time to recover.

column1: Can I get pregnant after stopping the injection?
column2: Yes, you can. Fertility returns within a few months for most women, sometimes up to a year — nothing to worry about.

column1: What should I do if my husband refuses to use a condom?
column2: Try explaining it protects both of you. You can also use other methods like pills, injections, or IUDs if he doesn’t agree.

column1: Can I get free contraception in Nepal?
column2: Yes! Government hospitals and health posts provide condoms, pills, and injections free of cost. Ask the local Female Community Health Volunteer (FCHV).

column1: Can men get side effects from condoms?
column2: Some may feel slight discomfort if it’s too tight or dry. Using the right size and a little water-based lubricant makes it more comfortable.

column1: Can family planning affect periods?
column2: Yes, sometimes. Some methods make periods lighter, irregular, or stop for a while. It’s usually harmless and goes back to normal after stopping.

column1: Are there any permanent methods for women?
column2: Yes, women can choose tubal ligation (minilap), a small surgery that permanently prevents pregnancy. It’s safe and free in many health centers.

column1: Is abortion legal in Nepal?
column2: Yes, abortion is legal up to 12 weeks of pregnancy, and up to 28 weeks for medical reasons. It must be done safely at registered clinics or hospitals.

column1: What if I had unprotected sex by mistake?
column2: You can take emergency contraception within 3–5 days. Don’t worry — just act quickly. It’s safe and available in most pharmacies.

column1: Is it safe to take birth control for many years?
column2: Yes, long-term use of pills, IUDs, or injections is safe. Health workers may suggest checkups, but there’s no harm in using them for years.

column1: Can I use contraception even if I don’t have children yet?
column2: Yes, of course. Contraception doesn’t depend on having children. It’s for anyone who wants to delay or prevent pregnancy safely.

column1: What if I’m worried about side effects?
column2: That’s natural. Talk to a health worker — they’ll help you pick the method that suits your body best. Everyone reacts differently, and that’s okay.

column1: Can family planning improve my relationship?
column2: Yes, it often does! When couples plan together, there’s less stress, more trust, and healthier communication.

column1: Is it bad if I don’t want to have children ever?
column2: Not at all. Family planning means choosing what’s right for you. Some people want kids, some don’t — both are okay.

column1: Can boys also learn about contraception?
column2: Yes! Boys should learn too. It helps them respect their partner, make safer choices, and share responsibility.

column1: Can I use two birth control methods together?
column2: Yes, that can give extra protection. For example, using condoms along with pills or IUD is very effective and also prevents infections.

column1: Is it safe to have sex after delivery?
column2: Usually after 6 weeks, but it’s best to check with a health worker. There are special family planning methods for breastfeeding mothers too.

column1: Can stress or sadness stop periods?
column2: Yes, stress, anxiety, or sudden weight changes can delay periods. It’s common — just relax, eat well, and they usually return to normal.

column1: Does taking family planning pills make skin fair or dark?
column2: No, birth control pills don’t change skin color. Some people notice small hormone effects like clearer skin, but it’s temporary."

column1: Can I get HIV from using the same toilet as someone?
column2: No, HIV doesn’t spread through toilets, touching, hugging, or sharing food. It only spreads through unprotected sex, blood, or breastfeeding.

column1: Can contraception make my periods painful?
column2: Some people feel mild cramps at first, but it usually settles. If pain continues, talk to a nurse — you may need a different method.

column1: Can teenagers use contraception?
column2: Yes, if they are sexually active, they can use protection. It’s about staying safe and healthy, not about being judged.

column1: Can I get pregnant if my husband had a vasectomy?
column2: No, once vasectomy works (after 3 months or 20 ejaculations), pregnancy is not possible. It’s a permanent and safe method.

column1: Can I use expired condoms or pills?
column2: Never use expired ones. They may not work properly. Always check the date before using.

column1: What if I don’t know which method suits me?
column2: That’s okay. Everyone’s body is different. A health worker will help you choose the method that fits your body and comfort.

column1: Can I get pregnant after miscarriage or abortion?
column2: Yes, you can get pregnant within a few weeks. If you’re not ready, start a family planning method right away.

column1: Is it okay to have sex during pregnancy?
column2: If your doctor says it’s safe, yes. Most couples can have sex normally unless there are complications.

column1: Can I take the pill without eating food?
column2: Yes, it’s okay. But taking it with food or at the same time daily helps avoid nausea and keeps the habit regular.

column1: Can I stop pills once my husband travels abroad?
column2: Yes, you can stop if you’re not sexually active. Start again when needed — just remember to give it a few days to take effect.

column1: Can family planning cause mood changes?
column2: Some people notice small mood swings with hormonal methods, but it usually settles. If it feels too strong, talk to your health worker.

column1: Can family planning pills help with acne or heavy periods?
column2: Yes! Many women find their skin improves and periods become lighter and less painful while on the pill.

column1: What if my partner hides using contraception?
column2: It’s better to be open, but sometimes people fear judgment. Try to talk calmly — family planning works best when both understand each other.

column1: Can I use birth control if I have diabetes or high blood pressure?
column2: Yes, but your doctor will help choose the safest method. There’s always an option that suits your health condition.

column1: Can birth control help with irregular periods?
column2: Yes, pills often help regulate periods and make cycles more predictable.

column1: What if I am scared of injections?
column2: That’s okay! You can choose pills, condoms, or an implant instead. Many methods don’t require injections.

column4: and know you took a responsible step to protect yourself.

column2: It can feel scary
column3: but you’re not alone. There are ways to stay safe now
column4: like emergency contraception and testing later for peace of mind. You’re handling this responsibly.

column1: Do I still need contraception if I’m not ovulating?
column2: It’s hard to be sure exactly when ovulation happens — bodies change month to month. Contraception gives dependable protection anytime.

column1: What if my partner doesn't believe in birth control?
column2: Everyone has different beliefs
column3: but your safety and future are yours to protect. You can kindly explain your needs — your voice matters.

column1: Can semen dry on skin and still cause pregnancy?
column2: Once dried
column3: sperm usually can’t survive. But if semen is wet and gets near the vagina
column4: there is a chance. Cleaning gently prevents worry later.

column1: Can I get contraception just to manage my hormones?
column2: Yes
column3: contraception is commonly used to balance hormones
column4: reduce acne
column5: and make cycles regular. Your comfort is important.

column1: Do I need protection if we only used hands?
column2: If fluids didn’t contact the vagina
column3: risk is low. If they did
column4: even a little
column5: condoms next time can help avoid worry.

column1: Can condoms break if they're too old?
column2: Yes
column3: expired condoms can dry out and tear easily. Always good to check the date — a quick habit that protects you.

column1: What if I don’t feel like I can talk to anyone about this?
column2: You have the right to a private and supportive space. I’m here to help you breathe and get through this step by step.

column1: Is it safe to use emergency pills more than once?
column2: They’re safe for occasional use
column3: but not the best regular method. You deserve a more steady option that gives lasting peace of mind.

column1: Can sperm reach the egg really fast?
column2: Yes
column3: they can start moving within minutes. That’s why using protection from the start is so helpful.

column1: What if I feel too shy to say no during sex?
column2: Your comfort matters most — consent is necessary. It’s okay to pause
column4: and speak up. Your body is yours and deserves respect every time.

column1: Can I use a condom if I’m allergic to latex?
column2: Yes, you can still safely use condoms. If you have a latex allergy, choose latex-free options like polyurethane or polyisoprene condoms. They offer the same pregnancy and infection protection while preventing allergic reactions. You can ask for these at pharmacies if unsure.

column1: Can I get pregnant if the condom slips a little?
column2: Yes, pregnancy is still possible if a condom slips during sex because some sperm can enter the vagina. Try to take emergency contraception within 72 hours for added protection. Next time, ensure the condom fits well and hold the base during withdrawal to prevent slipping. These things happen, so don’t panic — just take the right next step.

column1: Does using a condom every time protect me fully?
column2: Using a condom every single time gives very high protection from pregnancy and many infections. But they must be used correctly from start to finish of sex for best safety. Always check expiry date, fit, and avoid oil-based products that can damage them. When used properly, condoms are one of the best protection tools.

column1: Do I need to tell my age while buying condoms?
column2: No, you do not need to show your age or ID to buy condoms in Nepal. Anyone can buy them to protect their health, and pharmacy staff are trained to respect privacy. You are responsible and smart for choosing protection — feel confident while buying.

column1: Is pulling out safer if he is very careful?
column2: Pulling out (withdrawal) is risky because pre-ejaculate fluid can contain sperm even before he feels it. It requires perfect timing which is very hard in real life, especially for young couples. A condom or another reliable method keeps you much safer and more relaxed during sex.

column1: Can I use oil or lotion with condoms?
column2: No, avoid oils, lotions, or petroleum jelly because they weaken condoms and can cause breakage. Use water-based or silicone-based lubricants for comfort and protection. If dryness happens, adding lubricant can make sex safer and more enjoyable.

column1: Can I take two emergency pills to be safer?
column2: No, taking more than one dose at the same time does not increase protection. One dose is enough to prevent pregnancy after one unprotected sex. Taking extra pills may only increase side effects. If you need frequent protection, a regular method will reduce worry.

column1: Does emergency pill work after 3 days?
column2: It becomes less effective after 72 hours (3 days), but you should still take it as soon as possible. The earlier you take it, the better it works. If more than 3 days have passed, consult a health worker or consider a copper IUD which can work up to 5 days after sex.

column1: Is it normal to bleed a little after taking emergency pill?
column2: Yes, light spotting or irregular bleeding can happen after taking an emergency pill. It’s a common side effect and usually settles on its own. Your period might come early or late this cycle — that’s normal too. If bleeding becomes very heavy or painful, talk to a health worker.

column1: Will birth control pills delay my period?
column2: Yes, sometimes periods may come slightly late or lighter when starting pills, but it usually becomes regular in a few months. Pills help your body adjust hormone levels safely. If unsure, a pregnancy test can give peace of mind.

column1: Can sperm pass through clothes?
column2: Thick and dry clothes act as a strong barrier, so pregnancy is extremely unlikely through clothing. Sperm cannot swim through layers of fabric. Only direct contact of semen with the vagina can cause pregnancy.

column1: Is sex safe during breastfeeding?
column2: Yes, sex is safe while breastfeeding, but remember that you can still get pregnant even if periods have not fully returned. Using contraception helps you plan your next pregnancy. Many mothers choose condoms or implants while breastfeeding.

column1: Can I buy emergency pills without prescription?
column2: Yes, you can buy emergency contraception directly from pharmacies in Nepal without any prescription. The pharmacist can guide you if you need help, and your privacy will be respected.

column1: Do I need to take pills at the same time daily?
