column2: Yes, taking birth control pills at the same time daily helps keep hormone levels steady and the protection strong. Setting an alarm or reminder can make it easy and stress-free.

column1: Can stress cause late periods?
column2: Yes, stress can affect hormones and delay your period even without pregnancy. Try calming routines like rest, hydration, and self-care. If the delay continues, a pregnancy test helps remove doubt.

column1: Is vasectomy a painful surgery?
column2: Vasectomy is a small, quick procedure usually done with local anesthesia. Most men feel only mild discomfort and recover in a few days. It does not affect sexual performance or masculinity.

column1: Can a man still be strong after vasectomy?
column2: Yes, vasectomy does not affect a man’s strength, stamina, sex drive, or masculinity. He remains completely normal physically and sexually — only sperm release is blocked.

column1: If I missed one pill what should I do?
column2: Take the missed pill as soon as you remember, then continue the rest at your usual time. Missing one pill usually does not reduce protection. If you had unprotected sex recently, using a condom for the next 7 days can give extra safety.

column1: Can I take pills if I am underweight?
column2: Yes, weight does not stop most people from using birth control pills safely. A health worker can help choose the best type for your body and needs.

column1: Can condoms be used during menstruation?
column2: Yes, condoms are safe and effective during periods. They help prevent pregnancy and protect from infections, and they also keep things cleaner.

column1: Do I need parental permission to use pills?
column2: No, adults can choose contraception independently. Your reproductive health choices are personal and confidential.

column1: Can I get pregnant if he ejaculates outside but near the vagina?
column2: Yes, pregnancy can still happen if semen touches the vaginal opening because sperm can move inside. Using condoms or emergency pills can reduce risk if this happens. It’s common to feel anxious — you’re not alone.

column1: Is it harmful to use condoms daily?
column2: No, condoms are safe to use whenever needed. They do not harm the body and provide great protection every time.

column1: Does implant move inside my arm?
column2: Implants are placed securely under the skin and usually stay in the same spot. If you feel unsure, a health worker can check it easily. It continues to protect you even if you can’t always feel it clearly.

column1: Can I drink alcohol while using pills?
column2: Yes, alcohol does not stop pills from working — but be careful not to miss doses if you drink. Keeping a routine helps maintain protection.

column1: Is there a free family planning service in Nepal?
column2: Yes, government health posts and hospitals provide free contraception options like condoms, pills, injectables, and counseling. You can discuss choices privately with trained staff.

column1: Can I stop pills anytime?
column2: Yes, you can stop whenever you want. However, use another method right away if you want to avoid pregnancy. Your body will return to natural cycles soon.

column1: Do condoms have different sizes?
column2: Yes, condoms come in different sizes. Choosing a comfortable size helps prevent breakage and slipping and keeps sex enjoyable.

column1: Can expired condoms still work?
column2: Expired condoms can dry out or weaken, making them more likely to tear. Always check the date on the pack to ensure best protection.

column1: Does having sex standing prevent pregnancy?
column2: No, sex position does not prevent pregnancy. Sperm can reach the egg in any position. Only contraception can protect you well.

column1: How soon can I get pregnant after implant removal?
column2: Fertility can return quickly — sometimes even within a few weeks. If you want to avoid pregnancy, start another method immediately after removal.

column1: Can I get pregnant if he did not finish inside?
column2: Yes, pre-ejaculate can carry sperm and may cause pregnancy. Using a condom properly helps prevent that worry.

column1: Are copper IUDs safe for young women?
column2: Yes, copper IUDs are safe for many young women, including those who have not yet had children. They provide long-lasting protection without hormones. A professional will check if it's suitable for you.

column1: Do condoms protect from all infections?
column2: They protect strongly from infections that spread through bodily fluids like HIV. But for skin-to-skin infections such as herpes or warts, protection is not 100%. Still, condoms greatly reduce the risk and are very important for safety.

column1: Is it okay to hide contraception use?
column2: Your health decisions are private. If you feel unsafe or pressured, using contraception quietly can protect you. Health workers can support you confidentially without judging.

column1: Can a girl buy condoms?
column2: Yes, condoms are for everyone — not just men. Anyone can buy and carry them to protect themselves. Taking responsibility shows maturity and care for your health.

column1: Can I have sex on pill-free days?
column2: Yes, as long as you have taken your active pills correctly, you remain protected during the pill-free days. The monthly break does not remove the effect.

column1: Will emergency pills harm a future baby?
column2: No, if pregnancy still happens after taking an emergency pill, it does not harm the baby or cause birth defects. It simply tries to prevent pregnancy from starting.

column1: Does implant cause hair loss?
column2: Some people may experience mild hair changes, but it is usually temporary. If the change feels uncomfortable, a health worker can suggest another method.

column1: Can condoms break if they are too tight?
column2: Yes, tight condoms have a higher chance of breaking due to friction. Choosing the right size keeps sex safer and smoother.

column1: Do IUDs cause cancer?
column2: No, IUDs do not cause cancer. They are safe and widely used worldwide with strong research support behind them.

column1: Can I be pregnant with no symptoms?
column2: Yes, some early pregnancies have no noticeable signs. If your period is late and you had unprotected sex, taking a pregnancy test can give clarity.

column1: Is it safe to take pills while having acne?
column2: Yes, pills are safe to use and can even improve acne in some people. A health provider can help choose a type that suits your skin and health.

column1: Does long-term pill use harm fertility?
column2: No, pills do not damage fertility. Once you stop taking them, you can become pregnant whenever your body returns to its normal cycle.

column1: Is it safe to use condoms in water like a shower?
column2: Condoms can slip more easily in water, so be extra careful or avoid full intercourse in water. Dry surface use is much safer for protection.

column1: Can I get pregnant right after abortion?
column2: Yes, fertility can return quickly — even within a couple of weeks. Using contraception soon after abortion helps you plan a healthy future pregnancy.

column1: Can I remove an IUD myself?
column2: No, never try to remove an IUD at home. It must be done by a trained professional to avoid injury and ensure safety.

column1: Does vasectomy stop erection?
column2: No, vasectomy does not affect erections, sexual desire, or ability to enjoy sex. It only blocks sperm, not hormones or pleasure.

column1: Can breastfeeding be used as birth control alone?
column2: It can work only for the first 6 months, **if** you exclusively breastfeed and your periods have not returned. If any of these conditions change, pregnancy can happen — so additional contraception is safer.

column1: Is it painful to get an IUD inserted?
column2: Some people feel mild pain or cramping during insertion, while others feel only slight pressure. The discomfort usually lasts a short time and can be eased with rest and pain medicine afterward. Health workers are trained to make the process safe and gentle. You can always ask questions to feel more comfortable during the procedure.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I have sex before my period?
column2: Yes, it is still possible to get pregnant because sperm can live inside the body for up to 5 days. Even if you think your period is near, ovulation timing can change due to stress or health changes. If you want to avoid pregnancy, use protection every time.

column1: Does having sex frequently reduce sperm count?
column2: Frequent sex does not harm sperm count permanently. The body continues making sperm all the time. If a man ejaculates very often in one day, sperm count may temporarily drop, but it returns to normal quickly. There is no need to worry — the body balances itself naturally.

column1: Can I use two condoms for extra safety?
column2: No, using two condoms causes more friction, making them more likely to break. One properly used condom gives strong protection. If you worry about safety, add water-based lubricant to prevent tearing.

column1: Does the emergency pill cause infertility?
column2: No, emergency pills do not affect long-term fertility. They only work temporarily to delay ovulation. You can become pregnant normally in future cycles. They are safe — but not meant for frequent use.

column1: Is it normal to feel nervous buying contraception?
column2: Yes, many people feel shy or nervous, which is completely normal. But remember: protecting your health is smart and responsible. Pharmacy staff are used to helping customers like you and will respect your privacy without judgment.

column1: Can I shower after sex? Will it prevent pregnancy?
column2: Showering or washing after sex does not prevent pregnancy. Once sperm enters the vagina, showering cannot remove it. Only contraception can protect you effectively.

column1: Can I get pregnant from oral sex?
column2: No, pregnancy cannot occur from oral sex because the mouth and digestive system are separate from the reproductive system. However, some infections can spread through oral sex, so protection is still important for safety.

column1: Can condoms cause itching?
column2: Sometimes itching may happen if someone is allergic to latex or if there is too much friction. Switching to latex-free condoms or using lubricant can help. If irritation continues, check with a health provider for guidance.

column1: Is it harmful to take emergency pills more than once?
column2: It is safe to take emergency pills again if needed, but using them often can cause irregular periods and stress. A regular contraception method will give you more peace of mind and stronger protection.

column1: Do I need to rest after IUD insertion?
column2: Most people can return to normal activities the same day. Light cramping or spotting may happen for a day or two. Rest if you feel uncomfortable, and avoid inserting anything into the vagina for 24 hours unless advised otherwise.

column1: Can I get pregnant with copper IUD in place?
column2: Pregnancy with an IUD is very rare. If it does happen, seek medical help right away, as the pregnancy needs careful checking. The IUD is still one of the most effective long-term birth control options.

column1: Does contraceptive injection cause weight gain?
column2: Some people may notice small weight changes because of hormone effects, while many notice no change at all. Eating balanced meals and staying active helps keep your body healthy. Your provider can help choose a method that feels right for you.

column1: Is there any natural method to avoid pregnancy?
column2: Some people track menstrual cycles, but these natural methods require perfect timing and can be less reliable. If avoiding pregnancy is important right now, using a modern method is much safer and reduces anxiety.

column1: Can I travel with condoms in my bag?
column2: Yes, you can carry condoms anywhere — they are made to be portable and private. Just avoid keeping them in very hot places like cars or pockets for long periods, as heat can weaken them.

column1: Are period delays always a sign of pregnancy?
column2: No, delayed periods can also happen due to stress, illness, changes in routine, or hormonal imbalance. If you had unprotected sex, take a pregnancy test for reassurance. If delays happen often, speak to a health provider.

column1: Can a health worker keep my visit secret?
column2: Yes, health workers are trained to protect your privacy. Your information and choices about contraception are confidential. You deserve respect and care without judgment.

column1: Can I get pregnant during my first time having sex?
column2: Yes, pregnancy can happen anytime sperm reaches the egg — even the first time. Using protection from the beginning keeps you safe and helps you feel more relaxed.

column1: Will contraception affect my future baby?
column2: If you stop the contraception, your body can return to natural fertility and future babies will be healthy. Birth control has no harmful effects on children born later.

column1: Does the implant stop periods completely?
column2: Some people have lighter or fewer periods, and some may stop bleeding fully — which is safe. The implant keeps hormones steady, and as long as a health worker inserted it, it continues to protect you even without periods.

column1: Can I put on a condom after starting sex?
column2: No, condoms must be used from the beginning of contact. Pre-ejaculate fluid can contain sperm and infections. Always put the condom on before any contact with the vagina.

column1: Can emergency pills protect me for the next time I have sex?
column2: No, the pill only works for the previous unprotected sex. You are not protected for future sex, so use condoms or start a regular method to stay confident and safe.

column1: Do I need breaks from birth control pills?
column2: No, breaks are not needed. Stopping pills only increases risk of pregnancy and period irregularity. It’s safe to keep using them for years with check-ups.

column1: Can I judge fertility by checking discharge?
column2: Yes, discharge can help track ovulation — clear and stretchy discharge may indicate fertile days. But this method requires experience and can be less reliable alone. Using contraception gives stronger peace of mind.

column1: Can condoms get lost inside the vagina?
column2: A condom cannot travel to other parts of the body. If it slips inside, stay calm and gently remove it with clean fingers or visit a health worker. Avoid intercourse again until you use a new condom.

column1: Do pills cause cancer?
column2: Birth control pills do not increase the risk of most cancers; they can actually lower risk of ovarian and uterine cancer. A provider will check your medical history to ensure the safest type for you.

column1: Can IUD cause infertility?
column2: No, IUDs do not cause infertility. Fertility returns quickly after removal. Infections related to unsafe sex — not the IUD — are what can harm reproductive health, so condoms remain important.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I have sex during my period?
column2: Yes, it is possible because ovulation timing can vary each month. To avoid surprises, use protection during every sexual contact.

column1: Are irregular periods normal after emergency pill?
column2: Yes, emergency pills may cause periods to be early, late, or slightly different. This is temporary and settles in 1–2 months. If your period is very late, take a pregnancy test to be sure.

column1: Do condoms tear easily?
column2: No, condoms are strong when used correctly. Tears can happen if they are expired, opened with sharp objects, or used with oil-based products. Proper handling keeps them effective.

column1: Can I use birth control to treat heavy periods?
column2: Yes, pills and some hormonal methods can help make periods lighter and less painful. Many people use contraception for both health and pregnancy prevention.

column1: Can a man tell if a woman is using contraception?
column2: No, most methods are private and invisible. Your reproductive choices are personal, and you can use protection without anyone knowing if you want privacy.

column1: Will hormonal contraception affect my mood?
column2: Some people notice small mood changes while their body adjusts in the first few months. If changes feel hard or continue long-term, a health worker can help find a method that fits you better.

column1: Is it safe to use an IUD if I have not given birth?
column2: Yes, IUDs are recommended for many people who have never been pregnant. They are safe, effective, and long-lasting.

column1: Can birth control help with acne or PCOS?
column2: Yes, hormonal contraception can help manage acne and certain PCOS symptoms by balancing hormones. A healthcare provider will guide you to a suitable method for your health condition.

column1: Do pills protect against STIs?
column2: No, pills protect only from pregnancy. Using condoms along with pills gives double protection — from both infections and pregnancy.

column1: Can I start contraception immediately after giving birth?
column2: Yes, many methods can be started soon after childbirth, depending on your health and whether you are breastfeeding. A provider will help choose the option that fits your recovery and comfort.

column1: Can condoms be reused if washed?
column2: No, condoms are strictly single-use. Reusing can cause breakage and increase infection and pregnancy risk. Always use a new one each time.

column1: Does virginity change how contraception works?
column2: No, contraception works the same for everyone, regardless of whether they’ve had sexual experience before or not. It’s simply about protection and health care.

column1: Can I become pregnant if I don’t ovulate every month?
column2: Yes, even if ovulation doesn’t happen every cycle, you can still get pregnant on a month when it does occur. If you want to avoid pregnancy, consistent protection is key.

column1: Will using condoms reduce pleasure?
column2: Some people think so, but the right size and lubricant can make sex comfortable and enjoyable for both partners. Feeling safe can help you relax and enjoy the moment better. There are also ultra-thin and textured condoms designed for pleasure.

column1: Can I use contraception during menopause?
column2: Yes, until menopause is fully confirmed, pregnancy is still possible. A health worker can suggest options that also help manage symptoms like heavy bleeding or hot flashes.

column1: Can emergency pills work during ovulation?
column2: They are less effective if ovulation has already happened. But you should still take it — it may still help prevent pregnancy. If you are unsure, consider a copper IUD for the highest protection.

column1: Do I need to see a doctor before using condoms?
column2: No, condoms are easily available and safe to use without any medical visit. Anyone can use them right away for protection.

column1: Can I get pregnant after only touching genitals together?
column2: Yes, if semen or pre-ejaculate touches the vaginal area, pregnancy can still happen. It’s best to use protection whenever there is genital contact to avoid unnecessary stress.

column1: Can menstrual cups push my IUD out?
column2: It is unlikely, but be gentle when removing the cup and break the seal first. Your provider can teach you how to check IUD strings so you feel confident. Regular check-ups help ensure everything is in place.

column1: Is sex safe after abortion?
column2: Yes, once a health provider confirms healing (usually after 1–2 weeks), sex is safe. Use contraception if you want to avoid pregnancy soon after.

column1: Can I skip periods on purpose using pills?
column2: Yes, skipping the pill-free break is safe if recommended by your provider. Many people do this to avoid painful or inconvenient periods. It does not harm fertility or health.

column1: Can I get STIs even if I trust my partner?
column2: Yes, infections do not always show symptoms and can be unknowingly passed. Using condoms protects both of you and strengthens trust by caring for each other’s health.

column1: Does vasectomy affect ejaculation amount?
column2: No, ejaculation looks and feels the same after vasectomy. Only sperm is blocked — all other fluids remain normal. There is no change in manhood or pleasure.

column1: Can a 15-year-old get contraception without parental permission?
column2: Yes, in Nepal adolescents can get confidential sexual and reproductive health services without needing parental consent. Visit a youth-friendly health post or clinic for guidance.

column1: What contraceptives are safe for teenagers?
column2: Condoms, pills, and emergency contraception are safe for teens. A youth-friendly clinic can help choose what fits best for you.

column1: I’m unmarried and sexually active — can I go to a health post?
column2: Yes, you can. Health workers are trained to provide non-judgmental and private family-planning services for everyone.

column1: How do I talk to my parents about contraception?
column2: Try to choose a calm moment, say you want to learn about health and safety, and ask for their support or visit a counsellor if you feel shy.

column1: Is it safe to use condoms the first time I have sex?
column2: Yes, condoms are completely safe and also protect against infections. Use them correctly every time.

column1: Where can students get confidential family-planning advice in Kathmandu?
column2: You can visit Marie Stopes, FPAN, or government adolescent-friendly clinics in Kathmandu that offer confidential counselling.

column1: Can school health services provide contraceptive pills?
column2: Some schools refer students to nearby health posts, but usually, pills are given at health facilities or pharmacies.

column1: What if I’m scared someone will see me at the clinic?
column2: You can visit during quiet hours, ask for privacy, or call a helpline first. Health workers respect confidentiality.

column1: Are implants suitable for young women?
column2: Yes, contraceptive implants are safe for young women and provide long-term protection. They can be removed anytime you want.

column1: Can contraceptives affect my studies or mood?
column2: Most methods won’t affect your studies or energy. Some may cause mild changes, but these settle within a few weeks.

column1: What is the best contraceptive for a college student?
column2: Condoms are easy to access, pills are effective with regular use, and implants or injectables work well for longer-term protection.

column1: What if my boyfriend refuses to use condoms?
column2: You have the right to protect your health. Explain why it matters and don’t have unprotected sex if you’re uncomfortable.

column1: Can I get emergency pills without prescription in Nepal?
column2: Yes, emergency contraceptive pills are available in most pharmacies. Take them within 72 hours for best results.

column1: Will people judge me for buying condoms?
column2: No, don’t worry. Many people buy condoms, and pharmacists are used to it. You’re being responsible, not shameful.

column1: Is it okay to use contraceptives before marriage?
column2: Yes, family planning is for anyone who wants to prevent unplanned pregnancy, not just for married couples.

column1: Can using pills make me infertile later?
column2: No, once you stop taking pills, your fertility returns quickly. It doesn’t cause long-term infertility.

column1: How soon after childbirth can I start family planning?
column2: You can start immediately after birth with methods safe for breastfeeding, like condoms, LAM, or implants.

column1: Can I use an IUD if I haven’t had children yet?
column2: Yes, modern IUDs are safe for women whether or not they’ve had children.

column1: What if my husband says family planning is only for women?
column2: Family planning is for both partners. Men can use condoms or support shared decisions on spacing pregnancies.

column1: Is it painful to insert an implant or IUD?
column2: You might feel a small pinch or cramp, but it’s quick and done under local anaesthesia.

column1: Can I switch from one method to another easily?
column2: Yes, you can. A health worker will guide you on how to switch safely without a gap in protection.

column1: Do birth control pills cause weight gain?
column2: Some people notice small weight changes, but it’s usually temporary and can be managed by staying active.

column1: Are pills safe for women above 35?
column2: Yes, if you don’t smoke and are healthy, you can safely use pills after 35. Otherwise, your provider may suggest other options.

column1: Can I use emergency pills often?
column2: No, emergency pills are for occasional use only. Use regular contraception if you’re sexually active often.

column1: What if I vomit after taking the pill?
column2: If you vomit within 2 hours of taking your pill, take another one as soon as possible.

column1: Can I use family planning if I have irregular periods?
column2: Yes, but tell your provider. Some methods can help make your periods more regular.

column1: Will I lose my virginity if I use an IUD?
column2: No, an IUD is inserted into the uterus, not the hymen. It doesn’t affect virginity.

column1: Can I get pregnant while breastfeeding?
column2: Yes, after 6 months your risk increases. Use an additional family planning method after that period.

column1: How long after stopping injections can I get pregnant?
column2: It can take up to 9–10 months after your last shot for fertility to return, but it varies by person.

column1: Is withdrawal a safe method?
column2: It’s not very reliable; almost 1 in 5 couples get pregnant using only withdrawal. It’s better to use condoms or another method.

column1: Can I use the pill while having diabetes?
column2: Yes, but consult a doctor. Some pills may not be suitable depending on your blood sugar control.

column1: Can a breastfeeding mother use implants?
column2: Yes, implants are safe while breastfeeding and won’t affect your milk.

column1: What is LAM in family planning?
column2: LAM (Lactational Amenorrhea Method) is a natural method for breastfeeding mothers, effective only for the first 6 months after delivery.

column1: Can family planning affect my skin?
column2: Some pills can cause mild acne or clear it up. It depends on your body; side effects usually settle over time.

column1: Can I use condoms during periods?
column2: Yes, condoms can be used anytime you have sex, even during menstruation.

column1: What should I do if my period stops after using an implant?
column2: That’s normal; some methods reduce or stop bleeding. It’s safe and doesn’t harm fertility.

column1: Do I need my husband’s permission for family planning?
column2: No, every woman has the right to choose her own reproductive health options.

column1: Is it okay to feel emotional after starting contraception?
column2: Yes, hormone changes can cause mild mood shifts, but they usually improve as your body adjusts.

column1: Can I get family planning advice online?
column2: Yes, you can contact the Nepal Health Helpline (1115) or visit the FPAN and UNFPA websites for reliable guidance.

column1: I missed my pill yesterday what should i do?
column2: Take the missed pill as soon as you remember, even if it means taking two in one day.

column1: Can stress affect family planning methods?
column2: Stress doesn’t reduce the effectiveness of most methods, but it can delay your period sometimes.

column1: Is it safe to use contraceptives if I’m underweight?
column2: Yes, most methods are safe, but tell your provider so they can choose the best one for your health.

column1: Can I get pregnant right after removing my implant?
column2: Yes, fertility returns quickly after removal. Plan when you’re ready.

column1: Will contraception protect me from STIs?
column2: Only condoms protect against both pregnancy and infections. Use them even with other methods for full safety.

column1: Is it okay to take pills at night instead of morning?
column2: Yes, timing doesn’t matter as long as you take it at the same time every day.

column1: Can I take the pill during my period?
column2: Yes, you can start during your period; it helps confirm you’re not pregnant.

column1: Can I use an IUD if I have heavy periods?
column2: Hormonal IUDs can actually reduce heavy bleeding. Your provider can recommend the right one.

column1: I feel shy talking about contraception — what should I do?
column2: It’s okay to feel shy. You can start by chatting online with health counsellors or call youth-friendly helplines for support.

column1: Can birth control affect my ability to have children later?
column2: No, all methods are reversible. Once you stop, you can get pregnant again when you’re ready.

column1: I missed two pills this week am I pregnant?
column3: Don’t worry right away — just take the most recent missed pill as soon as possible and continue your pack. Use a condom for the next 7 days to stay protected.

column1: I’m scared my parents will find out I’m using contraception what should I do?
column3: It’s okay to feel worried. You can visit a youth-friendly clinic where your privacy is fully respected. No one will inform your parents without your consent.

column1: I had unprotected sex last night.what should I do now?
column3: You can take an emergency contraceptive pill within 72 hours. The sooner you take it, the better it works.

column1: Can I get family planning help if I’m under 18?
column2: Yes, definitely. Health workers are there to help young people like you confidentially — you won’t get in trouble.

column1: I’m afraid contraception will harm my future baby.
column2: Don’t worry — family planning doesn’t harm your future fertility or babies. Once you stop, your body returns to normal quickly.

column1: My boyfriend said pills cause cancer. Is that true?
column3: No, that’s a myth. Pills do not cause cancer. In fact, they can lower your risk of ovarian and uterine cancer.

column1: I feel guilty for using contraception before marriage.
column2: You don’t need to feel guilty. Taking care of your health and preventing unplanned pregnancy is a responsible choice.

column1: I used an emergency pill last month — is it safe to use again?
column2: It’s safe but not meant for regular use. Try switching to a long-term method like pills, injectables, or implants.

column1: What if my boyfriend doesn’t want me to use contraception?
column2: It’s your body and your choice. You can discuss it kindly but firmly, or visit a clinic alone if you need confidential support.

column1: I feel shy buying condoms from a pharmacy.
column2: It’s normal to feel that way at first. Remember, buying condoms means you’re being responsible — not shameful.

column1: I had my period after taking an emergency pill — does that mean it worked?
column2: Yes, if you got your period after taking the emergency pill, it means it worked properly.

column1: Can I get contraception without my husband knowing?
column2: Yes, you can. Family planning services in Nepal are confidential, and health workers will not share your information.

column1: What if my parents see me at the health post?
column2: You can visit at quieter hours or nearby clinics where staff are used to helping youth discreetly.

column1: I used a condom but it broke — what now?
column2: Don’t panic! Take an emergency pill within 72 hours and visit a health centre for advice if you’re unsure.

column1: Is it normal to bleed irregularly after using implants?
column2: Yes, light or irregular bleeding is common at first. It usually settles after a few months — don’t worry.

column1: Can I use pills if I’m breastfeeding a newborn?
column2: Yes, but only progestin-only pills are safe during breastfeeding. Avoid combined pills until six months after delivery.

column1: I feel weak after getting a Depo shot.Is that normal?
column2: Some people feel mild weakness, but it usually goes away. Eat well and rest — if it continues, talk to your health worker.

column1: My period stopped after using injection.Should I worry?
column2: No need to worry — some women stop having periods while using injections, and it’s perfectly safe.

column1: Can I get family planning at a private pharmacy?
column2: Yes, most pharmacies in Nepal sell condoms, pills, and emergency pills. They’re affordable and safe to use.

column1: I feel emotional after starting pills.What should I do?
column2: It’s normal to feel small mood changes at first. Give your body time to adjust, or talk to a provider if it bothers you.

column1: Is it okay to start family planning right after miscarriage?
column2: Yes, you can start as soon as you feel ready. It helps your body recover and prevents another unplanned pregnancy too soon.

column1: Do implants hurt when removed?
column2: You’ll feel a little pinch, but it’s quick and done under local anaesthesia. You can relax — it’s not painful.

column1: Can I get pregnant even if my partner didn’t finish inside?
column2: Yes, pregnancy can still happen due to pre-ejaculate fluid. Using condoms every time is safest.

column1: What if I forget my injection date?
column2: Try to get your next shot within 2 weeks of the due date. If it’s later, use a condom until your next injection.

column1: Are there side effects to using condoms?
column2: Condoms rarely cause side effects. Some may be allergic to latex, but you can use non-latex types instead.

column1: I’m afraid my friends will judge me for using contraception
column2: It’s okay to care about others’ opinions, but remember — it’s your health, and responsible choices deserve respect, not judgment.

column1: Do pills make you gain a lot of weight?
column2: Not usually. Some people gain a little due to water retention, but it balances out quickly.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I skip one pill?
column2: It’s unlikely if you take the next one quickly, but use condoms for a few days just to be safe.

column1: I’m breastfeeding and don’t want to get pregnant soon
column2: You can use condoms, LAM (for the first 6 months), or implants safely while breastfeeding.

column1: Will my husband notice if I use an implant?
column2: No, he won’t feel it during sex — it’s placed under the skin of your upper arm and not visible.

column1: Can I take emergency pills if I’m under 16?
column2: Yes, you can. Emergency contraception is safe for all ages and can prevent pregnancy after unprotected sex.

column1: I feel scared about inserting an IUD
column2: It’s normal to feel nervous. The procedure takes only a few minutes and is done gently by trained staff.

column1: What happens if I miss my period after taking the injection?
column2: It’s normal — the injection can stop periods temporarily. If you’re worried, take a pregnancy test for peace of mind.

column1: Can I use condoms and pills together?
column2: Yes, using both gives double protection — pills prevent pregnancy, and condoms protect from infections.

column1: What if my husband says we should have a baby right away but I’m not ready?
column2: You can gently explain that waiting helps your health and the baby’s future. You have the right to decide when you’re ready.

column1: Can contraception cause infertility?
column2: No, all methods are reversible. You can get pregnant soon after stopping when you wish.

column1: I’m scared my friends will gossip if they see me at a clinic
column2: That fear is common. Many clinics offer private timings — you can even call ahead for a discreet appointment.

column1: Can I stop using the pill anytime I want?
column2: Yes, you can stop anytime. But if you don’t want to get pregnant, use another method right away.

column1: What if I can’t remember to take my pill daily?
column2: That’s okay! You can try injections or implants that don’t need daily attention.

column1: Do I need to take a break after a few months of pills?
column2: No, you don’t need to stop unless you want to. Continuous use is safe and effective.

column1: Is it okay to feel scared about sex after childbirth?
column2: Yes, many new mothers feel that way. Take your time, talk with your partner, and use gentle protection when you’re ready.

column1: I’m 17 and my boyfriend wants sex
column2: but I’m not sure
column3: It’s okay to say no if you’re not ready. Consent is your right, and waiting until you feel comfortable is healthy.

column1: Can I get family planning help online in Nepal?
column2: Yes, several helplines and apps offer confidential advice, like the MoHP’s 1115 hotline and UNFPA-supported services.

column1: What if my partner laughs when I mention condoms?
column2: Stay calm and explain that using condoms shows care and maturity. You can also carry your own if needed.

column1: I missed my period after taking an emergency pill
column2: It’s normal for your period to come a bit early or late. If it delays more than a week, take a pregnancy test.

column1: I’m scared contraception will cause cancer
column2: Don’t worry — none of the approved family planning methods cause cancer. They’re tested and safe for use in Nepal.

column1: Can I get a family planning method without ID or citizenship card?
column2: Yes, most clinics and health posts don’t require documents for basic services like condoms or pills.

column1: My mother-in-law says using contraception is sinful
column2: Many people still believe that, but family planning is about protecting your health and your family’s future — not a sin.

column1: I want to stop using contraception but I’m afraid I’ll get pregnant soon
column2: That’s possible, as fertility returns quickly. Use condoms until you’re ready for pregnancy.

column1: I’m scared I’ll forget my next injection.
column2: Ask the health worker to mark it on your card or phone calendar — that way you won’t miss it!

column1: If I stop using contraception, how soon can I get pregnant?
column2: Fertility returns quickly after most methods. After stopping condoms or removing an IUD, conception can occur almost immediately because fertility is restored at once. Even after methods like injectables, women often regain fertility within a few months. Therefore, if you are planning to conceive or not, you should be aware that pregnancy is possible shortly after discontinuing use.

column1: How does unmet need for family planning vary by region or development region in Nepal?
column2: The Nepal Demographic and Health Survey (NDHS) (2016) showed unmet need is highest in the Western and Far-Western regions and lowest in the Eastern region. Also, in rural areas the unmet need tends to be higher compared to urban areas. This means programmes should place more focus in those regions with higher unmet need.

column1: What service availability issues affect family planning in certain provinces of Nepal (for example in the hills or remote areas)?
column2: According to the Nepal Health Facility Survey 2021, while nearly all facilities (98 %) offer at least one modern temporary method nationwide, fewer facilities offer implants (41 %) or IUDs (29 %), and only about 2 % offered sterilisation services where modern methods were available. Also in the SMNH Roadmap 2030 it is noted that in some provinces (such as Province 4) less than half of health posts have the full set of 5 modern methods available. Thus in remote or specific provinces the method‐mix and availability may be constrained.

column1: What is the goal of Nepal’s national family planning program?
column2: The goal of Nepal’s family planning program is to ensure that every couple and individual can freely decide the number and spacing of their children, and to have access to quality family planning services and information as a basic human right, according to the Ministry of Health and Population and UNFPA Nepal.

column1: How does family planning contribute to Nepal’s development goals?
column2: Family planning helps reduce maternal and infant mortality, improves women’s participation in education and employment, and supports Nepal’s Sustainable Development Goals on health, gender equality, and poverty reduction.

column1: Who coordinates family planning programs at the national level in Nepal?
column2: The Family Welfare Division under the Department of Health Services of the Ministry of Health and Population coordinates family planning programs nationally, working with partners like FPAN, UNFPA, and WHO.

column1: What is the role of Female Community Health Volunteers (FCHVs) in family planning?
column2: FCHVs distribute condoms and pills, provide counseling, refer clients for long-term methods, and play a vital role in educating rural communities about family planning options.

column1: My husband and I feel our family is complete. What permanent methods are available in Nepal, and what is the waiting period or consent process like?
column2: In Nepal, both male and female sterilization are available. For men, it's a vasectomy, a minor procedure. For women, it's tubal ligation, which requires a slightly more complex procedure. Legally, you must be at least 18 years old and provide full, free, and informed consent. Spousal consent is not a legal requirement, but healthcare providers often encourage couples to make the decision together. There is no mandated waiting period if you are certain. These services are available at most government hospitals and many private facilities.

column1: I live with my in-laws, and there is immense pressure to have a son. How can I use family planning without causing conflict in my household?
column2: This is a very common and challenging situation, and you are not alone. First and foremost, please know that your health and personal choices are paramount. A strategic approach can help you navigate this family pressure. The most critical step is to involve your husband in a private conversation; if he is supportive, he can become your strongest ally in managing expectations from the wider family. To frame the conversation constructively, you could position the decision as a health-based recommendation, saying something like, "The doctor advised me to space my children for my own health and to ensure I can provide the best care for the children we already have," which uses the respected authority of a medical professional. Finally, for practical day-to-day management, you could consider a discreet, long-acting method like an IUD or implant, which is highly effective and doesn't require daily supplies or routines that others in the household might notice.

column1: How does wealth status affect the adolescent birth rate among married girls aged 15-19 in Nepal?
column2: Married girls in the poorest households have a rate of 83 births per 1,000, whereas those in the richest households have 31 births per 1,000.

column1: Can I get pregnant if it's my first time having sex?
column2: Yes, pregnancy can happen any time there’s unprotected sex — even the first time.

column1: Will the pill make me fat?
column2: Some people notice small weight changes, but it’s usually temporary and not caused directly by the pill.

column1: Can I reuse a condom if I wash it?
column2: No! Condoms are for one-time use only — washing or reusing them makes them unsafe.

column1: If I take two emergency pills, will it work better?
column2: No. Taking extra pills won’t make it more effective and may cause side effects. One dose is enough.

column1: Can I get pregnant if we do it standing up?
column2: Yes. Position doesn’t prevent pregnancy — only protection does.

column1: Will condoms break easily?
column2: Not if used correctly. Check the expiry date and don’t use sharp nails or teeth to open the packet.

column1: Can I get pregnant during my period?
column2: Yes, it’s rare but possible — sperm can live inside the body for several days.

column1: Do birth control pills make me emotional?
column2: Some people feel mood changes at first, but it usually balances out after a few weeks.

column1: Can I get pregnant if we only ‘do it’ once?
column2: Yes, pregnancy can occur even from one act of unprotected sex.

column1: Is it true that drinking Coke after sex prevents pregnancy?
column2: No. That’s a myth. Only proper contraception can prevent pregnancy.

column1: Can I get pregnant if he doesn’t ‘finish’ inside?
column2: Yes. Pre-ejaculate fluid can still contain sperm, so withdrawal isn’t fully safe.

column1: Will family planning make me infertile forever?
column2: No. Except for sterilization, all methods are reversible once stopped.

column1: Can condoms get lost inside the body?
column2: Rarely. If it slips inside, stay calm and remove it gently or see a health worker.

column1: Can I get pregnant if we didn’t ‘go all the way’?
column2: If sperm touches the vagina, pregnancy is possible even without full penetration.

column1: Can I use plastic wrap as a condom?
column2: No. Only real condoms are made to prevent pregnancy and infections safely.

column1: Can I get pregnant from oral sex?
column2: No, but oral sex doesn’t protect against sexually transmitted infections (STIs).

column1: Can I shower right after sex to avoid pregnancy?
column2: No. Washing doesn’t stop sperm once it’s inside the body.

column1: Do condoms expire?
column2: Yes. Always check the expiry date — old condoms can break easily.

column1: Can I use two condoms for extra safety?
column2: No. Double condoms cause friction and are more likely to tear.

column1: Do I need to rest after getting an implant?
column2: You might feel mild soreness, but you can continue your normal routine the same day.

column1: Can I get pregnant if it’s just the first few minutes?
column2: Yes. Pregnancy can happen even before full intercourse.

column1: Will taking hot water after sex stop pregnancy?
column2: No. That’s a myth — water doesn’t affect sperm once inside the body.

column1: Do condoms make sex less enjoyable?
column2: Many people say no — using the right size and brand helps comfort and pleasure.

column1: Can I take the emergency pill every time I have sex?
column2: No. It’s for emergencies only. Use regular contraception for ongoing protection.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I didn’t have an orgasm?
column2: Yes. Pregnancy depends on sperm meeting the egg, not on orgasm.

column1: Is the injection painful?
column2: Just a small pinch! It’s quick and done in seconds by trained staff.

column1: Can I use toothpaste as spermicide?
column2: No! Toothpaste is not safe for the body and doesn’t prevent pregnancy.

column1: Can I get pregnant from sitting on a toilet seat?
column2: No. Sperm cannot survive long outside the body.

column1: Can birth control make me glow or get pimples?
column2: Some notice skin improvements, others mild acne — it varies by person.

column1: Can I take birth control secretly?
column2: Yes. Most methods are private — pills, injectables, or implants can be used confidentially.

column1: Is it bad to take pills at night?
column2: No. Just take them at the same time every day for best results.

column1: Can I use expired condoms?
column2: No. Expired condoms can tear easily and don’t protect well.

column1: Can I get pregnant while breastfeeding?
column2: It’s less likely in the first 6 months, but still possible — you can use breastfeeding-safe contraception.

column1: Can my boyfriend buy pills for me?
column2: Yes. Anyone can buy contraceptives at pharmacies or health posts.

column1: Will contraception make me lose hair?
column2: Rarely. Some hormonal methods can cause slight changes, but it’s usually temporary.

column1: Can I get pregnant if we use the same condom twice?
column2: Yes. Reusing condoms makes them ineffective — always use a new one.

column1: Can I get pregnant through clothes?
column2: No. Sperm can’t pass through fabric or dry surfaces.

column1: Can condoms get stuck inside?
column2: Sometimes they can slip in — don’t panic, remove it carefully or visit a clinic.

column1: Can I use oil or Vaseline with condoms?
column2: No. Oil damages condoms. Always use water-based lubricants.

column1: Do I need to take a break from using the pill?
column2: No. You can safely use it for years with health checkups.

column1: Can I get pregnant from kissing or touching?
column2: No. Pregnancy only happens from sperm entering the vagina.

column1: Will condoms break if it’s too hot or cold?
column2: Extreme heat can damage them, so store in a cool, dry place.

column1: Can birth control make me stop having periods?
column2: Some methods like injections or implants can reduce or pause periods — it’s safe and reversible.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I pee right after sex?
column2: No. Urinating doesn’t prevent pregnancy.

column1: Is it true that men can feel the IUD during sex?
column2: Usually no — if inserted properly, it’s not noticeable.

column1: Can I get pregnant while on my honeymoon even with protection?
column2: If used correctly, protection works very well — enjoy safely!

column1: Will using birth control make me look older?
column2: No. It doesn’t affect your looks or aging.

column1: Can I take the emergency pill just in case, before sex?
column2: No. It only works after unprotected sex — use regular contraception for prevention.

column1: Can I use a balloon instead of a condom?
column2: No! Balloons are unsafe and can break — only medical condoms work properly.

column1: Can I get pregnant from swimming in a pool?
column2: No. Pregnancy can’t happen from swimming or pool water.

column1: Do condoms come in different sizes?
column2: Yes. Using the right size makes them safer and more comfortable.

column1: Can I still get pregnant if I take pills but vomit after?
column2: If you vomit within 2 hours of taking a pill, it may not work — take another.

column1: Is it okay to use birth control without telling my husband?
column2: If you feel unsafe discussing it, it’s okay to protect yourself privately.

column1: Can birth control affect my mood?
column2: Some feel minor mood changes, but they’re usually mild and temporary.

column1: Can I get pregnant while on birth control pills?
column2: It’s rare if taken correctly, but missing doses can reduce effectiveness.

column1: Can condoms break if we use too much lube?
column2: Not if it’s water-based. Oil-based lubricants can cause damage.

column1: Can I take emergency pills every week?
column2: No. Frequent use causes irregular cycles. Use a regular method instead.

column1: Can I still get pregnant if I use condoms sometimes?
column2: Yes. Condoms work only if used every time, from start to finish.

column1: Can men use family planning too?
column2: Yes. Condoms, vasectomy, and shared decision-making are all forms of male participation.

column1: Can I get pregnant if he pulls out early?
column2: Yes. Withdrawal is risky — pre-ejaculate fluid can contain sperm.

column1: Do I have to get my husband’s permission to use contraception?
column2: No. Family planning is your personal health right.

column1: Can birth control protect against STIs?
column2: Only condoms protect against infections like HIV, not pills or injections.

column1: Can I get pregnant after missing one pill?
column2: It’s unlikely, but take the missed pill as soon as possible and continue normally.

column1: Can family planning make me lose interest in sex?
column2: It affects everyone differently. Some feel no change; others feel more relaxed knowing they’re protected.

column1: Can I get pregnant after stopping birth control?
column2: Yes, fertility usually returns quickly after most methods.

column1: Do I have to bleed every month to be healthy?
column2: Not necessarily. Some contraceptives safely reduce or stop periods.

column1: Can I use family planning while having periods?
column2: Yes, some methods can start anytime with proper advice from a health worker.

column1: Can birth control protect me from infections?
column2: Only condoms protect against STIs — pills and injections do not.

column1: Can I use a condom if it’s a little old?
column2: If it’s past the expiry date or brittle, don’t use it — it may tear.

column1: Can family planning cause cancer?
column2: No. Most modern methods actually lower some cancer risks, like ovarian and uterine cancer.

column1: Can I use emergency contraception after 5 days?
column2: No, it’s only effective within 5 days — sooner is better.

column1: Can men take birth control pills too?
column2: No. Pills are designed for women’s hormones — men should use condoms or vasectomy.

column1: Can I use birth control while breastfeeding?
column2: Yes. Certain methods like progestin-only pills and injectables are safe during breastfeeding.

column1: Can I skip my period using the pill?
column2: Yes, by taking active pills continuously, but consult a health worker first.

column1: Can I use a condom in water?
column2: Water weakens condoms. Use them only on dry skin.

column1: Will family planning stop me from getting pregnant forever?
column2: Only permanent methods like sterilization do. Others are reversible.

column1: Can I take the pill without eating?
column2: Yes, but taking it with food may prevent nausea for some people.

column1: Can I use two methods at once?
column2: Yes! Using condoms plus another method gives double protection.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I’m under 18?
column2: Yes. Fertility starts after puberty, so contraception is important if sexually active.

column1: Can I get pregnant from touching sperm with my hand?
column2: Not unless sperm enters the vagina soon after contact.

column1: Can I get pregnant if it’s just a little bit inside?
column2: Yes. Even a small amount of sperm can cause pregnancy.

column1: Can I store condoms in my wallet?
column2: Not for long. Heat and friction can damage them — keep them in a cool, safe place.

column1: Can I get pregnant if it’s my first time and he uses protection?
column2: If the condom is used correctly, pregnancy risk is very low.

column1: Can I use birth control if I’m underweight?
column2: Yes. A health worker can recommend the best option for your body type.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I sleep right after sex?
column2: Yes, if unprotected. Sleeping doesn’t change the risk.

column1: Can I use a condom that’s too big?
column2: No. Loose condoms can slip off — use the right size for safety.

column1: Can I drink alcohol while on the pill?
column2: Yes, but don’t forget your daily dose. Alcohol doesn’t reduce effectiveness directly.

column1: Can I use family planning even if I have irregular periods?
column2: Yes. Some methods can even help regulate your cycle.

column1: Can I get pregnant from dry humping?
column2: Unlikely, but if sperm touches the vagina, there’s still a small risk.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I use a condom but it slips off?
column2: Yes, if sperm entered the vagina — consider emergency contraception.

column1: Can I take emergency pills twice in one month?
column2: Yes, if needed, but it’s not for regular use — get a long-term method.

column1: Can I use a condom that was in my bag for months?
column2: If it’s not expired or damaged, yes — otherwise, replace it.

column1: Can I take pills even if my period hasn’t started?
column2: Yes, but confirm with a health worker when to begin for best protection.

column1: Can I get pregnant if the condom breaks?
column2: Yes. Take emergency contraception as soon as possible.

column1: Can I use birth control without my family knowing?
column2: Yes. Services in Nepal are confidential and private.

column1: Can birth control cause infertility in men?
column2: No. Male fertility isn’t affected by their partner’s contraception.

column1: Can I get pregnant from touching semen?
column2: Only if semen is transferred directly into the vagina soon after.

column1: Can I take the pill late at night?
column2: Yes. Just take it at the same time daily — morning or night both work.

column1: Can I take emergency pills if I vomit right after sex?
column2: If you vomit within 2 hours of taking the pill, take another dose.

column1: Can I use my friend’s birth control pills?
column2: No. Everyone’s health and hormone needs differ — get your own prescription.

column1: What is the adolescent birth rate (girls aged 15-19) married or in‐union in Nepal according to MICS 2019?
column2: According to the MICS 2019, the adolescent birth rate is 63 births per 1,000 girls aged 15-19 who are married or in‐union at the national level.

column1: How does education affect the adolescent birth rate in Nepal (married girls aged 15-19)?
column2: Girls with no education have a rate of 166 births per 1,000, compared with 47 births per 1,000 among those with secondary education.

column1: Which province of Nepal had the highest adolescent birth rate (15-19) according to Nepal MICS Statistical Snapshot – Fertility & Family Planning (2019)?
column2: Province 2 had the highest rate: 96 births per 1,000 married/in-union girls aged 15-19.

column1: Are contraceptives safe for breastfeeding mothers?
column2: Yes, certain methods like progestin-only pills, injectables, and IUDs are safe during breastfeeding.

column1: Do men also need family planning?
column2: Yes! Men play a big role — using condoms, supporting partners, or choosing vasectomy.

column1: Can men take birth control pills too?
column2: No, those are for women’s hormones. Men can use condoms or vasectomy.

column1: Is vasectomy painful?
column2: It’s a simple, safe, and usually painless procedure done under local anesthesia.

column1: Can a man still have sex after vasectomy?
column2: Yes, sex life stays normal — only sperm is blocked, not pleasure or desire.

column1: Can vasectomy affect a man’s strength?
column2: No. It doesn’t affect energy, masculinity, or performance.

column1: Can I still ejaculate after vasectomy?
column2: Yes. You’ll still ejaculate normally — just without sperm.

column1: Can vasectomy be reversed?
column2: Sometimes, but it’s not guaranteed. It’s meant to be permanent.

column1: Can a man get an infection after vasectomy?
column2: Rarely. Proper care and hygiene prevent infections.

column1: Is condom use only a man’s responsibility?
column2: No. Family planning is a shared decision between partners.

column1: Why do some men refuse condoms?
column2: Some say it reduces pleasure, but the right size and type feel comfortable and safe.

column1: Can men use condoms with any lubricant?
column2: Only water-based lubricants. Oil-based ones can tear the condom.

column1: Do men also have family planning injections?
column2: Not yet. Male contraceptive injections are being tested but not widely available.

column1: Can men get pregnant?
column2: No. Only women can become pregnant, but men share equal responsibility for prevention.

column1: Can condoms fall off during sex?
column2: If the size is wrong or not held during withdrawal, yes — use the right fit.

column1: Can men feel if their partner is using an IUD?
column2: Usually no — if inserted properly, it’s not noticeable.

column1: Do men have side effects from condoms?
column2: Not usually. Rarely, latex allergy can cause irritation.

column1: Can a man’s sperm be weak because of condoms?
column2: No. Condoms don’t affect sperm quality — they only prevent transfer.

column1: Can I use two condoms — one for me and one for her?
column2: No. Friction between condoms can cause tearing.

column1: Can family planning make my wife infertile forever?
column2: No. Most methods are reversible — only sterilization is permanent.

column1: Can men get lazy after vasectomy?
column2: No. Vasectomy only blocks sperm; it doesn’t change hormones or energy.

column1: Is vasectomy like castration?
column2: No! Castration removes testicles, but vasectomy just blocks sperm flow.

column1: Can vasectomy cause erectile dysfunction?
column2: No. It doesn’t affect erections or performance.

column1: Can I still have children after vasectomy?
column2: Not naturally — you’d need medical help, so think carefully before doing it.

column1: Can condoms protect from all diseases?
column2: Condoms greatly reduce STI risk, but no method is 100% perfect.

column1: Can men get infections from not using condoms?
column2: Yes. STIs like HIV, syphilis, or gonorrhea can spread through unprotected sex.

column1: Can men use condoms multiple times?
column2: No. Always use a new condom each time you have sex.

column1: Do men have an emergency contraception pill?
column2: No. Only women’s emergency pills are available right now.

column1: Do men feel less pleasure with condoms?
column2: Some think so, but thinner condoms maintain natural feeling and safety.

column1: Can men buy birth control pills for their partner?
column2: Yes. Anyone can buy contraceptives in pharmacies.

column1: Can my wife get pregnant after giving birth?
column2: Yes! Ovulation can start again within weeks, even before her period returns.

column1: When can my wife start using contraception after delivery?
column2: She can start right after birth, depending on the method and breastfeeding.

column1: Can breastfeeding act as birth control?
column2: Yes, but only for the first 6 months, if periods haven’t returned and baby is fully breastfed.

column1: Can I have sex soon after childbirth?
column2: Usually after 4–6 weeks, when the body has healed. Always discuss with a doctor.

column1: Can my wife use an IUD right after giving birth?
column2: Yes. It can be inserted within 48 hours of delivery or after 6 weeks.

column1: Can breastfeeding women use pills?
column2: Yes, progestin-only pills are safe for breastfeeding mothers.

column1: Can a woman get pregnant while breastfeeding?
column2: Yes. It’s less likely, but possible once ovulation returns.

column1: Can family planning affect breast milk?
column2: Some hormonal methods can reduce milk slightly; others are safe — ask a nurse or doctor.

column1: Can condoms be used during breastfeeding?
column2: Yes. Condoms are completely safe for breastfeeding mothers.

column1: Can my wife use injection after birth?
column2: Yes, she can start after 6 weeks postpartum.

column1: Can I get my wife pregnant even if she just gave birth?
column2: Yes. Fertility can return quickly — use protection if you’re not planning another baby.

column1: Can my wife use an implant while breastfeeding?
column2: Yes, it’s safe and effective for nursing mothers.

column1: Can my wife take emergency pills after delivery?
column2: Yes, if needed — but it’s better to choose a regular method for ongoing protection.

column1: Can birth control affect a baby’s health through milk?
column2: No, the right postpartum methods are safe for babies.

column1: Can my wife get an IUD during C-section?
column2: Yes, it can be inserted immediately during the procedure.

column1: Can my wife take pills while breastfeeding twins?
column2: Yes, with the doctor’s advice — hormonal methods are safe if milk supply is good.

column1: Can women still have periods while breastfeeding?
column2: Some do, some don’t — it’s normal either way.

column1: Can a woman get pregnant before her first period after delivery?
column2: Yes, ovulation can happen before the first period.

column1: Can birth spacing affect a baby’s health?
column2: Yes. Waiting at least 2 years before next pregnancy improves mother and baby health.

column1: Can women get an implant during their period?
column2: Yes. It can be safely inserted during menstruation.

column1: Can family planning make childbirth harder later?
column2: No. It has no negative effect on future pregnancies.

column1: Can birth control make me permanently infertile?
column2: No. Most methods are reversible — only sterilization is permanent.

column1: Can I get cancer from birth control?
column2: No. In fact, it helps lower some cancer risks, like ovarian and uterine cancer.

column1: Can using condoms too often cause problems?
column2: No. Condoms are safe for everyday use if stored properly.

column1: Can I get pregnant from precum?
column2: Yes. Pre-ejaculate fluid can contain sperm, so use protection every time.

column1: Can women take pills without periods?
column2: Yes, but check with a health provider before starting.

column1: Can I get HIV from oral sex?
column2: There’s a small risk — condoms or dental dams can reduce it.

column1: Can I take two methods together for safety?
column2: Yes! Dual protection (like condoms plus pills) gives best results.

column1: Can I get pregnant even with IUD?
column2: It’s rare but possible — if you suspect, see a doctor right away.

column1: Can I use emergency pills too often?
column2: No. It can disturb your cycle — use a long-term method instead.

column1: Can pills stop working if I drink alcohol?
column2: No, but heavy drinking can make you forget doses.

column1: Can birth control cause weight loss?
column2: Not usually. Some people notice small changes that vary by method.

column1: Can birth control cause acne?
column2: Some methods help clear acne; others might worsen it slightly.

column1: Can I use herbs or home remedies for family planning?
column2: No. Only medically approved methods are safe and effective.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I take antibiotics while on the pill?
column2: Some antibiotics may reduce pill effectiveness — ask your doctor.

column1: Can I get pregnant after I stop breastfeeding?
column2: Yes! Fertility returns quickly — plan your next method early.

column1: Can I get pregnant with implant in my arm?
column2: It’s extremely rare. Implants are more than 99% effective.

column1: Can birth control delay my periods?
column2: Yes, some methods make cycles lighter or irregular — it’s normal.

column1: Can condoms tear if stored in jeans pocket?
column2: Yes, heat and friction can weaken them — store safely.

column1: Can I use male condoms and female condoms together?
column2: No. It increases friction and risk of tearing.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I have sex in water?
column2: Yes. Water doesn’t stop sperm from entering the body.

column1: Can I use condoms after checking the expiry date?
column2: Yes, only if still valid and in good condition.

column1: Can birth control make me infertile after stopping?
column2: No. Fertility returns soon after most methods are stopped.

column1: Can I use emergency pills as regular birth control?
column2: No. It’s only for emergencies — not a long-term option.

column1: Can birth control cause depression?
column2: Some people feel mood changes, but most don’t. If it bothers you, talk to a health worker.

column1: Can I get pregnant even after taking the pill on time?
column2: It’s very rare if you use it correctly every day.

column1: Can I get pregnant while using injections?
column2: Injections are 99% effective when taken on schedule.

column1: Can I use birth control even if I’m not married?
column2: Yes. Family planning is for anyone who wants to prevent pregnancy safely.

column1: Can birth control affect my periods permanently?
column2: No. Your normal cycle returns after stopping it.

column1: Can I use the pill to skip my period for a trip or event?
column2: Yes, it’s safe to skip occasionally under doctor’s advice.

column1: Can men feel difference with condoms?
column2: Some notice a slight change, but most say it feels natural when fitted right.

column1: Can condoms be used more than once in a night?
column2: Only once per act. Always change to a new condom.

column1: Can I use a condom that’s stored in my car?
column2: Avoid it — heat inside cars can damage condoms.

column1: Can I get pregnant if condom slips inside me?
column2: Yes, if semen entered. Use emergency contraception soon.

column1: Can I use toothpaste as lubricant?
column2: No! Toothpaste can cause burns. Use only water-based lubricants.

column1: Can I get pregnant from sperm on my finger?
column2: Only if sperm is fresh and enters the vagina quickly.

column1: Can I get HIV from kissing?
column2: No. HIV doesn’t spread through saliva.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I didn’t finish inside?
column2: Yes, because precum can contain sperm.

column1: Can I take pills while fasting?
column2: Yes. Just take them at your usual time with or without food.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I shower right after sex?
column2: No. Showering doesn’t stop sperm inside the body.

column1: Can I get pregnant through anal sex?
column2: No pregnancy risk, but STIs can still spread — use condoms for safety.

column1: Can I use oil as lubricant for condoms?
column2: No. Oil damages latex condoms. Use water-based lubricants instead.

column1: Can I still get pregnant if I use birth control and condom?
column2: Extremely unlikely — that’s double protection!

column1: Can I use emergency pill if condom breaks?
column2: Yes. Take it as soon as possible — within 5 days is best.

column1: Can I get HIV from mosquito bites?
column2: No. HIV doesn’t spread through mosquitoes.

column1: Can condoms cause itching?
column2: Sometimes latex allergy or dryness causes irritation — try non-latex or lubricated condoms.

column1: Can I use a female condom if my partner doesn’t want to use a male one?
column2: Yes. Female condoms are safe and effective alternatives.

column1: Can I get pregnant if we only have sex once a month?
column2: Yes, if it’s during ovulation and unprotected.

column1: Can I use expired birth control pills?
column2: No. Expired pills may lose effectiveness.

column1: Can I take pills even if I’m a virgin?
column2: Yes. They regulate cycles and prevent pregnancy if you become sexually active.

column1: Can birth control protect me from STIs?
column2: Only condoms provide STI protection — other methods don’t.

column1: Can I get pregnant during my first time?
column2: Yes, pregnancy can happen anytime sperm meets egg — even the first time.

column1: Can I use birth control before marriage?
column2: Yes. Family planning is about safety and choice, not marital status.

column1: Can a girl get pregnant if she’s standing during sex?
column2: Yes. Position doesn’t stop sperm from reaching the egg.

column1: Can I get pregnant from kissing?
column2: No. Pregnancy only happens when sperm enters the vagina.

column1: Can I get pregnant if it’s just the first few seconds?
column2: Yes, precum can contain sperm, so pregnancy is possible.

column1: Can I use two condoms to be extra safe?
column2: No. Double condoms can rub and tear — one good condom is enough.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I pee right after sex?
column2: No. Urinating doesn’t remove sperm that already entered the uterus.

column1: Can I use plastic wrap as a condom?
column2: No. Only real condoms are safe and tested for protection.

column1: Can I get pregnant from dry humping?
column2: Unlikely, but if semen touches the vagina, there’s a small chance.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I didn’t fully have sex?
column2: If sperm touched the vagina, pregnancy is possible.

column1: Can I use birth control without telling my parents?
column2: Yes. Services are confidential, especially at youth-friendly clinics.

column1: Can I buy condoms even if I’m under 18?
column2: Yes. There’s no age limit for buying protection.

column1: Can I use emergency pills every time I have sex?
column2: No. It’s for emergencies — not a regular method.

column1: Can I get pregnant after my period ends?
column2: Yes. Ovulation can happen anytime — always use protection.

column1: Can I get pregnant during my period?
column2: It’s rare, but possible if cycles are short or irregular.

column1: Can I stop my period using birth control pills?
column2: Yes, some pills can safely delay or skip a period under doctor’s guidance.

column1: Can I swim while on my period?
column2: Yes! Using pads, tampons, or menstrual cups keeps it hygienic and safe.

column1: Can sex during period cause pregnancy?
column2: It’s rare but possible — sperm can live inside the body for days.

column1: Can my period stop because of stress?
column2: Yes, stress can delay or pause periods temporarily.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I haven’t started my period yet?
column2: If ovulation has begun, yes — even before your first period.

column1: Can I use birth control to treat acne?
column2: Yes, some pills can improve skin by balancing hormones.

column1: Can I take pills even if I’m not sexually active?
column2: Yes, some people use them for cycle control or medical reasons.

column1: Can I swim right after sex?
column2: Swimming doesn’t prevent pregnancy — use contraception.

column1: Can I take birth control if I’m underweight?
column2: Yes, but check with a doctor for best options.

column1: Can I use pads and tampons together?
column2: Yes, if it makes you more comfortable — totally fine.

column1: Can birth control change my period color?
column2: Yes, hormones can make blood lighter or darker — it’s normal.

column1: Can birth control cause mood swings?
column2: Some people feel small changes, but they usually settle with time.

column1: Can I use period blood to test pregnancy?
column2: No. Only urine or blood tests at clinics are accurate.

column1: Can I get pregnant right after stopping pills?
column2: Yes! Fertility can return within days or weeks.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I use the pill incorrectly?
column2: Yes. Missing pills reduces protection — take it daily at the same time.

column1: Can I get pregnant while using condoms?
column2: It’s rare — only if the condom breaks or slips off.

column1: Can I get pregnant if my partner pulls out?
column2: Yes, withdrawal isn’t fully reliable because precum can contain sperm.

column1: Can I use IUD if I haven’t had a baby yet?
column2: Yes, IUDs are safe for women with or without children.

column1: Can I use birth control to make my periods regular?
column2: Yes, it’s often prescribed for that purpose.

column1: Can I get pregnant if my period is irregular?
column2: Yes. Irregular cycles don’t prevent pregnancy.

column1: Can period cramps mean I can’t get pregnant?
column2: No. Cramps don’t affect fertility.

column1: Can I take painkillers during periods?
column2: Yes, medicines like ibuprofen are safe and help reduce cramps.

column1: Can birth control stop cramps?
column2: Yes, many people notice lighter periods and less pain with hormonal birth control.

column1: Can I take the pill at different times each day?
column2: Try to take it at the same time daily for best protection.

column1: Can I drink alcohol while on birth control?
column2: Yes, alcohol doesn’t affect effectiveness — just don’t forget doses.

column1: Can I take the pill with cold medicine?
column2: Yes, most medicines don’t affect birth control, except some antibiotics.

column1: Can I lose weight because of birth control?
column2: Some do, but most people stay the same. It varies by method.

column1: Can birth control make me emotional?
column2: Some people feel small mood changes — it’s normal and temporary.

column1: Can birth control stop periods forever?
column2: No. Some methods pause periods, but they return when stopped.

column1: Can I use emergency pills if I vomit after sex?
column2: Yes, but if you vomit within 2 hours after taking it, take another dose.

column1: Can I use my friend’s birth control pills?
column2: No. Always get your own — doses may differ for each person.

column1: Can I get pregnant if we only had oral sex?
column2: No pregnancy risk, but STIs can still spread — use protection.

column1: Can I get pregnant from touching semen on clothes?
column2: No, sperm die quickly outside the body.

column1: Can I take pills if I have PCOS?
column2: Yes, some pills help manage PCOS symptoms — ask a doctor first.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I take pills at night instead of morning?
column2: Timing doesn’t matter much — just be consistent every day.

column1: Can I have sex during my period?
column2: Yes, it’s safe if both partners are comfortable. Use condoms for hygiene and STI protection.

column1: Can I use birth control if I have diabetes?
column2: Yes, but choose under medical advice to monitor hormone effects.

column1: Can I get pregnant right after stopping injections?
column2: Fertility may take a few months to return, but yes, pregnancy can happen.

column1: Can I get pregnant from precum if he doesn’t finish inside?
column2: Yes, precum can contain live sperm.

column1: Can I get pregnant if it’s too hot or cold?
column2: Temperature doesn’t stop sperm or pregnancy risk.

column1: Can I take birth control if I’m breastfeeding?
column2: Yes, some pills are safe — use progestin-only or non-hormonal methods.

column1: Can I get pregnant while taking antibiotics?
column2: Some antibiotics reduce pill effect — use backup protection.

column1: Can I take pills while sick with fever?
column2: Yes, unless you vomit within two hours of taking them.

column1: Can I get pregnant if he ejaculates near but not inside?
column2: Yes, sperm can travel into the vagina — use protection.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I just had sex once?
column2: Yes. One time is enough for pregnancy if unprotected.

column1: Can I get pregnant if it’s my safe days?
column2: Safe days are never fully reliable — cycles can change anytime.

column1: Can birth control change my libido?
column2: Yes, a few people notice change in desire, but it’s temporary.

column1: Can I take pills even if I’m under 16?
column2: Yes, with medical guidance — family planning is about health, not age.

column1: Can I get pregnant if the condom breaks but we stop immediately?
column2: Yes, semen may already be released — use emergency contraception.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I wash after sex?
column2: No. Washing doesn’t remove sperm that entered the body.

column1: Can birth control affect my future baby?
column2: No. It doesn’t harm future pregnancies or children.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I sit in a bathtub after sex?
column2: Yes, sperm don’t wash away like that.

column1: Can I use IUD if I’m scared of pain?
column2: Insertion takes a few minutes — mild pain, but safe and effective.

column1: Can I get pregnant if my boyfriend didn’t finish?
column2: Yes, because precum can still contain sperm.

column1: Can I take pills from the middle of the pack?
column2: No. Start with the first pill for proper hormone balance.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I stop pills for a few days?
column2: Yes. Missing pills lowers protection quickly.

column1: Can I take pills only when I have sex?
column2: No. Pills need daily use to prevent pregnancy effectively.

column1: Can I take expired pills if I missed my dose?
column2: No. Expired pills may not work — always check the date.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I skip one injection?
column2: Yes. Injections must be taken on time to stay effective.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I’m overweight?
column2: Birth control still works, but some methods may vary — check with a doctor.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I’m underweight?
column2: Yes. Weight doesn’t stop fertility.

column1: Can birth control stop hair fall?
column2: Sometimes, yes. Hormonal balance can reduce hair loss.

column1: Can I take pills to make my periods lighter?
column2: Yes, many pills reduce bleeding and cramps.

column1: Can I get pregnant from sitting on a toilet seat?
column2: No. Sperm can’t survive outside the body that long.

column1: Can I get pregnant from semen on hands?
column2: Only if sperm is fresh and directly enters the vagina.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I shower right away after sex?
column2: No. Water doesn’t wash out sperm already inside.

column1: Can I use emergency pills while on regular birth control?
column2: Yes, it’s safe — continue your usual method after taking it.

column1: Can I use condoms during oral sex?
column2: Yes. It reduces STI risks and is safe for both partners.

column1: Can birth control help with heavy bleeding?
column2: Yes, some methods regulate or reduce heavy flow.

column1: Can I take pills without food?
column2: Yes, but taking them with food can prevent nausea.
