column1: Can I use emergency pills if I’m breastfeeding?
column2: Yes, they’re safe for mothers and babies.

column1: Can I get pregnant while using implant?
column2: Extremely rare — implants are over 99% effective.

column1: Can I use the same condom twice?
column2: No. Always use a new condom each time.

column1: Can I use toothpaste to clean condoms?
column2: No! Condoms are single-use — cleaning ruins them.

column1: Can I use tissue or paper as a condom?
column2: No. Only real condoms are safe for protection.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I only had oral sex?
column2: No pregnancy risk, but STIs can still spread.

column1: Can I get pregnant from anal sex?
column2: No, but it can still transmit infections — use condoms.

column1: Can I get pregnant if it’s my first period after birth?
column2: Yes. Fertility can return fast — use protection early.

column1: Can I use pills secretly from my partner?
column2: Yes. Your health decisions are private.

column1: Can birth control cause nausea?
column2: Sometimes, especially at first — taking pills with food helps.

column1: Can I switch from pills to injection anytime?
column2: Yes, but ask a health worker for correct timing.

column1: Can I use condom and pill together?
column2: Yes! Dual protection prevents both pregnancy and STIs.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I have sex only once a month?
column2: Yes, if it happens near ovulation — use protection every time.

column1: Can I get pregnant if I use condoms incorrectly?
column2: Yes. Always check expiry, put it on before any contact, and hold the base after sex.

column1: Can birth control change my breast size?
column2: Maybe slightly, but it’s temporary and safe.

column1: How do I tell my partner I want to use protection?
column2: Be honest and calm. Explain it’s about care and safety for both of you.

column1: What if my partner refuses to use condoms?
column2: Stand firm. Using condoms protects you both — no condom means no sex.

column1: How can I talk about birth control without sounding weird?
column2: Start with trust: 'I care about us and want to stay safe together.'

column1: What if my partner laughs when I talk about protection?
column2: Don’t feel embarrassed — it shows maturity, not awkwardness.

column1: My boyfriend says condoms reduce pleasure — what should I do?
column2: You can suggest thin condoms or talk about shared comfort — safety first.

column1: How do I convince my girlfriend to use birth control?
column2: Have an open talk. Focus on planning, not blame — respect her decision too.

column1: My partner gets angry when I mention birth control. What should I do?
column2: Stay calm. If anger continues, seek support — decisions should be mutual.

column1: How do I tell my husband I don’t want another baby yet?
column2: Be clear and kind: 'I love our family, but I’m not ready right now.'

column1: How do I bring up family planning before marriage?
column2: Talk about future goals and timing. It shows responsibility, not fear.

column1: What if my partner hides that they stopped using contraception?
column2: That’s a breach of trust — discuss openly or seek counseling support.

column1: How do I talk about my period or fertility with my partner?
column2: It’s natural. Educating your partner helps them support you better.

column1: What if my partner wants sex but I don’t?
column2: You can always say no. Consent must come from both sides every time.

column1: How do I know if my partner truly respects consent?
column2: If they listen, stop when asked, and make you feel safe — that’s respect.

column1: My boyfriend says I don’t love him if I refuse sex. What do I do?
column2: Love isn’t proven through sex. Stand by your comfort and boundaries.

column1: How do I talk to my partner about STI testing?
column2: Say you both should test before going unprotected — it’s care, not mistrust.

column1: My partner says we don’t need protection because we’re in love. Is that okay?
column2: Love doesn’t prevent pregnancy or infections — protection still matters.

column1: How do I say no without hurting feelings?
column2: Be gentle but firm: 'I care about you, but I’m not ready for that step yet.'

column1: My partner gets jealous if I talk to friends. Is that normal?
column2: No. Healthy relationships are built on trust, not control.

column1: How do I tell my partner I had an abortion before?
column2: Share only when you feel safe — it’s your choice and your past.

column1: My partner wants to have a baby but I don’t. What should I do?
column2: Talk openly. Family planning should always be a joint decision.

column1: What if I’m scared my partner will leave me for saying no to sex?
column2: If they leave for that, they didn’t truly respect you — you deserve respect.

column1: How can I discuss contraception without making it awkward?
column2: Make it a shared topic — talk casually like about health or plans.

column1: How do I handle fights about using condoms?
column2: Pause, talk later calmly, and focus on shared safety, not blame.

column1: My boyfriend says he’ll pull out — should I trust that?
column2: No. Withdrawal is unreliable — always use a condom.

column1: How do I know my partner is ready for sex emotionally?
column2: If they can talk openly, respect consent, and show maturity, they might be ready.

column1: My partner laughs at me for suggesting birth control. What should I do?
column2: Explain calmly why it’s important — or rethink the relationship if ignored.

column1: How do I ask my husband to get a vasectomy?
column2: Start with shared planning: 'We’ve had our kids, maybe it’s time to consider permanent options.'

column1: What if my partner says family planning is a woman’s job?
column2: It’s a shared responsibility — both partners should participate equally.

column1: My wife doesn’t want to use contraception. What should I do?
column2: Talk openly, understand her reasons, and explore options together with a health worker.

column1: How do I support my wife emotionally after using birth control?
column2: Check in often, talk about side effects, and show care and patience.

column1: How do I tell my partner I want to delay pregnancy?
column2: Be honest: 'I want us to be ready before having a child.'

column1: What if my partner wants to keep trying for a boy?
column2: Gender preference shouldn’t control family planning — talk about equality and health.

column1: My partner makes all decisions about family size. What can I do?
column2: You both have equal rights — involve a counselor or family health worker.

column1: How do I tell my partner I’m not ready for kids yet?
column2: Say it kindly: 'I want us to enjoy our time together before planning for children.'

column1: My boyfriend doesn’t understand periods. Should I explain?
column2: Yes. Educating him can reduce stigma and build empathy.

column1: My girlfriend feels shy to talk about sex. How can I help?
column2: Be patient. Create a safe, non-judgmental space for open talk.

column1: How do I tell my partner I’m scared of pregnancy?
column2: Say it honestly — fear is normal and worth sharing.

column1: My partner pressures me to prove love through sex. Is that okay?
column2: No. True love respects boundaries — pressure isn’t love.

column1: What if my partner hides their sexual history?
column2: You deserve honesty — talk openly or seek help if you feel unsafe.

column1: How can I ask my partner if they’re using protection with others?
column2: Be calm: 'I care about both of our health, so I need to ask this honestly.'

column1: My partner refuses to get tested for STIs. What should I do?
column2: Don’t risk it. No test means no unprotected sex — safety first.

column1: How do I know if my partner is lying about being on birth control?
column2: You can talk openly or suggest visiting a clinic together.

column1: My boyfriend said he’ll leave if I use contraception. What should I do?
column2: That’s manipulation — your body, your choice.

column1: How do I talk about fertility problems with my partner?
column2: Be gentle. Say, 'We’ll figure this out together — it’s not anyone’s fault.'

column1: My husband ignores my wishes about family size. What can I do?
column2: You have the right to decide too — seek community health support if needed.

column1: My partner doesn’t want to use condoms after marriage. Is that fine?
column2: If you’re not planning a baby, keep using contraception — discuss calmly.

column1: How can I encourage my partner to learn about birth control?
column2: Share educational videos or visit a clinic together — make it teamwork.

column1: My girlfriend says she’s scared of pills. How can I help?
column2: Support her — suggest talking to a nurse or doctor for reassurance.

column1: How do I tell my partner I had unprotected sex before?
column2: Be honest and responsible — also suggest both get tested for safety.

column1: What if my partner’s family pressures us to have kids soon?
column2: Stay united as a couple — plan based on readiness, not pressure.

column1: How do I rebuild trust after hiding contraception use?
column2: Apologize, explain why you did it, and rebuild with honesty.

column1: How can I discuss family planning without sounding controlling?
column2: Use 'we' language — make it a shared decision, not an order.

column1: My partner doesn’t like talking about sex. How do I start?
column2: Start small, stay kind, and avoid judging — openness takes time.

column1: How do I comfort my partner after a pregnancy scare?
column2: Be supportive, stay calm, and discuss safer methods together.

column1: My boyfriend blames me for taking emergency pills. What do I say?
column2: Say it’s about safety and responsibility, not blame.

column1: My girlfriend says she trusts me so we don’t need condoms. Should I agree?
column2: Trust doesn’t replace safety — keep using protection.

column1: My partner doesn’t believe in contraception. How can I convince them?
column2: Share accurate info or visit a counselor together.

column1: My husband says it’s my duty to have kids. What can I do?
column2: It’s a joint choice, not a duty — seek support if pressured.

column1: My wife wants another baby but I’m not ready. What should I say?
column2: Be kind: 'I want to plan properly so we can support our family better.'

column1: How can I tell my partner I’m not enjoying sex?
column2: Be honest but gentle — focus on what feels good and communicate openly.

column1: My partner makes decisions about my body. Is that okay?
column2: No. Every person has full rights over their own body and health.

column1: How do I talk about consent if we’ve already had sex before?
column2: Consent is needed every time — talk openly before intimacy.

column1: My partner doesn’t understand what consent means. How do I explain?
column2: Say it’s about both saying yes freely, not pressure or guilt.

column1: My partner says using contraception means I don’t trust them. What do I say?
column2: It’s about being safe and responsible, not mistrust.

column1: My boyfriend hides condoms so I can’t use them. What should I do?
column2: That’s control and unsafe — seek help or leave if needed.

column1: How can I build confidence to talk about protection?
column2: Practice what you want to say — confidence comes with honesty.

column1: My girlfriend gets shy when I buy condoms. What can I do?
column2: Normalize it — buying protection shows care, not shame.

column1: My partner said I should not use birth control without permission. Is that right?
column2: No one controls your body — it’s your decision.

column1: My partner calls me 'bad' for using contraception. What should I do?
column2: Ignore the shame — choosing safety is responsible, not wrong.

column1: How can I talk about safe sex with a new partner?
column2: Bring it up early — 'I always use protection to stay healthy.'

column1: My boyfriend wants proof I’m a virgin. What do I say?
column2: Virginity can’t be proven — say no to disrespectful demands.

column1: My partner lies about condom use. What should I do?
column2: That’s serious — don’t continue unprotected sex until trust is rebuilt.

column1: How do I support my partner if they fear side effects?
column2: Listen, share facts, and visit a clinic together for reassurance.

column1: My partner says I’m overthinking family planning. Am I?
column2: No. Being prepared is smart, not overthinking.

column1: How can I talk about birth spacing without offending my in-laws?
column2: Say it’s for mother and baby’s health — not rejection of tradition.

column1: My partner wants to keep pregnancy a secret. Should I agree?
column2: Only if it feels safe. Secrets can cause emotional harm — seek support.

column1: How do I stop feeling guilty for saying no to sex?
column2: Remind yourself: your body, your choice — guilt isn’t needed for self-respect.

column1: My partner blames me for infertility. What should I say?
column2: Infertility can affect anyone — both partners should get tested.

column1: How can I make family planning feel romantic, not awkward?
column2: Frame it as care and trust — use it to protect your future together.

column1: My boyfriend says condoms mean I don’t trust him. How do I respond?
column2: Say it’s not about trust — it’s about shared safety and love.

column1: My husband refuses to discuss contraception. What can I do?
column2: Try gently, or involve a health worker to mediate the discussion.

column1: How do I tell my partner I want to stop using hormonal methods?
column2: Be open: 'I’d like to switch to another method — can we decide together?'

column1: My partner says contraception causes infertility. Is that true?
column2: No. It doesn’t harm long-term fertility — myths are common but false.

column1: How can I tell my partner I want to focus on my career first?
column2: Explain your goals kindly — planning isn’t rejection, it’s preparation.

column1: My partner keeps comparing me to others. What can I do?
column2: Tell them it hurts — comparisons harm relationships and trust.

column1: How can I build trust after a pregnancy scare?
column2: Be honest, forgive, and commit to using reliable methods together.

column1: My partner avoids talking about family planning. How do I start?
column2: Pick a calm time and ask: 'Can we plan for our future together?'

column1: My boyfriend says I’m not fun because I use protection. What should I say?
column2: Fun should never come before safety — stand by your choice.

column1: My girlfriend wants to stop using condoms. Should I agree?
column2: Only if both are tested and another reliable method is in place.

column1: How can I handle guilt after using emergency pills?
column2: You did the right thing — protecting yourself isn’t shameful.

column1: My partner keeps forgetting to use protection. What do I do?
column2: Remind them kindly, or take charge of safety yourself.

column1: How do I comfort my partner after a miscarriage?
column2: Offer emotional support, listen, and heal together without blame.

column1: My partner says contraception is a sin. What can I do?
column2: Respect beliefs but share facts — planning families is responsible.

column1: How can I talk about fertility testing without sounding rude?
column2: Say, 'It’s for both of us — just to understand our health better.'

column1: My husband doesn’t listen when I talk about spacing births. What can I do?
column2: Seek help from a female health worker or counselor for joint discussion.

column1: My partner gets moody when I mention protection. What should I do?
column2: Stay patient and calm — talk at a better time when they’re relaxed.

column1: My boyfriend wants to record our private moments. Is that okay?
column2: Only if you both agree fully — never under pressure or secrecy.

column1: My girlfriend cries after talking about sex. What should I do?
column2: Be gentle, listen, and stop any pressure — emotional comfort comes first.

column1: My partner says I’m overreacting about pregnancy risk. Am I?
column2: No — being cautious is responsible, not overreacting.

column1: How can I talk to my partner about visiting a family planning clinic together?
column2: Invite tham kindly. 'Let's learn together so we can decide safely.'

column1: Which groups have the highest unmet need for family planning in Nepal?
column2: Unmet need is highest among women in remote mountain regions, those with no education, and adolescents or newly married young couples.

column1: Why is postpartum family planning underutilized in Nepal?
column2: Although hospitals provide counseling, many women lack follow-up services after discharge or are unaware that postpartum methods are available.

column1: How does education level influence fertility behavior in Nepal?
column2: Women with secondary or higher education have fewer children and are more likely to use modern contraception than those with no schooling.

column1: What is the “Costed Implementation Plan for Family Planning 2015–2020”?
column2: It’s a national roadmap that set targets to raise the modern contraceptive prevalence rate to 50% and reduce unmet need to 10% by 2020 through expanded access and awareness.

column1: What are “youth-friendly” family planning services?
column2: These are confidential, non-judgmental services that provide counseling, contraceptives, and education tailored to adolescents and young people.

column1: How do cultural norms affect contraceptive use in Nepal’s hill and mountain areas?
column2: In conservative or remote communities, discussions on contraception may be taboo, and women often require their husband’s or elder’s permission to use family planning.

column1: After an abortion, what percentage of Nepali women used modern contraception according to a recent study?
column2: About 59% of women used modern contraception after an abortion in Nepal.

column1: What does the term “unmet need for family planning” refer to in Nepali context?
column2: It refers to married women who say they want to delay or stop childbearing but are not using any contraceptive method. Evidence shows this is high among certain sub-groups in Nepal.

column1: How has Nepal’s family planning program evolved historically?
column2: The first national FP programme was launched decades ago; for example, the FPAN was founded in 1959 and since then FP services have expanded, with the government developing a Costed Implementation Plan and setting higher targets.

column1: Why are health facilities across Nepal reporting shortages of contraceptive injections and IUDs?
column2: Because the federal procurement of essentials paused around two years, the dollar appreciated against the Nepali rupee, and major aid grants (such as from USAID) were suspended — leading to very low stocks of methods like Depo-Provera and IUDs.

column1: How much did Nepal increase its domestic financing for contraceptive commodities, and why is this significant?
column2: The government increased domestic financing to over US $355,000 (up from about US $135,868 the previous year) which unlocked a match fund of US $711,359 from UNFPA for high-quality contraceptive commodities in 2024. This shows commitment and enables sustained access despite supply chain stresses.

column1: What is causing the fertility rate in Nepal to drop to around two children per woman, despite many people wanting more?
column2: Key factors include high cost of living, job insecurity, unaffordable housing/childcare, labour migration causing spousal separation, and limited reproductive health access—leading some couples to have fewer children than they want.

column1: What are the implications if family planning budgets are cut at district hospitals in Nepal?
column2: Budget cuts may disrupt FP programmes, potentially increasing unintended pregnancies, unsafe abortions, and maternal/child mortality. District hospitals struggling with funding pose risk to programme continuity.

column1: What percent of people in Karnali Province reportedly have access to family-planning tools, and what does this highlight?
column2: In Karnali Province, approximately 53% of citizens reportedly have access to family-planning tools, but only about 47% use them, showing a gap between access and actual use.

column1: What might the contraceptive shortage in Nepal mean for unintended pregnancies and abortion rates?
column2: The shortage of key contraceptives such as shots, IUDs and even pills could lead to more unintended pregnancies, which in turn raise demand for unsafe abortions and could reverse gains in maternal health.

column1: Why is rising economic pressure among Nepali couples relevant to family planning programmes?
column2: Because financial insecurity, rising cost of living, and fewer stable jobs influence reproductive choices—some couples delay or avoid having children, which alters demand for family planning services and shifts planning needs.

column1: What is the significance of the “gap between desired and actual family size” in Nepal currently?
column2: It shows that many people want more children but cannot have them due to external constraints (economic, migration, health) — indicating that fertility decline isn’t always by choice, and family planning and reproductive rights must respond accordingly.

column1: In what way do international aid and global policies influence Nepal’s family planning programmes?
column2: Changes in global funding (aid suspensions, donor priorities) and international policies (e.g., commodity supply partnerships) significantly affect Nepal’s family planning programme viability and timing of procurement of methods.

column1: What role does the appreciation of foreign currency (USD) against Nepali rupee play in family planning commodities?
column2: It increases procurement cost of imported contraceptives, causing delays and shortages in supply as seen in Nepali health logistics under current budget constraints.

column1: What is Nepal’s challenge in translating awareness of family planning into actual uptake?
column2: Although awareness is high (e.g., “almost 90% aware” in some areas), use remains comparatively low because of access, cultural barriers, service quality, stock outs and method mix limitations.

column1: Can hormonal contraceptives cause infertility in the future?
column2: No. Most hormonal contraceptives (like pills, injectables, or implants) are reversible — fertility returns soon after stopping. However, for some, it may take a few months for regular cycles to resume.

column1: What should a woman do if she has unprotected sex and doesn’t want to become pregnant?
column2: Take emergency contraception within 72 hours (e.g., emergency pills) or have a copper IUD inserted within five days.

column1: What is the difference in modern contraceptive use between Terai (Madhesh) and Mountain (Karnali) regions of Nepal?
column2: Modern contraceptive use is generally lower in mountain and remote provinces such as Karnali and Sudurpashchim compared with the Terai plains (Madhesh)
column3: where access is higher but social and cultural barriers still limit use in some districts.

column1: Which province shows the highest adolescent birth rate and what does this imply for family planning services there?
column2: Province 2 (Madhesh Province) historically records a higher adolescent birth rate. This implies an urgent need for adolescent-friendly family planning services
column4: and school-based sexual and reproductive health education.

column1: How does unmet need for family planning vary across provinces in Nepal?
column2: Unmet need for family planning is higher among provinces with more remote or poor populations
column3: such as Karnali and some districts in Sudurpashchim
column4: compared to urbanised provinces like Bagmati.

column1: What regional differences exist in the types of contraceptive methods used across Nepal?
column2: Rural and poorer districts rely more on long-term or permanent methods such as sterilisation
column3: while urban provinces prefer short-term and reversible methods like injectables
column4: pills
column5: and implants.

column1: In which provinces do people report the highest awareness of contraceptive methods?
column2: National surveys show that overall awareness of family planning methods is high across Nepal
column3: but specific method awareness (like intrauterine devices or implants) is lower in mountain provinces compared to Bagmati and Koshi Provinces.

column1: How does education level by province influence family planning knowledge and use?
column2: Provinces with higher female school attainment
column4: report better family planning knowledge and higher modern contraceptive uptake than provinces with lower female education levels.

column1: Are there provincial differences in service delivery for family planning?
column2: Yes. Provinces with remote districts such as Karnali and Sudurpashchim rely more on outreach programs and Female Community Health Volunteers (FCHVs)
column3: while urban provinces depend more on health facilities and private clinics.

column1: How do migration patterns in certain provinces affect contraceptive use?
column2: Provinces with high male out-migration
column3: like some in the Terai and hill districts
column4: experience irregular contraceptive use and changing demand patterns. When men return home
column5: there are sudden spikes in demand for short-term or emergency contraceptive methods.

column1: Which provinces have seen slower progress in modern contraceptive uptake in recent years?
column2: Some provinces such as Madhesh and Karnali have shown slower growth in the use of modern contraceptive methods
column3: while Bagmati and Lumbini have progressed faster.

column1: How does wealth-related inequality in family planning use differ across provinces?
column2: Inequalities are more visible in mixed urban-rural provinces like Bagmati
column3: where wealthier urban residents have better access than rural poor. The poorest in Karnali and Sudurpashchim show the lowest usage of contraceptive methods.

column1: What is the status of postpartum family planning uptake across provinces?
column2: Postpartum family planning use is higher in provinces with better facility delivery rates such as Bagmati and Gandaki
column3: and lower in mountain provinces where fewer women give birth in health facilities.

column1: In which provinces are youth-friendly family planning services more available?
column2: Youth-friendly services and youth centres are mainly located in urbanised provinces such as Bagmati
column4: and Lumbini
column5: while Madhesh and Karnali lag behind in youth-targeted services.

column1: How do cultural norms across provinces influence family planning acceptance?
column2: Conservative cultural norms in parts of Madhesh and remote mountain areas often reduce open discussion and acceptance of family planning
column3: while urban and more educated provinces such as Gandaki show greater acceptance.

column1: Which provinces show a gap between access to contraceptive supplies and actual use?
column2: Provinces such as Karnali and certain districts in Lumbini have reasonable access to family planning supplies but low usage
column3: suggesting that social stigma or fear of side effects remain barriers.

column1: Are emergency contraceptives known and used evenly across Nepal?
column2: No. Awareness and use of emergency contraceptives are higher in urban provinces
column3: while rural and mountain provinces have limited knowledge and access.

column1: How do contraceptive stockouts differ regionally in Nepal?
column2: Stockouts of contraceptive supplies occur more frequently in remote provinces such as Karnali and Sudurpashchim due to transportation challenges and delays in supply chains.

column1: What do provincial data show about discontinuation of contraceptive methods?
column2: Discontinuation rates are higher in provinces where follow-up counselling is weaker
column3: often in remote provinces. Provinces with strong health facility networks have lower discontinuation rates.

column1: Which provinces have a higher share of female sterilisation compared to reversible methods?
column2: Rural provinces such as parts of Lumbini and Madhesh have higher rates of female sterilisation
column3: while Bagmati and Koshi show greater use of reversible methods like injectables and implants.

column1: How does provider availability for long-acting contraceptive methods vary by province?
column2: Trained provider availability for long-acting reversible contraceptives (like implants and intrauterine devices) is higher in urban provinces such as Bagmati and Koshi
column3: but limited in remote ones like Karnali.

column1: Which provinces report higher use of traditional methods and why?
column2: Traditional methods like withdrawal and rhythm are more common in some Terai and hill districts where myths about modern contraception and limited counselling persist. This is especially noticeable in Madhesh and certain hill regions.

column1: What role do Female Community Health Volunteers (FCHVs) play in family planning across provinces?
column2: FCHVs are crucial in provinces like Karnali and Sudurpashchim where health facilities are limited. They provide pills
column4: and counselling
column5: improving short-term method access in remote areas.

column1: Which provinces have recently improved in meeting demand for modern contraceptive methods?
column2: Bagmati and Lumbini provinces have shown relatively higher levels of demand satisfied with modern methods in recent national surveys.

column1: How do provincial budgets and governance affect family planning service delivery?
column2: Provinces that prioritise health budgets and maintain consistent procurement
column4: perform better. Those with weaker budgets face service disruptions and outreach challenges.

column1: What is the status of postpartum counselling for family planning during facility deliveries?
column2: Postpartum counselling linked to deliveries is more frequent in hospitals within Bagmati and Gandaki Provinces than in remote provincial hospitals

column1: How effective are provincial health systems in monitoring family planning trends?
column2: Provinces like Bagmati and Koshi have stronger Health Management Information Systems (HMIS) that guide outreach and restocking
column3: while others face reporting delays that hinder service response.

column1: What local initiatives have improved family planning uptake in certain regions?
column2: Effective initiatives include mobile outreach in remote districts
column4: and school-based sexual and reproductive health education
column5: often supported by the Family Planning Association of Nepal (FPAN) and local NGOs.

column1: How do provincial cultural and linguistic differences shape family planning education and messaging?
column2: In Madhesh
column3: family planning messages need to be culturally sensitive and delivered in local languages with male engagement. In mountain provinces
column4: pictorial education materials and community leader involvement are more effective.

column1: Which provinces are most vulnerable to contraceptive supply disruptions?
column2: Remote provinces such as Karnali and Sudurpashchim are most vulnerable to international supply delays because they have weaker buffer stocks and transportation is difficult.

column1: What do regional data say about male involvement in family planning decisions?
column2: Male involvement is often lower in conservative provinces like Madhesh and mountain regions. Provinces with active male engagement programs show higher couple participation in family planning decisions.

column1: How is the new National Family Planning Costed Implementation Plan 2024-2030 in Nepal changing the approach to family planning commodities?
column2: The plan emphasises increased domestic budgeting and procurement of contraceptive supplies, along with a sustainability strategy for family planning commodities, ensuring that supply chains remain robust and independent of external funding.

column1: What bottleneck was identified in the 2025 assessment of post-pregnancy family planning in Nepal?
column2: The bottleneck assessment found that in many districts the linkage between maternity services and immediate family planning counselling or access is weak — there is limited social and behaviour change communication and outreach after childbirth.

column1: What does recent research say about unmet need for family planning among women in certain provinces of Nepal?
column2: A 2024 study found that women in provinces such as Madhesh, Gandaki and Sudurpashchim had significantly higher odds of unmet need for family planning compared to Koshi Province, highlighting persistent regional disparities.

column1: How are male partners in Nepal influencing family planning utilisation according to recent community studies?
column2: A 2025 study in a Tharu community showed that male involvement such as discussing family planning with a partner and supporting clinic visits is strongly associated with higher family planning uptake — lack of male involvement remains a barrier in many settings.

column1: What role is digital health and task-sharing playing in Nepal’s family planning efforts?
column2: The World Health Organization and United Nations Population Fund supported initiative in 2024 introduced digital adaptation kits and task-sharing models for family planning counselling and service delivery, aimed at scaling up more efficiently.

column1: How will decentralisation affect family planning service delivery in Nepal’s provinces?
column2: With the shift to provincial and federal governance, provinces will have more autonomy to allocate health budgets, plan family planning services, and integrate them with local health systems — offering both opportunity and risk depending on local capacity.

column1: Why is addressing postpartum family planning more crucial now in Nepal?
column2: Because many women now deliver in facilities, the period immediately after childbirth is a critical opportunity for counselling and initiation of contraceptive methods to prevent short-interval pregnancies; however, follow-up remains weak in some rural and remote provinces.

column1: What are the implications of the 2024 indicator summary sheet for modern contraceptive prevalence in Nepal?
column2: The summary shows that progress has slowed in increasing modern contraceptive prevalence, indicating that Nepal must shift from expanding basic access to addressing quality, equity, and method mix issues.

column1: In what ways are youth and adolescents becoming a focal point in Nepal’s family planning strategy?
column2: Recent workshops in December 2024 emphasised comprehensive sexuality education, youth-friendly services, and the inclusion of young people in family planning programme design — young people’s voices are now being prioritised.

column1: How is migration (internal or international) influencing family planning demand in Nepal?
column2: With many men working abroad or in other provinces, couples face irregular contact, which affects contraceptive consistency, creates peaks of demand when partners return, and complicates service timing and counselling.

column1: What recent initiative is being taken to ensure the contraceptive supply chain is resilient in Nepal?
column2: The 2024 to 2030 plan includes a contingency buffer for family planning commodities, greater domestic procurement, and decentralised storage and distribution systems to minimise stock-outs in remote provinces.

column1: Why are method mix and choice becoming more emphasised in Nepal’s current family planning policy?
column2: Because simply increasing prevalence is not enough — improving the range of methods such as short-term, long-acting reversible, and permanent methods, and aligning them with clients’ needs for spacing or limiting pregnancies is now central to addressing stagnation in uptake.

column1: What barrier remains prominent in mountainous and remote provinces of Nepal in delivering family planning services?
column2: Geographic access remains difficult, transport and logistics cause delays in service delivery, and counselling and follow-up support are weaker — these continue to constrain uptake compared to provinces with easier access.

column1: How is gender empowerment being linked with family planning uptake in recent Nepal studies?
column2: Research suggests that women with greater decision-making power in households, higher education, and less spousal separation are more likely to use modern family planning methods — integrating gender empowerment into family planning programmes is increasingly important.

column1: What recent research finds about traditional contraceptive method use and modern method adoption in Nepal?
column2: Recent research found that traditional method use remains significant in some groups, and that women using traditional methods are less likely to transition to modern methods unless targeted counselling, access, and awareness improve.

column1: What is the main commitment of the Government of Nepal regarding family planning?
column2: The Government of Nepal is committed to providing equitable access to voluntary Family Planning services based on informed choice for all individuals and couples, especially for the poor, vulnerable, and marginalized groups.

column1: What is the main aim of the National Family Planning Program of Nepal?
column2: The main aim of the National Family Planning Program is to ensure that individuals and couples can fulfill their reproductive needs by using appropriate family planning methods based on informed choice.

column1: Why is family planning important for a country like Nepal?
column2: Family planning reduces unmet needs for contraceptives and unintended pregnancies, improves maternal and child health, empowers women, enhances economic growth, and helps improve the overall quality of life.

column1: Which groups are prioritized under Nepal’s Family Planning Program?
column2: The program prioritizes the poor, vulnerable, marginalized communities, rural populations, Dalit groups, and those with high unmet needs for family planning services.

column1: Which ministry is responsible for family planning in Nepal?
column2: The Ministry of Health of the Government of Nepal is responsible for implementing and managing family planning programs.

column1: How does family planning contribute to national development?
column2: Family planning helps to improve maternal and child health, empowers women to participate in the workforce, increases economic productivity, and allows families and governments to invest more in education, healthcare, and infrastructure.

column1: Which national plans and strategies include family planning as a key component?
column2: Family planning is included in the Nepal Health Sector Program II (2010–2015), National Family Planning Costed Implementation Plan (2015–2021), Nepal Health Sector Strategy (2015–2020), and Nepal’s commitments to Family Planning 2020 (FP2020).

column1: What types of organizations provide family planning information and services in Nepal?
column2: Family planning services are provided through the government health system, social marketing organizations, non-governmental organizations, and the private sector.

column1: Which family planning methods are provided regularly through government health facilities?
column2: Temporary methods like male condoms, oral contraceptive pills, and injectable contraceptives are regularly provided through health posts, sub-health posts, and Primary Health Care Outreach Clinics.

column1: What role do Female Community Health Volunteers play in family planning?
column2: Female Community Health Volunteers provide information about family planning to communities, distribute condoms, and resupply oral pills.

column1: Where are Long-Acting Reversible Contraceptive (LARC) services available in Nepal?
column2: LARC services, including Intrauterine Contraceptive Devices (IUCDs) and implants, are available in a limited number of Primary Health Care Centers and health posts with trained healthcare providers.

column1: How are sterilization services provided in Nepal?
column2: Sterilization services are provided at static sites and also through scheduled “seasonal” or mobile outreach services.

column1: Which health facilities provide all types of temporary family planning methods regularly?
column2: Almost all District Family Planning and Maternal and Child Health (FP-MCH) clinics provide all types of temporary family planning methods regularly.

column1: What is the general objective of the Family Planning Program in Nepal?
column2: The general objective is to improve the health status of all people through an accountable and equitable health service delivery system that ensures informed choice and voluntary access to quality family planning services.

column1: What are the specific objectives of Nepal’s Family Planning Program?
column2: To increase access to and utilization of quality, safe, effective, and acceptable family planning services; focus on rural, poor, Dalit, and marginalized communities; create an enabling environment for men and women; and increase demand through behavior change communication.

column1: What does 'informed choice' mean in the context of family planning?
column2: Informed choice' means that individuals and couples have the right to make voluntary and well-informed decisions about whether and when to use family planning services, based on accurate information about available methods.

column1: How does the Family Planning Program empower women?
column2: The program empowers women by allowing them to plan their pregnancies, invest more in their children’s education and health, and participate in income-generating activities outside the home.

column1: How does family planning help in reducing unintended pregnancies?
column2: By providing access to a range of contraceptive methods and information, family planning helps couples avoid unintended pregnancies and space their children according to their preference.

column1: What kind of behavior change communication activities are included in the program?
column2: Behavior change communication activities include awareness campaigns, community mobilization, educational programs, and counseling to increase understanding and acceptance of family planning services.

column1: How does family planning contribute to economic growth in Nepal?
column2: Family planning supports economic growth by expanding a healthy and skilled labor force and allowing families and governments to invest more in education, health care, and infrastructure.

column1: How does the National Family Planning Program improve quality of life?
column2: It improves quality of life by promoting better health, reducing poverty, empowering women, and ensuring sustainable family and community development.

column1: What are some challenges to ensuring equitable access to family planning in Nepal?
column2: Challenges include limited availability of trained health workers, cultural and social barriers, geographical difficulties in rural areas, and lack of awareness among certain populations.

column1: Why does the government focus on the poor and marginalized in its family planning programs?
column2: Because these groups often have less access to information and health services, higher unmet needs for contraception, and greater vulnerability to poor reproductive health outcomes.

column1: What are Long-Acting Reversible Contraceptives (LARCs)?
column2: Long-Acting Reversible Contraceptives are methods like Intrauterine Contraceptive Devices (IUCDs) and implants that prevent pregnancy for an extended period and can be reversed when desired.

column1: What does the FP2020 commitment refer to?
column2: FP2020 (Family Planning 2020) is a global partnership to ensure that more women and girls can access voluntary family planning information, services, and supplies by the year 2020. Nepal is one of the countries committed to this initiative.

column1: What are the major governance and management challenges in implementing family planning services in Nepal?
column2: The major challenges in governance and management include the lack of realization of the overall benefits of family planning services and the shortage of a dedicated, trained workforce or managers at the provincial and local levels to manage these services effectively.

column1: Why is realizing the overall benefit of family planning services a challenge in Nepal?
column2: Many local authorities and community leaders still do not fully recognize how family planning contributes to health, economic growth, and women’s empowerment. This lack of awareness leads to weak policy implementation and low prioritization of family planning programs.

column1: What is the issue with workforce management in Nepal’s family planning program?
column2: There is a shortage of dedicated and trained personnel at the provincial and local levels, such as family planning supervisors or program managers, who are responsible for overseeing and coordinating family planning services.

column1: Why are trained managers important for family planning services?
column2: Trained managers ensure that family planning programs are well-organized, adequately funded, and effectively monitored. Without them, there are gaps in planning, logistics, and service delivery.

column1: How can governance and management challenges be addressed in family planning programs?
column2: These challenges can be addressed by increasing government investment in capacity building, assigning dedicated family planning managers or supervisors at all administrative levels, and raising awareness about the social and economic benefits of family planning.

column1: What are the major challenges related to the availability of family planning services in Nepal?
column2: The main challenges include ensuring the functionality of institutionalized family planning service centers and making both permanent and temporary family planning services available at hospitals and health facilities across the country.

column1: Why is the functionality of family planning service centers a concern in Nepal?
column2: Many institutionalized family planning service centers are not fully functional due to insufficient staffing, lack of equipment, or irregular supply of contraceptives and materials.

column1: What is the difference between permanent and temporary family planning services?
column2: Permanent services include sterilization procedures such as tubal ligation and vasectomy, while temporary services include condoms, pills, injectables, implants, and Intrauterine Contraceptive Devices (IUCDs) that can be discontinued anytime.

column1: Why is it important to ensure family planning services are available in hospitals?
column2: Hospitals serve a large population and provide comprehensive reproductive health services. Ensuring that family planning services are available at hospitals increases accessibility and allows clients to receive reliable, safe, and quality care.

column1: How can the Government of Nepal improve the availability of family planning services?
column2: The government can strengthen institutionalized family planning service centers, ensure consistent supply chains, recruit and train adequate staff, and integrate family planning services into all hospitals and health facilities.

column1: What are the key challenges related to service delivery of family planning in Nepal?
column2: Key challenges include the shortage of trained service providers for Long-Acting Reversible Contraceptive (LARC) and permanent methods, as well as issues with commodity security such as procurement delays and transportation problems.

column1: Why is the lack of trained service providers a challenge for family planning in Nepal?
column2: Family planning methods like implants, IUCDs, and sterilization require skilled health workers. The shortage of trained providers limits access to these services, especially in rural and remote areas.

column1: What does commodity security mean in the context of family planning?
column2: Commodity security refers to the consistent availability of family planning supplies and contraceptives when and where clients need them. It involves proper forecasting, procurement, and timely delivery of contraceptive materials.

column1: How do procurement delays affect family planning service delivery?
column2: Procurement delays cause shortages of contraceptives and other necessary supplies, disrupting service delivery and reducing the trust and satisfaction of users.

column1: What role does transportation play in the availability of family planning commodities?
column2: Transportation challenges make it difficult to deliver contraceptives and medical supplies to remote health centers, leading to stock-outs and interrupted services, especially in rural or mountainous regions.

column1: How can the Government of Nepal improve service delivery for family planning?
column2: The government can improve service delivery by training more healthcare providers in Long-Acting Reversible Contraceptive (LARC) and permanent methods, ensuring efficient procurement systems, improving transportation logistics, and maintaining a steady supply of commodities.

column1: What impact do these service delivery challenges have on people’s access to family planning?
column2: These challenges limit people’s access to quality and timely family planning services, especially in rural areas, leading to higher rates of unmet contraceptive needs and unintended pregnancies.

column1: Why is addressing family planning challenges important for Nepal’s development?
column2: Overcoming these challenges is essential to improve reproductive health, empower women, reduce poverty, and promote sustainable economic development through a healthier, more productive population.

column1: Which levels of government are involved in managing family planning services in Nepal?
column2: Family planning services are managed at the federal, provincial, and local levels of government. However, the lack of dedicated and trained staff at the provincial and local levels remains a challenge.

column1: What steps can be taken to strengthen Nepal’s family planning system overall?
column2: Steps include improving governance, ensuring service availability, training skilled health workers, enhancing supply chain management, and increasing awareness of family planning benefits among communities and policymakers.

column1: How has the use of female sterilization changed in Nepal between 2006 and 2022?
column2: The use of female sterilization as a permanent family planning method has gradually declined from 18% in 2006 to 13.4% in 2022, indicating a shift toward temporary and reversible methods.

column1: What is the trend of male sterilization in Nepal over the same period?
column2: Male sterilization has also declined significantly, from 6.3% in 2006 to just 3.6% in 2022, showing reduced participation of men in permanent family planning methods.

column1: What type of family planning methods are categorized as permanent in Nepal?
column2: Permanent family planning methods include female sterilization and male sterilization — both designed to permanently prevent future pregnancies.

column1: How has the use of intrauterine devices (IUDs) changed in Nepal?
column2: The use of intrauterine devices has remained low and almost unchanged, rising only slightly from 0.7% in 2006 to 1.3% in 2022.

column1: Which modern contraceptive method showed the greatest growth between 2006 and 2022?
column2: The use of implants increased by more than 600%, rising from less than 1% in 2006 to 6.1% in 2022, making it the fastest-growing family planning method in Nepal.

column1: What does the high growth in implant use indicate about family planning preferences in Nepal?
column2: It shows that more couples prefer long-acting reversible contraceptives that are safe, effective, and reversible, reflecting growing trust in modern contraceptive technology.

column1: How has the use of injectable contraceptives changed over time?
column2: Injectable contraceptive use remains one of the most common temporary methods, only slightly decreasing from 10.1% in 2006 to 9.3% in 2022.

column1: What trend is seen in the use of contraceptive pills in Nepal?
column2: The use of contraceptive pills increased moderately from 3.5% in 2006 to 4.5% in 2022, indicating stable but limited preference for short-acting oral methods.

column1: Has condom use changed much in Nepal between 2006 and 2022?
column2: Condom use has remained stable, fluctuating around 4.5% to 4.8%, suggesting consistent awareness and access but limited growth in male participation.

column1: What are long-acting reversible contraceptives, and how are they performing in Nepal?
column2: Long-acting reversible contraceptives include intrauterine devices and implants. Their combined use increased from 1.5% in 2006 to over 7% in 2022, driven mainly by the popularity of implants.

column1: What are short-acting reversible contraceptives, and how are they used in Nepal?
column2: Short-acting reversible contraceptives include pills, condoms, and injectables. These methods together account for around 18% of total contraceptive use in 2022, making them the most commonly used category.

column1: What overall shift in contraceptive method preference is seen in Nepal from 2006 to 2022?
column2: There has been a gradual move away from permanent methods (sterilization) toward long-acting reversible and short-acting modern methods, showing a preference for flexibility and reversibility in family planning choices.

column1: What might explain the decline in sterilization rates in Nepal?
column2: Factors include changing family size preferences, greater awareness of temporary methods, improved access to reversible options, and evolving gender roles that influence long-term fertility decisions.

column1: What does the steady use of short-acting methods suggest about family planning programs in Nepal?
column2: It suggests that awareness and access have improved, but long-term behavioral change and method diversification still need to be strengthened to ensure sustainable family planning outcomes.

column1: How do these trends reflect progress in Nepal’s national family planning goals?
column2: The increasing use of modern and reversible methods reflects positive progress toward universal access, though continued efforts are needed to ensure equity and male involvement in family planning.

column1: What is the main function of the Department of Health Services (DoHS) in Nepal?
column2: The Department of Health Services (DoHS) is responsible for delivering preventive, promotive, diagnostic, and curative health services throughout Nepal.

column1: Which division is responsible for family health programs in Nepal?
column2: The Family Welfare Division (FWD) under the Department of Health Services is responsible for implementing family health programs in Nepal.

column1: What are the key goals of the Family Welfare Division (FWD)?
column2: The Family Welfare Division aims to improve the overall quality of life of families by enhancing the health of mothers, newborns, and children and by increasing access to quality family planning and safe motherhood services.

column1: How does the Family Welfare Division ensure community participation in health programs?
column2: The Family Welfare Division promotes full participation and involvement of the community in public health activities through local programs and outreach initiatives.

column1: What types of health services are provided by the Ministry of Health in Nepal?
column2: The Ministry of Health provides promotional, preventive, diagnostic, curative, and palliative health care services through institutions established at community and central levels.

column1: What family health programs are prioritized by the Government of Nepal?
column2: Priority programs include family planning, adolescent sexual and reproductive health, safe motherhood, and neonatal health.

column1: Through which channels does the Family Welfare Division deliver reproductive health care services?
column2: Reproductive health services are delivered through Primary Health Care Outreach Clinics (PHC/ORC) and Female Community Health Volunteers (FCHVs).

column1: What role do Female Community Health Volunteers (FCHVs) play in Nepal’s health system?
column2: Female Community Health Volunteers help deliver reproductive health and family planning services to rural households and support community-based health programs.

column1: What are Primary Health Care Outreach Clinics (PHC/ORC) in Nepal?
column2: Primary Health Care Outreach Clinics are local health service delivery points that extend essential health services, including reproductive health and family planning, closer to rural communities.

column1: What is the focus of Nepal’s family health program under the Ministry of Health?
column2: The focus is on improving maternal, neonatal, and child health while expanding access to quality family planning and reproductive health services.

column1: What has Nepal achieved in terms of Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) related to health?
column2: Nepal has been able to partially achieve Millennium Development Goal (MDG) 4, which focuses on reducing child mortality, and MDG 5, which focuses on improving maternal health.

column1: What is Nepal’s commitment under the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) for maternal and child health?
column2: Nepal is committed to reducing maternal mortality, increasing institutional delivery, raising contraceptive prevalence, and lowering neonatal mortality by 2030.

column1: What specific targets has Nepal set for maternal and neonatal health under the SDGs?
column2: Nepal aims to reduce the maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births, increase institutional deliveries to 90%, achieve a contraceptive prevalence rate of 75%, and reduce neonatal mortality to 1 per 1,000 live births by 2030.

column1: Why is family health considered a priority program in Nepal?
column2: Family health is prioritized because improving the health of mothers, newborns, and children is key to enhancing the quality of life and achieving national development goals.

column1: What types of reproductive health activities does the Family Welfare Division conduct?
column2: The Division carries out planning, monitoring, and research related to reproductive health, along with implementing service delivery programs at national and community levels.

column1: How does the Family Welfare Division aim to reach rural households?
column2: It increases access and utilization of health services by bringing quality family planning and safe motherhood services closer to rural households through community participation.

column1: What is the overarching vision of the Family Welfare Division in Nepal?
column2: The Division envisions improving the overall quality of family life by ensuring equitable access to maternal, newborn, and reproductive health services.

column1: How does the Family Welfare Division align with the Constitution of Nepal?
column2: It operates under the constitutional mandate to provide equitable, accessible, and quality health services as a fundamental right of every citizen.

column1: Which key health indicators are being monitored by Nepal’s Family Welfare Division?
column2: Key indicators include maternal mortality ratio, institutional delivery rate, contraceptive prevalence rate, and neonatal mortality rate.

column1: How does the Family Welfare Division contribute to achieving national health goals?
column2: It designs and implements strategic programs focused on family planning, reproductive health, and safe motherhood, helping Nepal progress toward SDG health targets.

column1: What is the main objective of the Family Welfare Division in Nepal?
column2: The main objective of the Family Welfare Division is to improve the overall quality of life by enhancing the health status of mothers, newborns, and children, and by increasing access to quality family planning and safe motherhood services across Nepal.

column1: Which government body oversees preventive and promotive health services in Nepal?
column2: The Department of Health Services under the Ministry of Health oversees preventive, promotive, diagnostic, and curative health services throughout Nepal.

column1: What are the key programs managed by the Family Welfare Division?
column2: The key programs include family planning, adolescent sexual and reproductive health, safe motherhood, neonatal health, and reproductive health services through Primary Health Care Outreach Clinics and Female Community Health Volunteers.

column1: What role do Female Community Health Volunteers play in family welfare?
column2: Female Community Health Volunteers help deliver essential reproductive and child health services at the community level, support health education, and link families to nearby health facilities.

column1: What target has Nepal set for the Maternal Mortality Ratio under the Sustainable Development Goals by 2030?
column2: Nepal aims to reduce the Maternal Mortality Ratio to fewer than 70 maternal deaths per 100,000 live births by 2030.

column1: What is Nepal’s current Maternal Mortality Ratio according to the latest data?
column2: As of 2024, Nepal’s Maternal Mortality Ratio is approximately 142 deaths per 100,000 live births.

column1: What is Nepal’s Neonatal Mortality Rate as per recent estimates?
column2: According to 2023 data, Nepal’s Neonatal Mortality Rate is around 16.6 deaths per 1,000 live births.

column1: What is the target for Neonatal Mortality Rate by 2030 in Nepal?
column2: The target is to reduce neonatal deaths to fewer than 10 deaths per 1,000 live births by 2030.

column1: What is the goal for Institutional Delivery coverage under Nepal’s health targets?
column2: Nepal aims to achieve 90% institutional delivery coverage by 2030.

column1: What was the Institutional Delivery rate in Nepal in the fiscal year 2023-24?
column2: The Institutional Delivery rate was about 74% in 2023-24, indicating a decline compared to previous years.

column1: What is the current Contraceptive Prevalence Rate in Nepal?
column2: The Contraceptive Prevalence Rate is approximately 57%, with a target to increase it to 75% by 2030.

column1: How does family planning contribute to Nepal’s health goals?
column2: Family planning reduces maternal and neonatal mortality, helps space pregnancies safely, and contributes to overall family well-being and women’s empowerment.

column1: What progress has Nepal made towards Millennium Development Goals 4 and 5?
column2: Nepal has partially achieved Millennium Development Goals 4 and 5 by significantly reducing child and maternal deaths, but further progress is needed to sustain these improvements.

column1: How is the Family Welfare Division ensuring services reach rural households?
column2: The Division promotes outreach through community-level clinics, mobile services, and engagement of Female Community Health Volunteers to reach remote populations.

column1: Why is family planning considered a national priority program in Nepal?
column2: Because it directly affects maternal and child health, population growth, and overall socio-economic development, making it a cornerstone of Nepal’s public health strategy.

column1: How have contraceptive use trends changed across Nepal's provinces between 2016 and 2022?
column2: Contraceptive Prevalence Rate increased in all provinces, with Bagmati showing the highest rate at 57% and Karnali showing the lowest at 42%, reflecting improved outreach but continued regional inequality.

column1: What is the most commonly used modern family planning method in Nepal as of 2024?
column2: Injectable contraceptives remain the most preferred modern method nationwide, particularly in rural areas where monthly or quarterly visits to health posts are feasible.

column1: Why is the unmet need for family planning still high in Madhesh Province?
column2: Cultural norms, early marriage, limited mobility of women, and shortage of trained providers contribute to a higher unmet need for family planning in Madhesh Province compared to others.

column1: How are Female Community Health Volunteers improving access to family planning in remote districts?
column2: They provide door-to-door counselling, distribute short-term contraceptive methods, and refer clients to nearby health facilities for long-acting methods, bridging service gaps in rural and mountainous regions.

column1: What new approach has Nepal introduced to address adolescent reproductive health challenges?
column2: Comprehensive Sexuality Education has been integrated into school curricula and adolescent-friendly corners have been expanded in over 70% of primary health facilities nationwide.

column1: How is the Family Welfare Division addressing stock-outs of contraceptives in remote provinces?
column2: The Division has decentralized the logistics management system, improved forecasting, and established buffer stocks at provincial warehouses to prevent shortages during monsoon or roadblock seasons.

column1: Which provinces have the highest awareness of modern family planning methods?
column2: Bagmati and Gandaki provinces have the highest awareness levels, with over 95% of married women knowing at least one modern family planning method.

column1: What is the current national Contraceptive Prevalence Rate in Nepal?
column2: As of 2024, the national Contraceptive Prevalence Rate for modern methods is approximately 57%, according to the Department of Health Services annual report.

column1: How does migration influence family planning needs in western Nepal?
column2: High rates of male migration have created fluctuating demand for contraceptives, as couples often use short-term methods around the husband’s return periods.

column1: What barriers prevent consistent contraceptive use in hill and mountain regions?
column2: Limited transportation, infrequent health post visits, seasonal access issues, and myths about side effects make consistent contraceptive use difficult in these areas.

column1: What is Nepal’s target for family planning use under its 2030 national strategy?
column2: Nepal aims to reach a modern Contraceptive Prevalence Rate of 60% and reduce unmet need for family planning to below 10% by 2030.

column1: How are health workers trained to promote family planning services under federal governance?
column2: Provincial health training centers have been mandated to provide in-service and refresher training on counselling, infection prevention, and rights-based family planning to all health workers.

column1: What progress has Nepal made in post-pregnancy family planning?
column2: The rate of postpartum contraceptive use increased to 29% in 2024, supported by the integration of counselling during antenatal and postnatal care visits.

column1: How is technology being used to improve family planning data collection in Nepal?
column2: Digital tools such as the electronic Logistics Management Information System (eLMIS) and mobile reporting applications now track contraceptive stocks and service utilization in real time.

column1: Why is long-acting reversible contraception (LARC) uptake lower in some regions?
column2: In remote districts, lack of trained providers and misconceptions about intrauterine devices and implants have limited adoption of long-acting methods.

column1: How does education level affect family planning use in Nepal?
column2: Women with secondary or higher education are nearly twice as likely to use modern contraceptive methods compared to those with no education, according to NDHS 2022 data.

column1: What steps are being taken to increase male engagement in family planning programs?
column2: Community campaigns and couple counselling sessions are being expanded, with men encouraged to participate in decision-making and share responsibility for family planning choices.

column1: How has decentralization changed budget allocation for family planning in provinces?
column2: Each province now prepares its own health budget, including a specific line item for family planning, which has improved funding flexibility but introduced regional disparities in implementation.

column1: Which contraceptive methods are most preferred by urban versus rural women?
column2: Urban women are more likely to use implants and intrauterine devices, while rural women predominantly rely on injectables and female sterilization.

column1: What are the government’s new priorities for 2025 under the Family Planning Costed Implementation Plan?
column2: The 2025 plan emphasizes adolescent-friendly services, sustainable domestic financing, improved method mix, and digital tracking of commodities to strengthen nationwide access.

column1: When was the Family Planning Association of Nepal established?
column2: The Family Planning Association of Nepal was established in 1959 as the first national family planning service delivery and advocacy organization in Nepal.

column1: What is the main role of the Family Planning Association of Nepal?
column2: It delivers family planning and sexual and reproductive health services while advocating for reproductive rights and gender equality across Nepal.

column1: How does the Family Planning Association of Nepal collaborate with the Government of Nepal?
column2: It works as a major collaborator in the national sexual and reproductive health program, contributing a significant share of all such services delivered annually across the country.

column1: How many districts of Nepal are served by the Family Planning Association of Nepal?
column2: The Family Planning Association of Nepal provides services in 44 districts across Nepal.

column1: Which groups are prioritized by the Family Planning Association of Nepal for its services?
column2: It focuses on poor, marginalized, socially excluded, and underserved groups including female sex workers, people living with HIV, LGBTIQ people, injecting drug users, migrant workers, people with disabilities, survivors of gender-based violence, urban slum dwellers, and people affected by disaster or crisis.

column1: What is the mission statement of the Family Planning Association of Nepal?
column2: Its mission is to champion a volunteer movement for increased provision of sexual and reproductive health and rights to all, particularly those most at risk, marginalized, and underserved.

column1: What strategic outcomes were set by the Family Planning Association of Nepal for 2016–2022?
column2: The outcomes include ensuring that the Government of Nepal respects, protects, and fulfils sexual and reproductive rights and gender equality; empowering Nepalese people to act freely on their sexual and reproductive health and rights; delivering high-quality integrated sexual and reproductive health services; and maintaining a high-performing and accountable organization.

column1: Why has the Family Planning Association of Nepal been successful in its work?
column2: Its success comes from its wide network of service delivery points and its trained staff and volunteers who provide services even in areas where they are otherwise unavailable.

column1: What types of services are provided under the Integrated Package of Essential Services by the Family Planning Association of Nepal?
column2: The package includes sexuality counselling, contraception including emergency contraception, safe abortion, prevention and treatment of sexually transmitted and reproductive tract infections, HIV and AIDS care, obstetrics, gynaecological services, and sexual and gender-based violence support.

column1: How many total service delivery points does the Family Planning Association of Nepal operate?
column2: It operates 974 service delivery points across Nepal.

column1: What kinds of service delivery points are included in the Family Planning Association of Nepal’s network?
column2: The network includes 270 clinical service delivery points, 22 family health clinics, 56 community health clinics, 75 associate clinics, 117 mobile teams, and 794 non-clinical service delivery points.

column1: Approximately how many sexual and reproductive health services does the Family Planning Association of Nepal provide annually?
column2: It provides around four million sexual and reproductive health services each year across Nepal.

column1: What percentage of services provided by the Family Planning Association of Nepal are related to family planning?
column2: About 40% of all services provided are family planning services.

column1: What proportion of the Family Planning Association of Nepal’s services are related to sexually transmitted or reproductive tract infections?
column2: Approximately 14% of its services are related to sexually transmitted infections and reproductive tract infections.

column1: What proportion of the Family Planning Association of Nepal’s services are related to gynaecological and HIV services?
column2: Around 12% are gynaecological services, while 10% are related to HIV services.

column1: What percentage of the Family Planning Association of Nepal’s services fall into other categories outside family planning
column2: STIs
column4: About 24% of its total services fall under other categories, such as counselling, gender-based violence support, and obstetric care.

column1: How many clinical training centres are operated by the Family Planning Association of Nepal?
column2: It operates eight clinical training centres across Nepal.

column1: What is the purpose of the Family Planning Association of Nepal’s clinical training centres?
column2: They provide training in family planning and sexual and reproductive health for healthcare providers from both government and non-government organizations.

column1: Which organization accredits the Family Planning Association of Nepal’s clinical training centres?
column2: The training centres are accredited by the National Health Training Centre under the Ministry of Health and Population.

column1: What is the role of the Family Planning Association of Nepal in ensuring access for marginalized communities?
column2: It ensures that marginalized and underserved groups have access to essential sexual and reproductive health services, especially in regions where government services are limited.

column1: How does the Family Planning Association of Nepal contribute to gender equality in Nepal?
column2: It promotes reproductive rights, empowers women and marginalized groups, and provides gender-based violence prevention and response services as part of its integrated service package.

column1: What distinguishes the Family Planning Association of Nepal’s approach to service delivery?
column2: Its approach combines advocacy, service delivery, and community outreach through trained volunteers and mobile health teams, ensuring access for even the most remote populations.

column1: How does the Family Planning Association of Nepal support government and NGO health staff?
column2: It offers certified training on modern family planning methods, sexual and reproductive health services, counselling skills, and gender-sensitive service delivery.

column1: How has the Family Planning Association of Nepal addressed the needs of key populations such as people living with HIV and LGBTIQ individuals?
column2: It provides inclusive and stigma-free sexual and reproductive health services tailored to the needs of people living with HIV and LGBTIQ individuals, ensuring equal access and rights.

column1: What does the abbreviation FPAN stand for?
column2: FPAN stands for the Family Planning Association of Nepal.

column1: What does the abbreviation SRH stand for in the context of the Family Planning Association of Nepal?
column2: SRH stands for Sexual and Reproductive Health.

column1: What does the abbreviation GBV stand for in the Family Planning Association of Nepal’s service list?
column2: GBV stands for Gender-Based Violence.

column1: What does the abbreviation PLHIV mean in the Family Planning Association of Nepal’s focus population?
column2: PLHIV means People Living with Human Immunodeficiency Virus.

column1: What does the abbreviation LGBTIQ stand for in the Family Planning Association of Nepal’s context?
column2: LGBTIQ stands for Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, Intersex, and Queer or Questioning individuals.

column1: What is the average number of children per woman in Nepal?
column2: According to the 2022 Nepal Demographic and Health Survey, women in Nepal have an average of 2.1 children per woman.

column1: How has fertility in Nepal changed over time?
column2: Fertility in Nepal has declined from 4.6 children per woman in 1996 to 2.1 children per woman in 2022.

column1: What is the difference in fertility between rural and urban women in Nepal?
column2: Rural women have more children than urban women, with 2.4 children on average compared to 2.0 among urban women.

column1: How does fertility vary by ecological zone in Nepal?
column2: Fertility varies by ecological zone: women in the hill zone have 1.8 children on average, 2.2 in the terai zone, and 2.7 in the mountain zone.

column1: Which province in Nepal has the highest fertility rate?
column2: Madhesh Province has the highest fertility rate, with 2.7 children per woman.

column1: Which province in Nepal has the lowest fertility rate?
column2: Gandaki Province has the lowest fertility rate, with 1.4 children per woman.

column1: How does education level affect fertility in Nepal?
column2: Fertility declines with increasing education: women with no education have 3.3 children on average, while women with more than secondary education have 1.6.

column1: How does household wealth affect fertility in Nepal?
column2: Fertility declines with higher household wealth: women in the poorest households have 2.8 children, while those in the richest have 1.6.

column1: What percentage of pregnancies in Nepal end in live births?
column2: According to the survey, 80% of pregnancies result in live births.

column1: What percentage of pregnancies in Nepal end in losses or abortions?
column2: Twenty percent of pregnancies end in losses, including 9% miscarriages, 10% induced abortions, and 1% stillbirths.

column1: How does induced abortion vary by pregnancy order in Nepal?
column2: Induced abortion increases with pregnancy order, from 2% of first pregnancies to 29% of fifth or higher order pregnancies.

column1: What is the median age at first menstruation for women in Nepal?
column2: The median age at first menstruation among women age 15–49 is 13.6 years.

column1: What is the median age at first marriage for women in Nepal?
column2: The median age at first marriage for women age 25–49 is 18.3 years.

column1: Do rural and urban women marry at the same age in Nepal?
column2: No, rural women marry earlier at 17.9 years on average, while urban women marry at 18.5 years.

column1: What is the median age at first marriage for men in Nepal?
column2: For men age 25–49, the median age at first marriage is 22.3 years.

column1: What is the median age at first sexual intercourse among women in Nepal?
column2: The median age at first sexual intercourse for women age 25–49 is 18.3 years.

column1: What is the median age at first sexual intercourse among men in Nepal?
column2: For men age 25–49, it is 20.7 years.

column1: What is the median age at first birth for women in Nepal?
column2: The median age at first birth among women age 25–49 is 20.6 years.
