column1: How does the age at first birth differ between rural and urban women in Nepal?
column2: Urban women give birth for the first time at 21.1 years on average, while rural women do so at 20.3 years.

column1: What percentage of adolescent women in Nepal were married before age 15?
column2: Three percent of adolescent women age 15–19 were married before age 15.

column1: What percentage of adolescent men in Nepal were married before age 15?
column2: Fewer than one percent of adolescent men age 15–19 were married before age 15.

column1: What percentage of adolescent women in Nepal have ever been pregnant?
column2: Overall, 14% of adolescent women age 15–19 have ever been pregnant.

column1: Which province in Nepal has the highest teenage pregnancy rate?
column2: Karnali Province has the highest teenage pregnancy rate at 21%.

column1: Which province in Nepal has the lowest teenage pregnancy rate?
column2: Bagmati Province has the lowest teenage pregnancy rate at 8%.

column1: How does teenage pregnancy vary with household wealth in Nepal?
column2: Teenage pregnancy declines with household wealth, from 17% among the poorest to only 4% among the richest households.

column1: How does education level affect teenage pregnancy in Nepal?
column2: Teenage pregnancy declines with education, from 33% among women with no education to 8% among those with higher secondary education.

column1: What percentage of married women in Nepal use any method of family planning?
column2: In Nepal, 57% of married women age 15–49 use any method of family planning.

column1: What percentage of married women in Nepal use modern family planning methods?
column2: 43% of married women use modern methods of family planning.

column1: What are the most popular modern family planning methods among married women in Nepal?
column2: The most popular modern methods are female sterilization (13%), injectables (9%), and implants (6%).

column1: What percentage of married women in Nepal use traditional methods of family planning?
column2: Fifteen percent of married women use traditional methods, including withdrawal (13%) and the rhythm method (2%).

column1: How has the use of modern family planning methods changed since 1996 in Nepal?
column2: The use of modern methods increased from 26% in 1996 to 44% in 2006, but has stagnated since then.

column1: How has the use of traditional family planning methods changed since 2006 in Nepal?
column2: The use of traditional methods increased from 4% in 2006 to 15% in 2022.

column1: What does 'informed choice' mean in family planning?
column2: It means clients are informed about the side effects of the method, what to do if side effects occur, and about other available family planning options.

column1: What percentage of women using modern methods in Nepal were informed about side effects?
column2: 58% of women using modern methods were informed about side effects.

column1: What percentage of women were informed what to do if they experience side effects?
column2: 53% were informed about what to do if they experience side effects.

column1: What percentage of women were told about other available family planning methods?
column2: 57% were informed about other family planning methods.

column1: What percentage of women received all three types of information for informed choice?
column2: 42% of women using modern methods received all three types of information.

column1: What percentage of married women in Nepal have been pressured to become pregnant?
column2: Nine percent of married women reported being pressured by their husband or family to become pregnant when they did not want to.

column1: How does pressure to become pregnant vary by number of children?
column2: Pressure is higher among women with five or more children (23%) compared to those with three or four (13%) or none (11%).

column1: What percentage of married women in Nepal want to stop having children?
column2: 61% of married women do not want any more children.

column1: What percentage of married women want to delay childbearing?
column2: 17% of married women want to delay childbearing for at least two years.

column1: What is the total demand for family planning among married women in Nepal?
column2: 78% of married women have a demand for family planning, including those who want to stop or delay childbearing.

column1: What is the unmet need for family planning in Nepal?
column2: 21% of married women have an unmet need for family planning.

column1: How many women in Nepal have demand for family planning satisfied by modern methods?
column2: Among married women, 55% of their demand for family planning is satisfied by modern methods.

column1: Which province has the highest demand satisfied by modern family planning methods?
column2: Sudurpashchim Province has the highest at 59%.

column1: Which province has the lowest demand satisfied by modern family planning methods?
column2: Gandaki Province has the lowest at 44%.

column1: How has the demand satisfied by modern methods changed over time in Nepal?
column2: It increased from 43% in 1996 to 61% in 2006, but has stagnated since then.

column1: Who makes decisions about family planning in Nepali households?
column2: 91% of married women make the decision to use or not use family planning either alone (14%) or jointly with their husband or partner (77%).

column1: How does education affect decision-making about family planning in Nepal?
column2: Sole decision-making decreases with higher education, while joint decision-making with partners increases with education and wealth.

column1: What percentage of women and men are exposed to family planning messages in Nepal?
column2: 45% of women and 59% of men aged 15–49 were exposed to family planning messages in the past 12 months.

column1: What are the most common sources of family planning messages in Nepal?
column2: The most common sources are outdoor signs or billboards, posters or leaflets, and social media.

column1: How many people in Nepal were not exposed to family planning messages recently?
column2: 34% of women and 21% of men were not exposed to family planning messages in the 12 months before the survey.

column1: What is Nepal's target for the modern contraceptive prevalence rate (mCPR) by 2030?
column2: Nepal aims to reach a modern contraceptive prevalence rate of 70% by 2030, an increase from 48% in 2016.

column1: What is Nepal's target for reducing unmet needs for family planning by 2030?
column2: Nepal has set a target to reduce unmet needs for family planning to 10% or less by 2030.

column1: What initiatives has Nepal implemented to achieve its family planning goals?
column2: Nepal has implemented initiatives such as increasing access to contraceptives, improving the quality of services, expanding outreach to underserved populations, strengthening health worker capacity, and improving the contraceptive supply chain.

column1: What is the vision of Nepal for family planning by 2030?
column2: By the end of 2030, Nepal envisions a country where every individual and family leads a healthy, happy, and prosperous life, fully exercising their sexual and reproductive health and rights.

column1: What are the main objectives of Nepal’s Family Planning (FP) 2030 commitment?
column2: The main objectives are: strengthen health governance for family planning, improve equitable access to contraceptives, ensure youth-friendly reproductive health services, ensure year-round availability of contraceptives, implement behavioral change interventions, and ensure incremental budget allocation for universal health coverage.

column1: How does Nepal plan to strengthen health governance for family planning?
column2: Nepal plans to strengthen health governance for family planning by improving coordination and management within the federalized health system.

column1: What steps are being taken to make family planning services more responsive to adolescents and youth?
column2: Nepal is ensuring that sexual and reproductive health services are tailored to address the needs and concerns of adolescents and youth effectively.

column1: How does Nepal plan to ensure continuous availability of family planning commodities?
column2: Nepal aims to ensure round-the-year availability of contraceptive commodities at all service delivery points by strengthening supply chains and inventory management.

column1: What are demand generation and behavioral change interventions in family planning?
column2: Demand generation and behavioral change interventions refer to tailored programs and campaigns that promote awareness and positive attitudes toward family planning and encourage the use of contraceptive methods.

column1: Why is incremental budget allocation important for family planning in Nepal?
column2: Incremental budget allocation is important to ensure sustainable funding for family planning programs and to achieve universal health coverage.

column1: How is Nepal improving the supply chain for contraceptives?
column2: Nepal is improving the supply chain through better logistics, procurement planning, and monitoring systems to ensure timely delivery and reduce stockouts.

column1: Who are the main beneficiaries of Nepal’s FP2030 initiatives?
column2: The main beneficiaries include individuals and couples, especially adolescents, youth, and underserved populations in rural and marginalized communities.

column1: What does FP2030 stand for in the context of Nepal?
column2: FP2030 refers to Nepal’s commitment under the global Family Planning 2030 initiative to ensure access to voluntary, informed, and equitable family planning services.

column1: How does Nepal’s FP2030 commitment align with the country's overall health vision?
column2: Nepal’s FP2030 commitment aligns with its national vision of achieving universal health coverage and ensuring the well-being of all individuals through reproductive health and rights.

column1: What is an unintended pregnancy?
column2: An unintended pregnancy is one that occurs either when no children or no more children were desired (unwanted) or earlier than desired (mistimed).

column1: What are the main causes of unintended pregnancies?
column2: Most unintended pregnancies result from not using contraception or from not using it consistently or correctly.

column1: Why are unintended pregnancies a public health concern?
column2: They are linked with adverse social and health outcomes such as abortion, late prenatal care, poor birth preparedness, preterm birth, low birth weight, and neonatal morbidity and mortality.

column1: What are the risks of short or long inter-pregnancy intervals?
column2: Intervals shorter than 18 months or longer than 59 months increase risks of adverse perinatal outcomes like preterm birth, low birth weight, and neonatal death.

column1: How soon can a woman become pregnant after childbirth?
column2: A woman who is not fully breastfeeding can become pregnant as soon as four to six weeks after childbirth.

column1: What is the relationship between breastfeeding and fertility?
column2: Even with full breastfeeding, if menstruation resumes and no contraceptive is used, a woman can become pregnant.

column1: What is the average day of first ovulation after childbirth?
column2: The mean day of first ovulation ranges from 45 to 94 days postpartum.

column1: How does family planning help reduce health risks?
column2: Planned and healthy birth spacing lowers unintended pregnancies and reduces exposure to pregnancy-related health risks for mothers and babies.

column1: What are the benefits of voluntary family planning?
column2: Voluntary family planning is a cost-effective intervention that saves lives, supports economic development, and helps achieve Sustainable Development Goals.

column1: What is the status of family planning in Nepal according to recent surveys?
column2: 10% of women want another child within two years, 13% after two or more years, 43% use modern methods, and 21% have an unmet need for family planning.

column1: What is the total fertility rate and wanted fertility rate in Nepal?
column2: The total fertility rate is 2.1 and the wanted fertility rate is 1.7, showing that women want an average of 0.4 fewer children than they currently have.

column1: What is postpartum family planning (PPFP)?
column2: Postpartum family planning focuses on preventing unintended and closely spaced pregnancies during the first 12 months after childbirth.

column1: What is post-abortion family planning (PAFP)?
column2: Post-abortion family planning provides contraceptive methods immediately after an abortion to reduce repeat abortions and unmet needs.

column1: What are the World Health Organization (WHO) recommendations for postpartum contraceptive methods?
column2: Women can start progestogen-only pills or implants immediately after delivery, injectables after 6 weeks, intrauterine devices (IUDs) within 48 hours or after 4 weeks, and combined hormonal methods after 6 months.

column1: When can post-abortion women start contraception?
column2: They can start all hormonal methods immediately or within 7 days of abortion, except IUDs which can be inserted after confirming successful abortion.

column1: Why do many postpartum women have an unmet need for family planning?
column2: Due to low demand, inadequate counseling, limited access to services, socio-cultural norms, and fear of side effects.

column1: What are common bottlenecks in postpartum family planning services?
column2: Challenges include limited trained staff, stock-outs, workload, lack of motivation, poor data systems, and weak leadership and coordination.

column1: How does the lactational amenorrhea method (LAM) work?
column2: It prevents pregnancy during the first six months postpartum if the mother is fully breastfeeding and has not resumed menstruation.

column1: What percentage of postpartum women use modern contraception in Nepal?
column2: About 22% of postpartum women use a modern method, roughly half of the rate among all married women aged 15–49.

column1: What contraceptive methods are commonly used after abortion in Nepal?
column2: About 75% of women use contraception after abortion, with 61% using short-acting reversible contraceptives and 14% using long-acting and permanent methods.

column1: What are the objectives of the Bottleneck Analysis (BNA) on post-pregnancy family planning?
column2: To synthesize knowledge on scaling up post-pregnancy family planning, understand stakeholder perspectives, and identify key bottlenecks and solutions.

column1: What is an unintended pregnancy?
column2: An unintended pregnancy is one that is either unwanted (no children or no more children were desired) or mistimed (occurred earlier than desired).

column1: What are the main causes of unintended pregnancies?
column2: Most unintended pregnancies result from not using contraception, or from not using it consistently or correctly.

column1: Why are unintended pregnancies a public health concern?
column2: They are associated with adverse social and health outcomes for mothers, children, and families, including abortion, poor prenatal care, preterm birth, low birth weight, and early neonatal morbidity and mortality.

column1: What are the risks associated with short inter-pregnancy intervals?
column2: Risks include a higher chance of preterm birth, low birth weight, and fetal and early neonatal death, especially if the interval is shorter than 18 months.

column1: What are the risks associated with long inter-pregnancy intervals?
column2: Intervals longer than 59 months are associated with a higher risk of adverse perinatal outcomes, and intervals longer than 50 months increase the chance of fetal and early neonatal death.

column1: When can a woman who is not fully breastfeeding become pregnant after childbirth?
column2: A woman who is not fully breastfeeding can become pregnant as soon as four to six weeks after childbirth.

column1: Can a fully breastfeeding woman get pregnant?
column2: Yes, a fully breastfeeding woman can conceive if her monthly bleeding starts and she is not using a contraceptive method.

column1: What is the benefit of planned and healthy birth spacing?
column2: It reduces the number of unintended pregnancies and lowers the number of women and babies exposed to pregnancy-related health risks.

column1: What is the full form of FP?
column2: FP stands for Family Planning.

column1: How does Family Planning help?
column2: Family Planning helps to save the lives of mothers and their children by preventing unintended and closely spaced pregnancies.

column1: What is the full form of SDG?
column2: SDG stands for Sustainable Development Goal.

column1: What is Nepal's current Total Fertility Rate?
column2: Nepal has met its Sustainable Development Goal target of reducing the Total Fertility Rate to 2.1.

column1: What is the wanted fertility rate in Nepal?
column2: The wanted fertility rate in Nepal is 1.7.

column1: What percentage of women in Nepal use modern Family Planning methods?
column2: Only 43% of women in Nepal were using modern Family Planning methods according to a recent national survey.

column1: What is the unmet need for Family Planning in Nepal?
column2: 21% of women in Nepal had an unmet need for Family Planning.

column1: What is the full form of PPFP?
column2: PPFP stands for Postpartum Family Planning.

column1: What is the focus of Postpartum Family Planning?
column2: Postpartum Family Planning focuses on the prevention of unintended and closely spaced pregnancies through the first 12 months following childbirth.

column1: Why do postpartum women have a high unmet need for Family Planning?
column2: Postpartum mothers often do not receive the services they need to support longer birth intervals, making them among those with the greatest unmet need.

column1: What is the full form of PAFP?
column2: PAFP stands for Post-Abortion Family Planning.

column1: Why is Post-Abortion Family Planning important?
column2: It is essential to avoid unintended pregnancies post-abortion and the risks associated with repeat abortions. It helps reduce repeat abortions and unmet needs for contraception.

column1: What percentage of postpartum women in Nepal use a modern contraceptive method at one year?
column2: At one year, 22% of postpartum women report using a modern method of contraception.

column1: What is the usage rate of IUDs among Postpartum Family Planning users in Nepal?
column2: The use of IUD services among Postpartum Family Planning users is low, at 0.1%.

column1: What is the usage rate of implants among Postpartum Family Planning users in Nepal?
column2: The use of implant services among Postpartum Family Planning users is 3%.

column1: What percentage of abortion clients in Nepal use contraception post-procedure?
column2: 75% of abortion clients use some type of contraceptive method post-procedure.

column1: When can a postpartum woman initiate progestogen-only pills and implants?
column2: Postpartum women can immediately initiate progestogen-only pills and progestogen-only implants after delivery.

column1: When can a postpartum woman initiate an IUD?
column2: A postpartum woman can initiate an IUD within 48 hours or from 4 weeks after delivery.

column1: When can a postpartum woman initiate combined hormonal contraceptives?
column2: A postpartum woman can initiate combined hormonal contraceptives 6 months after delivery.

column1: Do postpartum women need to rule-out pregnancy before starting progestogen-only methods in the first 6 months?
column2: No, postpartum women can initiate progestogen-only methods within the first 6 months immediately without the need to rule-out pregnancy.

column1: What is the full form of LAM?
column2: LAM stands for Lactational Amenorrhea Method.

column1: What support should be given to women using the Lactational Amenorrhea Method?
column2: They should be supported to transition to another contraceptive method within 6 months of delivery, as protection is only assured for the first 6 months under specific conditions.

column1: When can a post-abortion woman initiate hormonal contraception?
column2: Post-abortion women can initiate all hormonal methods of contraception immediately, or within 7 days of an abortion, without waiting for menstruation.

column1: When can a woman start contraception after taking medical abortion drugs?
column2: Women can start contraception after taking the first pill of the medical abortion regimen, except for IUDs, which are inserted after the abortion is confirmed successful.

column1: What are some health system bottlenecks for Postpartum Family Planning?
column2: Bottlenecks include human resource availability, capacity, motivation, and attitudes; supplies/equipment shortages; resourcing issues; fees; and weak health management information systems.

column1: What are some demand-side barriers to Postpartum Family Planning?
column2: Barriers include socio-cultural and gender norms, reduced sexual activity during postpartum abstinence, fears of contraceptive side effects, and the perception that breastfeeding provides sufficient protection.

column1: What is the objective of the Bottleneck Analysis mentioned in the text?
column2: The Bottleneck Analysis aims to synthesize knowledge on scaling up post-pregnancy family planning, understand stakeholder perspectives on inhibiting factors, and build consensus on solutions.

column1: What is the primary source for family planning statistics in Nepal?
column2: The Nepal Demographic and Health Survey (NDHS), conducted periodically by the Ministry of Health and Population (MoHP) with New ERA and ICF International, is the most legitimate and comprehensive source.

column1: According to NDHS 2022
column2: what is the national modern Contraceptive Prevalence Rate (mCPR) for married women?
column3: The national modern Contraceptive Prevalence Rate (mCPR) for currently married women aged 15-49 is 43%.

column1: How does the use of modern family planning methods vary by province?
column2: There is significant variation. Province 2 has the highest modern Contraceptive Prevalence Rate (mCPR) at 55%, while Karnali Province has the lowest at 31%.

column1: Which province has the highest demand for family planning satisfied with modern methods?
column2: Province 2 has the highest demand satisfied with modern methods, at 68%.

column1: Which province has the lowest demand for family planning satisfied with modern methods?
column2: Karnali Province has the lowest demand satisfied with modern methods, at 46%.

column1: What is the unmet need for family planning at the national level?
column2: The total unmet need for family planning among married women in Nepal is 21%. This includes a 13% unmet need for spacing births and an 8% unmet need for limiting births.

column1: How does the unmet need for family planning vary across the provinces?
column2: Unmet need is highest in Karnali Province (27%) and Sudurpashchim Province (26%). It is lowest in Province 2 (15%) and Bagmati Province (16%).

column1: What is the Total Fertility Rate (TFR) in Nepal?
column2: The national Total Fertility Rate (TFR) is 2.1 children per woman, which is the replacement level.

column1: Are there regional differences in the Total Fertility Rate (TFR)?
column2: Yes, fertility is higher in the Terai region (2.3) compared to the Hill (1.9) and Mountain (1.7) regions. At the provincial level, Province 2 has the highest TFR (2.6) and Gandaki Province the lowest (1.6).

column1: What is the most popular modern contraceptive method in Nepal?
column2: Female sterilization is the most common modern method (9%), followed by injectables (8%) and male condoms (7%).

column1: Are there geographic variations in the choice of contraceptive method?
column2: Yes. For example, female sterilization is more common in Lumbini Province (13%) and Province 2 (12%), while injectables are more prevalent in Province 2 (13%) and Bagmati (9%). Implants are used most in Sudurpashchim Province (4%).

column1: What percentage of married women use traditional contraceptive methods?
column2: Nationally, 4% of married women use traditional methods. Use is highest in Bagmati Province (7%) and lowest in Karnali Province (1%).

column1: What is the knowledge of family planning methods among women and men?
column2: Knowledge is universal, with nearly all women (99%) and men (99%) aged 15-49 knowing at least one modern method of contraception.

column1: Despite high knowledge
column2: what are the main reasons for not using family planning?
column3: The main reasons include concerns about side effects/health risks (26%), opposition from the woman herself or her partner (10%), and infrequent sex or subfecundity (8%).

column1: How does the fertility preference of women vary by region?
column2: A higher percentage of women in Province 2 (36%) want another child soon compared to Bagmati Province (21%).

column1: What is the median age at first birth for women in Nepal?
column2: The median age at first birth for women aged 25-49 is 20.3 years. This is slightly higher in urban areas (21.1 years) compared to rural areas (19.9 years).

column1: What is the full form of NDHS?
column2: NDHS stands for Nepal Demographic and Health Survey.

column1: What is the full form of mCPR?
column2: mCPR stands for modern Contraceptive Prevalence Rate.

column1: What is the full form of TFR?
column2: TFR stands for Total Fertility Rate.

column1: What is the full form of MoHP?
column2: MoHP stands for Ministry of Health and Population.

column1: What are the main types of contraceptive methods available in Nepal?
column2: Methods are categorized as Short-Acting Reversible Contraceptives (SARCs), Long-Acting and Permanent Methods (LAPMs), and traditional methods. SARCs include pills, condoms, and injectables. LAPMs include implants and IUDs.

column1: What is the most commonly used modern contraceptive method in Nepal?
column2: According to the NDHS 2022, female sterilization (9%) is the most common, followed by injectables (8%) and male condoms (7%).

column1: What is Depo-Provera?
column2: Depo-Provera is the brand name for a popular injectable contraceptive in Nepal. It contains the hormone progestin and is given as an injection every three months.

column1: How effective is the injectable (Depo-Provera)?
column2: It is over 99% effective with correct use. Its real-world effectiveness is very high because it does not require daily action.

column1: What are the potential side effects of injectable contraceptives?
column2: Common side effects can include irregular bleeding, weight gain, headaches, and a delay in the return of fertility after stopping the injections.

column1: What is an IUD?
column2: An Intrauterine Device (IUD) is a small, T-shaped device made of plastic and copper that is inserted into a woman's uterus by a trained health worker.

column1: How long does an IUD last?
column2: A copper IUD can provide protection against pregnancy for up to 10 years or more, depending on the type. It is a form of Long-Acting Reversible Contraceptive (LARC).

column1: Is the IUD effective immediately after insertion?
column2: Yes, the IUD is effective immediately after insertion, making it a good option for post-pregnancy family planning.

column1: What are the potential side effects of the IUD?
column2: Some women may experience heavier periods and more cramping, especially in the first few months after insertion.

column1: What is a contraceptive implant?
column2: An implant is a small, flexible rod about the size of a matchstick that is placed under the skin of a woman's upper arm by a trained provider. It releases the hormone progestin.

column1: How long does a contraceptive implant last?
column2: Implants like Implanon or Jadelle can provide protection for 3 to 5 years, depending on the type. They are a form of Long-Acting Reversible Contraceptive (LARC).

column1: Are contraceptive implants available in Nepal?
column2: Yes, but their use is relatively low (3% among postpartum users according to one survey). The government is working to increase access to this method.

column1: What is the full form of LARC?
column2: LARC stands for Long-Acting Reversible Contraceptive. This category includes IUDs and implants.

column1: How do combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs) work?
column2: Often called 'the pill', COCs contain two hormones, estrogen and progestin. They work primarily by preventing ovulation.

column1: How effective are oral contraceptive pills?
column2: They are over 99% effective with perfect use. With typical use, they are about 93% effective, as missing pills reduces effectiveness.

column1: What is the difference between progestin-only pills (POPs) and combined pills?
column2: Progestin-Only Pills (POPs), or 'mini-pills', contain only one hormone and are often recommended for breastfeeding women. They must be taken at the same time every day.

column1: How effective are male condoms?
column2: When used correctly and consistently, male condoms are 98% effective. They are the only method that also provides protection against Sexually Transmitted Infections (STIs).

column1: What is female sterilization?
column2: Female sterilization, or tubal ligation, is a permanent surgical procedure that blocks the fallopian tubes to prevent pregnancy permanently.

column1: What is male sterilization (vasectomy)?
column2: Vasectomy is a permanent surgical procedure that blocks or cuts the vas deferens, the tubes that carry sperm. It is a safe and effective method, but uptake is very low in Nepal.

column1: What is the Lactational Amenorrhea Method (LAM)?
column2: LAM is a temporary, natural method for postpartum women. It is highly effective for up to 6 months if the woman is fully or nearly fully breastfeeding and has not had her period return.

column1: Can a woman get pregnant while breastfeeding?
column2: Yes. While breastfeeding can delay the return of fertility, it is not a reliable contraceptive after 6 months, or if supplementation is used, or if menstruation returns.

column1: What are emergency contraceptive pills (ECPs)?
column2: ECPs, often called the 'morning-after pill', are used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected sex or contraceptive failure (like a condom break). They are not for regular use.

column1: Where can one get contraceptives in Nepal?
column2: Contraceptives are available for free or at a low cost at government health posts, primary health care centers, hospitals, and through many non-governmental organization clinics and private pharmacies.

column1: Are contraceptives provided for free in Nepal?
column2: Yes, the Government of Nepal is committed to providing a range of contraceptive methods free of cost through its public health facilities.

column1: What should a woman do if she experiences side effects from her contraceptive method?
column2: She should not discontinue the method without consulting a health worker. Side effects often subside after a few months, and a health worker can help manage them or switch her to a more suitable method.

column1: Who can use an IUD?
column2: Most women can safely use an IUD, including women who have or have not had children. A health worker can perform a simple screening to check for any conditions that might prevent its use.

column1: Is it true that some contraceptives can cause infertility?
column2: No, this is a myth. With the exception of permanent sterilization, fertility returns after stopping all modern contraceptive methods. There may be a delay with injectables, but it is not permanent.

column1: What is the biggest challenge facing Nepal's family planning program currently?
column2: A critical challenge is the nationwide shortage of contraceptives, including Depo-Provera injections and IUDs, caused by procurement delays, budget constraints, and the suspension of USAID grants.

column1: What are the main health system bottlenecks for providing post-pregnancy family planning?
column2: Bottlenecks include a lack of trained staff, heavy workloads for providers, frequent stock-outs of methods, poor knowledge among some providers, and weak coordination between different levels of the health system.

column1: What are the main demand-side barriers to using family planning in Nepal?
column2: Barriers include fear of side effects, opposition from husbands or family members, religious or cultural misconceptions, and the belief that breastfeeding provides sufficient protection against pregnancy.

column1: Why is there a high unmet need for family planning despite high awareness?
column2: Even though 99% of people know about contraception, unmet need remains high (21%) due to myths about side effects, gender power imbalances, limited method choice at facilities, and poor quality of counseling.

column1: What are the consequences of the contraceptive shortage?
column2: The shortage leads to a rise in unintended pregnancies, unsafe abortions, and maternal and infant mortality, reversing decades of public health progress.

column1: How do gender norms affect family planning use?
column2: Deep-rooted patriarchal norms often mean that men make final decisions on fertility and contraception. Women may lack the agency to demand or use family planning without their partner's consent.

column1: What are the specific family planning challenges for adolescent and young people?
column2: Adolescents face stigma, judgmental attitudes from health workers, lack of youth-friendly services, and confidentiality concerns, which prevent them from accessing the contraception they need.

column1: Are family planning services accessible for people with disabilities?
column2: People with disabilities often face significant physical, communication, and attitudinal barriers when trying to access sexual and reproductive health services, including family planning.

column1: What are the challenges for women in remote areas like the Mountain regions?
column2: Women in remote areas have limited geographic access to health facilities that offer a full range of methods. They often rely on community health workers who may only provide short-acting methods like condoms or pills.

column1: What is "method mix" and why is it a challenge in Nepal?
column2: Method mix refers to the variety of contraceptives available. In Nepal, there is over-reliance on a few methods (female sterilization, injectables). The low use of LARCs like implants and IUDs indicates a gap in providing long-term options.

column1: How does the lack of male involvement pose a challenge?
column2: Male involvement is low, with male sterilization (vasectomy) accounting for less than 1% of contraceptive use. Engaging men as supportive partners and users is a major challenge.

column1: What are the financial barriers to family planning?
column2: While the government provides contraceptives for free, its budget is insufficient. The Family Welfare Division needs NPR 540 million but receives only around NPR 100 million, leading to dependency on donors and procurement problems.

column1: How does the suspension of USAID grants impact family planning?
column2: The suspension has worsened contraceptive shortages, as USAID was a major supplier. It has also increased patient load at government facilities, stretching their limited resources even further.

column1: What are the specific family planning needs of postpartum women?
column2: Postpartum women have a high unmet need. They require counseling and access to methods that are safe for breastfeeding and can be started immediately after childbirth, but often do not receive these services.

column1: What barriers do post-abortion women face in accessing family planning?
column2: Post-abortion women may face stigma, lack of immediate counseling at the facility, and fears about side effects, especially if they were not using contraception before their pregnancy.

column1: How does misinformation about contraceptives act as a barrier?
column2: Widespread myths, such as contraceptives causing cancer or permanent infertility, deter many potential users. This misinformation is often spread through community networks and social media.

column1: What is the "three-tiered government system" and how does it affect family planning?
column2: Nepal's federal system has three tiers: Federal, Provincial, and Local. A challenge is ensuring clear roles, coordination, and budget flow between these levels for effective family planning service delivery.

column1: What is the challenge with the Health Management Information System (HMIS) for family planning?
column2: The HMIS does not always accurately capture data on contraceptive stocks and distribution, making it difficult to forecast needs and prevent stock-outs at the local level.

column1: Are there socio-cultural barriers specific to certain ethnic groups?
column2: Yes, some ethnic and religious communities have pronatalist beliefs (valuing many children) or specific traditions that discourage modern contraceptive use, viewing it as against their culture or God's will.

column1: What is being done to address the family planning challenges?
column2: The government and partners are working to integrate family planning with other health services, train more health workers on LARC insertion, conduct behavior change campaigns to address myths, and improve the supply chain logistics.

column1: When did Nepal start including family planning as part of its national health strategy?
column2: Nepal included family planning as part of its national health strategy in 1959.

column1: What is FP2020 and what is Nepal's involvement in it?
column2: FP2020 is a global initiative launched after the 2012 London Summit on Family Planning to provide voluntary family planning services to 120 million women and girls by 2020. Nepal joined FP2020 in 2015 and committed to identifying and addressing barriers to family planning access.

column1: What percentage of health facilities in Nepal offer contraceptives?
column2: About 98% of health facilities in Nepal offer some type of contraceptives.

column1: What percentage of health facilities in Nepal offer family planning services five days or more per week?
column2: Approximately 97% of health facilities in Nepal provide family planning services five days or more per week.

column1: What is the most popular source for modern contraception methods in Nepal?
column2: The public sector is the most popular source for modern contraception methods in Nepal, serving about 70% of users.

column1: What percentage of modern contraceptive users in Nepal receive services from non-governmental organizations?
column2: Around 6% of modern contraceptive users in Nepal receive their methods from non-governmental organizations.

column1: What percentage of modern contraceptive users in Nepal receive services from the private medical sector?
column2: About 19% of modern contraceptive users in Nepal receive their methods from the private medical sector.

column1: What challenges exist in accessing family planning services in Nepal?
column2: Challenges include inequalities among vulnerable groups, adolescents, and rural residents, shortage of trained health workers, and stock-outs of contraceptives in some areas.

column1: What is the Female Community Health Volunteer Program in Nepal?
column2: The Female Community Health Volunteer Program, established in 1988, connects rural communities with government health services. Over 51,000 volunteers work across all 75 districts focusing on maternal health, child health, and family planning.

column1: What family planning services do Female Community Health Volunteers provide?
column2: Female Community Health Volunteers resupply oral contraceptive pills and provide condoms as part of their role in promoting family planning.

column1: What was Nepal's fertility rate in 1996 and 2016?
column2: Nepal's fertility rate declined from 4.6 births per woman in 1996 to 2.3 births per woman in 2016.

column1: What percentage of women in Nepal have begun childbearing by age 18?
column2: About 21% of women aged 25 to 49 in Nepal have begun childbearing by age 18.

column1: What are the most popular modern contraception methods among married women in Nepal?
column2: Among married women aged 15 to 49, the most popular modern methods are female sterilization (15%), injectables (9%), male sterilization (6%), and oral pills (5%).

column1: How has the use of traditional family planning methods changed in Nepal?
column2: The use of traditional family planning methods increased from 4% in 2006 to 10% in 2016.

column1: At what age group is contraceptive use highest among married women in Nepal?
column2: Contraceptive use is highest among married women aged 35 to 44, with 69% using some form of contraception.

column1: Why do many women in Nepal discontinue contraceptive use within 12 months?
column2: The main reasons are that their husbands are away (47%), fear of side effects or health concerns (18%), and desire to become pregnant (13%).

column1: Why is the use of long-acting and reversible contraceptives low in Nepal?
column2: The use of long-acting and reversible contraceptives is low due to poor awareness, fear of side effects, and misconceptions about safety and fertility.

column1: How is the government addressing low use of long-acting contraceptives in Nepal?
column2: The government is training service providers in long-acting methods and expanding the types of methods offered.

column1: Where are intrauterine devices and implants available in Nepal?
column2: Intrauterine devices and implants are provided in selected primary health centers and health posts with trained health workers.

column1: What are satellite clinics in Nepal's family planning system?
column2: Satellite clinics are outreach centers started by the Family Health Division to improve access to family planning services in rural areas across all 75 districts.

column1: Are family planning services free in Nepal?
column2: Yes, family planning services are free in public hospitals, but private sector services can be expensive in urban areas.

column1: What are common issues faced by the Female Community Health Volunteer Program?
column2: Common issues include frequent stock-outs of contraceptives like condoms and oral pills, limiting continuous use.

column1: How many Female Community Health Volunteers had condoms available during the 2014 survey?
column2: According to the 2014 national survey, 59% of Female Community Health Volunteers had condoms available on the survey day.

column1: How many Female Community Health Volunteers had oral contraceptives available during the 2014 survey?
column2: About 58% of Female Community Health Volunteers had oral contraceptives available during the 2014 survey.

column1: What are the most common temporary family planning methods in Nepal?
column2: The most common temporary family planning methods are male condoms and oral pills.

column1: What level of training is required to provide family planning methods like implants and sterilization?
column2: Implants, intrauterine devices, and sterilization procedures require advanced provider skills and well-equipped facilities.

column1: What is the awareness level of emergency contraception in Nepal?
column2: Only about one-third of married women and half of married men in Nepal have heard of emergency contraception.

column1: What percentage of married women in Nepal have used emergency contraception?
column2: Less than 1% of married women in Nepal have ever used emergency contraception.

column1: When did abortion become legal in Nepal?
column2: Abortion became legal in Nepal in 2002 and has been available throughout the country since 2004.

column1: What percentage of women receive family planning counseling after abortion in Nepal?
column2: Only 44% of women report receiving family planning counseling during the post-abortion period.

column1: What challenges exist in post-abortion family planning services in Nepal?
column2: Post-abortion services often lack coordination between abortion and family planning clinics, leading to low contraceptive use and high discontinuation rates.

column1: What is the impact of migration on family planning in Nepal?
column2: Migration, especially of men, affects family planning use. Wives of migrant husbands have lower contraceptive use and higher unmet need.

column1: What percentage of households in Nepal had at least one migrant in the past 10 years?
column2: About 47% of households in Nepal had at least one migrant in the past 10 years.

column1: What was the unmet need for family planning in Nepal in 2011 and 2016?
column2: Unmet need for family planning decreased from 28% in 2011 to 24% in 2016.

column1: Why is unmet need for family planning high among women with migrant husbands?
column2: Because husbands are away for long periods, women are often counted as having unmet need even if they are not sexually active, and they may not plan contraception before their husbands return.

column1: How do wives of migrant husbands usually prepare for family planning?
column2: Most wives of migrant husbands do not make arrangements before their husbands return, relying on condoms or withdrawal when he is home.

column1: Which methods are commonly used by wives of migrant husbands?
column2: They most commonly use condoms, pills, and injectables, depending on how frequently their husbands return home.

column1: Why do some women stop using family planning methods when their husbands leave?
column2: Many women stop using family planning to avoid rumors of infidelity while their husbands are away.

column1: How does advance notice of a husband’s return affect contraceptive choice?
column2: If a husband informs his wife a month before returning, she is more likely to use pills or injectables. If he informs her only a week before, she is more likely to use condoms or not prepare at all.

column1: When did Nepal start including family planning as part of its national health strategy?
column2: Nepal included family planning as part of its national health strategy in 1959.

column1: What is FP2020 and what is Nepal's involvement in it?
column2: FP2020 is a global initiative launched after the 2012 London Summit on Family Planning to provide voluntary family planning services to 120 million women and girls by 2020. Nepal joined FP2020 in 2015 and committed to identifying and addressing barriers to family planning access.

column1: What percentage of health facilities in Nepal offer contraceptives?
column2: About 98% of health facilities in Nepal offer some type of contraceptives.

column1: What percentage of health facilities in Nepal offer family planning services five days or more per week?
column2: Approximately 97% of health facilities in Nepal provide family planning services five days or more per week.

column1: What is the most popular source for modern contraception methods in Nepal?
column2: The public sector is the most popular source for modern contraception methods in Nepal, serving about 70% of users.

column1: What percentage of modern contraceptive users in Nepal receive services from non-governmental organizations?
column2: Around 6% of modern contraceptive users in Nepal receive their methods from non-governmental organizations.

column1: What percentage of modern contraceptive users in Nepal receive services from the private medical sector?
column2: About 19% of modern contraceptive users in Nepal receive their methods from the private medical sector.

column1: What challenges exist in accessing family planning services in Nepal?
column2: Challenges include inequalities among vulnerable groups, adolescents, and rural residents, shortage of trained health workers, and stock-outs of contraceptives in some areas.

column1: What is the Female Community Health Volunteer Program in Nepal?
column2: The Female Community Health Volunteer Program, established in 1988, connects rural communities with government health services. Over 51,000 volunteers work across all 75 districts focusing on maternal health, child health, and family planning.

column1: What services do Female Community Health Volunteers provide?
column2: Female Community Health Volunteers resupply oral contraceptive pills and provide condoms as part of their role in promoting family planning.

column1: What was Nepal's fertility rate in 1996 and 2016?
column2: Nepal's fertility rate declined from 4.6 births per woman in 1996 to 2.3 births per woman in 2016.

column1: What percentage of women in Nepal have begun childbearing by age 18?
column2: About 21% of women aged 25 to 49 in Nepal have begun childbearing by age 18.

column1: What are the most popular modern contraception methods among married women in Nepal?
column2: Among married women aged 15 to 49, the most popular modern methods are female sterilization (15%), injectables (9%), male sterilization (6%), and oral pills (5%).

column1: How has the use of traditional family planning methods changed in Nepal?
column2: The use of traditional family planning methods increased from 4% in 2006 to 10% in 2016.

column1: At what age group is contraceptive use highest among married women in Nepal?
column2: Contraceptive use is highest among married women aged 35 to 44, with 69% using some form of contraception.

column1: Why do many women in Nepal discontinue contraceptive use within 12 months?
column2: The main reasons are that their husbands are away (47%), fear of side effects or health concerns (18%), and desire to become pregnant (13%).

column1: Why is the use of long-acting and reversible contraceptives low in Nepal?
column2: The use of long-acting and reversible contraceptives is low due to poor awareness, fear of side effects, and misconceptions about safety and fertility.

column1: How is the government addressing low use of long-acting contraceptives in Nepal?
column2: The government is training service providers in long-acting methods and expanding the types of methods offered.

column1: Where are intrauterine devices and implants available in Nepal?
column2: Intrauterine devices and implants are provided in selected primary health centers and health posts with trained health workers.

column1: What are satellite clinics in Nepal's family planning system?
column2: Satellite clinics are outreach centers started by the Family Health Division to improve access to family planning services in rural areas across all 75 districts.

column1: Are family planning services free in Nepal?
column2: Yes, family planning services are free in public hospitals, but private sector services can be expensive in urban areas.

column1: What are common issues faced by the Female Community Health Volunteer Program?
column2: Common issues include frequent stock-outs of contraceptives like condoms and oral pills, limiting continuous use.

column1: How many Female Community Health Volunteers had condoms available during the 2014 survey?
column2: According to the 2014 national survey, 59% of Female Community Health Volunteers had condoms available on the survey day.

column1: How many Female Community Health Volunteers had oral contraceptives available during the 2014 survey?
column2: About 58% of Female Community Health Volunteers had oral contraceptives available during the 2014 survey.

column1: What are the most common temporary family planning methods in Nepal?
column2: The most common temporary family planning methods are male condoms and oral pills.

column1: What level of training is required to provide family planning methods like implants and sterilization?
column2: Implants, intrauterine devices, and sterilization procedures require advanced provider skills and well-equipped facilities.

column2: Only about one-third of married women and half of married men in Nepal have heard of emergency contraception.

column1: What percentage of married women in Nepal have used emergency contraception?
column2: Less than 1% of married women in Nepal have ever used emergency contraception.

column2: Abortion became legal in Nepal in 2002 and has been available throughout the country since 2004.

column2: Migration, especially of men, affects family planning use. Wives of migrant husbands have lower contraceptive use and higher unmet need.

column1: What percentage of households in Nepal had at least one migrant in the past 10 years?
column2: About 47% of households in Nepal had at least one migrant in the past 10 years.

column1: What was the unmet need for family planning in Nepal in 2011 and 2016?
column2: Unmet need for family planning decreased from 28% in 2011 to 24% in 2016.

column1: Why is unmet need for family planning high among women with migrant husbands?
column2: Because husbands are away for long periods, women are often counted as having unmet need even if they are not sexually active, and they may not plan contraception before their husbands return.

column1: How do wives of migrant husbands usually prepare for family planning?
column2: Most wives of migrant husbands do not make arrangements before their husbands return, relying on condoms or withdrawal when he is home.

column1: Which methods are commonly used by wives of migrant husbands?
column2: They most commonly use condoms, pills, and injectables, depending on how frequently their husbands return home.
