column2: If a husband informs his wife a month before returning, she is more likely to use pills or injectables. If he informs her only a week before, she is more likely to use condoms or not prepare at all.

column1: What was the source of the family planning data for Province 1 and nationwide in Nepal?
column2: The data comes from the Nepal Demographic and Health Survey (NDHS) 2016.

column1: What percentage of follow-up respondents knew at least one modern method of family planning?
column2: 100 percent of follow-up respondents knew at least one modern method of family planning.

column1: What proportion of follow-up respondents reported not using any family planning method?
column2: 57.2 percent of follow-up respondents reported not using any family planning method.

column1: What percentage of follow-up respondents used modern methods of family planning?
column2: 20.6 percent of follow-up respondents used modern methods of family planning.

column1: What percentage of follow-up respondents used traditional family planning methods?
column2: 22.2 percent of follow-up respondents used traditional family planning methods.

column1: Which was the most commonly used family planning method among follow-up respondents?
column2: The most commonly used method among follow-up respondents was withdrawal, used by 49.4 percent.

column1: Which modern method was most used by follow-up respondents?
column2: Among modern methods, injectables were the most used by 19.3 percent of follow-up respondents.

column1: What percentage of follow-up respondents used pills as their family planning method?
column2: 18.1 percent of follow-up respondents used pills as their family planning method.

column1: What was the percentage of implant or Norplant users among follow-up respondents?
column2: 4.8 percent of follow-up respondents used implants or Norplant as their family planning method.

column1: How many follow-up respondents used an intrauterine device (IUD)?
column2: 2 follow-up respondents, representing 2.4 percent, used an intrauterine device (IUD).

column1: What was the percentage of condom use among follow-up respondents?
column2: 3.6 percent of follow-up respondents used male condoms as their primary family planning method.

column1: What percentage of follow-up respondents had an unmet need for spacing births?
column2: 19.1 percent of follow-up respondents had an unmet need for spacing births.

column1: What percentage of follow-up respondents had an unmet need for limiting births?
column2: 25.8 percent of follow-up respondents had an unmet need for limiting births.

column1: How did the use of traditional methods in the follow-up study compare to Province 1 and nationwide?
column2: Traditional method use was higher in the follow-up study (22%) compared to Province 1 (17%) and nationwide (14%).

column1: How did modern method use in the follow-up study compare to Province 1 and nationwide?
column2: Modern method use was lower in the follow-up study (21%) compared to Province 1 and nationwide (both 36%).

column1: What is one reason for the lower proportion of modern method users in the follow-up study?
column2: Modern method users were disproportionately undersampled in the follow-up study.

column1: Which methods were excluded from the follow-up study sample?
column2: Users of male and female sterilization were excluded from the survey sample.

column1: What percentage of follow-up respondents were not in need of family planning?
column2: 9.3 percent of follow-up respondents reported no unmet need for family planning.

column1: What percentage of follow-up respondents were infecund or menopausal?
column2: 6.3 percent of follow-up respondents were infecund or menopausal.

column1: According to the NDHS, what percentage of Province 1 respondents used injectables?
column2: 33.6 percent of Province 1 respondents used injectables according to the NDHS.

column1: According to the NDHS, what percentage of respondents nationwide used injectables?
column2: 29.5 percent of respondents nationwide used injectables.

column1: According to the NDHS, what percentage of Province 1 respondents used withdrawal?
column2: 30 percent of Province 1 respondents used withdrawal according to the NDHS.

column1: According to the NDHS, what percentage of respondents nationwide used withdrawal?
column2: 25.5 percent of respondents nationwide used withdrawal according to the NDHS.

column1: What was the total number of follow-up respondents in the family planning study?
column2: The total number of follow-up respondents was 194.

column1: How many follow-up respondents were family planning users?
column2: 83 follow-up respondents were users of family planning methods.

column1: According to Table 3.5, what was the most common secondary method among follow-up respondents?
column2: The most common secondary method was withdrawal, used by 7 respondents.

column1: What was the percentage of respondents using no secondary method?
column2: 95.4 percent (185 of 194) used no secondary method.

column1: Which secondary methods were least reported among follow-up respondents?
column2: Male condom and periodic abstinence were the least reported secondary methods, each used by one respondent.

column1: What percentage of respondents used injectables as their primary method in Table 3.5?
column2: 9.3 percent of respondents used injectables as their primary method in Table 3.5.

column1: What percentage of respondents used withdrawal as their primary method according to Table 3.5?
column2: 24.2 percent of respondents used withdrawal as their primary method according to Table 3.5.

column1: How many respondents reported not using any method according to Table 3.5?
column2: 99 respondents reported not using any method according to Table 3.5.

column1: What percentage of respondents reported not using any method in Table 3.5?
column2: 51 percent of respondents reported not using any method in Table 3.5.

column1: What misunderstanding about traditional methods was revealed in the follow-up interviews?
column2: Many respondents did not consider traditional methods like withdrawal or periodic abstinence as 'family planning methods'.

column1: What was one reason respondents did not report using traditional methods in the NDHS?
column2: Respondents often believed that traditional methods did not count as 'family planning' methods.

column1: How did the number of nonusers change between the NDHS and the follow-up study?
column2: The number of nonusers decreased from 111 in the NDHS to 99 in the follow-up study.

column1: Which traditional methods were often underreported in the NDHS?
column2: Withdrawal and periodic abstinence were often underreported in the NDHS.

column1: What percentage of women reported using withdrawal in the NDHS compared to the follow-up study?
column2: 41 women reported using withdrawal in the NDHS, compared to 47 in the follow-up study.

column1: What common Nepali terms were used to refer to the withdrawal method?
column2: Respondents used phrases like 'letting it out,' 'throwing it out,' 'taking it out,' or 'being careful' to describe withdrawal.

column1: What was one cultural or linguistic reason for underreporting withdrawal use?
column2: There is no direct word for 'withdrawal' in the Nepali language, leading to confusion during interviews.

column1: How many women in the NDHS who said they were nonusers later reported using withdrawal?
column2: Eight women who initially said they were nonusers later reported using withdrawal.

column1: How many women who said they were nonusers later reported using periodic abstinence?
column2: Two women who initially said they were nonusers later reported using periodic abstinence.

column1: How many of these women started using the methods between the NDHS and follow-up interview?
column2: Only one of these women started using the method between the NDHS and follow-up interview.

column1: Which previous studies support similar findings of underreporting traditional methods?
column2: Studies in Ghana (Staveteig 2016, 2017) and Burkina Faso (Rossier et al., 2014) found similar underreporting.

column1: Can family planning methods make women permanently sterile?
column2: No. Most methods are temporary and fertility returns after stopping them. Only sterilization is permanent.

column1: Is it true that IUDs can move around the body?
column2: No. An IUD stays safely inside the uterus and cannot travel to other parts of the body.

column1: Are contraceptive methods available free of cost in Nepal?
column2: Yes. Most contraceptive methods like condoms, pills, injectables, IUDs, and sterilization are available free at government health posts and hospitals.

column1: Do education and wealth influence contraceptive use?
column2: Yes. Women with higher education and higher income are more likely to use modern family planning methods.

column1: How does family planning help Nepal’s national goals?
column2: Family planning supports Nepal’s Sustainable Development Goals and the Nepal Health Sector Strategy 2016–2021 by improving maternal and child health.

column1: Which organizations conduct family planning and health surveys in Nepal?
column2: The Ministry of Health, New ERA, and The DHS Program (USAID-funded) conduct the Nepal Demographic and Health Survey.

column1: How many Nepali women use contraceptives?
column2: As of 2019, around 47% of Nepali women aged 15 to 49 use either permanent or temporary contraceptive methods.

column1: Which contraceptive methods are most common among Nepali women?
column2: Female sterilization, injectables, birth control pills, implants, and IUDs are commonly used by women in Nepal.

column1: Do more women or men use contraceptives in Nepal?
column2: Women overwhelmingly use contraceptives more than men. Only about 10% of men had undergone sterilization, compared to 28% of women."

column1: Why do experts say women bear more of the contraceptive burden in Nepal?
column2: Most available contraceptive methods are designed for women and involve invasive procedures such as injections or implants, while men have limited temporary options beyond condoms.

column1: What are some common side effects of contraceptive use among women?
column2: Women report side effects such as mood changes, weight gain, nausea, migraines, irregular periods, and thinning hair. In rare cases, hormonal methods may lead to depression, anxiety, or heart problems.

column1: Do all women experience severe side effects from contraceptives?
column2: No. According to gynecologist Dr. Heera Tuladhar, fewer than 10% of women experience severe side effects, but minor effects still affect quality of life.

column1: Are emotional effects of contraceptives often studied in Nepal?
column2: No. Emotional and psychological impacts, such as mood changes and social stigma, are rarely researched or discussed in Nepal.

column1: Is there stigma around using contraceptives in Nepal?
column2: Yes. Talking about contraceptives, especially for unmarried women, is still considered taboo. Many women fear judgment or discrimination from society and even healthcare providers.

column1: Why do unmarried women in Nepal face barriers to contraception?
column2: Unmarried women often face shame or moral judgment when seeking contraceptive advice, making it difficult for them to access reproductive healthcare.

column1: Why is it important to study the emotional burden of contraceptive use?
column2: Because contraceptive use affects not only physical health but also emotional well-being, sexual satisfaction, and social relationships, which are often ignored in research and policy.

column1: What role should healthcare providers play in family planning services?
column2: Healthcare providers should listen to patients without bias, respect unmarried women's choices, and focus on the comfort and informed consent of contraceptive users.

column1: Is access to contraceptives equal across Nepal?
column2: No. Some rural or marginalized areas still have limited access to contraceptive supplies and counseling services.

column1: Are male contraceptive options in Nepal limited?
column2: Yes. Apart from condoms and vasectomy, there are no temporary male contraceptive methods available in Nepal.

column1: How can Nepal improve family planning equality between men and women?
column2: By promoting male involvement in family planning, investing in male contraceptive research, and reducing social stigma around male participation.

column1: What is the total fertility rate in Nepal?
column2: According to NDHS 2022, the total fertility rate in Nepal is 2.1 children per woman.

column1: Has fertility in Nepal decreased in recent years?
column2: Yes. According to NDHS 2022, fertility declined from 2.3 children per woman in 2016 to 2.1 in 2022, showing a gradual decline.

column1: Which province has the highest fertility rate?
column2: According to NDHS 2022, Karnali Province has the highest fertility rate at 3.0 children per woman.

column1: Which province has the lowest fertility rate?
column2: According to NDHS 2022, Bagmati Province has the lowest fertility rate at 1.6 children per woman.

column1: What percentage of currently married women use any method of contraception?
column2: According to NDHS 2022, 57% of currently married women in Nepal use a family planning method.

column1: What proportion of women use modern methods?
column2: According to NDHS 2022, 43.8% of married women use modern contraceptive methods.

column1: What are the most common modern contraceptive methods?
column2: According to NDHS 2022, the most common modern methods are injectables (13%), female sterilization (10%), implants (8%), male sterilization (4%), and pills (3%).

column1: What are the main traditional methods?
column2: According to NDHS 2022, the main traditional methods are withdrawal (10%) and rhythm/calendar methods (3%).

column1: What is the unmet need for family planning?
column2: According to NDHS 2022, 20% of married women have an unmet need for family planning — about 1 in 5 women who wish to avoid pregnancy are not using contraception.

column1: What is the demand satisfied by modern methods?
column2: According to NDHS 2022, about 68% of the total family planning demand is satisfied by modern contraceptive methods.

column1: Which province has the highest contraceptive use?
column2: According to NDHS 2022, Bagmati Province has the highest contraceptive use at 63%.

column1: Which province has the lowest contraceptive use?
column2: According to NDHS 2022, Karnali Province has the lowest contraceptive use at 46%.

column1: What percentage of teenagers have begun childbearing?
column2: According to NDHS 2022, 14% of teenage girls (15–19 years) have begun childbearing — 11% have had a live birth and 3% are pregnant.

column1: Which province has the highest teenage pregnancy?
column2: According to NDHS 2022, teenage pregnancy is highest in Karnali (21%) and Madhesh (20%).

column1: Which province has the lowest teenage pregnancy?
column2: According to NDHS 2022, Bagmati Province has the lowest teenage pregnancy rate at 8%.

column1: Do urban and rural fertility levels differ?
column2: Yes. According to NDHS 2022, urban women have 1.9 children on average, while rural women have 2.4.

column1: Does education affect fertility?
column2: Yes. According to NDHS 2022, women with no education have 3.1 children, while those with secondary or higher education have 1.8.

column1: What is the average desired family size?
column2: According to NDHS 2022, Nepali women desire 2.2 children, while men prefer 2.3.

column1: How has adolescent fertility changed since 2016?
column2: According to NDHS 2022, adolescent fertility dropped from 88 to 73 births per 1,000 women aged 15–19.

column1: What proportion of married women wish to have no more children?
column2: According to NDHS 2022, 55% of married women say they want no more children.

column1: What percentage want to delay their next birth?
column2: About 21% of married women want to delay their next birth for at least two years.

column1: Where do women obtain contraceptives?
column2: According to NDHS 2022, 72% of modern contraceptives are provided by government health facilities, and 25% from private or NGO facilities.

column1: What percentage of women heard about family planning through media?
column2: About 40% of women heard about family planning via radio, TV, or social media in recent months.

column1: Do most couples communicate about family planning?
column2: Yes. According to NDHS 2022, 79% of married women said their husbands know whether they use contraception.

column1: What percentage of women rely on sterilization?
column2: According to NDHS 2022, female sterilization (10%) and male sterilization (4%) are common permanent methods.

column1: How satisfied are women with family planning services in Nepal?
column2: According to NDHS 2022, most women reported satisfaction with family planning services, though access remains unequal in remote areas.

column1: What is Nepal’s national goal for fertility under SDG 3.7.1?
column2: According to NDHS 2022, Nepal’s target is to maintain a total fertility rate of 2.1 births per woman by 2030.

column1: What are the most common reasons for not using contraception?
column2: According to NDHS 2022, common reasons include concern about side effects, infrequent sex, and opposition from partners.

column1: What is NDHS?
column2: NDHS stands for the Nepal Demographic and Health Survey. It is a large national survey that collects information about fertility, family planning, child health, maternal health, and nutrition to guide government policies and programs.

column1: Who conducts the NDHS survey?
column2: The NDHS is conducted by Nepal’s Ministry of Health and Population (MoHP) in collaboration with New ERA and ICF International, with support from USAID. It follows international DHS standards to ensure reliable and comparable data.

column1: How often is NDHS conducted in Nepal?
column2: NDHS is usually carried out every five years. Past surveys were done in 1996, 2001, 2006, 2011, 2016, and 2022.

column1: Why is NDHS data important?
column2: NDHS data helps the government and health partners plan family health programs, improve services, and track progress toward national and global goals like the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

column1: Why do you use NDHS 2022 data only?
column2: The NDHS 2022 is the latest official national survey on health, fertility, and family planning in Nepal. NDHS surveys are conducted roughly every five years, so 2022 remains the most recent verified data available. The next survey is expected around 2027.

column1: When will NDHS be updated again?
column2: NDHS surveys are done every five years. Since the last one was in 2022, the next NDHS is expected in 2027. Once it’s published, national indicators will be updated.

column1: What target has Nepal committed to for the modern contraceptive prevalence rate (mCPR) by 2030?
column2: Nepal has committed to increasing the modern contraceptive prevalence rate to about 60–70% by 2030, depending on the population group measured.

column1: How many women in Nepal were estimated to be using modern contraception in 2023?
column2: Around 3.26 million women in Nepal were estimated to be using modern methods of contraception in 2023.

column1: What was the estimated modern contraceptive prevalence rate (mCPR) in Nepal in 2023?
column2: The 2023 Track20 statistical model estimated Nepal’s mCPR at around 36% among all women of reproductive age.

column1: What baseline and target mCPR values were listed in Nepal’s FP2030 commitment form?
column2: The commitment form lists a baseline mCPR of about 44% in 2019, with a goal of reaching 60% or higher by 2030.

column1: What is Nepal’s family planning commitment for 2030?
column2: Nepal has committed to reach 60–70% modern contraceptive use by 2030.,"FP2030 Commitment Document

column1: What is the timeframe by which local and provincial governments are expected to build capacity for FP stewardship under Nepal’s Plan?
column2: The capacity development of local and provincial governments is a primary focus until 2025 under the Plan’s implementation framework. (Source: National Family Planning Costed Implementation Plan 2024-2030 and HIPs, 2025-11-08)

column1: How is financing handled in the 2024-2030 Plan?
column2: The Plan is costed — meaning resources are specified (or will be) for delivering planned family-planning services, scaling up HIPs, monitoring & evaluation, and capacity strengthening across levels of government. (Source: National Family Planning Costed Implementation Plan 2024-2030 and HIPs, 2025-11-08)"

column1: What is the rationale for needing this updated implementation plan (2024-2030) in Nepal?
column2: Because of persistent unmet need, method‐mix gaps, and a federalised health system context, the country needs a rights‐based, costed roadmap to achieve its 2030 family-planning commitments.","National Family Planning Costed Implementation Plan 2024-2030 and HIPs","2025-11-08"

column1: What role do High Impact Practices (HIPs) play in the 2024-2030 Plan?
column2: HIPs are evidence-based practices identified in the Plan to accelerate family‐planning impact, and their scaling-up is integrated into the costed implementation plan.","National Family Planning Costed Implementation Plan 2024-2030 and HIPs","2025-11-08"

column1: What is a key focus for improving access in marginalized populations according to the Plan?
column2: Ensuring that underserved, remote, and socio‐economically disadvantaged populations receive family-planning services, with special efforts to reduce inequities.","National Family Planning Costed Implementation Plan 2024-2030 and HIPs","2025-11-08"

column1: In Nepal’s CIP 2024-2030, which levels of government are emphasised for stewardship and implementation of family planning?
column2: The federal, provincial and local government levels are emphasised for stewardship, financing, monitoring and implementation of family‐planning services.","National Family Planning Costed Implementation Plan 2024-2030 and HIPs","2025-11-08"

column1: What is one of the primary objectives of the 2024-2030 Plan regarding service delivery?
column2: To expand access to quality family‐planning services across federal, provincial and local levels, ensuring method choice and equity.","National Family Planning Costed Implementation Plan 2024-2030 and HIPs","2025-11-08

column1: What are the two main documents combined in Nepal’s 2024-2030 family-planning roadmap?
column2: According to the study by National Family Planning Costed Implementation Plan 2024-2030 and HIPs, 2025-11-08) The Costed Implementation Plan and a set of High Impact Practices (HIPs) for family planning in Nepal.

column1: What strategic period does Nepal’s Family Planning Costed Implementation Plan cover?
column2: The plan covers the years 2024 to 2030. (Source: National Family Planning Costed Implementation Plan 2024-2030 and HIPs, 2025-11-08)

column1: What is the vision stated in Nepal’s Costed Implementation Plan (2024-2030) for family planning?
column2: By 2030, Nepal envisions that every individual and family will lead a healthy, happy and prosperous life, fully exercising their sexual and reproductive health and rights. (Source: National Family Planning Costed Implementation Plan 2024-2030 and HIPs, 2025-11-08)

column1: What is FP2030?
column2: FP2030 is a global partnership that supports countries in improving access to family planning services. It helps governments, health workers, and communities make sure people can choose if and when they want to have children, safely and freely. FP2030 also provides data, funding support, and shared goals to help countries like Nepal increase access to modern contraception by the year 2030.

column1: Is community-level family planning service delivery included in the commitment?
column2: Yes, Nepal emphasizes community-based distribution and counseling services to reach women in rural areas.

column1: Does Nepal emphasize adolescent and youth reproductive health in FP2030?
column2: Yes, Nepal’s commitment includes improving access to contraceptive information and services for adolescents and young people.

column1: Which government body leads family planning efforts in Nepal?
column2: The Ministry of Health and Population leads, specifically the Family Welfare Division and Reproductive Health Unit.

column1: What is Nepal trying to reduce through its FP2030 commitment?
column2: Nepal is committed to reducing unmet need for family planning and ensuring access to modern methods for all.

column1: What is Nepal’s main FP2030 goal for contraceptive use?
column2: Nepal aims to increase modern contraceptive prevalence to around 60–70% by 2030.,

column1: Why is family planning important in Nepal?
column2: Family planning helps reduce unplanned pregnancies, improves maternal health, and supports economic stability for families and communities.

column1: What age should people start learning about family planning?
column2: It’s good to start learning in teenage years, around 15–19, to build awareness before becoming sexually active.

column1: Is it okay to talk about contraception in school or with teachers?
column2: Yes, open discussions help reduce myths and promote healthy, informed decisions.

column1: Why do some people in villages still avoid using contraceptives?
column2: Many still believe in myths or lack access to reliable information and services.

column1: Are all contraceptive methods free in Nepal?
column2: Most are free in government health posts and hospitals, thanks to the National Family Planning Program.

column1: Does using birth control pills affect future pregnancy chances?
column2: No, fertility usually returns quickly after stopping the pills.

column1: Can men also take responsibility for family planning?
column2: Yes, men can use condoms or undergo vasectomy, and support their partners in making decisions.

column1: Is it true that condoms can break easily?
column2: Only if used incorrectly. Proper use and storage make them 98% effective.

column1: Are there any long-term methods for women who already have children?
column2: Yes, IUDs and implants provide protection for 3–10 years without daily effort.

column1: What should I do if I forget to take my pill?
column2: Take it as soon as you remember, and use a backup method like condoms for the next 7 days.

column1: Are emergency contraceptives safe?
column2: Yes, they are safe for occasional use but should not replace regular contraception.

column1: Do health workers keep my information private if I ask about contraception?
column2: Yes, your privacy and confidentiality are always respected in health facilities.

column1: Can contraceptives protect me from sexually transmitted infections (STIs)?
column2: Only condoms protect against both pregnancy and STIs.

column1: Is it harmful to use contraceptives before having children?
column2: No, it’s completely safe and does not cause infertility.

column1: Why do some people believe contraceptives cause weight gain?
column2: Some hormonal methods may cause temporary changes, but not permanent weight gain.

column1: How do I convince my partner to use protection?
column2: Start an honest conversation about shared responsibility and mutual health benefits.

column1: Are there any mobile apps in Nepal for family planning information?
column2: Yes, organizations like FPAN and UNFPA have digital tools and helplines for youth.

column1: What if my family doesn’t support me learning about contraception?
column2: You can seek youth-friendly services or confidential counseling at local health posts.

column1: Can I stop using contraception anytime I want?
column2: Yes, most methods are reversible; you can stop when ready to plan a pregnancy.

column1: How can I find out which contraceptive method is best for me?
column2: Visit a health post or FCHV who can help based on your age, health, and lifestyle.

column1: Are natural methods like the calendar method effective?
column2: They can work but are less reliable (around 75% effective) compared to modern methods.

column1: Is it safe to get an implant or IUD in rural areas?
column2: Yes, trained health workers provide safe insertion and removal services even in rural clinics.

column1: Can a breastfeeding mother use contraception?
column2: Yes, methods like condoms, implants, and certain pills are safe for breastfeeding mothers.

column1: Does family planning also help reduce poverty?
column2: Yes, families who plan children can manage resources better, improving education and living standards.

column1: How many people in Nepal currently use contraceptives?
column2: Around 58% of married women use some form of contraception according to NDHS 2022.

column1: Why do some couples still have large families despite education?
column2: Cultural preferences for sons and limited access to services influence family size.

column1: Can unmarried people use contraceptives?
column2: Yes, contraception is for anyone who wants to prevent unwanted pregnancy or plan safely.

column1: What if I’m embarrassed to buy condoms?
column2: You can get them from health posts, NGOs, or vending machines anonymously in some places.

column1: Are there any side effects of injectables?
column2: Some may cause irregular bleeding or mood changes, but most women adjust over time.

column1: Why should young people care about family planning?
column2: Because it helps prevent early pregnancies, keeps education on track, and supports a healthy future.

column1: What is the main government body responsible for family planning in Nepal?
column2: The Ministry of Health’s Family Health Division (FHD) leads the National Family Planning Program.

column1: How is family planning integrated into Nepal’s health system?
column2: It is part of the country’s basic health service package and available free of charge at all public health facilities and through community-based outreach.

column1: What short-acting contraceptive methods are commonly available in Nepal?
column2: Pills, condoms, and injectables are available year-round at peripheral health facilities.

column1: Who provides family planning counseling and supplies at the village level?
column2: Female Community Health Volunteers (FCHVs) provide counseling, resupply pills and condoms, and refer clients for other services.

column1: What long-acting family planning methods are available in Nepal?
column2: Long-acting methods such as intrauterine devices (IUCDs) and implants are available at higher-level centers or outreach camps.

column1: Are family planning services free in Nepal?
column2: Yes, all methods are free under the essential health package, and women even receive small compensation for voluntary sterilization.

column1: What is the purpose of 'visiting provider' teams in Nepal’s family planning program?
column2: They deliver contraceptive supplies and services to remote areas, often funded by UNFPA or DFID.

column1: What right related to family planning is guaranteed by Nepal’s Constitution?
column2: The 2015 Constitution recognizes reproductive health, including family planning, as a fundamental right.

column1: What are Nepal’s key family planning goals under the 2015–2020 Costed Implementation Plan (CIP)?
column2: To raise modern contraceptive prevalence rate (mCPR) from 47% to 50%, meet 62.9% of demand, reduce unmet need to 22%, and achieve replacement-level fertility (TFR 2.1) by 2021.

column1: How much budget was allocated for Nepal’s Family Planning CIP 2015–2020?
column2: About NPR 13,765 million (USD 154 million) shared between the government and development partners.

column1: What are the priorities of Nepal’s new FP2030 and CIP (2024–2030) commitments?
column2: They focus on adolescents and youth, commodity security, and strengthening community-level distribution.

column1: How are family planning and maternal health linked in Nepal?
column2: FP efforts are integrated with maternal and newborn care, including postpartum and post-abortion family planning counseling.

column1: What is Nepal’s total fertility rate (TFR) as of 2022?
column2: Around 2.1 children per woman, approaching replacement level fertility.

column1: What is the contraceptive prevalence rate (CPR) among married women in Nepal (2022)?
column2: About 57% of married women use some form of contraception, with 43% using modern methods.

column1: What percentage of married women in Nepal have an unmet need for family planning?
column2: Around 21% of married women have an unmet need for family planning services.

column1: How has Nepal’s fertility rate changed over time?
column2: The total fertility rate dropped from 4.8 children per woman in 1998 to 2.1 in 2022.

column1: How has the unmet need for family planning changed since 1996?
column2: It has decreased from 32% in 1996 to around 21% in 2022.

column1: Which areas in Nepal have the lowest contraceptive use?
column2: Mountainous Karnali Province and southern Madhesh Province show lower contraceptive use due to early marriage and cultural barriers.

column1: Which population group in Nepal has the lowest family planning use?
column2: Muslim women, with only about 33% using any family planning method.

column1: What inequities exist in family planning use in Nepal?
column2: Rural, low-education, and poorer populations use contraception less than urban and wealthier groups.

column1: What is the Family Planning Association of Nepal (FPAN) and what does it do?
column2: FPAN, established in 1959, is the IPPF affiliate that runs clinics in about 37 districts and delivers around 25–30% of NGO-provided FP services.

column1: What services does FPAN provide?
column2: It offers counseling, contraception, safe abortion, and youth reproductive health services.

column1: What role does Marie Stopes International (Sunaulo Parivar) play in Nepal?
column2: It operates clinics and mobile teams providing contraception, safe abortion, and maternal care, performing about 28% of all sterilizations in Nepal.

column1: What are some other NGOs supporting family planning in Nepal?
column2: ADRA, CARE, Save the Children, and others run outreach and counseling programs in partnership with government teams.

column1: What is the role of UNFPA in Nepal’s family planning program?
column2: UNFPA provides free contraceptive supplies, technical assistance, and funding support, and helps run outreach in hard-to-reach districts.

column1: Which donors support Nepal’s family planning supply chain and logistics?
column2: USAID supports the Global Health Supply Chain Program, which supplied over 23 million contraceptives between FY2017–2022.

column1: What impact did USAID’s contraceptive support have?
column2: It provided around 1.6 million couple-years of protection through supply and distribution support.

column1: Which countries and donors co-fund Nepal’s maternal and family health programs?
column2: The UK (FCDO/DFID), Global Financing Facility (GFF), Japan, and Korea contribute to Nepal’s reproductive health programs.

column1: What global commitment framework guides Nepal’s family planning goals?
column2: Nepal participates in the FP2030 global partnership, aligning with international targets for access and reproductive health.

column1: What are some of the key indicators of Nepal’s progress in family planning?
column2: TFR: 2.1; CPR: 57%; modern CPR: 43%; unmet need: 21% (NDHS 2022).

column1: What overall progress has Nepal made in family planning?
column2: Nepal has made steady progress through government leadership, NGO partnerships, and international support, though regional and social gaps remain.

column1: What is FPAN's contribution to family planning services in Nepal?
column2: FPAN provides about 25–30% of the total family planning services in Nepal.

column1: In how many districts of Nepal does FPAN currently operate?
column2: FPAN serves nearly half of Nepal’s 75 districts.

column1: Which areas of Nepal does FPAN mainly focus on?
column2: FPAN primarily works in the southern flatlands where the population is more concentrated.

column1: What types of services does FPAN provide?
column2: FPAN provides a wide range of primary and reproductive health care services including contraceptive counseling, infertility treatment, immunization, and general health check-ups.

column1: Does FPAN offer abortion services?
column2: Yes, FPAN provides safe and legal abortion services.

column1: Why is FPAN’s presence important in Nepal’s southern flatlands?
column2: Because the population is dense in that region, making access to family planning and health services more necessary.

column1: What kind of counseling does FPAN provide?
column2: FPAN offers contraceptive counseling to help individuals and couples make informed reproductive health choices.

column1: Besides family planning, what other health services does FPAN provide?
column2: FPAN also provides general health check-ups, immunization, infertility diagnosis, and treatment services.

column1: How does FPAN support reproductive health in Nepal?
column2: By offering education, counseling, and access to modern family planning methods and healthcare facilities.

column1: What is the overall goal of FPAN’s services?
column2: FPAN aims to improve reproductive health, reduce unintended pregnancies, and promote family well-being across Nepal.

column1: What does the CIP stand for in the context of family planning in Nepal?
column2: CIP stands for Costed Implementation Plan.

column1: What is the main goal of Nepal’s Costed Implementation Plan (CIP) for Family Planning?
column2: The CIP aims to scale up rights-based family planning in Nepal by focusing on strategic areas that improve access, quality, and equity.

column1: What are the five strategic areas of focus in the CIP?
column2: The five areas are Enabling Environment, Demand Generation, Service Delivery, Capacity Building, and Research & Innovation.

column1: How does the CIP plan to increase demand satisfied for modern contraceptives?
column2: It aims to raise the percentage from 56% (NDHS 2011) to 62.9% by 2020.

column1: What is the target increase in the Contraceptive Prevalence Rate (CPR) for modern methods?
column2: The goal is to increase CPR from 47% in 2014 to 50% by 2020.

column1: What is Nepal’s goal for reducing the unmet need for family planning according to the CIP?
column2: The plan aims to reduce unmet need from 25.2% in 2014 to 22%.

column1: What fertility level does Nepal aim to achieve through the CIP?
column2: Nepal aims to reach a replacement-level fertility rate of 2.1 births per woman by 2021.

column1: Why were the targets in the CIP described as modest?
column2: Because although Nepal made progress in family planning, the CPR has remained stagnant in recent years.

column1: What inequalities in family planning use does the CIP acknowledge?
column2: There are significant variations by age, geographic region, wealth, and spousal separation.

column1: Who are the main focus groups of the CIP?
column2: The strategy focuses on the poor, vulnerable, and marginalized groups to ensure equal access to contraceptive choices.

column1: What changes in contraceptive methods does the strategy promote?
column2: It encourages a balanced method mix between permanent, long-acting reversible, and short-acting methods.

column1: What is the total estimated cost for scaling up family planning in Nepal from 2015 to 2020?
column2: The total required resources are NPR 13,765.2 million (approximately USD 154.2 million) over six years.

column1: What percentage of the total budget is allocated for direct FP service delivery?
column2: About 57% of the total cost is for delivering family planning interventions.

column1: What percentage of the total cost is for program-level activities?
column2: Around 35% of the total is for program costs, such as awareness and implementation activities.

column1: What portion of the budget covers indirect costs like administration and utilities?
column2: About 8% of the total cost is allocated to indirect expenses such as health facility overhead and utilities.

column1: How does the CIP aim to strengthen Nepal’s family planning system overall?
column2: By improving service delivery, investing in research and innovation, and ensuring family planning services reach all population groups fairly.

column1: What is the largest planned expenditure category among the program costs?
column2: Enhancing Service Delivery, with a planned expenditure of 1,836.9 million NPR.

column1: Which category has the second-highest planned expenditure?
column2: Demand Generation, with 738.4 million NPR.

column1: How much is allocated for Capacity Building?
column2: 793.8 million NPR is planned for Capacity Building.

column1: What is the planned expenditure for Enabling Environment?
column2: 679.2 million NPR.

column1: How much funding is allocated for General Programme Management?
column2: 303.1 million NPR.

column1: What is the budget for Research and Innovation in the family planning scale-up program?
column2: 446.3 million NPR.

column1: What is the total projected expenditure for program costs under the family planning scale-up?
column2: The total is 4,797.7 million NPR.

column1: How will scaling up family planning affect maternal mortality in Nepal?
column2: It is estimated to reduce maternal deaths by about 230 each year by 2030.

column1: What is the expected impact of FP scale-up on infant mortality?
column2: Approximately 3,000 fewer infant deaths are projected each year by 2030.

column1: What does CYP stand for in the context of family planning?
column2: CYP stands for Couple Years of Protection, a measure of contraceptive coverage over time.

column1: What is the projected number of Couple Years of Protection (CYPs) by 2030?
column2: About 2.9 million CYPs are expected under the FP scale-up scenario.

column1: How will the FP scale-up affect Nepal’s population size by 2030?
column2: The population is projected to reach 32 million under FP scale-up, compared to 33.5 million without it.

column1: What is the expected change in dependency ratio due to FP scale-up?
column2: The dependency ratio is expected to be lower, contributing to higher economic productivity.

column1: By how much is Nepal’s income per capita projected to increase by 2030 due to FP scale-up?
column2: Income per capita is expected to be 4.6% higher due to the demographic dividend.

column1: How will slower population growth benefit the government financially?
column2: It leads to cost savings as fewer people require social services.

column1: What is the estimated total cost savings from 2015 to 2030 under FP scale-up?
column2: A cumulative cost savings of 46,569.9 million NPR is projected compared to the alternative scenario.

column1: In which sectors will these cost savings occur?
column2: Primary education, child immunization, treatment of child pneumonia, maternal health services, and improved water sources.

column1: For every rupee spent on family planning, how much will Nepal save?
column2: Nepal is projected to save 3.1 rupees in key social sectors for every rupee spent.

column1: Are there additional benefits beyond the mentioned sectors?
column2: Yes, including better pregnancy outcomes, reduced unsafe abortions, improved HIV/STI prevention, social service savings, climate benefits, and enhanced gender equality.

column1: How does FP scale-up contribute to women’s empowerment?
column2: By reducing unintended pregnancies and improving access to reproductive health services, it supports women’s rights, empowerment, and gender equality.

column1: What are some major factors behind the decline in fertility in Nepal?
column2: Increased age at marriage, better access to girls’ education, a lower ideal number of children, and improved access to modern contraception.

column1: How has the ideal number of children among women changed over time?
column2: It declined from 2.9 in 1996 to 2.1 in 2011 according to the Nepal Demographic and Health Survey (NDHS).

column1: What role does girls’ education play in reducing fertility rates?
column2: Educated girls tend to marry later and make informed decisions about family planning, contributing to lower fertility rates.

column1: What percentage of Nepal’s population is under the age of 15?
column2: About 37% of the population is under 15 years old, down from 41% in 2006.

column1: What percentage of the population is under the age of five?
column2: Around 11% of the population is under five years old, showing a decline since 2006.

column1: What does the decline in the under-five population indicate?
column2: It indicates a continuing decline in fertility and birth rates.

column1: What proportion of the population is 65 years and older?
column2: People aged 65 and older make up about 6% of the total population, up from 4% in 2006.

column1: Where is the decline in fertility more evident, urban or rural areas?
column2: The decline is more noticeable in urban areas, suggesting the fertility transition began there.

column1: What is the main difference in fertility trends between urban and rural Nepal?
column2: Urban areas have experienced faster fertility decline, while rural areas are transitioning more slowly.

column1: How many Nepalese of working age currently live abroad?
column2: About 2 million people aged 15–59 live abroad, up from 760,000 in 2001.

column1: What percentage of households have at least one member living abroad?
column2: Around 25% of households report at least one member living outside the country.

column1: What percentage of households reported migration in the past 10 years?
column2: About 57% of households reported that at least one person had migrated in the past decade.

column1: On average, how many people migrate from households that reported migration?
column2: On average, about two people migrate from each such household.

column1: How has the rate of female-headed households changed over time?
column2: It increased from 15% in 2001 to 23% in 2006 and 26% in 2011.

column1: Why has the number of female-headed households increased?
column2: Because many working-age men have migrated abroad, leaving women to manage households.

column1: What overall demographic trend does the data suggest for Nepal?
column2: Nepal is experiencing a demographic transition with lower fertility, smaller household sizes, and more aging population.

column1: What does the fertility decline imply for Nepal’s development?
column2: It indicates social progress, with better education, health access, and family planning awareness contributing to smaller, healthier families.

column1: How much did Nepal’s contraceptive prevalence rate (CPR) for modern methods increase between 2001 and 2014?
column2: It increased from 35% in 2001 to 43% in 2011 (NDHS) and 47.1% in 2014 (MICS).

column1: Has access to modern contraceptive services become universal in Nepal?
column2: No, access to modern contraceptive services is still not universal and varies across different regions.

column1: Which region of Nepal has the highest contraceptive prevalence rate?
column2: The Far Western Terai region, with a rate of 55.1%.

column1: Which region has the lowest contraceptive prevalence rate?
column2: The Eastern Hill region, with only 32%.

column1: What are some key factors affecting access to family planning services in Nepal?
column2: Factors include the availability and capacity of service providers, availability of supplies, cultural and social beliefs, and the accessibility of health facilities.

column1: What action is recommended to improve FP service utilization in low-coverage areas?
column2: District-level analysis of service delivery and community needs should be conducted to address regional disparities.

column1: What inequality exists between wealth groups in modern contraceptive use?
column2: The poorest quintile has a 35.6% use rate, while the richest quintile has 48.9%.

column1: How does contraceptive use differ between rural and urban areas?
column2: Rural areas have lower overall contraceptive use but higher sterilization rates, while urban women more often use pills, condoms, and traditional methods.

column1: How does migration affect family planning data in Nepal?
column2: Because many husbands live abroad, some married women are not currently using contraceptives, which lowers the overall CPR despite actual need.

column1: What is the CPR among married women living with their husbands?
column2: It is 55.5%, indicating higher contraceptive use when husbands are present.

column1: Why should women whose husbands are away not be excluded from FP programs?
column2: They may need contraceptives when their husbands return, so their needs should be considered in FP planning.

column1: What was Nepal’s demand satisfied for modern contraceptive methods according to NDHS 2011?
column2: It was 56%.

column1: What is the national target for demand satisfied for modern contraceptives?
column2: The goal is to reach 75%.

column1: Which regions have the lowest levels of demand satisfied for modern contraceptives?
column2: Western Hill, Eastern Hill, and Eastern Mountain regions.

column1: Which groups have the lowest demand satisfied for modern contraceptive methods?
column2: Adolescent girls (24.3%), women in the Eastern Hills (42.7%), Western Hill (44.2%), and those in the lowest wealth quintile (49.3%).

column1: What does the variation in demand satisfied indicate?
column2: It shows inequality in access and use of modern family planning methods across different socio-economic and regional groups.

column1: What is one of the main reasons rural areas rely more on sterilization methods?
column2: Limited access to short-term contraceptives like pills and condoms and cultural preferences for permanent solutions.

column1: What does a high CPR among women living with husbands suggest?
column2: It suggests that migration skews national data, as women whose husbands are abroad are less likely to use contraception.

column1: What steps can help Nepal achieve its 75% FP demand satisfaction target?
column2: Improving service delivery, addressing social barriers, ensuring consistent supply, and focusing on underserved regions and youth.

column1: Which contraceptive methods saw a remarkable increase in use between 1996 and 2006?
column2: Female sterilization, pills, injectables, and male condoms.

column1: Which methods showed a slight decline in use by 2011?
column2: Female sterilization and injectables.

column1: Which method saw an increase in use by 2011?
column2: Male sterilization.

column1: How did the use of Intrauterine Contraceptive Devices (IUCD) and implants change between 2006 and 2011?
column2: Their uptake rate doubled, although they still had relatively low use overall.

column1: How did the use of traditional family planning methods change over time?
column2: It doubled from 3.7% to 6.5% between 2006 and 2011, but later declined to 2.5% according to NMICS 2015.

column1: What percentage of women and men saw a family planning message on posters or hoarding boards according to NDHS 2011?
column2: 55% of women and 70% of men aged 15–49.

column1: What percentage of women and men heard FP messages on the radio?
column2: 52% of women and 59% of men heard FP messages broadcast through radio.

column1: Where is exposure to family planning messages lower?
column2: Exposure is lower in rural areas and among older age groups of women.

column1: Why is it important for older women and mothers-in-law to receive FP information?
column2: Because they often influence the family decisions and can guide younger women about family planning.

column1: How has the private sector’s role in family planning changed?
column2: The private sector has expanded rapidly, and the government encourages it to play a greater role in national FP programs.

column1: Which FP methods are commonly available through government health posts and outreach clinics?
column2: Short-acting methods like male condoms, pills, and injectables.

column1: Where are IUCD and implant services available?
column2: At a limited number of Primary Health Care Centres and health posts where trained personnel are available.

column1: How are sterilization services provided across districts?
column2: They are offered at static sites or through scheduled seasonal or mobile outreach services.

column1: Which clinics regularly provide all types of temporary FP methods?
column2: District Family Planning, Maternal and Child Health (FPMCH) clinics.

column1: Who else provides FP services besides the government?
column2: INGOs, NGOs, private service providers, and social marketing systems.

column1: What proportion of people obtain contraceptives from the government sector?
column2: 69% of users, a decline from 77% in 2006.

column1: Which NGO sectors contribute most to contraceptive services?
column2: Marie Stopes International (6%) and Family Planning Association of Nepal (2%).

column1: Which sector has seen the most significant increase in FP service provision?
column2: The commercial private sector, which rose from 14% in 2006 to 22% in 2011.

column1: What proportion of pill, injectable, and condom users obtain their methods from pharmacies?
column2: 32% of pill users, 12% of injectable users, and 52% of condom users.

column1: Why are pharmacies important in Nepal’s FP system?
column2: They are widespread, provide quick access to short-term methods, and are a major source of out-of-pocket health spending, especially in urban areas.

column1: What risk exists when women don’t receive full information about contraceptive methods?
column2: Their method choices become limited, reducing their ability to make informed reproductive health decisions.

column1: What proportion of Nepal's population is made up of adolescents and youth?
column2: Adolescents and youth account for one-third of Nepal’s population.

column1: Is early marriage and childbearing common in Nepal?
column2: Yes, early marriage and early childbearing continue to be the norm, although the median age at first marriage has been increasing.

column1: What is the adolescent birth rate in Nepal?
column2: The adolescent birth rate is 81 per 1,000 women, decreasing from 71 in 2014 (MICS).

column1: How can contraceptive use benefit adolescents and youth?
column2: It can prevent unintended pregnancies, early childbearing, and related health and social consequences.

column1: What is the level of knowledge about family planning among adolescents and youth in Nepal?
column2: Knowledge about family planning is almost universal, at 99.9%.

column1: What percentage of married adolescent girls (15-19) use modern contraceptive methods?
column2: Only 14% of married adolescent girls aged 15-19 are currently using modern contraception.

column1: What percentage of married women aged 20-24 use modern contraceptives?
column2: About 24% of married women aged 20-24 are currently using modern contraception.

column1: Which age group has the highest unmet need for family planning?
column2: Married girls aged 15-19 have the highest unmet need at 42%, followed by married women aged 20-24 at 37%.

column1: Is data on contraceptive use and unmet need among young people widely available in Nepal?
column2: No, data on contraceptive use and unmet need among young people is largely unavailable.

column1: According to global surveys, how does contraceptive use differ between unmarried and married young women?
column2: Unmarried young women are more likely to use modern contraceptives and also have higher levels of unmet need compared to currently married young women.

column1: Why is addressing family planning among adolescents important?
column2: Because it helps reduce early pregnancies, improves health outcomes, and supports young women in completing education and delaying childbearing.

column1: Has adolescent childbearing in Nepal been increasing or decreasing?
column2: Adolescent childbearing is decreasing but remains common.

column1: What are the consequences of early childbearing for adolescents?
column2: Early childbearing can lead to health risks, school dropout, and social and economic challenges for young mothers.

column1: Is access to high-quality family planning services considered a human right?
column2: Yes, FP services should be provided without discrimination or coercion.

column1: Which sectors provide FP information and services in Nepal?
column2: Government, social marketing, non-governmental organizations (NGOs), and private sectors.

column1: Which FP methods are regularly provided through government health facilities?
column2: Short-acting methods such as male condoms, pills, and injectables.

column1: Who provides FP information and distributes condoms and pills at the community level?
column2: Female Community Health Volunteers (FCHVs).

column1: Where are IUCD and implant services available?
column2: At a limited number of Primary Health Care Centres (PHCCs) and Health Posts with trained personnel.

column1: How are sterilization services provided across districts?
column2: Through static sites or scheduled 'seasonal' and mobile outreach services.

column1: Do all district hospitals provide temporary and permanent FP methods?
column2: Yes, almost all district hospitals provide all types of temporary and permanent FP methods regularly.

column1: Can women access all seven FP methods at central, regional, and district levels?
column2: Yes, but at primary health care level, access to the full range of methods is limited.

column1: Are FP services integrated into the Ministry of Health and Population’s health care delivery?
column2: Yes, FP services are integrated at all levels of health care delivery.

column1: What supply-related challenges affect FP service access?
column2: Shortage of skilled service providers, lack of contraceptive supplies, and limited human resources.

column1: What demand-related challenges affect access to FP services?
column2: Travel arrangements, costs of travel and services, and social or cultural norms requiring permission from family members.

column1: What measures has the Government of Nepal taken to reduce access barriers?
column2: Providing free counseling, free contraceptives, nominal compensation for voluntary surgical contraception, and covering costs included in the essential health package.

column1: Why do some women face difficulty accessing FP services?
column2: Challenges include transportation issues, time and cost constraints, and gender/cultural norms requiring family permission.

column1: Are FP services available in all geographical districts?
column2: Yes, in principle, women should be able to access FP services at any service delivery point in all districts, though practical barriers remain.

column1: How does integration of FP services help women?
column2: It allows women to access services at multiple levels of care and provides consistent availability of contraceptive options.

column1: How has the Government of Nepal facilitated access to FP services in postpartum and post-abortion care?
column2: By integrating FP into postpartum, post-abortion services, immunization programs, and expanding service sites offering long-acting methods.

column1: What proportion of health facilities providing safe abortion services offer at least five contraceptive methods?
column2: 91.4% of health facilities.

column1: What percentage of women accepted any contraceptive method after an abortion?
column2: Only 30% of women accepted a method after an abortion.

column1: Why is contraceptive uptake low in postpartum and post-abortion periods?
column2: Due to poor quality counseling during postpartum and post-abortion visits.

column1: What percentage of postpartum women and women who had an abortion did not receive FP counseling?
column2: 91% of postpartum women and 56% of women who had abortions did not receive counseling.

column1: How does quality of service influence FP method acceptance?
column2: Quality of service affects acceptance, rejection, and discontinuation of FP methods.

column1: What percentage of contraceptive users discontinued a method within 12 months?
column2: 51% of users discontinued a method within 12 months.

column1: What are the main reasons for contraceptive discontinuation?
column2: 26% due to husbands being away, 12% due to fear of side effects or health concerns, and 5% because the woman wanted to become pregnant.

column1: Which modern contraceptive method was most commonly discontinued?
column2: Oral pills.

column1: How can fear of side effects be reduced among contraceptive users?
column2: Through quality counseling that provides full information on side effects and what to do if they occur.

column1: What percentage of women received full information on side effects?
column2: 63% of women received full information on possible side effects.

column1: What percentage of women were informed about what to do if side effects occur?
column2: 59% of women received this information.

column1: Which methods had the lowest rates of information provision about side effects?
column2: Oral pills and female sterilization.

column1: What initiatives has the MoHP/FHD undertaken to improve quality of care?
column2: Competency-based training, infection prevention training, comprehensive FP training, and establishment/strengthening of FP service centers.

column1: Why is long-term support needed for quality improvements in FP services?
column2: Sustainable results require ongoing investments, regular protocol updates, monitoring, audits, and community education.

column1: Why is trained and competent human resource vital for FP services?
column2: Skilled providers ensure integrated, high-quality services and improve access and utilization.

column1: What challenges exist in the distribution of skilled health providers?
column2: Shortages of obstetricians/gynecologists, nurses, and female health professionals, especially at district and primary health levels.

column1: How does lack of trained providers affect FP service availability?
column2: It limits access to long-acting reversible methods and causes interruptions in supply.

column1: Can healthcare providers’ misconceptions affect FP access?
column2: Yes, negative perceptions or misconceptions among providers can limit clients’ access to their preferred FP methods.

column1: How is FP training institutionalized in Nepal?
column2: Through a nationwide network of training health sites under the National Health Training Center (NHTC) and a national training plan coordinated with the Family Health Division.

column1: What challenges exist in FP training?
column2: Insufficient pool of trainers, limited coverage of service providers, and underrepresentation of private sector providers.

column1: Who procures most of the FP commodities in Nepal?
column2: The Government of Nepal procures most FP commodities for the public sector and often for NGOs.

column1: When was the Logistics Management Division (LMD) established and for what purpose?
column2: LMD was established in 1993 by the MoHP to manage procurement and logistics of all health commodities, including contraceptives.

column1: Has the national capacity for forecasting, purchasing, and distributing FP commodities improved?
column2: Yes, under LMD leadership, national capacity has significantly improved.

column1: What is the stock-out status of male condoms, oral pills, and injectables in health facilities?
column2: No stock-outs were reported in 100% of PHCCs and SHPs, and 99% of hospitals and health posts.

column1: What percentage of PHCCs and health posts had no stock-out of IUCDs and implants?
column2: 80% of PHCCs and 72% of health posts had no stock-out.

column1: Why are long-acting methods like IUCDs and implants available only at limited sites?
column2: Due to lack of supplies and skilled personnel.

column1: What factors contribute to stock-outs of contraceptives at service delivery points?
column2: Long bureaucratic procedures for purchasing, interrupted supply from regional and district stores, and lack of trained health staff to provide services.

column1: How does knowledge of contraceptive methods affect FP service uptake?
column2: Knowledge is crucial for increasing uptake, as it allows individuals and couples to make informed choices.

column1: What are the main channels through which the population receives FP messages?
column2: Radio, television, and posters.

column1: Why is uptake of modern contraceptives hindered despite knowledge?
column2: Misconceptions, myths, fear of side effects, cultural and religious beliefs, and son preference hinder uptake.

column1: Which age group has the lowest demand satisfied by modern methods?
column2: Married adolescents aged 15–19 years, with 24.3% demand satisfied.

column1: Which group has the highest unmet need for spacing?
column2: Married adolescents aged 15–19 years, with 37.5% unmet need.

column1: How does male migration affect contraceptive use?
column2: Married women discontinue contraception when husbands are away and often fail to resume use when husbands return.

column1: What role do men play in family planning decisions?
column2: Men significantly influence FP decisions, so their engagement and education are crucial for reducing unmet need.

column1: What misconceptions do some men have about contraceptive use?
column2: About 20% of men believe that women who use contraception may become promiscuous.

column1: Which men are more likely to have misconceptions about contraception?
column2: Men living in rural areas, Terai, and Western regions, especially the Western Hill sub-region.

column1: Which men are less likely to have misconceptions about contraceptive use?
column2: Men with SLC or higher education and those in the highest wealth quintile.

column1: What strategies are recommended to improve FP service uptake and reduce myths?
column2: Targeted communication and behavior change approaches, focusing on adolescents, migrants, and increasing men’s involvement in FP.

column1: How can male involvement benefit family planning outcomes?
column2: It can help eliminate myths, encourage women to seek services, and improve uptake of modern contraceptive methods.

column1: What is the target for demand satisfied for modern contraceptives in Nepal’s FP scale-up?
What is the projected Contraceptive Prevalence Rate (CPR) for modern methods by 2021?
What is the projected unmet need for family planning by 2021?
What will be the total fertility rate (TFR) if these targets are achieved?
column2: 2.1 births per woman, which represents replacement level fertility.

column1: Why were these targets considered modest?
column2: Because they reflect the context of Nepal, which has made gains in FP but has recently experienced stalling CPR and variations by age, region, wealth, and spousal separation.

column1: What is the main goal of the FP strategy in Nepal?
column2: To give women a choice in contraceptive methods and to reach poor, vulnerable, and marginalized groups.

column1: What approach is planned regarding contraceptive method mix?
column2: The strategy aims for a balance between permanent, long-acting reversible methods, and short-acting methods, with gradual changes over time.

column1: Why is focusing on poor and marginalized groups important?
column2: Because these groups often have less access to FP services and higher unmet need.

column1: What does the CPR variation by age, region, wealth, and spousal separation indicate?
column2: It indicates inequalities in access and use of contraceptive methods across different population groups.

column1: How does the FP strategy aim to address these inequalities?
column2: By targeting vulnerable populations, offering method choice, and improving access to a balanced mix of contraceptives.

column1: What is the purpose of Nepal's Costed Implementation Plan (CIP) for FP?
column2: To strengthen the foundation for FP programming and service delivery, identify activities to implement, and estimate resources needed to achieve results at national and district levels.

column1: How was the CIP developed?
column2: Through strategic directions guided by extensive consultations with stakeholders at national, regional, and district levels, aligned with the National Health Sector Program (NHSP III 2015-2020).

column1: How does CIP relate to previous health sector plans?
column2: Like NHSP I and II, NHSP III recognizes FP as a priority, and CIP aligns FP as a component of the reproductive health package and essential health services.

column1: What are the main uses of the CIP?
column2: Inform policy dialogue, planning, and budgeting; prioritize FP strategies; guide FHD, NHTC, LMD, and NHEICC implementation plans; support understanding of financial and technical needs; aid advocacy efforts; and set benchmarks for monitoring the national FP program.

column1: What is the vision of the CIP?
column2: Healthy, happy, and prosperous individuals and families through fulfillment of their reproductive and sexual rights and needs.

column1: What is the goal of the CIP?
column2: Women and girls, especially the poor, vulnerable, and marginalized, exercise informed choice to access and use voluntary FP through increased and equitable access to quality FP information and services.

column1: How do strategic action areas and objectives support the CIP goal?
column2: They address key FP issues and challenges, ensure resources target areas with the highest need, and aim to reduce unmet need for FP in Nepal.

column1: Over what period does the CIP plan its activities and budget?
Who can use the CIP as a guide?
column2: Development partners and implementing agencies for planning and ensuring the success of the national FP program.

column1: How does the CIP support advocacy efforts for FP?
column2: By providing clear messages on the impact of FP on health and non-health sectors, including cost-savings to justify investments.

column1: What role does CIP play in monitoring FP programs?
column2: It sets benchmarks that MoHP and development partners can use to monitor and support the national FP program.

column1: Why does CIP focus on poor, vulnerable, and marginalized women and girls?
column2: Because these groups have higher unmet need for FP and less access to information and services.

column1: What are the five strategic action areas of the Costed Implementation Plan on FP?
column2: Enabling Environment, Demand Generation, Service Delivery, Capacity Building, and Research & Innovation.

column1: What is the objective of the Enabling Environment strategic area?
column2: To strengthen the enabling environment for family planning.

column1: What is the objective of the Demand Generation strategic area?
column2: To increase health care seeking behavior among populations with high unmet need for modern contraception.

column1: What is the objective of the Service Delivery strategic area?
column2: To enhance FP service delivery including commodities to meet the needs of marginalized, rural residents, migrants, adolescents, and other special groups.

column1: What is the objective of the Capacity Building strategic area?
column2: To strengthen the capacity of service providers to expand the FP service delivery network.

column1: What is the objective of the Research and Innovation strategic area?
column2: To strengthen the evidence base for effective program implementation through research and innovations.

column1: What is the role of General Programme Management in the CIP?
column2: To manage and oversee the implementation of all activities, ensure alignment and coordination among interventions, and pull all program components together.

column1: What does General Programme Management cover in terms of costs?
column2: Full costs of government personnel required to implement FP activities at central, regional, and district levels, including salaries, allowances, and time allocated to FP.

column1: How were costed activities for each Strategic Action Area and General Programme Management developed?
column2: Through Key Informant Interviews, multiple rounds of consultations at central, regional, and district levels involving stakeholders from government, donors, civil society, professional organizations, social marketing, and private sector.

column1: Who estimated the costs of the CIP activities including commodities?
column2: An expert group including the Technical Working Group (TWG) members.

column1: Who reviewed the estimated costs and strategic interventions?
column2: Oxford Policy Management (OPM) and technical experts at UNFPA Headquarters.

column1: What was the purpose of the review by OPM and UNFPA experts?
column2: To ensure that strategic interventions are in line with global recommendations and best practices.

column1: What is the projected total population of Nepal by 2030 under the counterfactual scenario?
column2: Almost 33.5 million.

column1: What is the projected total population of Nepal by 2030 under the FP scale-up scenario?
column2: Just over 32 million.

column1: What is the total dependency ratio and why is it important?
column2: The total dependency ratio is the number of children and older people per 100 working-age people; a lower ratio means less economic burden on working-age individuals, allowing greater investment in education and health.

column1: How does the total dependency ratio change under the FP scale-up scenario by 2030?
column2: It declines to 58 children and older people per 100 working-age individuals, compared to 63 under the counterfactual scenario.

column1: What drives the decline in total dependency ratio under the FP scale-up scenario?
column2: Mainly the decline in youth dependency ratio (fewer children per working-age person), while the old-age dependency ratio starts to rise slightly.

column1: What is the demographic dividend and how is it linked to FP scale-up?
column2: It is the potential economic benefit from a larger proportion of the population being of working age; FP scale-up lowers fertility and dependency ratios, contributing to this dividend.

column1: By how much is income per capita projected to increase by 2030 under the FP scale-up scenario?
column2: 4.6% higher compared to the counterfactual scenario.

column1: What factors, besides FP, are needed to realize the demographic dividend?
column2: Investment in education, health, governance, and wider economic policies to increase labor participation, savings, investment, and productivity.

column1: How many fewer maternal deaths are projected per year by 2030 under the FP scale-up scenario?
column2: Approximately 230 fewer maternal deaths per year.

column1: What is the projected maternal mortality rate in 2030 under the FP scale-up scenario?
column2: 18.1 per 100,000 live births.

column1: What is the projected maternal mortality rate in 2030 under the counterfactual scenario?
column2: 20.8 per 100,000 live births.

column1: Why is the estimate of maternal mortality reduction considered conservative?
column2: Because there is insufficient evidence to robustly quantify additional impacts of FP scale-up through channels like higher maternal education levels.

column1: How do lower fertility rates contribute to health benefits?
column2: They reduce maternal mortality and improve maternal and child health outcomes by allowing better spacing and care for pregnancies.

column1: What is the projected reduction in infant deaths per year by 2030 under the FP scale-up scenario?
column2: Approximately 3,000 fewer infant deaths per year compared to the counterfactual scenario.

column1: Why is the estimate of reduced infant deaths considered conservative?
column2: Because FP not only reduces the number of births but also reduces the chance of children dying in their first year, which is not fully quantified.

column1: How can FP help reduce child mortality?
column2: By enabling birth spacing; studies show child mortality can be reduced by 13% with spacing of 2 years or more, and 25% with spacing of 3 years or more.

column1: What are the key social and economic benefits of FP scale-up?
column2: Slower population growth, healthier population, fewer children needing education and health services, and sectoral cost savings.

column1: How many fewer children aged 6-10 would require primary education under the FP scale-up scenario?
column2: Cumulative savings of 20,231.9 million NPR over 2015-2030, or 13,629.0 million NPR if discounted at 3%.

column1: What are the savings in immunization costs under the FP scale-up scenario?
column2: Cumulative savings of 10,057.0 million NPR over 2015-2030, or 7,530.4 million NPR if discounted at 3%.

column1: What are the savings for treatment of child pneumonia under the FP scale-up scenario?
column2: Cumulative savings of 1,865.2 million NPR over 2015-2030, or 1,384.7 million NPR if discounted at 3%.

column1: What are the savings in maternal health costs under the FP scale-up scenario?
column2: Cumulative savings of 13,511.9 million NPR over 2015-2030, or 10,081.9 million NPR if discounted at 3%.

column1: What are the savings in providing access to improved water sources under the FP scale-up scenario?
column2: Cumulative savings of 903.0 million NPR over 2015-2030, or 641.1 million NPR if discounted at 3%.

column1: What assumption is made about universal coverage for education, immunization, and water?
column2: Universal primary education by 2021, full vaccination by age 1 by 2021, and universal improved water coverage by 2021.

column1: Why is the cost difference for water supply smaller than other sectors?
column2: Because universal coverage is assumed to have been reached by 2021, and continuing supply costs are lower than initial connection costs.

column1: How does FP contribute to sectoral cost savings?
column2: By reducing the number of children and mothers needing services, which lowers costs in education, immunization, child health, maternal health, and water provision.

column1: What was the estimated additional total expenditure for FP scale-up in 2015?
column2: 1,081.8 million NPR per year.

column1: How does the model project additional FP scale-up costs by 2020?
column2: Additional costs are projected to decline to 671.7 million NPR per year by 2020 due to front-loaded programme expenditure.

column1: Why is the annual cost per user in Nepal higher than the Guttmacher Institute’s estimate for Asia?
column2: Because Nepal's estimate includes comprehensive programme costs for scale-up, whereas many studies consider only direct intervention costs.

column1: What does a Benefit-Cost Ratio (BCR) greater than 1 indicate?
column2: It indicates that the benefits of the programme outweigh its costs.

column1: What is the net present value (NPV) in economic evaluation?
column2: NPV is total discounted benefits minus total discounted costs, showing the net benefit of the programme.

column1: What discount rate is used as the base case for health sector economic evaluation in this analysis?
column2: A 3% discount rate.

column1: Why are other discount rates (5% and 7%) also analyzed?
column2: To perform sensitivity analysis and see how results change under different discount rates.

column1: What is the purpose of comparing costs and benefits to a counterfactual scenario?
column2: It shows the incremental costs and benefits of the FP scale-up scenario relative to what would happen without scale-up.

column1: Why does the study include programme costs in addition to direct costs in its cost estimation?
