column2: Women in the Gandaki Province have about two times higher odds of unmet need for limiting births compared to women in other provinces (AOR: 2.11).

column1: What is the relationship between parity (number of children) and unmet need for family planning?
column2: Unmet need for limiting births increases with parity. Multiparous women (those with two or more children) have 17% unmet need for limiting, compared to only 0.5% among primiparous women (one child).

column1: How does region affect the likelihood of unmet need for limiting births?
column2: Women from the Hill region are 1.45 times more likely to have unmet need for limiting compared to women from other regions.

column1: What is the timeframe by which local and provincial governments are expected to build capacity for FP stewardship under Nepal’s Plan?
column2: The capacity development of local and provincial governments is a primary focus until 2025 under the Plan’s implementation framework. (Source: National Family Planning Costed Implementation Plan 2024-2030 and HIPs, 2025-11-08)

column1: How is financing handled in the 2024-2030 Plan?
column2: The Plan is costed — meaning resources are specified (or will be) for delivering planned family-planning services, scaling up HIPs, monitoring & evaluation, and capacity strengthening across levels of government. (Source: National Family Planning Costed Implementation Plan 2024-2030 and HIPs, 2025-11-08)"

column1: What is the rationale for needing this updated implementation plan (2024-2030) in Nepal?
column2: Because of persistent unmet need, method‐mix gaps, and a federalised health system context, the country needs a rights‐based, costed roadmap to achieve its 2030 family-planning commitments.","National Family Planning Costed Implementation Plan 2024-2030 and HIPs","2025-11-08"

column1: What role do High Impact Practices (HIPs) play in the 2024-2030 Plan?
column2: HIPs are evidence-based practices identified in the Plan to accelerate family‐planning impact, and their scaling-up is integrated into the costed implementation plan.","National Family Planning Costed Implementation Plan 2024-2030 and HIPs","2025-11-08"

column1: What is a key focus for improving access in marginalized populations according to the Plan?
column2: Ensuring that underserved, remote, and socio‐economically disadvantaged populations receive family-planning services, with special efforts to reduce inequities.","National Family Planning Costed Implementation Plan 2024-2030 and HIPs","2025-11-08"

column1: In Nepal’s CIP 2024-2030, which levels of government are emphasised for stewardship and implementation of family planning?
column2: The federal, provincial and local government levels are emphasised for stewardship, financing, monitoring and implementation of family‐planning services.","National Family Planning Costed Implementation Plan 2024-2030 and HIPs","2025-11-08"

column1: What is one of the primary objectives of the 2024-2030 Plan regarding service delivery?
column2: To expand access to quality family‐planning services across federal, provincial and local levels, ensuring method choice and equity.","National Family Planning Costed Implementation Plan 2024-2030 and HIPs","2025-11-08

column1: What are the two main documents combined in Nepal’s 2024-2030 family-planning roadmap?
column2: According to the study by National Family Planning Costed Implementation Plan 2024-2030 and HIPs, 2025-11-08) The Costed Implementation Plan and a set of High Impact Practices (HIPs) for family planning in Nepal.

column1: What strategic period does Nepal’s Family Planning Costed Implementation Plan cover?
column2: The plan covers the years 2024 to 2030. (Source: National Family Planning Costed Implementation Plan 2024-2030 and HIPs, 2025-11-08)

column1: What is the vision stated in Nepal’s Costed Implementation Plan (2024-2030) for family planning?
column2: By 2030, Nepal envisions that every individual and family will lead a healthy, happy and prosperous life, fully exercising their sexual and reproductive health and rights. (Source: National Family Planning Costed Implementation Plan 2024-2030 and HIPs, 2025-11-08)

column1: What is FP2030?
column2: FP2030 is a global partnership that supports countries in improving access to family planning services. It helps governments, health workers, and communities make sure people can choose if and when they want to have children, safely and freely. FP2030 also provides data, funding support, and shared goals to help countries like Nepal increase access to modern contraception by the year 2030.

column1: Is community-level family planning service delivery included in the commitment?
column2: Yes, Nepal emphasizes community-based distribution and counseling services to reach women in rural areas.

column1: Does Nepal emphasize adolescent and youth reproductive health in FP2030?
column2: Yes, Nepal’s commitment includes improving access to contraceptive information and services for adolescents and young people.

column1: Which government body leads family planning efforts in Nepal?
column2: The Ministry of Health and Population leads, specifically the Family Welfare Division and Reproductive Health Unit.

column1: What is Nepal trying to reduce through its FP2030 commitment?
column2: Nepal is committed to reducing unmet need for family planning and ensuring access to modern methods for all.

column1: What is Nepal’s main FP2030 goal for contraceptive use?
column2: Nepal aims to increase modern contraceptive prevalence to around 60–70% by 2030.,

column1: Why is family planning important in Nepal?
column2: Family planning helps reduce unplanned pregnancies, improves maternal health, and supports economic stability for families and communities.

column1: What age should people start learning about family planning?
column2: It’s good to start learning in teenage years, around 15–19, to build awareness before becoming sexually active.

column1: Is it okay to talk about contraception in school or with teachers?
column2: Yes, open discussions help reduce myths and promote healthy, informed decisions.

column1: Why do some people in villages still avoid using contraceptives?
column2: Many still believe in myths or lack access to reliable information and services.

column1: Are all contraceptive methods free in Nepal?
column2: Most are free in government health posts and hospitals, thanks to the National Family Planning Program.

column1: Does using birth control pills affect future pregnancy chances?
column2: No, fertility usually returns quickly after stopping the pills.

column1: Can men also take responsibility for family planning?
column2: Yes, men can use condoms or undergo vasectomy, and support their partners in making decisions.

column1: Is it true that condoms can break easily?
column2: Only if used incorrectly. Proper use and storage make them 98% effective.

column1: Are there any long-term methods for women who already have children?
column2: Yes, IUDs and implants provide protection for 3–10 years without daily effort.

column1: What should I do if I forget to take my pill?
column2: Take it as soon as you remember, and use a backup method like condoms for the next 7 days.

column1: Are emergency contraceptives safe?
column2: Yes, they are safe for occasional use but should not replace regular contraception.

column1: Do health workers keep my information private if I ask about contraception?
column2: Yes, your privacy and confidentiality are always respected in health facilities.

column1: Can contraceptives protect me from sexually transmitted infections (STIs)?
column2: Only condoms protect against both pregnancy and STIs.

column1: Is it harmful to use contraceptives before having children?
column2: No, it’s completely safe and does not cause infertility.

column1: Why do some people believe contraceptives cause weight gain?
column2: Some hormonal methods may cause temporary changes, but not permanent weight gain.

column1: How do I convince my partner to use protection?
column2: Start an honest conversation about shared responsibility and mutual health benefits.

column1: Are there any mobile apps in Nepal for family planning information?
column2: Yes, organizations like FPAN and UNFPA have digital tools and helplines for youth.

column1: What if my family doesn’t support me learning about contraception?
column2: You can seek youth-friendly services or confidential counseling at local health posts.

column1: Can I stop using contraception anytime I want?
column2: Yes, most methods are reversible; you can stop when ready to plan a pregnancy.

column1: How can I find out which contraceptive method is best for me?
column2: Visit a health post or FCHV who can help based on your age, health, and lifestyle.

column1: Are natural methods like the calendar method effective?
column2: They can work but are less reliable (around 75% effective) compared to modern methods.

column1: Is it safe to get an implant or IUD in rural areas?
column2: Yes, trained health workers provide safe insertion and removal services even in rural clinics.

column1: Can a breastfeeding mother use contraception?
column2: Yes, methods like condoms, implants, and certain pills are safe for breastfeeding mothers.

column1: Does family planning also help reduce poverty?
column2: Yes, families who plan children can manage resources better, improving education and living standards.

column1: How many people in Nepal currently use contraceptives?
column2: Around 58% of married women use some form of contraception according to NDHS 2022.

column1: Why do some couples still have large families despite education?
column2: Cultural preferences for sons and limited access to services influence family size.

column1: Can unmarried people use contraceptives?
column2: Yes, contraception is for anyone who wants to prevent unwanted pregnancy or plan safely.

column1: What if I’m embarrassed to buy condoms?
column2: You can get them from health posts, NGOs, or vending machines anonymously in some places.

column1: Are there any side effects of injectables?
column2: Some may cause irregular bleeding or mood changes, but most women adjust over time.

column1: Why should young people care about family planning?
column2: Because it helps prevent early pregnancies, keeps education on track, and supports a healthy future.

column1: Why is family planning important in Nepal?
column2: Family planning helps reduce unplanned pregnancies, improves maternal health, and supports economic stability for families and communities.

column2: It’s good to start learning in teenage years, around 15–19, to build awareness before becoming sexually active.

column2: Yes, open discussions help reduce myths and promote healthy, informed decisions.

column2: Many still believe in myths or lack access to reliable information and services.

column2: Yes, organizations like FPAN and UNFPA have digital tools and helplines for youth.

column2: You can seek youth-friendly services or confidential counseling at local health posts.

column2: Yes, most methods are reversible; you can stop when ready to plan a pregnancy.

column2: Yes, trained health workers provide safe insertion and removal services even in rural clinics.

column2: Yes, methods like condoms, implants, and certain pills are safe for breastfeeding mothers.

column2: Yes, families who plan children can manage resources better, improving education and living standards.

column2: Around 58% of married women use some form of contraception according to NDHS 2022.

column2: Cultural preferences for sons and limited access to services influence family size.

column2: You can get them from health posts, NGOs, or vending machines anonymously in some places.

column1: Are there any side effects of injectables?
column2: Some may cause irregular bleeding or mood changes, but most women adjust over time.

column1: Why should young people care about family planning?
column2: Because it helps prevent early pregnancies, keeps education on track, and supports a healthy future.

column1: What is the relationship between wealth and unmet need for family planning?
column2: Poorer women have a higher total unmet need (24.7%) compared to richer women (16.9%). Wealthier women are less likely to have unmet need for spacing or limiting.

column1: How does women’s education affect unmet need for family planning?
column2: Women with no education have the lowest unmet need for spacing (3.2%) but the highest unmet need for limiting (13.2%). Women with secondary education have higher unmet need for spacing (11.9%).

column1: How does husband’s education affect unmet need for family planning?
column2: As the husband's education level increases, the likelihood of unmet need for spacing and limiting decreases.

column1: Which occupation group has the highest and lowest unmet need for limiting births?
column2: Women in agriculture have the highest unmet need for limiting (14.7%), while those in sales and service have the lowest (11.1%).

column1: What is the effect of media exposure on unmet need for family planning?
column2: Women exposed to mass media have lower unmet need for both spacing and limiting compared to those without exposure.

column1: Which age group has the lowest odds of unmet need for family planning according to regression analysis?
column2: Women aged 20–34 years and 35–49 years have lower odds of total unmet need and unmet need for spacing compared to those under 20 years.

column1: What is the association between ethnicity and unmet need for family planning?
column2: Madheshi women have 21% lower odds of total unmet need and 34% lower odds of unmet need for spacing compared to Brahmin/Chhetri women.

column1: How does religion influence unmet need for family planning?
column2: Non-Hindu women have 28% higher odds of unmet need for limiting and 37% higher odds of unmet need for spacing compared to Hindu women.

column1: What is the impact of education level on unmet need for spacing according to regression analysis?
column2: Women with secondary education are about two times more likely to have unmet need for spacing than those with no education (AOR: 1.91; 95% CI: 1.38–2.64).

column1: How does household wealth influence the odds of unmet need for family planning?
column2: Women from wealthier households have lower odds of total unmet need, unmet need for spacing, and unmet need for limiting.

column1: What is the relationship between a woman’s desire for more children and her unmet need for spacing?
column2: Women undecided about having another child have nearly two times higher odds of unmet need for spacing compared to those who want another child (AOR: 1.92; 95% CI: 1.50–2.46).

column1: Which province has the highest odds of unmet need for limiting births?
column2: Women in Gandaki Province have about two times higher odds of unmet need for limiting births (AOR: 2.11; 95% CI: 1.65–2.70).

column1: How does parity influence unmet need for family planning?
column2: Multiparous women (two or more children) have higher unmet need for limiting (17%) compared to primiparous women (0.5%).

column1: How does region affect the likelihood of unmet need for limiting births?
column2: Women from the Hill region are 1.45 times more likely to have unmet need for limiting compared to other regions.

column1: What is the trend of unmet need across education levels of husbands?
column2: As husbands' education increases from no education to higher levels, unmet need for both spacing and limiting consistently decreases.

column1: What is the relationship between women’s age and type of unmet need (spacing vs limiting)?
column2: Younger women have higher unmet need for spacing, while older women have higher unmet need for limiting.

column1: Which ethnic group has the highest total unmet need for family planning?
column2: The Dalit ethnic group has the highest total unmet need (25.5%), mainly due to high unmet need for spacing births (11%).

column1: What is the goal of USAID Nepal’s Family Planning Service Strengthening Program?
column2: To strengthen access and availability of comprehensive family planning services across Nepal.

column1: Which government division leads family planning efforts in Nepal?
column2: The Family Health Division under the Ministry of Health and Population (MOHP).

column1: When did USAID and the Government of Nepal begin working together on family planning?
column2: They have been partners since the early 1960s.

column1: What is the total budget of the Family Planning Service Strengthening Program?
column2: It is a four-year, $10 million program.

column1: What is the main focus of this USAID program?
column2: To increase access to and use of quality family planning services, especially among populations with high unmet need.

column1: What does 'unmet need' mean in family planning?
column2: It refers to married women who want to stop or delay childbearing but are not using contraception.

column1: What percentage of married women in Nepal had unmet need for family planning according to 2011 data?
column2: 27 percent of married women reported unmet need.

column1: What was the contraceptive prevalence rate in Nepal according to the 2011 survey?
column2: It was 43.2 percent.

column1: What was Nepal’s MDG 5 contraceptive target for 2015?
column2: The target was a contraceptive prevalence rate of 67 percent.

column1: Why was the USAID program launched again despite past successes?
column2: Because modern contraceptive use had stagnated and unmet need remained high.

column1: What are the main results the USAID program aims to achieve?
column2: It aims to expand services, improve quality, train health workers, and reach disadvantaged populations.

column1: What are long-acting reversible and permanent methods in family planning?
column2: They include IUDs, implants, non-scalpel vasectomy, and minilaparotomy.

column1: Which health facilities are targeted for expansion under this program?
column2: District hospitals, Primary Health Care Centers, Health Posts, and facilities with birthing centers.

column1: What type of services does the program aim to expand at VSC sites?
column2: Comprehensive family planning services including all contraceptive methods.

column1: What does VSC stand for?
column2: VSC stands for Voluntary Surgical Contraception.

column1: Who are the main target groups of this USAID program?
column2: Hard-to-reach, marginalized, and disadvantaged populations with high unmet need.

column1: How does the program plan to increase access in remote areas?
column2: By expanding outreach, satellite clinics, and mobile family planning services.

column1: How will the program strengthen the capacity of health workers?
column2: Through competency-based training, supervision, coaching, and mentoring.

column1: What kind of training is given to government health workers under this program?
column2: Training for IUD insertion, implant services, non-scalpel vasectomy, and minilaparotomy.

column1: What type of counseling training is provided?
column2: Family planning counseling and interpersonal communication training to improve service quality.

column1: What does the program do to ensure the quality of data?
column2: It supports data quality assurance, LMIS, and HMIS systems.

column1: What does LMIS stand for?
column2: Logistic Management Information System.

column1: What does HMIS stand for?
column2: Health Management Information System.

column1: What role does the HC3 project play in relation to this program?
column2: It complements this program by increasing service utilization through communication efforts.

column1: What are the five family planning methods mentioned in the program?
column2: They include condoms, pills, injectables, implants, and IUDs.

column1: How does the program support postpartum family planning?
column2: By providing family planning services through static, outreach, and health facilities right after childbirth.

column1: What types of communication does the program use for awareness?
column2: It uses street drama, radio, interpersonal communication, and television programs.

column1: What are the expected outcomes for health workers?
column2: Improved skills, confidence, and ability to deliver comprehensive, quality family planning services.

column1: What kind of facilities are strengthened to ensure year-round availability of services?
column2: Clinics, hospitals, health posts, and centers with birthing facilities.

column1: How does the program promote sustainable skill transfer among workers?
column2: By implementing task shifting, coaching, and mentoring strategies.

column1: Which methods are included in the competency-based training for health workers?
column2: IUD, implant, non-scalpel vasectomy, and minilaparotomy procedures.

column1: What does 'task shifting' mean in this program?
column2: Allowing trained staff at different levels to provide certain family planning services to improve access.

column1: Why is on-site mentoring important in this program?
column2: It ensures continuous skill improvement and service quality in real working conditions.

column1: How does the program ensure year-round service availability?
column2: By expanding and strengthening comprehensive family planning services in all target sites.

column1: What kind of support does USAID provide at the district level?
column2: Technical, logistic, and capacity-building support.

column1: What does 'social behavior change communication' mean in this context?
column2: Activities designed to influence attitudes and behaviors toward family planning using media and community engagement.

column1: What is the duration of the Family Planning Service Strengthening Program?
column2: It is a four-year initiative.

column1: Which organization funds this family planning program in Nepal?
column2: The United States Agency for International Development (USAID).

column1: What is the main role of the Ministry of Health and Population in this program?
column2: To coordinate and oversee national family planning service delivery efforts.

column1: What does the program mean by 'comprehensive services'?
column2: It includes all contraceptive methods and counseling services for informed choice.

column1: How will the program help reach women with high unmet need?
column2: By expanding services to disadvantaged and hard-to-reach populations.

column1: What does ‘quality family planning services’ include?
column2: It includes safe procedures, informed counseling, and consistent availability of all methods.

column1: How is the USAID program helping meet Nepal’s national health goals?
column2: By supporting MOHP to improve access and quality of family planning services across the country.

column1: What are outreach and satellite clinics?
column2: Mobile or temporary clinics that bring services closer to rural and marginalized populations.

column1: How will the program improve service delivery in rural areas?
column2: Through mobile clinics, outreach services, and health post strengthening.

column1: What are the expected improvements in family planning facilities?
column2: Year-round availability of all contraceptive methods and trained staff.

column1: What are postpartum family planning services?
column2: Family planning options provided immediately after childbirth to prevent unplanned pregnancies.

column1: What is minilaparotomy?
column2: A small surgical procedure used for female sterilization.

column1: What is a non-scalpel vasectomy?
column2: A minimally invasive permanent birth control method for men.

column1: Why is supportive supervision important in this program?
column2: It ensures that trained workers maintain service quality and follow safe practices.

column1: What kind of awareness activities are used in this program?
column2: Street drama, radio, TV programs, and interpersonal communication sessions.

column1: How does the program improve counseling quality?
column2: Through targeted training on communication and client-centered counseling skills.

column1: What kind of logistic support does the program provide?
column2: Supplies, equipment, and system strengthening for continuous service delivery.

column1: What kind of data systems does the program strengthen?
column2: It supports both Logistic and Health Management Information Systems.

column1: What are mobile family planning services?
column2: Traveling clinics that provide comprehensive contraceptive services in remote areas.

column1: What does the program mean by 'competency-based training'?
column2: Training that focuses on practical skills and proficiency rather than just theory.

column1: What is the benefit of providing five family planning methods at every facility?
column2: It ensures clients can choose freely among all available options.

column1: How does USAID’s program help meet MDG 5?
column2: By increasing contraceptive use, improving service quality, and reducing maternal deaths.

column1: Why is reaching disadvantaged populations important?
column2: Because they often have the highest unmet need and lowest access to services.

column1: Which methods fall under 'long-acting reversible contraception'?
column2: IUDs and implants.

column1: What is the main purpose of improving counseling skills?
column2: To ensure clients make informed and confident family planning decisions.

column1: What are 'static clinics' in this program?
column2: Fixed health facilities that continuously provide family planning services.

column1: How does the program ensure quality improvement?
column2: Through regular supervision, coaching, and follow-up support for providers.

column1: What is the importance of post-training mentoring?
column2: It helps reinforce learning and ensures proper application of skills in real settings.

column1: What are 'outreach clinics'?

column2: USAID and Nepal’s Ministry of Health and Population (MOHP).

column2: On-site coaching for practical service delivery improvement.

column1: What does women's empowerment mean in the context of Nepal?
column2: Women's empowerment refers to a woman's sense of self-worth, right to make choices, access to opportunities and resources, control over her life inside and outside the home, and ability to influence social change.

column1: What global commitment emphasized women's empowerment and reproductive rights for Nepal?
column2: Nepal became a signatory to the International Conference on Population and Development (ICPD) held in Cairo in 1994, which emphasized women's empowerment and reproductive rights.

column1: Which Sustainable Development Goal focuses on gender equality and women's empowerment?
column2: Sustainable Development Goal 5 (SDG-5) focuses on achieving gender equality and empowering all women and girls.

column1: What indicators does the Nepal Demographic and Health Survey use to measure women's empowerment?
column2: The NDHS measures women's empowerment through employment, earnings, control over income, participation in household decision-making, and attitudes toward intimate partner violence.

column1: What percentage of Nepal’s population is constituted by Dalits?
column2: Dalits make up about 13.6 percent of Nepal’s total population according to the 2011 census.

column1: Why are Dalit women considered marginalized in Nepalese society?
column2: Dalit women face caste-based discrimination and are deprived of opportunities in social, economic, educational, and political fields, leading to reduced empowerment and access to services.

column1: What is the national target for modern contraceptive prevalence set by Nepal’s National Health Sector Strategy (2016–2021)?
column2: Nepal set a target to achieve a 52% modern contraceptive prevalence rate by 2020.

column1: How is women’s empowerment related to family planning and abortion decisions?
column2: Empowered women are more likely to exercise control over fertility, make autonomous health decisions, and access safe abortion and family planning services.

column1: What benefits can result from empowering women in terms of health outcomes?
column2: Empowerment improves maternal and child health, reduces mortality, enhances reproductive rights, and contributes to socio-economic development.

column1: What are the main barriers faced by women regarding abortion knowledge and access in Nepal?
column2: Many women lack awareness about abortion laws, face social stigma, and have limited access to safe abortion services.

column1: What is the main study design used to assess women’s empowerment and family planning decisions in marginalized women of Morang district?
column2: A cross-sectional study using a concurrent mixed-method approach (quantitative + qualitative) was conducted from February 2017 to March 2018.

column1: Who were the key participants in the Morang district study?
column2: The study included 316 married marginalized women of reproductive age (15–49 years) and 15 key informant interviews with healthcare providers and local leaders.

column1: Which ethnic groups were included as marginalized women in the study?
column2: Marginalized women included Dalit, Janajati, Muslim, and Madhesi ethnic groups.

column1: What was the median women’s empowerment score in the study and how was it categorized?
column2: The median empowerment score was 7.5, and women were categorized as having above-average empowerment (≥7.5) or below-average empowerment (<7.5).

column1: What factors were used to measure women’s empowerment in the study?
column2: Fifteen variables such as education, occupation, socioeconomic status, age at marriage, child mortality, contraception decision-making, ability to refuse sex, and participation in social groups were used.

column1: What percentage of participants were Dalit and what proportion were homemakers?
column2: About 73% of participants were Dalit, and 88.6% were homemakers.

column1: What was the literacy rate among the women studied in Morang district?
column2: Around 76.9% of women were literate.

column1: What proportion of women married before the age of 20 in the study?
column2: About 82.6% of women were married early between 12 and 19 years of age.

column1: How many women had knowledge about their fertile period and abortion law?
column2: Only 27.8% had knowledge of the fertile period, and a mere 2.5% were aware of the legal provision for abortion.

column1: What proportion of women had knowledge of modern contraceptive methods?
column2: About 77% of women had knowledge about modern contraceptive methods.

column1: What were the most commonly used contraceptive methods among women in the study?
column2: Depo-Provera (41.6%) and sterilization (39.3%) were the most commonly used contraceptive methods.

column1: What percentage of women were currently using modern contraception?
column2: Approximately 63.8% of women were currently using modern contraceptive methods.

column1: What was the relationship between women’s empowerment and contraceptive use in the study?
column2: Current use of modern contraceptives was more common among women with below-average empowerment (p=0.041, OR 0.593, CI: 0.36–0.98).

column1: What issues were identified by key informants as barriers to women's empowerment?
column2: Illiteracy, poverty, and domestic violence were identified as major barriers to empowerment among marginalized women.

column1: What social challenges affect abortion practices among marginalized women?
column2: Abortion is stigmatized in many communities, and women fear social rejection, leading to unsafe or secret abortions.

column1: What are some unsafe abortion practices reported by healthcare providers?
column2: Some women use native herbal methods or unprescribed medications at home, leading to complications like bleeding and infections.

column1: Which age group reportedly seeks abortion services most frequently?
column2: Abortion was reported to be most common among women aged 20–35 years.

column1: What are the main causes of abortion according to healthcare providers?
column2: Unwanted pregnancies, unmet family planning needs, and failure to follow Depo-Provera schedules were cited as main causes.

column1: What effect does media exposure have on family planning awareness in Nepal?
column2: Women exposed to media are more informed about contraceptive options and have lower unmet need for family planning.

column1: What steps can help improve women’s empowerment and reproductive health outcomes in Nepal?
column2: Improving education, increasing access to health services, promoting economic independence, and addressing stigma around abortion and contraception are key strategies.

column1: What is the goal of USAID Nepal’s Family Planning Service Strengthening Program?
column2: To strengthen access and availability of comprehensive family planning services across Nepal.

column1: Which government division leads family planning efforts in Nepal?
column2: The Family Health Division under the Ministry of Health and Population (MOHP).

column1: When did USAID and the Government of Nepal begin working together on family planning?
column2: They have been partners since the early 1960s.

column1: What is the total budget of the Family Planning Service Strengthening Program?
column2: It is a four-year, $10 million program.

column1: What is the main focus of this USAID program?
column2: To increase access to and use of quality family planning services, especially among populations with high unmet need.

column1: What does 'unmet need' mean in family planning?
column2: It refers to married women who want to stop or delay childbearing but are not using contraception.

column1: What percentage of married women in Nepal had unmet need for family planning according to 2011 data?
column2: 27 percent of married women reported unmet need.

column1: What was the contraceptive prevalence rate in Nepal according to the 2011 survey?
column2: It was 43.2 percent.

column1: What was Nepal’s MDG 5 contraceptive target for 2015?
column2: The target was a contraceptive prevalence rate of 67 percent.

column1: Why was the USAID program launched again despite past successes?
column2: Because modern contraceptive use had stagnated and unmet need remained high.

column1: What are the main results the USAID program aims to achieve?
column2: It aims to expand services, improve quality, train health workers, and reach disadvantaged populations.

column1: What are long-acting reversible and permanent methods in family planning?
column2: They include IUDs, implants, non-scalpel vasectomy, and minilaparotomy.

column1: Which health facilities are targeted for expansion under this program?
column2: District hospitals, Primary Health Care Centers, Health Posts, and facilities with birthing centers.

column1: What type of services does the program aim to expand at VSC sites?
column2: Comprehensive family planning services including all contraceptive methods.

column1: What does VSC stand for?
column2: VSC stands for Voluntary Surgical Contraception.

column1: Who are the main target groups of this USAID program?
column2: Hard-to-reach, marginalized, and disadvantaged populations with high unmet need.

column1: How does the program plan to increase access in remote areas?
column2: By expanding outreach, satellite clinics, and mobile family planning services.

column1: How will the program strengthen the capacity of health workers?
column2: Through competency-based training, supervision, coaching, and mentoring.

column1: What kind of training is given to government health workers under this program?
column2: Training for IUD insertion, implant services, non-scalpel vasectomy, and minilaparotomy.

column1: What type of counseling training is provided?
column2: Family planning counseling and interpersonal communication training to improve service quality.

column1: What does the program do to ensure the quality of data?
column2: It supports data quality assurance, LMIS, and HMIS systems.

column1: What does LMIS stand for?
column2: Logistic Management Information System.

column1: What does HMIS stand for?
column2: Health Management Information System.

column1: What role does the HC3 project play in relation to this program?
column2: It complements this program by increasing service utilization through communication efforts.

column1: What are the five family planning methods mentioned in the program?
column2: They include condoms, pills, injectables, implants, and IUDs.

column1: How does the program support postpartum family planning?
column2: By providing family planning services through static, outreach, and health facilities right after childbirth.

column1: What types of communication does the program use for awareness?
column2: It uses street drama, radio, interpersonal communication, and television programs.

column1: What are the expected outcomes for health workers?
column2: Improved skills, confidence, and ability to deliver comprehensive, quality family planning services.

column1: What kind of facilities are strengthened to ensure year-round availability of services?
column2: Clinics, hospitals, health posts, and centers with birthing facilities.

column1: How does the program promote sustainable skill transfer among workers?
column2: By implementing task shifting, coaching, and mentoring strategies.

column1: Which methods are included in the competency-based training for health workers?
column2: IUD, implant, non-scalpel vasectomy, and minilaparotomy procedures.

column1: What does 'task shifting' mean in this program?
column2: Allowing trained staff at different levels to provide certain family planning services to improve access.

column1: Why is on-site mentoring important in this program?
column2: It ensures continuous skill improvement and service quality in real working conditions.

column1: How does the program ensure year-round service availability?
column2: By expanding and strengthening comprehensive family planning services in all target sites.

column1: What kind of support does USAID provide at the district level?
column2: Technical, logistic, and capacity-building support.

column1: What does 'social behavior change communication' mean in this context?
column2: Activities designed to influence attitudes and behaviors toward family planning using media and community engagement.

column1: What is the duration of the Family Planning Service Strengthening Program?
column2: It is a four-year initiative.

column1: Which organization funds this family planning program in Nepal?
column2: The United States Agency for International Development (USAID).

column1: What is the main role of the Ministry of Health and Population in this program?
column2: To coordinate and oversee national family planning service delivery efforts.

column1: What does the program mean by 'comprehensive services'?
column2: It includes all contraceptive methods and counseling services for informed choice.

column1: How will the program help reach women with high unmet need?
column2: By expanding services to disadvantaged and hard-to-reach populations.

column1: What does ‘quality family planning services’ include?
column2: It includes safe procedures, informed counseling, and consistent availability of all methods.

column1: How is the USAID program helping meet Nepal’s national health goals?
column2: By supporting MOHP to improve access and quality of family planning services across the country.

column1: What are outreach and satellite clinics?
column2: Mobile or temporary clinics that bring services closer to rural and marginalized populations.

column1: How will the program improve service delivery in rural areas?
column2: Through mobile clinics, outreach services, and health post strengthening.

column1: What are the expected improvements in family planning facilities?
column2: Year-round availability of all contraceptive methods and trained staff.

column1: What are postpartum family planning services?
column2: Family planning options provided immediately after childbirth to prevent unplanned pregnancies.

column1: What is minilaparotomy?
column2: A small surgical procedure used for female sterilization.

column1: What is a non-scalpel vasectomy?
column2: A minimally invasive permanent birth control method for men.

column1: Why is supportive supervision important in this program?
column2: It ensures that trained workers maintain service quality and follow safe practices.

column2: Street drama, radio, TV programs, and interpersonal communication sessions.

column1: How does the program improve counseling quality?
column2: Through targeted training on communication and client-centered counseling skills.

column2: Supplies, equipment, and system strengthening for continuous service delivery.

column1: What kind of data systems does the program strengthen?
column2: It supports both Logistic and Health Management Information Systems.

column1: What are mobile family planning services?
column2: Traveling clinics that provide comprehensive contraceptive services in remote areas.

column1: What does the program mean by 'competency-based training'?
column2: Training that focuses on practical skills and proficiency rather than just theory.

column1: What is the benefit of providing five family planning methods at every facility?
column2: It ensures clients can choose freely among all available options.

column1: How does USAID’s program help meet MDG 5?
column2: By increasing contraceptive use, improving service quality, and reducing maternal deaths.

column2: Because they often have the highest unmet need and lowest access to services.

column2: To ensure clients make informed and confident family planning decisions.

column1: Question
column2: Answer

column1: What is the main focus of the Guttmacher report on Nepal?
column2: The Guttmacher report focuses on meeting the contraceptive and maternal and newborn health (MNH) needs of women in Nepal, showing how investments in both areas can save lives and reduce healthcare costs.

column1: How many unintended pregnancies occur in Nepal each year?
column2: According to the Guttmacher Institute (2019), around 539,000 unintended pregnancies occur annually in Nepal, which is about 45% of all pregnancies.

column1: What does 'unmet need for contraception' mean?
column2: It means women who want to avoid pregnancy but are not using any modern contraceptive method. Meeting this need could prevent many unintended pregnancies.

column1: How many women in Nepal have an unmet need for modern contraception?
column2: As of 2019, about 44% of women aged 15–49 who wanted to avoid pregnancy were not using modern contraceptives.

column1: Why is meeting contraceptive needs important for Nepal?
column2: Meeting contraceptive needs helps reduce unintended pregnancies, unsafe abortions, and maternal deaths, while supporting families to plan their futures better.

column1: What impact does contraception have on maternal deaths?
column2: If all women who wanted to avoid pregnancy used modern contraception, Nepal could prevent around 300 maternal deaths each year.

column1: How does fulfilling contraceptive needs affect newborn health?
column2: It helps ensure babies are born at the right time and in better health, reducing risks for both mothers and newborns.

column1: How much would it cost to provide full maternal and newborn health care in Nepal?
column2: According to the Guttmacher Institute (2019), it would cost about US$131 million annually to provide full maternal and newborn health care to all women in need.

column1: Is investing in contraception cost-effective?
column2: Yes! Every dollar spent on modern contraception in Nepal saves more than two dollars in maternal and newborn health care costs.

column1: What happens if unmet contraceptive needs are fully met?
column2: If all unmet needs are met, about 469,000 unintended pregnancies and 306,000 induced abortions could be prevented each year.

column1: How does family planning empower women?
column2: Family planning allows women to make decisions about their own health, education, and career, leading to more independence and equality.

column1: What are modern contraceptive methods?
column2: Modern contraceptive methods include pills, injectables, implants, IUDs, condoms, and sterilization.

column1: How do traditional contraceptive methods differ from modern ones?
column2: Traditional methods like withdrawal or calendar tracking are less reliable than modern methods like pills or IUDs, which are proven to be more effective.

column1: How does family planning benefit society?
column2: It reduces pressure on health systems, supports economic growth, and helps create healthier families and communities.

column1: What role do healthcare workers play in family planning?
column2: Healthcare workers provide counseling, distribute contraceptives, and educate women and families about safe reproductive health choices.

column1: Why is access to family planning still limited in rural Nepal?
column2: Many rural areas face challenges like lack of trained providers, limited supplies, and cultural barriers that prevent open discussion of contraception.

column1: How can Nepal improve access to family planning?
column2: By investing in health infrastructure, ensuring consistent contraceptive supply, training local workers, and raising community awareness.

column1: How can digital tools help in family planning awareness?
column2: Chatbots, mobile apps, and online health campaigns can help spread reliable information about contraception and maternal care, especially in remote areas.

column1: What are the benefits of spacing pregnancies?
column2: Spacing pregnancies gives mothers time to recover, improves child health, and reduces the risk of complications during childbirth.

column1: Why is it important to include men in family planning conversations?
column2: When men understand and support family planning, couples make better shared decisions and reduce the social stigma around contraception.

column1: What challenges do adolescents face in accessing contraception in Nepal?
column2: Young people often face judgment, lack of privacy, and limited access to youth-friendly health services.

column1: How can Nepal’s provinces use this data?
column2: Provincial governments can plan health budgets, allocate resources fairly, and target regions with higher unmet needs for contraception.

column1: What is the role of education in improving family planning?
column2: Education helps women understand their reproductive rights and options, leading to better health decisions and lower fertility rates.

column1: How can contraception help reduce poverty?
column2: By allowing families to plan and invest in their children’s health and education, contraception supports long-term economic stability.

column1: What is the link between maternal and newborn health (MNH) and contraception?
column2: Better contraception reduces risky and unplanned pregnancies, which directly improves maternal and newborn health outcomes.

column1: How many births in Nepal are attended by skilled health workers?
column2: As of 2019, about 61% of births were attended by skilled health professionals, showing improvement but still room for growth.

column1: What percentage of pregnant women in Nepal receive full antenatal care?
column2: Around 64% of pregnant women made the minimum four antenatal visits, according to Guttmacher (2019).

column1: Why are cost savings important for Nepal’s health system?
column2: Cost savings from contraception can be reinvested in hospitals, medicines, and health worker training to strengthen the entire system.

column1: How can governments encourage contraceptive use?
column2: By promoting awareness campaigns, offering free or low-cost contraceptives, and ensuring privacy and respect for all clients.

column1: Why are unintended pregnancies risky?
column2: They can lead to unsafe abortions, health complications, and emotional stress for families.

column1: How can meeting contraceptive needs prevent unsafe abortions?
column2: By reducing unintended pregnancies, the need for unsafe abortions also decreases significantly.

column1: Why are poor women more affected by lack of contraception?
column2: Poorer women often have less access to healthcare and information, making them more vulnerable to unintended pregnancies.

column1: What does the report say about equity in family planning?
column2: Meeting contraceptive needs benefits poor women the most — reducing unintended pregnancies among them by nearly 89%.

column1: What is the role of government policy in reproductive health?
column2: Strong policies ensure resources, training, and awareness reach every province, improving equality in access to reproductive services.

column1: Why should we invest in maternal health and contraception together?
column2: Because combining them saves more lives and money than investing in either alone, creating stronger health outcomes overall.

column1: What can communities do to support family planning?
column2: Communities can encourage open discussions, respect women’s choices, and support couples in planning their families.

column1: How can technology support health data collection?
column2: Digital records and mobile surveys help monitor contraceptive use and identify areas where more services are needed.

column1: What is the main message of the Guttmacher report?
column2: Investing in both modern contraception and quality maternal care is the smartest, most cost-effective way to save lives in Nepal.

column1: How can young couples benefit from family planning?
column2: It helps them plan their future, focus on education or careers first, and start a family when they’re truly ready.

column1: What can be done to reduce stigma around contraception?
column2: Open education, community talks, and positive media messages can help normalize family planning.

column1: What is the connection between family planning and gender equality?
column2: When women can control their fertility, they gain more control over their education, employment, and future, promoting gender equality.

column1: How do contraceptive services contribute to Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)?
column2: They support goals related to health, gender equality, and poverty reduction — especially SDG 3 (Good Health) and SDG 5 (Gender Equality).

column1: How can better planning save mothers' lives?
column2: Access to contraception helps avoid high-risk pregnancies and gives women time to recover between births.

column1: Why is it important to strengthen Nepal’s health system?
column2: A stronger system ensures every woman, even in remote areas, can access safe childbirth and modern contraception.

column1: What are the main barriers to achieving full contraceptive coverage?
column2: Limited funding, social stigma, lack of education, and gaps in supply chains are key barriers.

column1: How do investments in contraception affect newborn survival?
column2: They lower premature births and improve care conditions for both mother and baby.

column1: What is the estimated cost of expanding both contraception and MNH care?
column2: The total cost would be about US$131 million annually, combining both contraception and maternal-newborn health services.

column1: How can policy-makers use this data?
column2: They can use it to design cost-effective family planning programs that prioritize women’s health and reduce national healthcare spending.

column1: How can individuals contribute to better reproductive health?
column2: By staying informed, supporting open conversations, and helping spread accurate information about family planning and safe motherhood.

column1: What does reproductive health mean according to WHO?
column2: It is a state of complete physical, mental, and social well-being in all matters related to the reproductive system, not just the absence of disease.

column1: What does reproductive health imply for men and women?
column2: That they have the freedom and right to decide when and how to reproduce and access safe and affordable family planning methods.

column1: Why is family planning considered vital for maternal health?
column2: Because it reduces unwanted pregnancies and lowers pregnancy-related deaths.

column1: How did Nepal’s Total Fertility Rate (TFR) change between 1976 and 2006?
column2: It decreased from 6.3 in 1976 to 3.1 in 2006.

column1: What was the increase in contraceptive prevalence rate from 1976 to 2006 in Nepal?
column2: It increased from 2.9% to 48%.

column1: What was the decline in maternal mortality rate in Nepal from 1996 to 2006?
column2: It declined from 539 to 281 per 100,000 live births.

column1: What contributed most to the decline in maternal mortality rate in Nepal?
column2: Increased use of family planning and awareness through education and communication campaigns.

column1: What was the objective of the Lamjung District family planning study?
column2: To assess knowledge and practices of contraception among married women of reproductive age visiting Lamjung District Hospital.

column1: What age group was included in the Lamjung family planning study?
column2: Married women aged 15–49 years who had at least one child.

column1: Where was the Lamjung family planning study conducted?
column2: At Lamjung District Hospital, Nepal.

column1: What was the duration of the Lamjung family planning study?
column2: From October 2011 to December 2011.

column1: How many participants were included in the Lamjung study?
column2: There were 100 married women participants.

column1: What percentage of women in the Lamjung study had knowledge about family planning?
column2: 94% of women had knowledge about family planning.

column1: What percentage of women were using contraception in the Lamjung study?
column2: 68% were using modern contraceptives.

column1: What percentage of women were not using any contraception in the Lamjung study?
column2: 32% were not using any contraception.

column1: What was the most common age group of participants in the Lamjung study?
column2: The 20–24 year age group, representing 32% of participants.

column1: Which age group was the second largest in the Lamjung study?
column2: The 25–29 year age group, with 30% of participants.

column1: What was the most commonly used contraceptive method in the Lamjung study?
column2: Injectable contraceptives, used by 54% of women.

column1: What was the second most used contraceptive method in the Lamjung study?
column2: Oral contraceptive pills, used by 28% of women.

column1: What percentage of women used permanent female sterilization in the Lamjung study?
column2: 12.5% of women underwent sterilization.

column1: What percentage of women used IUCDs in the Lamjung study?
column2: 6.2% of women used intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUCDs).

column1: What was the most common reason for not using contraception in the Lamjung study?
column2: Because their husbands were abroad, reported by 60% of non-users.

column1: What was another major reason for not using contraception in the Lamjung study?
column2: A wish to have more children, reported by 33.3% of non-users.

column1: What was the percentage of women who gave no response for not using contraception?
column2: 3.3% of participants gave no response.

column1: What type of study design was used in the Lamjung research?
column2: It was a cross-sectional descriptive study.

column1: How were the participants selected in the Lamjung study?
column2: They were randomly selected from women attending the hospital’s outpatient clinic.

column1: What data collection method was used in the Lamjung study?
column2: Structured interviews using a pre-designed questionnaire.

column1: Was consent obtained from participants in the Lamjung study?
column2: Yes, verbal consent was taken and participation was voluntary.

column1: How was the collected data analyzed in the Lamjung study?
column2: The data were compiled and analyzed using Microsoft Excel.

column1: What percentage of Pakistani rural women were using contraception according to Mustafa et al.?
column2: Only 53% of rural Pakistani women were using family planning methods.

column1: What was the main source of awareness for family planning in the Pakistani study?
column2: Media was the main source of awareness.

column1: In Kathmandu, what percentage of women were aware of at least one family planning method?
column2: 93% of participants were aware of at least one method.

column1: In the Kathmandu study, what percentage of women had ever used family planning?

column1: What was the contraceptive prevalence rate in the Kathmandu study?
column2: It was 33.5%.

column1: What was the most commonly known method in the Kathmandu study?
column2: Depo-Provera (injectable contraception) was the most commonly known method.

column1: What does Depo-Provera refer to?
column2: It is a type of injectable contraceptive given every few months to prevent pregnancy.

column1: What are examples of long-term and reversible contraceptive methods?
column2: Implants, IUCDs, and injectable contraceptives.

column1: Why is knowledge of contraception important?
column2: Because awareness is a key factor in deciding to use family planning methods.

column1: What role do media play in family planning awareness?
column2: They help spread information and increase knowledge about contraceptive methods.

column1: What percentage of women in the Lamjung study were not using contraception because their husbands were abroad?
column2: 60% of non-users cited their husband being abroad.

column1: What does TFR stand for?
column2: Total Fertility Rate.

column1: What does a lower TFR indicate?
column2: It indicates that women are having fewer children on average.

column1: What does contraceptive prevalence rate measure?
column2: It measures the percentage of women currently using any method of contraception.

column1: What percentage of women in India and Pakistan had knowledge of contraception in comparative studies?
column2: In Pakistan 81%, and in India 82.2% had knowledge of contraception.

column1: Which temporary methods were most preferred among Nepalese women?
column2: Injectable contraceptives and oral pills.

column1: Which permanent method was used by some women in the Lamjung study?
column2: Female sterilization.

column1: Why do many rural women prefer temporary methods of contraception?
column2: Because they may wish to have more children later.

column1: How did the Kathmandu and Lamjung studies compare in terms of contraceptive use?
column2: Both showed higher use of temporary methods like injectables and pills.

column1: What factor did rural studies in Nepal identify as influencing contraceptive use?
column2: Exposure to electronic media messages about family planning.

column1: What was the key finding of the Lamjung study about rural women’s family planning knowledge?
column2: Most women had good knowledge but not all practiced contraception.

column1: What was the recommendation of the Lamjung study?
column2: That continuous education and government efforts are needed to promote long-term, reversible methods.

column1: What kind of efforts were suggested to improve contraception use?
column2: Government and community-based education about safety and benefits of modern methods.

column1: What is one of the goals of Nepal’s five-year development reproductive health program?
column2: To increase the use of quality reproductive health services among women, men, and adolescents.

column1: What behavioral changes does Nepal’s reproductive health program aim to promote?
column2: Safer sex practices and responsible reproductive behavior.

column1: What is meant by ‘responsible decisions’ in family planning?
column2: Making informed and voluntary choices about when and how to have children.

column1: Why is family planning important for social development?
column2: Because it promotes healthier families and contributes to the overall welfare and progress of a country.

column1: What was the total number of married women who participated in the Lamjung study?
column2: 100 women participated in total.

column1: Which contraceptive method had the least use in the Lamjung study?
column2: IUCDs, used by only 6.2% of participants.

column1: Why did some women not use contraception due to male sterilization?
column2: Because their husbands had undergone vasectomy, making contraception unnecessary.

column1: Why is continuous family planning education necessary in rural areas?
column2: Because awareness alone is not enough; consistent use and trust in modern methods must increase.

column1: Which contraceptive method was most preferred in Kathmandu according to earlier studies?
column2: Injectable contraceptives were most commonly preferred.

column1: What percentage of women in the Lucknow city study used oral pills?
column2: 36.6% of women used oral pills.

column1: What did the Lamjung study conclude about rural women’s awareness levels?
column2: That awareness was high, but more work is needed to improve actual usage rates.

column1: What is the difference between awareness and practice in family planning?
column2: Awareness means knowing about methods, while practice means actually using them.

column1: Why is it important to include both men and women in family planning discussions?
column2: Because both partners share responsibility for reproductive decisions and health.

column1: What is the key message of the Lamjung family planning study?
column2: That rural women in Nepal are knowledgeable but need more encouragement to practice contraception regularly.

column1: What is the current status of maternal mortality globally?
column2: Maternal mortality remains a leading cause of death among women of reproductive age, especially in developing countries.

column1: How many maternal deaths occurred globally in 2017?
column2: Approximately 295,000 women died during pregnancy and childbirth in 2017.

column1: Where do most maternal deaths occur?
column2: About 94% of maternal deaths occur in low-resource settings with high fertility rates, low literacy, poverty, poor access to health services, and low-quality medical care.

column1: Are maternal deaths preventable?
column2: Yes, the majority of maternal deaths are preventable through appropriate birth spacing, antenatal care (ANC), skilled birth attendants (SBAs) during delivery, and postnatal care.

column1: How could maternal and newborn deaths be reduced globally?
column2: If all women who wanted to prevent or delay pregnancies used contraceptives and all pregnant women and newborns received recommended health care services, maternal deaths could drop by 67% and newborn deaths by 77%.

column1: What global health transition is affecting maternal health priorities?
column2: Developing countries face an epidemiological transition where noncommunicable diseases (NCDs) are rising, creating competing priorities for essential health services.

column1: How is the maternal health budget in developing countries?
column2: Maternal health services consume 15.8% of the total health budget and 37% of the free health care budget, the highest proportion among health conditions.

column1: Why are maternal health services vulnerable to de-prioritization?
column2: As health systems face trade-offs in allocating limited resources, maternal health services can be deprioritized despite their critical importance.

column1: What is the leading cause of death among women of reproductive age in Nepal?
column2: Non-communicable diseases (NCDs) are the leading cause, accounting for almost 49% of deaths among women of reproductive age.

column1: What proportion of deaths among reproductive-age women is due to maternity-related risk factors?
column2: Maternity-related risk factors account for 9% of deaths in women of reproductive age in Nepal.

column1: What is the current maternal mortality ratio (MMR) in Nepal?
column2: Nepal has an MMR of 239 per 100,000 live births.

column1: What is the lifetime risk of maternal death in Nepal?
column2: The lifetime risk of maternal death in Nepal is 1 in 150.

column1: Is Nepal on track to achieve the SDG target for maternal mortality?
column2: Recent estimates suggest Nepal is likely to miss the SDG target of 70 maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, with a projected MMR of 199 per 100,000 by 2030.

column1: How has maternal mortality in Nepal changed from 1990 to 2017?
column2: Nepal’s MMR declined faster than the global rate, at 2.9% per year compared to 2.0% globally, though progress has slowed in recent years.

column1: What improvements in maternal health services have occurred in Nepal?
column2: Between 2001 and 2016, ANC from skilled providers increased from 28% to 84%, four ANC visits increased from 14% to 69%, institutional delivery rose from 6% to 57%, and total fertility rate declined from 4.1 to 2.3 children per woman.

column1: What is the strategy to further reduce MMR in Nepal?
column2: The strategy focuses on expanding maternal health service coverage, increasing utilization in previously low coverage areas, and ensuring universal access to ANC, skilled birth attendance, institutional delivery, and postnatal care.

column1: What are Nepal’s maternal health targets for 2030 under the SDGs?
column2: Nepal aims to achieve 90% coverage for four ANC visits, institutional delivery, SBA delivery, and three postnatal care visits. Additionally, Nepal plans to increase modern contraceptive prevalence rate to 60% and reduce total fertility rate to 2.1 children per woman.

column1: What trade-off does Nepal’s health system face regarding maternal health?
column2: Nepal must balance expediting progress in maternal health while managing resources efficiently as NCDs account for an increasing share of mortality.

column1: Why is understanding determinants of service coverage important?
column2: Understanding determinants of service coverage helps maximize the efficiency and effectiveness of resources allocated to maternal health.

column1: What has been the government of Nepal’s (GoN) approach to maternal health?
column2: Maternal health has been a priority, reflected in policy initiatives like maternity incentives, skilled birth attendant policies, and birth preparedness programs.

column1: What is the maternity incentive scheme?
column2: Introduced in 2005, it encourages women to visit health facilities for maternity care to improve access and utilization of services.

column1: What policy was introduced in 2006 regarding skilled birth attendants (SBAs)?
column2: The policy emphasized the importance of SBAs at every birth and committed to training and deploying skilled doctors, nurses, and auxiliary nurse midwives across Nepal.

column1: What is the purpose of the full birth preparedness package introduced in 2008/09?
column2: It aims to improve timely access to delivery care services nationwide.

column1: What does the Nepal Health Sector Strategy (NHSS) 2015/16-2020/21 aim to achieve?
column2: NHSS aims to expand equitable access to and utilization of quality family planning services, increase availability of modern FP methods, and meet the demand for FP.

column1: What maternal and child health initiatives has Nepal endorsed?
column2: Nepal endorsed the National Neonatal Health Strategy in 2004 and the Every Newborn Action Plan in 2016, focusing on maternal and child health.

column1: What is the equity-oriented approach to maternal health in Nepal?
column2: This approach ensures that gains in maternal health services are first realized by disadvantaged populations to improve overall indicators and reduce inequalities.

column1: How does the shift from MDGs to SDGs affect maternal health strategies?
column2: The SDG approach emphasizes 'leaving no one behind,' meaning no goal is considered achieved unless it is met for all population subgroups.

column1: Why is identifying subgroups lagging in maternal health service coverage important?
column2: It ensures targeted interventions to reduce maternal mortality and improve maternal health outcomes across all population groups.

column1: What previous analyses does this study build upon?
column2: It builds on analyses by the Policy, Planning and Monitoring Division of the MOHP and the Integrated Health Information Management Section, supported by UKaid Nepal Health Sector Support Programme (NHSSP), focusing on inequalities in maternal health service utilization.

column1: How is the risk of maternal death related to pregnancy?
column2: The risk of dying from maternal causes is linked to unwanted pregnancies and the risk of obstetric complications.

column1: How can maternal deaths be prevented?
column2: Increasing the availability and use of modern contraceptives to delay pregnancies, along with providing high-quality pregnancy and childbirth care, can prevent many maternal deaths.

column1: What other factors influence a woman’s ability to utilize maternal health services?
column2: Poverty, literacy rates, overall human development, and status as a household head affect a woman’s ability to access and use maternal health services.

column1: What has been the GoN’s approach to expanding maternal health and FP coverage?
column2: The Government of Nepal has prioritized expanding coverage through a series of policy initiatives aimed at overcoming barriers and improving access to high-quality services.

column1: Why are statistical models used in maternal health policy?
column2: Statistical models help understand determinants of service coverage, incidence of maternal conditions, and predict the effects of interventions.

column1: How can analysis guide policy decisions?
column2: Analysis informs the expansion of service coverage and ensures the rational use of limited resources by identifying which interventions are most effective.

column1: What is family planning in simple terms?
column2: Family planning means allowing couples and individuals to decide freely and responsibly the number and spacing of their children.

column1: Why is family planning important for family wellbeing?
column2: It helps couples avoid unwanted pregnancies and plan births, improving the health and happiness of the family.

column1: When was the family planning program first introduced in Nepal?
column2: The family planning program in Nepal was first initiated in 1959 by the Family Planning Association of Nepal.

column1: When did the Nepal government start providing family planning services?
column2: The government of Nepal began family planning service delivery in 1968.

column1: What was the contraceptive prevalence rate (CPR) in Nepal in 1976?
column2: The contraceptive prevalence rate in Nepal was 2.9 percent in 1976.

column1: What was Nepal’s CPR in 2016?
column2: In 2016, the contraceptive prevalence rate in Nepal reached 53 percent.

column1: Which organization first initiated family planning in Nepal?
column2: The Family Planning Association of Nepal (FPAN) initiated the family planning program in 1959.

column1: How does family planning help in reducing poverty?
column2: Family planning helps reduce poverty by allowing families to plan their resources and improve maternal and child health, which supports economic development.

column1: What was the goal of the Millennium Development Goals related to family planning?
column2: It aimed to increase contraceptive prevalence and reduce maternal mortality by improving access to reproductive health services.

column1: What did the WHO define family planning as?
column2: WHO defined family planning as a voluntary way of thinking and living to promote family health and contribute to national development.

column1: What is the main contribution of family planning programs?
column2: They help avoid unwanted pregnancies and ensure all births are planned.

column1: How does family planning improve women’s health?
column2: It allows women to delay motherhood, space births, and avoid unsafe abortions, improving their physical and mental health.

column1: What is the link between family planning and maternal mortality?
column2: If the unmet need for family planning were fulfilled, maternal mortality could drop by 25–35 percent.

column1: What is the unmet need for family planning in Nepal?
column2: As of 2016, 24 percent of married women in Nepal had an unmet need for family planning.

column1: What percentage of married women in Nepal currently use contraceptives?
column2: Around 53 percent of married women in Nepal use some form of family planning method.

column1: Which contraceptive methods are most commonly known in Nepal?
column2: Injectables, female sterilization, condoms, and contraceptive pills are the most commonly known methods.

column1: What percentage of married women know about injectables in Nepal?
column2: According to NDHS 2016, 99.4 percent of married women know about injectables.

column1: Which family planning methods are most used by women in Nepal?
column2: Female sterilization and injectables are the most commonly used methods among Nepali women.

column1: What is meant by unmet need for family planning?
column2: It refers to women who wish to delay or stop childbearing but are not using any method of contraception.

column1: How much did contraceptive use increase over 30 years in Nepal?
column2: Contraceptive use increased 16 times over the past 30 years in Nepal.

column1: What percentage of married women in Nepal use modern contraceptive methods?
column2: About 43 percent of married women use modern contraceptive methods.

column1: What are modern methods of contraception?
column2: Modern methods include sterilization, injectables, implants, IUDs, pills, and condoms.

column1: What are traditional methods of contraception?
column2: Traditional methods include withdrawal and calendar (rhythm) methods.

column1: What role does family planning play in reproductive health?
column2: It ensures healthy spacing and timing of births, protecting the health of mothers and children.

column1: What was the CPR increase between 2011 and 2016 in Nepal?
column2: The contraceptive prevalence rate increased by only 3 percent between 2011 and 2016.

column1: Why is family planning considered a basic human right?
column2: Because it allows individuals and couples to make informed and voluntary decisions about reproduction.

column1: What are the five modern family planning methods available in Nepal?
column2: They are female sterilization, male sterilization, injectables, implants, and condoms.

column1: Why do some rural Nepali families hesitate to use contraception?
column2: In rural areas, contraceptive use is sometimes viewed as risky and can be influenced by social and economic factors.

column1: How does migration affect contraceptive use in Nepal?
column2: Migration separates couples, leading to lower contraceptive use, especially in rural districts.

column1: How can family planning reduce child mortality?
column2: By helping mothers space births and stay healthy, reducing risks for infants and young children.

column1: What was the unmet need for family planning in 1996?
column2: It was 31 percent among married women in Nepal in 1996.

column1: How did the unmet need for family planning change by 2016?
column2: It decreased to 24 percent in 2016.

column1: What does CPR stand for in family planning?
column2: CPR stands for Contraceptive Prevalence Rate.

column1: What does a higher CPR indicate?
column2: It shows that more people are using contraceptive methods, meaning better access and awareness of family planning.

column1: Which plan first recognized family planning in Nepal?
column2: The third five-year development plan (1965–70) first emphasized family planning in Nepal.

column1: What is the National Health Policy of Nepal related to family planning?
column2: Formulated in 1991, it aimed to improve public health and included family planning as a major component.

column1: Why was family planning started in developing countries in the 1960s?
column2: It was introduced to control rapid population growth and promote economic development.

column1: How does family planning contribute to national development?
column2: By improving family health, reducing poverty, and supporting economic productivity.

column1: What is voluntary surgical contraception (VSC)?
column2: It includes permanent methods like male vasectomy and female tubal ligation.

column1: What are the benefits of spacing births?
column2: It allows mothers to recover health, ensures better child care, and reduces risks for both mother and baby.

column1: Which contraceptive method is most popular among Nepali women?
column2: Female sterilization has been the most commonly used method for decades.

column1: What is the relationship between education and contraceptive use?
column2: Higher education levels, especially among women, are linked to increased contraceptive use.

column1: What are the main sources of contraceptives in Nepal?
column2: Government hospitals, health posts, sub-health posts, and primary health centers.

column1: When was the National Adolescent Health and Development Strategy introduced?
column2: It was introduced in 2005 to improve adolescent health and reproductive awareness.

column1: What are the main reasons for slow CPR growth in rural Nepal?
column2: High migration, lack of awareness, and traditional beliefs slow CPR growth.

column1: What was Nepal’s fertility rate in 1991 compared to 2001?
column2: It decreased from 5 children per woman in 1991 to 4.1 in 2001.

column1: What is the goal CPR for Nepal by 2017?
column2: Nepal aimed to achieve a CPR of 65 percent by 2017.

column1: How does family planning help achieve the Millennium Development Goals?
column2: It reduces maternal and child mortality and supports gender equality and poverty reduction.

column1: What is emergency contraception?
column2: It is a method used after unprotected sex to prevent pregnancy, known by only 34 percent of women in Nepal.

column1: Why is informed choice important in family planning?
column2: Because it ensures individuals use methods suitable for their health, beliefs, and lifestyle.

column1: What is the most effective long-term contraceptive method?
column2: Female sterilization and implants are considered highly effective long-term methods.

column1: How does family planning relate to gender equality?
column2: It empowers women to make reproductive choices and participate equally in education and work.

column1: What is the main goal of family planning (FP) services in Nepal?
column2: Family planning services in Nepal aim to help couples plan and space their births and limit the number of children by providing access to high-quality FP methods.

column1: How do FP services help reduce maternal morbidity and mortality?
column2: FP services reduce maternal morbidity and mortality by preventing unintended and high-risk pregnancies and improving child health outcomes.
