column1: What are long-acting reversible contraceptives (LARCs)?
column2: LARCs are highly effective contraceptives such as IUCDs and implants that prevent pregnancy for several years and are reversible when removed.

column1: What is an IUCD?
column2: An IUCD (Intrauterine Contraceptive Device) is a small T-shaped device inserted into the uterus to prevent pregnancy for up to 10 years.

column1: What is a contraceptive implant?
column2: An implant is a small, flexible rod placed under the skin of the upper arm that releases hormones to prevent pregnancy for 3–5 years.

column1: What is the effectiveness of IUCDs?
column2: IUCDs are more than 99% effective in preventing pregnancy when inserted correctly by a trained health worker.

column1: What is the effectiveness of implants?
column2: Implants are also more than 99% effective in preventing pregnancy and can last for several years.

column1: What are short-term family planning methods?
column2: Short-term methods include condoms, oral contraceptive pills, and injectables.

column1: What are permanent methods of contraception?
column2: Permanent methods include female sterilization (tubal ligation) and male sterilization (vasectomy).

column1: Who can use LARCs?
column2: Most women of reproductive age can safely use LARCs, including those who have never given birth or are breastfeeding.

column1: Can family planning methods be reversed?
column2: Yes, reversible methods like IUCDs and implants can be removed anytime, and fertility returns quickly after removal.

column1: What is the Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC) wheel?
column2: The MEC wheel helps health workers identify which contraceptive methods are safe based on a client’s health condition.

column1: What is the Family Planning Decision-Making Tool (DMT)?
column2: It is a counseling aid that helps clients make informed decisions about which family planning method suits them best.

column1: What is the informed choice poster?
column2: It is an educational poster that informs clients about all available contraceptive options to help them choose freely and knowledgeably.

column1: What is the purpose of infection prevention in family planning?
column2: Infection prevention ensures that instruments used for IUCD or implant procedures are sterilized to prevent infections.

column1: What is an autoclave used for?
column2: An autoclave sterilizes family planning instruments and equipment to maintain hygiene and safety.

column1: Which districts were supported under the NHSSP FP3 program?
column2: Lalitpur, Nuwakot, Okhaldhunga, Sindhuli, and Gorkha districts in Nepal were supported.

column1: Why was the FP3 program implemented?
column2: It was launched to restore and strengthen family planning services in earthquake-affected districts of Nepal.

column1: Which organizations supported the FP3 program?
column2: The program was implemented by the Ministry of Health and NHSSP with support from USAID and UKaid.

column1: What are IEC materials in family planning?
column2: IEC (Information, Education and Communication) materials include posters, job aids, and counseling tools that promote awareness and informed choices.

column1: What was included in the IUCD insertion set?
column2: It included forceps, speculum, scissors, uterine sound, kidney tray, and bowls for safe IUCD procedures.

column1: What was included in the implant insertion set?
column2: It included forceps, trocar with cannula, gallipot, dissecting forceps, and blade holder for implant insertion and removal.

column1: What is a pregnancy rule-out job aid?
column2: It is a guide used by health workers to rule out pregnancy before providing a contraceptive method.

column1: What is the Visiting Provider (VP) approach?
column2: Trained nurses or ANMs visit birthing centers to provide LARC services or mentor local staff in delivering these services.

column1: What is a comprehensive mobile FP camp (VSC+)?
column2: It is a mobile outreach program providing voluntary surgical contraception and other FP services in remote areas.

column1: How were female community health volunteers (FCHVs) involved?
column2: FCHVs promoted family planning awareness and encouraged couples to use contraceptive methods in their communities.

column1: What is unmet need for contraception?
column2: Unmet need refers to women who want to avoid or delay pregnancy but are not using any contraceptive method.

column1: Why is informed choice important in family planning?
column2: Informed choice ensures that individuals select contraceptive methods based on full understanding of options, benefits, and side effects.

column1: How does family planning help after natural disasters?
column2: It ensures continued access to reproductive health services and prevents unintended pregnancies when health systems are disrupted.

column1: What infection prevention tools were provided to health centers?
column2: Autoclaves, sterilization drums, and infection prevention kits were supplied to birthing centers.

column1: What does NHSSP stand for?
column2: NHSSP stands for Nepal Health Sector Support Programme.

column1: What does LARC expansion through mentoring mean?
column2: It means training and guiding health workers to provide LARC services safely and effectively in rural areas.

column1: What is a birthing center (BC)?
column2: A birthing center is a health facility where women can give birth safely and access family planning services.

column1: What is the role of the Family Health Division (FHD)?
column2: FHD oversees family planning policies, training, and service delivery across Nepal.

column1: What is contraceptive prevalence rate (CPR)?
column2: It is the percentage of women using any method of contraception among all women of reproductive age.

column1: What is voluntary surgical contraception (VSC)?
column2: It is a permanent method of family planning for men or women who no longer wish to have children.

column1: What are the benefits of using implants or IUCDs?
column2: They are long-term, convenient, cost-effective, and highly reliable methods of preventing pregnancy.

column1: What is meant by “informed family planning choice”?
column2: It means choosing a contraceptive method freely after receiving complete, unbiased information on all available options.

column1: What is the role of IEC posters in family planning?
column2: They create awareness, educate clients, and encourage informed and voluntary contraceptive use.

column1: What outcomes were achieved by the FP3 project?
column2: 143 birthing centers were equipped with FP instruments, 200 IUCD sets, 309 implant sets, and 21 autoclaves were distributed to improve service delivery.

column1: What was the goal of the NHSSP family planning programme after the 2015 earthquake?
column2: The programme aimed to restore and strengthen family planning services, especially focusing on long-acting reversible contraceptives (LARCs), in five earthquake-affected districts so that women could safely access contraception again.

column1: What are long-acting reversible contraceptives (LARCs)?
column2: LARCs are modern family planning methods such as IUCDs and implants that prevent pregnancy for several years but can be removed any time a woman wants to become pregnant.

column1: Why were LARC services prioritized?
column2: LARC services were prioritized because they are safe, effective, and convenient for women in remote or disrupted areas where frequent clinic visits are difficult.

column1: How does improving family planning support recovery after a disaster?
column2: Improving family planning after a disaster helps families plan safely, prevents unplanned pregnancies, and reduces pressure on already stressed health services.

column1: What is infection-prevention equipment and why is it needed?
column2: Infection prevention equipment includes sterilizers, autoclaves, and clean surgical tools that ensure procedures like IUCD or implant insertions are done safely and hygienically.

column1: What does the “informed choice” poster teach?
column2: The informed choice poster reminds clients that every woman has the right to choose a contraceptive method freely after understanding all available options and their benefits.

column1: What is the Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC) wheel?
column2: The MEC wheel is a counseling tool for health workers that helps them determine which contraceptive methods are medically safe for each woman based on her health conditions.

column1: What is a pregnancy rule-out job aid?
column2: A pregnancy rule-out job aid is a simple checklist used by health providers to confirm that a woman is not pregnant before offering contraception.

column1: How did Nepal support remote areas with family planning after the quake?
column2: Nepal used the Visiting Provider approach and comprehensive mobile family planning camps to deliver LARC services and counseling to women in remote birthing centers.

column1: How can family planning volunteers help today?
column2: Female Community Health Volunteers (FCHVs) play an essential role by sharing accurate family planning information, motivating couples, and guiding them to nearby health facilities for services.

column1: What was Nepal's main goal under the FP2020 global partnership?
column2: Nepal aimed to improve access to family planning services and increase contraceptive use to save lives and improve health outcomes.

column1: By how much did Nepal commit to increasing funding for family planning programs each year?
column2: Nepal committed to increasing funding for family planning programs by at least 7 percent annually.

column1: Why is family planning important for women and children in Nepal?
column2: It prevents unintended pregnancies, reduces high-risk births, and helps save the lives of mothers and children.

column1: Who faces higher risks related to pregnancy in Nepal?
column2: Poor, rural, and disadvantaged women face higher risks due to limited access to family planning and maternal healthcare.

column1: What is the maternal mortality rate mentioned for Nepalese women?
column2: About 1 in 200 women in Nepal will die from pregnancy- or delivery-related causes in her lifetime.

column1: How can family planning reduce maternal deaths in Nepal?
column2: By helping women avoid high-risk pregnancies and allowing proper spacing between births, maternal deaths can be reduced.

column1: What percentage of children in Nepal die before their fifth birthday?
column2: Around 38 in every 1,000 children die before their fifth birthday.

column1: How many maternal deaths could be prevented by 2035 through improved family planning access?
column2: Approximately 4,500 maternal deaths could be prevented among the poorest women by 2035.

column1: How many child deaths could be prevented by 2035 with better family planning access?
column2: Around 144,000 child deaths could be prevented among low-income families by 2035.

column1: What is the contraceptive prevalence rate (CPR) goal for Nepal by 2020?
column2: Nepal aimed to reach a contraceptive prevalence rate (CPR) of 57.2 percent by 2020.

column1: How many unintended pregnancies could be prevented annually by 2020 with more modern contraceptive use?
column2: Around 100,000 unintended pregnancies could be prevented each year by 2020.

column1: What are long-acting reversible contraceptives (LARCs)?
column2: They are methods like intrauterine devices (IUDs) and implants that provide effective, long-term protection against pregnancy.

column1: Why are long-acting reversible contraceptives encouraged in Nepal?
column2: Because they are effective, convenient, and reduce the number of unintended pregnancies among women.

column1: How many new intrauterine device (IUD) users were expected by 2020?
column2: The goal was to increase IUD users by about 35,000 by 2020.

column1: How many new implant users were targeted by 2020?
column2: Nepal aimed to increase implant users by approximately 50,000 by 2020.

column1: What is the cost to avert one unintended pregnancy through family planning?
column2: It costs about US$2 to avert one unintended pregnancy.

column1: What is the estimated cost to save one child’s life using family planning investment?
column2: It costs about US$91 to save one child’s life through family planning initiatives.

column1: What is the estimated cost to prevent one maternal death through family planning?
column2: It costs about US$906 to prevent one maternal death through family planning services.

column1: What other sectors benefit from investments in family planning?
column2: Education, economic development, and gender equality all benefit from improved family planning.

column1: What is Nepal’s Family Planning Costed Implementation Plan (CIP)?
column2: It is a roadmap outlining goals, funding, and strategies to increase family planning use and access by 2020.

column2: MOHP coordinates national family planning service delivery, policy formulation, and implementation.

column1: Why does the government emphasize voluntary family planning?
column2: To ensure that individuals can freely make informed decisions about if and when to have children.

column1: What does unmet need for family planning mean?
column2: It refers to women who want to delay or stop childbearing but are not using any method of contraception.

column1: Why is family planning access lower among poor women in Nepal?
column2: Due to barriers such as lack of information, cost, cultural restrictions, and distance from health facilities.

column1: What kind of policies did Nepal plan to create to improve access?
column2: Policies focused on removing barriers and expanding access to quality family planning services for all groups.

column1: How does family planning support gender equality?
column2: It empowers women to make decisions about their bodies, education, and career, promoting equal opportunities.

column1: What type of contraceptive methods should health facilities provide according to Nepal’s plan?
column2: A full range, including short-term, long-term, and permanent methods to meet different needs.

column1: What are high-risk pregnancies?
column2: Pregnancies that occur too early, too late, too frequently, or under unsafe conditions that threaten the health of mother or baby.

column1: Why is it important to space births?
column2: Proper spacing allows mothers to recover, improves child health, and reduces the risk of complications.

column2: It reduces healthcare costs, increases women’s participation in the workforce, and contributes to national productivity.

column1: What does ‘incremental cost-effectiveness’ mean in family planning?
column2: It refers to the additional cost required to achieve specific health outcomes, like preventing a pregnancy or saving a life.

column1: What is the FP2020 initiative?
column2: A global partnership aimed at enabling women and girls to decide freely and responsibly whether and when to have children.

column1: How does family planning improve education outcomes?
column2: It allows women and girls to continue education by reducing early and unintended pregnancies.

column1: What is one reason why Nepal’s government prioritizes long-acting methods?
column2: They require fewer follow-ups and are more reliable for women in remote areas.

column1: How does family planning improve child survival rates?
column2: By reducing unplanned pregnancies, ensuring proper birth spacing, and allowing parents to focus on each child’s health and nutrition.

column1: What kind of women benefit most from improved family planning access?
column2: Poor, rural, and marginalized women benefit the most because they face the greatest access barriers.

column1: What is a voluntary surgical contraception (VSC)?

column1: What improvements were observed in the availability of basic equipment for FP service delivery between 2015 and 2021?

column4: examination lights

column4: FP counseling kits
column5: fact sheets at service sites

column1: What is the service readiness index and how did it change between 2015 and 2021?
column2: The service readiness index measures the availability of key items supporting FP service delivery; overall readiness did not change significantly between 2015 and 2021.

column1: How did the availability of FP guidelines in facilities change between 2015 and 2021?
column2: Facilities with FP guidelines increased from 12.8% in 2015 to 20.4% in 2021

column1: How did the availability of blood pressure measuring devices with stethoscopes change from 2015 to 2021?
column2: Facilities with access to digital or manual BP apparatus with a stethoscope increased from 86.6% in 2015 to 96.4% in 2021

column1: How did provider adherence to FP service quality standards change from 2015 to 2021?
column2: The overall index of providers’ adherence to quality FP service standards improved from 27% in 2015 to 36% in 2021.

column1: Which domains of FP service delivery did not show improvement in provider adherence between 2015 and 2021?
column2: There were no observed improvements in the domains of physical examination and discussion of partners and sexually transmitted infections (STIs).

column1: Which regions showed exceptions in the pattern of provider adherence improvements?

column1: How did client satisfaction with FP services change between 2015 and 2021?
column2: Client satisfaction improved
column3: as the proportion of clients reporting problems during visits declined by 5 percentage points between 2015 and 2021.

column1: What does the decline in client-reported problems indicate?
column2: The decline in client-reported problems indicates improved service quality and client satisfaction with FP services.

column1: How did stockouts of combined oral contraceptive pills change from 2015 to 2021?

column2: The proportion of facilities storing contraceptives in well-ventilated rooms increased from 83% in 2015 to 93% in 2021

column1: How did the timeliness of FP commodity deliveries change between 2015 and 2021?
column2: Facilities receiving FP commodities within two weeks of placing an order increased from 71% in 2015 to 81% in 2021

column1: What do the trends in contraceptive commodity management suggest?

column3: with improved storage and delivery timeliness but increased stockouts of oral contraceptive pills.

column1: When did the Nepal Family Planning Project start and end?
column2: It started in December 2016 and ended in December 2021.

column1: What was the main goal of the Nepal Family Planning Project?
column2: To increase access to and use of family planning services among excluded and marginalized women and adolescent girls in 15 districts of Nepal.

column1: Which provinces were covered by the Nepal Family Planning Project?
column2: Province 1, Province 2, Lumbini Province, Karnali Province, and Sudurpaschim Province.

column1: Who funded the Nepal Family Planning Project?
column2: The project was funded by UKaid with a total budget of GBP 4.7 million.

column1: Which organizations implemented the project?
column2: Adventist Development Relief Agency, Marie Stopes International, and Jhpiego, in collaboration with the Government of Nepal.

column1: What was the total budget expenditure of the project?
column2: The project spent GBP 4.6 million, achieving 99 percent financial expenditure.

column1: How many health facilities integrated family planning and immunization services?
column2: A total of 27 health facilities integrated FP and immunization services.

column1: How many women received FP services at immunization clinics?
column2: Around 1,047 women received family planning services at immunization clinics.

column1: How many people were reached through family planning demand generation activities?
column2: A total of 18,951 people were reached through FP demand generation activities.

column1: What percentage of participants in FP demand generation activities were female?
column2: About 41 percent of participants were female.

column1: What percentage of participants were male in FP demand generation activities?
column2: Around 59 percent of participants were male.

column1: How many adolescent girls were reached through social mobilizers and peer educators?
column2: A total of 3,733 adolescent girls were reached through social mobilizers and peer educators.

column1: How many adolescent girls were referred to FP services?
column2: 983 adolescent girls were referred to family planning services.

column1: What percentage of referred adolescent girls adopted a contraceptive method?
column2: About 71 percent of referred adolescent girls adopted a contraceptive method.

column1: How many women adopted a long-acting reversible contraceptive (LARC)?
column2: A total of 30,274 women adopted a LARC method.

column1: What percentage of LARC users were from marginalized ethnic groups?

column1: What was the gender breakdown in trainings and orientations under the project?
column2: Out of 64,551 total participants, 72 percent were female.

column2: Through capacity building, use of QI/MSS tools, and health worker training to improve service standards.

column1: What percentage of LARC users came from marginalized ethnic groups?

column1: How many unsafe abortions were averted by the project?
column2: Around 6,000 unsafe abortions were prevented through FP services.

column1: How many unintended pregnancies were averted through the project?
column2: Approximately 54,713 unintended pregnancies were averted.

column1: How many maternal deaths were averted through family planning interventions?
column2: A total of 47 maternal deaths were prevented.

column1: What was the key lesson learned regarding community engagement?
column2: Engaging local governments and community leaders is crucial for increasing FP uptake and creating supportive environments.

column1: What tool was used to assess the quality of FP services?
column2: Quality Improvement (QI) and Minimum Service Standards (MSS) tools were used.

column1: What impact did COVID-19 have on project implementation?
column2: COVID-19 caused disruptions, but timely adaptations ensured activities continued.

column1: What was one major logistical challenge during the project?
column2: Disruptions to supply chains, especially at the last mile, were a major challenge.

column1: How did the project address stock-outs of FP commodities?
column2: By closely monitoring contraceptive stock levels to avoid shortages.

column1: What structural challenge did the federal transition cause?
column2: The transition to federalism created confusion over roles between federal, provincial, and local governments.

column1: What was one key challenge related to human resources?
column2: Low motivation among health workers affected service delivery.

column1: What infrastructural issue did many health facilities face?
column2: Inadequate infrastructure and lack of proper facilities in some areas.

column1: What social barrier limited FP use in some communities?
column2: Cultural and religious barriers, particularly in Muslim and marginalized communities, limited FP adoption.

column1: What was one major success of policy advocacy efforts?
column2: It increased support for FP programs among elected leaders, religious figures, and minority communities.

column1: How did the project improve value for money (VfM)?
column2: By consistently reducing the cost per LARC user each year and maintaining efficient financial management.

column1: What does LARC stand for in family planning?

column1: What methods are included in LARC?
column2: Implants and intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUCDs).

column1: What was one key recommendation for the future?
column2: To scale up FP programs in low-performing districts and tailor them to local contexts.

column1: How will local government ownership help FP programs?
column2: It ensures sustainability and alignment with local health priorities under the federal system.

column1: What does QI/MSS assessment help identify?

column1: What was the long-term goal of Nepal’s FP efforts?

column2: Community events and outreach that raise awareness and motivate people to use family planning services.

column1: What does ‘federal context’ refer to in Nepal’s FP program?

column1: Why must FP programs be localized?

column2: Through regular assessments using the QI/MSS framework and supervision visits.

column1: What financial efficiency did the project maintain?
column2: It achieved 98.9 percent of planned spending, showing strong financial performance.

column2: That sociocultural norms and limited awareness remain major barriers to contraceptive uptake.

column1: What is one key takeaway for Nepal’s FP future?
column2: Nepal needs to accelerate progress and strengthen local government ownership to meet its FP and SDG targets.

column1: "Which countries are being compared for FP services in this study?","Nepal and Sri Lanka, both low- and middle-income countries in the SAARC region."
"How do Nepal and Sri Lanka compare in terms of population and fertility?","Both countries have similar populations and total fertility rates: 2.3 per woman in Nepal and 2.2 per woman in Sri Lanka."
"What is the contraceptive prevalence rate (CPR) in Nepal and Sri Lanka?","In Nepal, CPR is 53% with 43% using modern methods. In Sri Lanka, CPR is 65% with 54% using modern methods."
"How do the Human Development Index (HDI) rankings of Nepal and Sri Lanka compare?","Nepal is ranked 142 and Sri Lanka 72 in the HDI 2020."

"What is the status of health service delivery in both countries?","Both countries are recovering from civil conflicts and have devolved some health services to subnational governance. Nepal implemented the new system in 2017, while Sri Lanka has a devolved health system since 1989."

"What is SSLE in the context of FP services?","SSLE stands for South-South Learning Exchange, a systematic approach used to expand and accelerate rights-based FP services through health system strengthening."
"When did Nepal and Sri Lanka start the SSLE process?","The conversation started in January 2020, using the WHO FP Accelerator project five-step methodology."
"How was SSLE impacted by COVID-19?","Despite the COVID-19 pandemic and other challenges, SSLE continued."
"What progress had been made by December 2021?","The two countries reached the fourth step of SSLE and began implementing lessons learned."

"How many exchange and in-country meetings were held during the SSLE process?","Three exchange meetings between the countries and four in-country meetings were held to absorb lessons and prepare for the next exchange."
"When is the final evaluation of the SSLE outcomes planned?","December 2022."

"Who were the key stakeholders in the Nepal team for SSLE?","Key stakeholders included Adventist Development and Relief Agency (team leader), Family Welfare Division-Department of Health Services (Chief FP and RH section and Chief Child Health and Immunisation section), DFID Nepal (Health Advisor), Ipas (Deputy Chief of Party), Knowledge Success, Nepal CRS Company (Managing Director), Nepal Health Sector
column2: Support
column4: (FP
column5: Advisor),

column1: "Who were the key stakeholders in the Sri Lanka team for SSLE?","Key stakeholders included Family Health Bureau (FHB) (Director/Maternal and Child Health and National Programme Manager-FP Programme), Family Planning Association of Sri Lanka (Executive Director and Advocacy Director), UNFPA (National Programme Associate), and WHO Sri Lanka (NPO)."

"What role did WHO catalytic funds play in the SSLE process?","WHO catalytic funds facilitated the SSLE process, mainly supporting online calls and monitoring the SSLE due to travel restrictions from COVID-19."

"What domestic resources supported SSLE implementation in Sri Lanka?","Domestic resources from the Ministry of Health supported development, piloting, and scaling up of a new web-based LMIS and updating the Reproductive Health information system with PPFP information."

"What domestic resources supported SSLE implementation in Nepal?","In Nepal, the Ministry of Health, UN societies including WHO, civil society, academia, and implementing partners supported and funded the strengthening and integration of PPFP into RMNCAH services."
"Who conducted the evaluation of the SSLE process?","An independent consultant from Sri Lanka carried out the evaluation."
"How was the evaluation conducted?","The evaluation was transparent, inclusive, participatory, and focused on learning, ensuring high engagement and consultation with stakeholders throughout."

"What framework was used for the evaluation of SSLE?","The evaluation was framed around the five steps of WHO SSLE methodology: (1) Define the need and purpose of the learning exchange, (2) Plan the SSLE, (3) Facilitate the learning exchange, (4) Support implementation of the action plan, (5) Follow-up after the learning exchange, with an additional question on WHO’s effectiveness as a knowledge broker."
"What was the purpose of the evaluation?","The evaluation aimed to draw lessons from the implementation of SSLE between Nepal and Sri Lanka and assess the role of WHO in facilitating the process."

"What methods were used for data collection and analysis in the SSLE evaluation?","The evaluation used mixed methods, drawing on quantitative and qualitative data, including desk reviews, key informant interviews (KIIs), and face-to-face/telephone interviews with stakeholders."

"What sources were included in the desk review?","Global, regional, and country-level documents such as existing policies, strategies, programme documents, SSLE meeting notes, shared documents, WHO GPW13, WHO Country Cooperation Strategies of Nepal and Sri Lanka, Demographic and Health Surveys, FP2020 Commitments update questionnaires, and the 2016 Sri Lanka National Family Planning Review."
"How were key informants selected for interviews?","Five key informants were identified in consultation with the Ministry of Health (MoH) and WHO Country Office (WCO)."

"What monitoring systems were used during SSLE?","An inbuilt monitoring system tracked progress, reasons for delays, and problem-solving through monthly reports, teleconferences, post-meeting questionnaires, and an After-Action Review conducted at the end of step three."
"What was the purpose of the After-Action Review?","To evaluate knowledge exchange, understand what worked or didn’t, analyze why, and identify changes needed for effective implementation."

"What did Nepal identify as key gaps in FP programmes?","Use of modern contraceptives had stagnated at ~43%, demand satisfied with modern methods was 56%, postpartum FP use was low (22.6%), and unmet need was high (31.5%) compared to all married women (mCPR 43%, unmet need 24%). Postpartum family planning (PPFP) was identified as a missed opportunity."

"What learning need did Nepal identify for SSLE?","To improve organisation of clinical services to strengthen integration of PPFP, with a focus on provincial-level ownership and practical 'how-to' approaches for reproductive health service delivery throughout the lifecycle."

"What task-sharing experience was shared by Nepal?","Nepal successfully implemented task-sharing for implant insertion from medical officers to Public Health Nursing Sisters (PHNS), maintaining service continuity despite staff transfers."
What is postpartum family planning?
column2: Postpartum family planning refers to the prevention of unintended and closely spaced pregnancies during the first twelve months following childbirth.

column1: Why is postpartum family planning important?
column2: Postpartum family planning helps protect the health of mothers and infants by preventing closely spaced pregnancies and allowing families to plan their desired number of children.

column1: Who are the primary beneficiaries of postpartum family planning services?
column2: Married women who have recently given birth and are within the first year after delivery are the primary beneficiaries of postpartum family planning services.

column2: Common methods include condoms
column4: and oral contraceptive pills

column3: the belief that family planning is unnecessary during breastfeeding
column4: fear of side effects
column5: not having resumed sexual activity

column2: Women are more likely to start using family planning methods after their menstrual cycle resumes because they perceive the return of fertility.

column2: Women who have previously used family planning methods are more likely to continue or resume their use after childbirth due to prior knowledge and positive experience.

column1: What is meant by unmet need for family planning?
column2: Unmet need refers to women who wish to delay or stop having children but are not using any family planning method.

column2: Unmet need for spacing means a woman wants to delay her next pregnancy for at least two years but is not using a contraceptive method.

column2: Unmet need for limiting means a woman does not want more children but is not using any contraceptive method.

column1: Why is knowledge and use of family planning important for PLHIV?
column2: It helps reduce the risk of HIV transmission to infants born to infected mothers and supports the health and well-being of both mother and child.

column1: Do women living with HIV have reproductive rights
column2: Yes, similar to uninfected women, women living with HIV have the right to determine the number and timing of their pregnancies and to achieve safe reproductive intentions.

column1: Can PLHIV use contraceptive methods safely?
column2: Yes, PLHIV can safely and effectively use all currently available contraceptive methods, including emergency contraception, female sterilization, and vasectomy for permanent contraception if desired.

column1: What is the role of family planning in preventing mother-to-child transmission (PMTCT) of HIV
column2: Preventing unintended pregnancies among women living with HIV is a key component of the four-pronged UN strategy for PMTCT, which emphasizes access to reproductive health services and planned pregnancies to reduce in-utero HIV exposure.

column1: How does planned pregnancy benefit HIV-positive women?
column2: Planned pregnancies allow couples to conceive when the HIV-positive mother’s viral load is low and her health is optimal, significantly reducing the risk of mother-to-child transmission.

column1: Why is avoiding unplanned pregnancies important for PLHIV?
column2: It reduces the number of children exposed to HIV during the in-utero stage and improves overall health outcomes for both mother and child.

column1: What should FP initiatives for PLHIV focus on?
column2: They should expand coverage, improve the quality of FP services, and address the specific contraceptive needs of PLHIV, who are at higher risk of unplanned pregnancies.
