column2: By including comprehensive reproductive health education in the curriculum and training teachers to teach these topics without discomfort.

column1: Why do some teachers hesitate to teach family planning topics?
column2: Teachers may feel embarrassed discussing reproductive health with students
column3: especially if their relatives or children are in the class.

column1: How can schools make family planning education more youth-friendly?
column2: They can use interactive learning methods
column4: and culturally sensitive materials to make students comfortable with the topic.

column1: Why is it important to involve youth groups in family planning awareness?
column2: Youth groups can spread accurate information
column4: and make family planning discussions more acceptable among young people.

column1: How can mass media help increase family planning awareness?
column2: Radio
column4: and social media can share positive messages
column5: success stories
column6: and correct information to a wider audience

column1: What are some supply-related problems that affect family planning access in Nepal?
column2: Problems include long distance to health centers
column4: limited contraceptive options
column5: and inconsistent service hours.

column1: How can improving supply systems help increase contraceptive use?
column2: Ensuring consistent stock
column4: and multiple options allows more people to choose and continue using the methods that work best for them.

column1: Why should family planning programs include community members in planning?
column2: Involving local people ensures that programs respect cultural beliefs
column4: and build community ownership for better outcomes.

column1: How can youth-led community clubs support family planning programs?
column2: They can organize awareness campaigns
column4: and work with leaders to promote gender equality and responsible family planning.

column1: What kind of behavior change is needed for better family planning practices?
column2: Families need to move toward shared decision-making
column4: and respect for both men’s and women’s reproductive choices.

column1: How can mass media messages encourage the use of family planning?
column2: By promoting success stories
column4: and showing family planning as a normal
column5: responsible choice for healthy families.

column1: Why is gender equality important in family planning?
column2: When both men and women have equal voices
column4: mutual respect
column5: and healthier family outcomes.

column1: How can violence related to family planning decisions be prevented?
column2: By promoting awareness
column4: and involving both genders in education about mutual respect and shared decisions.

column1: What steps can be taken to reach underprivileged and rural populations for family planning services?
column2: Mobile clinics
column4: and culturally adapted programs can help bring services to marginalized and hard-to-reach areas.

column1: How can reproductive health education be improved in schools?
column2: Teachers can be trained to teach family planning comfortably
column4: youth-friendly teaching methods.

column1: Why is shared decision-making between couples important for family well-being?
column2: It helps both partners feel valued
column4: and leads to healthier
column5: well-planned families.

column1: What role can community leaders play in improving family planning?
column2: Community leaders can influence public opinion
column4: and encourage equal participation from both men and women.

column1: Why is open communication about family planning still a challenge in Nepal?
column2: Cultural norms discourage open talk about sexual health
column3: creating discomfort and misinformation among couples and families.

column1: How can youth be encouraged to participate in family planning advocacy?
column2: By training them
column4: and recognizing them as key voices for spreading awareness and reducing stigma.

column1: Where has most research on family planning needs and use among PLHIV been conducted?
column2: Most research has been conducted in African nations, with very few studies in Asian countries.

column1: Is there data on family planning uptake among PLHIV in Nepal?
column2: Available data in Nepal has not been disaggregated by HIV status, so the specific uptake among PLHIV is not well documented.

column1: What factors may contribute to low utilization of FP services among PLHIV in Nepal?
column2: HIV-related stigma and discrimination in both rural and urban areas may prevent PLHIV from using available services, including family planning.

column1: What was the main goal of the 2008 Nepal Medical College study on family planning?
column2: The study aimed to assess the awareness and practice of family planning methods among women attending the gynecology outpatient department of Nepal Medical College Teaching Hospital.

column1: How many women participated in the 2008 family planning study?
column2: A total of 300 women participated in the study conducted at Nepal Medical College Teaching Hospital.

column1: What percentage of women in the study were aware of at least one family planning method?
column2: According to the study
column3: 98% of women were aware of at least one family planning method.

column1: Which family planning method was most widely known among women in the study?
column2: Condoms were the most commonly known method
column3: followed by Depo-Provera and oral contraceptive pills.

column1: What percentage of women had ever used any family planning method?
column2: The study found that 56% of women had used some form of family planning method at least once.

column1: Which method was most commonly used among those women?
column2: Depo-Provera injection was the most commonly used method among women who practiced family planning.

column1: What percentage of women used Depo-Provera as their method of contraception?
column2: About 41% of the users preferred Depo-Provera injection as their contraceptive method.

column1: How many women preferred oral contraceptive pills according to the study?
column2: Around 19% of the women used oral contraceptive pills for birth control.

column1: What percentage of women used condoms as their main contraceptive method?
column2: About 16% of the women reported using condoms.

column1: Was female sterilization a common choice?
column2: Yes
column3: around 12% of women in the study had undergone female sterilization as a permanent method.

column1: How many women reported using IUCD (Copper-T)?
column2: Only around 4% of women used IUCD as their preferred method.

column1: Did the study show a link between education and awareness?
column2: Yes
column3: women with higher education levels showed greater awareness and use of family planning methods.

column1: What was the awareness rate among illiterate women in the study?
column2: Even among illiterate women
column3: awareness was high—about 91% knew at least one method.

column1: How many educated women were aware of family planning methods?
column2: Almost 100% of literate women in the study were aware of family planning options.

column1: Was age related to contraceptive awareness?
column2: Yes
column3: awareness was highest among women aged 20 to 39 years.

column1: What was the most common source of information about family planning?
column2: Friends and health workers were the most common sources of information.

column1: What percentage of women learned about family planning from friends?
column2: Around 42% of women said they first heard about family planning from friends.

column1: What percentage received information from health workers?
column2: About 36% of the women got their information from health workers.

column1: Did media play a role in spreading family planning awareness?
column2: Yes
column3: around 14% of women learned about contraceptive methods through mass media like radio or television.

column1: What percentage of women said they heard about family planning from their husbands?
column2: Only about 8% mentioned their husbands as the source of information.

column1: Did all women who knew about family planning actually use it?
column2: No
column3: only 56% had ever used family planning methods even though almost all were aware of them.

column1: What reasons did women give for not using contraception?
column2: The most common reasons were desire for more children
column4: husband’s disapproval
column5: or religious beliefs.

column1: What percentage of non-users wanted more children?
column2: About 36% of non-users said they wanted more children.

column1: How many women were afraid of side effects?
column2: Around 21% of women avoided family planning due to fear of side effects.

column1: How many said their husbands did not approve?
column2: Approximately 17% of non-users said their husbands did not approve of contraceptive use.

column1: What proportion mentioned religious or cultural reasons for not using family planning?
column2: About 8% of women said religion or culture discouraged them from using contraception.

column1: Did women with more children use family planning more often?
column2: Yes
column3: women with two or more children were more likely to use family planning methods than those with fewer children.

column1: What did the study find about women with no children?
column2: Most women without children had not used any family planning method.

column1: Did the study mention how many women used family planning for spacing births?
column2: Yes
column3: about 72% of the users said they used contraception for spacing rather than limiting births permanently.

column1: How many women used it for limiting births?
column2: Around 28% of the users said they used contraception for limiting or stopping births.

column1: Was male participation in family planning high?
column2: No
column4: as most methods were female-based.

column1: Did most women make family planning decisions alone?
column2: Many women made decisions jointly with their husbands
column3: but some still depended on their spouse’s approval.

column1: What did the study suggest about counseling?
column2: It emphasized the importance of counseling by health workers to reduce misconceptions and increase confidence in methods.

column1: Was the overall attitude toward family planning positive?
column2: Yes
column3: the majority of women expressed a positive attitude toward family planning.

column1: Did the study show that knowledge always leads to practice?
column2: No
column4: actual practice was much lower
column5: showing a gap between awareness and use.

column1: What can be done to close the awareness–practice gap?
column2: Better counseling
column4: and addressing myths can help improve consistent use.

column1: What does Depo-Provera require for effectiveness?
column2: It requires an injection every 3 months to maintain effectiveness.

column1: Why did some women prefer Depo-Provera?
column2: Women preferred Depo-Provera because it is convenient
column4: and does not require daily action like pills.

column1: Why did some women not prefer IUCDs?
column2: Some avoided IUCDs due to fear of discomfort
column4: or lack of awareness about the procedure.

column1: How did social factors affect use of contraception?
column2: Cultural pressure
column4: and myths influenced whether women used contraception.

column1: Did women trust health workers for family planning advice?
column2: Yes
column3: most women said they trusted health workers and wanted more guidance and reassurance.

column1: Was there any mention of media campaigns?
column2: Yes
column3: the study suggested using more mass media campaigns to reach women who rely on friends for information.

column1: Did women who had antenatal checkups know more about contraception?
column2: Yes
column3: women who visited health centers for antenatal care had higher awareness and better understanding.

column1: What conclusion did the study reach about awareness?
column2: The study concluded that awareness of family planning methods among women was very high.

column1: What conclusion did the study reach about practice?
column2: The study found that practice was moderate despite high awareness
column3: showing the need for more education and involvement.

column1: What overall recommendation did the researchers make?
column2: They recommended strengthening health education
column4: and male participation to improve contraceptive use.

column1: What was the main goal of the Nepal Family Planning Project (2016–2020)?
column2: To increase access to and utilization of family planning services among marginalized women and adolescent girls across five provinces in Nepal.

column1: Which organization funded the Nepal Family Planning Project?
column2: The project was funded by UKaid with a total budget of GBP 4.7 million.

column1: Which provinces were covered under the Nepal Family Planning Project?
column2: Province 1, Province 2, Lumbini Province, Karnali Province, and Sudurpaschim Province.

column1: Who implemented the Nepal Family Planning Project?
column2: It was implemented in partnership with Adventist Development Relief Agency, Marie Stopes International, and Jhpiego, in collaboration with the Government of Nepal.

column1: How many health facilities integrated family planning with immunization services?
column2: A total of 27 health facilities integrated FP/immunization services.

column1: How many women received family planning services at immunization clinics?
column2: Around 1,047 women received FP services at immunization clinics.

column1: How many people were reached through family planning demand generation activities?
column2: A total of 18,951 people were reached.

column1: How many adolescent girls were reached through social mobilizers and peer educators?
column2: A total of 3,733 adolescent girls were reached.

column1: What percentage of adolescent girls adopted a contraceptive method after being referred?
column2: About 71 percent adopted a contraceptive method.

column1: How many women adopted long-acting reversible contraceptives (LARC)?
column2: A total of 30,274 women adopted LARC methods.

column1: What percentage of LARC users were from marginalized ethnic groups?
column2: 56 percent of LARC users were from marginalized ethnic groups.

column1: How many health facilities were assessed using QI/MSS tools?
column2: A total of 188 health facilities were assessed.

column1: How many adolescent-friendly service (AFS) sites were established under the project?
column2: A total of 144 AFS sites were established.

column1: How many adolescents adopted a contraceptive method from AFS sites?
column2: 23,977 adolescents adopted a contraceptive method.

column1: What was the total number of people trained and oriented under the project?
column2: A total of 64,551 people were trained, with 72% being women.

column1: What was the financial expenditure rate of the project?
column2: The project achieved 99% financial expenditure, spending GBP 4.6 million out of GBP 4.7 million.

column1: What challenges did the project face during implementation?
column2: Challenges included COVID-19, transition to federalism, supply chain disruptions, low worker motivation, poor infrastructure, and cultural barriers.

column1: What cultural groups faced barriers to using modern contraceptives?
column2: Muslim and other marginalized communities faced barriers.

column1: What helped service providers identify gaps in service quality?
column2: Assessments using QI/MSS tools helped identify gaps.

column1: What helped avoid stock-outs of family planning commodities?
column2: Close monitoring of contraceptive stock levels prevented stock-outs.

column1: What ensured project activities continued during the COVID-19 pandemic?
column2: Timely adaptations to the pandemic context ensured continuity of activities.

column1: What role did local governments and community leaders play in the project?
column2: Their engagement helped create a supportive service environment and increased FP service uptake.

column1: What did the project’s advocacy efforts achieve?
column2: They built support for FP programs among local leaders and increased community acceptance.

column1: What did studies and assessments under the project aim to understand?
column2: They aimed to understand factors influencing FP service utilization.

column1: What high-level event was organized to support family planning advocacy?
column2: A national Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights Policy Dialogue was held.

column1: What should Nepal focus on post-project to meet FP targets?
column2: Nepal should scale up programs in low-performing districts and tailor activities to local needs.

column1: How did the project improve cost efficiency?
column2: It reduced the cost per LARC user and improved value for money indicators.

column1: What was the share of marginalized groups among total LARC users?
column2: Marginalized groups made up 84% of total LARC users.

column1: What percentage of training participants were female?
column2: 72% of training participants were women.

column1: What family planning methods were most used by adolescents?
column2: Injectables (35%), implants (37%), pills (26%), and IUCDs (2%).

column1: What was the main lesson learned from engaging local leaders?
column2: Engagement with local leaders increases FP acceptance and service uptake.

column1: What was the impact of integrating FP with immunization services?
column2: It allowed postpartum mothers to access FP services conveniently.

column1: What was the total number of unintended pregnancies averted by the project?
column2: About 54,713 unintended pregnancies were averted.

column1: How many unsafe abortions were prevented by the project?
column2: Around 19,197 unsafe abortions were prevented.

column1: How many maternal deaths were averted?
column2: An estimated 47 maternal deaths were averted.

column1: How did the project perform financially overall?
column2: It achieved high efficiency, spending 98.9% of its total budget.

column1: Which tool was used to assess service quality?
column2: The Quality Improvement (QI) and Minimum Service Standard (MSS) tools were used.

column1: Why is the Nepal Family Planning Project important for marginalized women?
column2: It improved access to modern contraceptives and reproductive health services for disadvantaged groups.

column1: What long-term goal does the project contribute to?
column2: It supports Nepal’s progress toward Sustainable Development Goal targets on health and gender equality.

column1: Why must FP programs be tailored locally in Nepal?
column2: Because different districts have diverse cultural, social, and infrastructural contexts.

column1: What key indicator needs rapid improvement in Nepal?
column2: The contraceptive prevalence rate and demand satisfaction for FP services.

column1: What was the trend in cost per LARC user from 2017–2020?
column2: The cost per LARC user consistently decreased each year, improving efficiency.

column1: What is the overall conclusion of the project?
column2: Family planning access improved, but Nepal needs to accelerate progress to meet SDG targets.

column1: What is the Family Planning Association of Nepal (FPAN)?
column2: FPAN is Nepal's first national family planning service delivery and advocacy organization, established in 1959.

column1: When was FPAN established?
column2: FPAN was established in 1959.

column1: What is the mission of FPAN?
column2: The mission of FPAN is to champion a volunteer movement for increased provision of sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR) to all, particularly those most at risk, marginalized, and under-served.

column1: In how many districts does FPAN serve?
column2: FPAN serves people in 44 districts of Nepal.

column1: Which groups does FPAN primarily focus on?
column2: FPAN focuses on poor, marginalized, socially excluded and underserved populations, including PLHIV, LGBTIQ people, female sex workers, MSM, migrant workers, PWD, survivors of GBV, and people affected by disasters.

column1: What services are included in FPAN's Integrated Package of Essential Services (IPES)?
column2: IPES includes sexuality counselling, contraception, emergency contraception, safe abortion, STIs/RTIs treatment, HIV & AIDS services, obstetrics, gynecological care, and sexual & gender-based violence services.

column1: How many service delivery points does FPAN operate?
column2: FPAN operates 974 service delivery points including clinical and non-clinical sites.

column1: How many SRH services does FPAN provide annually?
column2: FPAN provides approximately four million sexual and reproductive health services each year.

column1: What percentage of FPAN's services are related to family planning?
column2: About 40 percent of FPAN's services are related to family planning.

column1: What is the role of FPAN's clinical training centres?
column2: FPAN's eight clinical training centres provide accredited sexual and reproductive health training to healthcare providers from FPAN, government, and NGO health facilities.

column1: What is the main aim of Nepal’s National Family Planning Program?
column2: To ensure that individuals and couples can fulfill their reproductive needs by using appropriate family planning methods based on informed choice.

column1: Who does the Government of Nepal aim to prioritize in family planning services?
column2: The poor, vulnerable, and marginalized groups.

column1: What does family planning help reduce in Nepal?
column2: Unmet need for contraceptives and unintended pregnancies.

column1: How does family planning improve maternal and child health?
column2: By preventing high-risk pregnancies and ensuring proper birth spacing.

column1: How does family planning empower women?
column2: It allows women to invest more in their children and participate in the workforce.

column1: What broader impact does family planning have on a community or nation?
column2: It helps boost economic growth and improve overall quality of life.

column1: Which ministry oversees the National Family Planning Program in Nepal?
column2: The Ministry of Health of the Government of Nepal.

column1: In which national health plans is family planning included as a priority program?
column2: Nepal Health Sector Program II (2010–2015), National FP Costed Implementation Plan (2015–2021), and Nepal Health Sector Strategy (2015–2020).

column1: What global commitment aligns with Nepal’s family planning efforts?
column2: FP2020 global partnership commitments.

column1: Which sectors provide family planning information and services in Nepal?
column2: Government, social marketing organizations, NGOs, and private sectors.

column1: Which temporary family planning methods are provided through health posts and outreach clinics?
column2: Male condoms, oral pills, and injectables.

column1: Who distributes condoms and resupplies pills in the community?
column2: Female Community Health Volunteers (FCHVs).

column1: Where are long-acting reversible contraceptive services like IUCDs and implants available?
column2: At Primary Health Care Centers and selected health posts with trained providers.

column1: How are sterilization services provided in Nepal?
column2: At static sites or through scheduled seasonal or mobile outreach services.

column1: What do district FP MCH clinics provide?
column2: All types of temporary family planning methods on a regular basis.

column1: What is the overall objective of Nepal’s FP program?
column2: To improve the health status of all people through accountable and equitable FP service delivery.

column1: What are the specific objectives of the FP program?
column2: To increase access to safe, effective, and acceptable FP services; create an enabling environment; and increase demand for FP through communication activities.

column1: Which groups receive special focus under the FP program?
column2: Rural, poor, Dalit, marginalized, and those with high unmet needs.

column1: What does the policy on enabling environment aim to strengthen?
column2: It aims to establish family planning as a reproductive right of both females and males.

column1: What is the goal of the demand generation policy?
column2: To increase health-seeking behavior among populations with high unmet need for modern contraception.

column1: What does the service delivery policy aim to enhance?
column2: Availability of FP services and commodities for marginalized, rural, migrant, and adolescent populations.

column1: How does the FP program plan to increase contraceptive availability?
column2: By ensuring a broader range of modern contraceptive methods and improving method mix.

column1: How will family planning be integrated into other health services?
column2: Through effective integration with maternal, child, and reproductive health services.

column1: What will be strengthened to ensure regular availability of FP commodities?
column2: Procurement and logistics management systems.

column1: Which approach promotes FP service delivery across sectors?
column2: A mix of government, private, NGO, and social marketing approaches.

column1: What is the aim of the capacity-building strategy?
column2: To strengthen the capacity of service providers and expand the FP service delivery network.

column1: What is the goal of the research and innovation strategy in FP?
column2: To strengthen the evidence base for effective program implementation.

column1: How does family planning contribute to economic development in Nepal?
column2: By enabling families to invest more in education, healthcare, and infrastructure.

column1: What is meant by 'informed choice' in family planning?
column2: It means individuals and couples freely choose FP methods after receiving complete and unbiased information.

column1: How does family planning support gender equality?
column2: By giving women more control over their reproductive health and life decisions.

column1: Which FP methods are considered long-acting reversible contraceptives (LARC)?
column2: IUCDs and implants.

column1: Which FP methods are considered temporary or short-acting?
column2: Condoms, pills, and injectables.

column1: Who provides FP information at the community level in Nepal?
column2: Female Community Health Volunteers (FCHVs).

column1: Why are mobile outreach services important for sterilization in Nepal?
column2: Because they reach remote and underserved communities.

column1: What is a key objective related to service delivery equity?
column2: Ensuring FP services are accessible regardless of sex, caste, ethnicity, or socioeconomic status.

column1: What role do behavior change communication activities play in FP?
column2: They increase awareness and demand for FP services.

column1: What is a challenge in expanding LARC services in Nepal?
column2: Limited availability of trained health care providers at health posts.

column1: Why is family planning considered part of reproductive rights?
column2: Because it allows individuals to decide freely and responsibly on the number and spacing of their children.

column1: Which groups are targeted for improved FP access under the program?
column2: Rural, poor, Dalit, migrants, adolescents, and marginalized communities.

column1: What system ensures consistent supply of FP commodities in Nepal?
column2: The strengthened logistics and procurement management system.

column1: What is meant by ‘effective method mix’ in family planning?
column2: Providing a variety of contraceptive options to meet diverse user needs.

column1: Which program period did the National FP Costed Implementation Plan cover?
column2: The years 2015 to 2021.

column1: What kind of services are provided through PHC outreach clinics?
column2: Temporary family planning methods such as condoms, pills, and injectables.

column1: Why is integrating FP into other health services beneficial?
column2: It increases access and convenience for clients receiving multiple services at once.

column1: What is a primary expected outcome of Nepal’s FP program?
column2: Improved overall health status and quality of life for individuals and families.

column1: How do FP programs help reduce poverty?
column2: By allowing families to plan financially and invest more resources per child.

column1: Which social factor influences contraceptive use in Nepal?
column2: Education level and awareness about reproductive health.

column1: How do FCHVs support the national FP goals?
column2: They bridge the gap between communities and health facilities through education and supply distribution.

column1: What is the government’s commitment regarding voluntary FP services?
column2: To ensure equitable access to voluntary and informed FP choices for all citizens.

column1: Are most people living with HIV in Nepal aware of family planning methods?
column2: Yes, almost everyone living with HIV in Nepal has heard about at least one modern family planning method.

column1: Which family planning method is most familiar to people living with HIV in Nepal?
column2: Condoms are the most well-known family planning method among people living with HIV in Nepal.

column1: Which family planning methods are commonly known apart from condoms?
column2: Most people also know about Depo-Provera injections, birth control pills, male and female sterilization, and intrauterine contraceptive devices, also called IUCDs.

column1: Which family planning method do people living with HIV know the least about?
column2: The least known method is the implant, which fewer people have heard about compared to other methods.

column1: Do most people living with HIV in Nepal use family planning methods?
column2: Yes, most people living with HIV in Nepal use some form of family planning method.

column1: Did the use of family planning methods increase after people were diagnosed with HIV?
column2: Yes, the use of family planning methods increased slightly after diagnosis, with more people choosing to use condoms for protection.

column1: What is the most commonly used family planning method after HIV diagnosis?
column2: Condoms are the most commonly used method after diagnosis, used by more than 80 percent of people.

column1: Which methods were more popular before HIV diagnosis?
column2: Before diagnosis, Depo-Provera injections and condoms were the most popular family planning methods.

column1: Do people continue using the same methods after HIV diagnosis?
column2: No, many people switch from female methods like injections or pills to male methods like condoms after diagnosis.

column1: Why do people living with HIV prefer condoms after diagnosis?
column2: Condoms are preferred because they help prevent both pregnancy and the spread of HIV to partners.

column1: Did the use of other methods like pills or IUCDs change after diagnosis?
column2: Yes, the use of short-term and long-term methods like pills, Depo-Provera, implants, and IUCDs dropped sharply after diagnosis.

column1: Do people living with HIV use emergency contraception?
column2: A small number, about three percent, said they used emergency contraception recently.

column1: What are the main reasons some people do not use any family planning method?
column2: The most common reason is having sex irregularly. Other reasons include both partners being HIV positive, fear of side effects, a partner’s refusal, or not knowing which methods are safe.

column1: Do many people living with HIV in Nepal skip family planning because of fear of side effects?
column2: Yes, some people avoid family planning because they worry about side effects from certain methods.

column1: Do both partners being HIV positive affect their use of family planning?
column2: Yes, some couples who are both HIV positive feel they do not need family planning, so they do not use any methods.

column1: Does education make a difference in using family planning among people with HIV?
column2: Yes, people with higher education are more likely to use family planning methods than those with less education.

column1: Does knowing a spouse’s HIV status affect family planning use?
column2: Yes, people who know their spouse’s HIV status are much more likely to use family planning than those who do not know.

column1: Are men or women more likely to use family planning methods among people living with HIV?
column2: Men are more likely than women to use or report using modern family planning methods.

column1: Does age affect whether people use family planning methods?
column2: People between 20 and 39 years old are more likely to use family planning methods than those in other age groups.

column1: Does religion affect family planning use among people living with HIV?
column2: No, religion was not found to affect whether people use family planning methods.

column1: Does ethnicity affect the use of family planning among people living with HIV?
column2: No, ethnicity was not found to have a significant effect on family planning use.

column1: Does starting Antiretroviral Therapy influence the use of family planning?
column2: No, being on Antiretroviral Therapy or the length of time receiving it did not affect family planning use.

column1: Do people with higher CD4 counts use family planning more often?
column2: No clear link was found between CD4 count levels and family planning use.

column1: Do people who have told their spouse about their HIV status use more family planning?
column2: Most people who have shared their HIV status with their spouse are already using some form of family planning, but disclosure alone was not the strongest factor.

column1: Do people who do not want more children still use family planning?
column2: Yes, about seven out of ten people who do not want more children still use a family planning method.

column1: What do people who do not want more children but are not using family planning usually do?
column2: Some of them abstain from sex, while others avoid family planning because of irregular sexual activity or fear of side effects.

column1: Before diagnosis, who mainly used family planning methods in couples?
column2: Before diagnosis, most couples used female methods such as injections, pills, and sterilization.

column1: After diagnosis, who mainly used family planning methods in couples?
column2: After diagnosis, most couples switched to male methods such as condoms and male sterilization.

column1: What caused the shift from female to male family planning methods after HIV diagnosis?
column2: After HIV diagnosis, people preferred condoms to reduce the risk of HIV transmission, which led to more use of male methods.

column1: How common is it for people living with HIV to tell their spouse about their HIV status?
column2: It is very common—about 86 percent of people said they had told their spouse about their HIV status.

column1: Do people living with HIV usually know their spouse’s HIV status?
column2: Most people do, but around one in ten said they did not know their spouse’s HIV status because their spouse had not been tested.

column1: Are most people living with HIV receiving Antiretroviral Therapy in Nepal?
column2: Yes, the large majority—about 84 percent—are receiving Antiretroviral Therapy.

column1: Do many people get diagnosed with HIV recently or long ago?
column2: More than half of the people were diagnosed within the last two years.

column1: Is family planning awareness high among people living with HIV in Nepal?
column2: Yes, awareness is almost universal, with nearly everyone knowing about at least one modern method.

column1: Does being married early affect the use of family planning among people living with HIV?
column2: No clear link was found between age at marriage and family planning use.

column1: Do people’s fertility desires affect whether they use family planning?
column2: No, the desire to have more children did not show a strong connection with whether they used family planning.

column1: Are condoms used regularly by people living with HIV in Nepal?
column2: Yes, almost everyone who used condoms said they used them consistently over the past three months.

column1: Do people living with HIV in Nepal still use long-term family planning methods like IUCD or implants?
column2: Very few do; after diagnosis, the use of long-term methods dropped to about two percent.

column1: Is irregular sexual activity a major reason for not using family planning?
column2: Yes, it is the most common reason for not using any family planning method.

column1: Do people living with HIV in Nepal rely more on male or female family planning methods after diagnosis?
column2: They rely much more on male methods—about 91 percent use male methods and only 9 percent use female methods after diagnosis.

column1: What does equitable access in family planning mean?
column2: It means providing FP services fairly to everyone regardless of their income, gender, ethnicity, or location.

column1: Why is voluntary participation important in family planning?
column2: Because it ensures people make their own informed decisions without pressure or coercion.

column1: What are the benefits of spacing births through family planning?
column2: It improves the health of mothers and children and reduces maternal mortality.

column1: What is one economic benefit of family planning for a country like Nepal?
column2: It supports economic growth by creating a healthier and more productive workforce.

column1: What role do community leaders play in promoting family planning?
column2: They help build trust, spread accurate information, and encourage local participation.

column1: Why is there a focus on marginalized and rural populations in Nepal’s FP program?
column2: Because they often face more barriers in accessing health services.

column1: What are examples of behavior change communication activities in FP?
column2: Health campaigns, posters, community meetings, and radio programs promoting FP awareness.

column1: What is the purpose of integrating FP services with other health programs?
column2: To make services more efficient and accessible for people seeking general healthcare.

column1: How does FP contribute to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)?
column2: By improving health, gender equality, and reducing poverty.

column1: What challenge does Nepal face in achieving FP targets?
column2: Low awareness, cultural barriers, and limited trained personnel in remote areas.

column1: Why are male involvement and education important in FP?
column2: Because shared responsibility between partners leads to better FP outcomes.

column1: What is the significance of reproductive rights in family planning?
column2: They protect individuals' freedom to decide if and when to have children.

column1: What is meant by high unmet need for contraception?
column2: When people want to avoid pregnancy but are not using any contraceptive method.

column1: How does FP improve maternal health?
column2: By preventing unplanned pregnancies and unsafe abortions.

column1: Why is training healthcare providers important for FP service delivery?
column2: To ensure safe and effective counseling and administration of contraceptives.

column1: What kind of contraceptives does the government provide for free?
column2: Condoms, pills, injectables, and sometimes implants and IUCDs at public facilities.

column1: What is one role of social marketing organizations in FP?
column2: To promote and distribute affordable contraceptives through commercial channels.

column1: What are FP commodities?
column2: Items like pills, condoms, injectables, implants, and IUCDs used to prevent pregnancy.

column1: Why is logistics management important in FP programs?
column2: It ensures a continuous supply of contraceptives and prevents stock shortages.

column1: What are some cultural barriers to using family planning in Nepal?
column2: Religious beliefs, myths, gender inequality, and lack of partner support.

column1: How can FP services reach remote or mountainous areas?
column2: Through mobile outreach clinics and trained community health volunteers.

column1: What is the role of adolescents in FP education?
column2: They are key audiences for awareness programs to prevent early pregnancies.

column1: What does the term 'method mix' refer to in FP?
column2: The variety of contraceptive methods available to meet different user needs.

column1: What is the advantage of using long-acting reversible contraceptives (LARCs)?
column2: They provide protection for several years and don’t require daily attention.

column1: How do FP programs support women's empowerment?
column2: By giving women control over reproduction, allowing them to pursue education and careers.

column1: What is the link between FP and child health?
column2: It allows families to plan spacing, giving better care and nutrition to each child.

column1: Which government document guides FP policy from 2015–2020?
column2: The Nepal Health Sector Strategy (NHSS) 2015–2020.

column1: How does FP reduce the risk of unsafe abortion?
column2: By preventing unintended pregnancies before they occur.

column1: Which FP method is permanent for women?
column2: Female sterilization (tubal ligation).

column1: Which FP method is permanent for men?
column2: Male sterilization (vasectomy).

column1: Why is FP considered a human right?
column2: Because it allows everyone to make free and informed decisions about reproduction.

column1: How do FP programs help reduce gender inequality?
column2: By ensuring women have equal say in reproductive decisions and opportunities.

column1: Why is advocacy important in FP programs?
column2: It influences leaders and policymakers to support FP funding and implementation.

column1: How can schools promote FP awareness?
column2: Through health education and life skills programs for adolescents.

column1: What is a PHC Outreach Clinic’s role in FP?
column2: To provide temporary FP methods and health education in rural communities.

column1: Why is research important for FP policy-making?
column2: It helps identify challenges, measure progress, and guide future strategies.

column1: What is the significance of FP in poverty reduction?
column2: Families with fewer children can allocate more resources to health and education.

column1: What can happen if FP commodities run out?
column2: Unmet needs increase, leading to more unintended pregnancies.

column1: Which FP program emphasizes equitable access for all?
column2: The National Family Planning Program of Nepal.

column1: Why are men encouraged to participate in FP decisions?
column2: Because shared decisions strengthen relationships and improve health outcomes.

column1: What is one key challenge in FP communication?
column2: Combating misinformation and cultural taboos about contraceptives.

column1: What is the benefit of mobile FP clinics?
column2: They bring services closer to people in remote and underserved areas.

column1: Which contraceptive method also helps prevent sexually transmitted infections (STIs)?
column2: Condoms.

column1: What does NHSS stand for?
column2: Nepal Health Sector Strategy.

column1: Why is the FP program linked to national development?
column2: Because healthier families lead to stronger communities and economic progress.

column1: Which FP policy promotes innovation and research?
column2: The National FP Costed Implementation Plan 2015–2021.

column1: What is the goal of FP training programs?
column2: To build the skills of health workers for safe and effective service delivery.

column1: Why is regular supply of FP commodities essential?
column2: To maintain trust in services and avoid discontinuation of contraceptive use.

column1: How does FP benefit men as well as women?
column2: It helps both partners plan their families and improve their quality of life.

column1: What is the ultimate goal of the National Family Planning Program?
column2: To improve health and quality of life through informed and voluntary FP use.

column1: Who provides family planning services in Nepal?
column2: Family planning services in Nepal are provided by both government and non-government health facilities.

column1: In which district was data on family planning service use reviewed?
column2: Data was reviewed from health facilities under the District Health Office (DHO) Ilam.

column1: What variables were considered while analyzing family planning method use?
column2: Age, sex, ethnicity, and number of children were considered.

column1: What percentage of female users of spacing methods were in the age group 20-29 years?
column2: Around 53% of female users of spacing methods were in the age group 20-29 years.

column1: What percentage of female users of permanent methods were in the age group 25-29 years?
column2: Around 47% of female users of permanent methods were in the age group 25-29 years.

column1: What were the major reasons for IUCD removal?
column2: The major reasons included husband's migration and physical problems experienced by the user.

column1: What is the purpose of analyzing family planning trends and patterns in Nepal?
column2: The purpose is to improve reproductive health and inform policy.

column1: Why is family planning considered central to reproductive health?
column2: Family planning is central because it supports family wellbeing and enables couples to plan for healthy and desired pregnancies.

column1: What is one of the major contributions of family planning programs?
column2: They help avoid unwanted pregnancies and ensure that births are planned.

column1: What is the level of awareness of contraceptive methods among currently married women in Nepal?
column2: Knowledge of at least one contraceptive method is nearly universal among currently married women in Nepal.

column1: How has contraceptive use changed over the last 30 years in Nepal?
column2: Contraceptive use has increased dramatically, showing about a 16-fold rise.

column1: What was the contraceptive prevalence rate (CPR) in 1976 and in 2006?
column2: The CPR increased from 2.9 percent in 1976 to 48 percent in 2006.

column1: According to NDHS 2016, what percentage of currently married women are using some form of family planning?
column2: According to NDHS 2016, 53 percent of currently married women are using a family planning method.

column1: What percentage of married women in Nepal have an unmet need for family planning?
column2: Overall, 24 percent of married women have an unmet need for family planning.

column1: How is the unmet need for family planning divided between spacing and limiting births?
column2: 8 percent of unmet need is for spacing births and 16 percent is for limiting births.

column1: What was the contraceptive prevalence rate (CPR) among married women in Nepal by 2016?
column2: The contraceptive prevalence rate reached 53% among married women by 2016.

column1: How much did contraceptive use increase over the past 30 years in Nepal?
column2: Contraceptive use increased about 16-fold, rising from 2.9% in 1976 to 53%.

column1: What percentage of married women in Nepal have an unmet need for family planning?
column2: About 24% of married women have an unmet need for family planning.

column1: How is the unmet need for family planning divided?
column2: 8% of married women have an unmet need for spacing births, while 16% have an unmet need for limiting births.

column1: What is the level of awareness of contraceptive methods among currently married women in Nepal?
column2: Knowledge of at least one contraceptive method is nearly universal among currently married women.

column1: Why do many couples living with HIV in Nepal switch to condom use after diagnosis?
column2: Many couples switch to condoms after diagnosis because condoms help prevent both pregnancy and the transmission of HIV to their partner.

column1: Do women living with HIV use fewer family planning methods after diagnosis?
column2: Yes, after diagnosis, women tend to use fewer female family planning methods like pills or injections, as condom use becomes more common.

column1: Is it safe for people living with HIV to use hormonal methods like Depo-Provera?
column2: Yes, hormonal methods like Depo-Provera are generally safe for people living with HIV, but it is important to discuss with a healthcare provider to ensure no drug interactions with Antiretroviral Therapy.

column1: Why might some couples living with HIV stop using family planning after diagnosis?
column2: Some couples stop using family planning because they believe it is unnecessary if both partners are HIV positive or if they are not sexually active often.

column1: Do people living with HIV in Nepal get family planning information from health workers?
column2: Yes, most information about family planning for people living with HIV is shared by healthcare workers during Antiretroviral Therapy visits.

column1: Can people on Antiretroviral Therapy safely use any family planning method?
column2: Most family planning methods are safe for people on Antiretroviral Therapy, but methods should be chosen based on personal health and doctor’s advice.

column1: Is irregular sexual activity a common reason for not using contraception?
column2: Yes, almost half of the people who do not use any family planning said it was because they had sex irregularly.

column1: Do fear of side effects stop people from using family planning?
column2: Yes, some people are afraid of possible side effects from methods like injections or implants, which makes them avoid using them.

column1: How does a spouse’s refusal affect family planning use?
column2: About one in ten people said they do not use family planning because their spouse refuses or disagrees with it.

column1: Do people who know their spouse’s HIV status make better family planning decisions?
column2: Yes, people who know whether their spouse is HIV positive or not are more likely to choose and use a family planning method.

column1: Why is education important for family planning among people living with HIV?
column2: Education helps people understand the benefits and options of family planning, which leads to higher use of modern methods.

column1: Are people with no education less likely to use family planning?
column2: Yes, people with little or no education are less likely to use family planning compared to those with higher education.

column1: Do people living with HIV in Nepal still want to have children?
column2: Some do, but many prefer to delay or prevent pregnancy to protect their own health and reduce the risk of transmitting HIV.

column1: Can couples living with HIV safely have children if they want to?
column2: Yes, with proper medical guidance and Antiretroviral Therapy, couples living with HIV can safely plan for children.

column1: Why is condom use promoted more than other methods for people living with HIV?
column2: Condoms not only prevent pregnancy but also stop the spread of HIV and other sexually transmitted infections, making them a preferred option.

column1: Do both male and female condoms help prevent HIV transmission?
column2: Yes, both male and female condoms are effective in preventing the transmission of HIV when used correctly and consistently.

column1: Why did the use of Depo-Provera decrease after HIV diagnosis?
column2: After diagnosis, many people preferred condoms instead of injections, as condoms provide both protection from pregnancy and from HIV transmission.

column1: Do people living with HIV in Nepal use implants often?
column2: No, implants are the least known and least used family planning method among people living with HIV in Nepal.

column1: Do healthcare workers encourage the use of condoms among HIV-positive couples?
column2: Yes, healthcare workers often recommend condoms as the safest and most effective method for HIV-positive couples.

column1: Is sterilization a common choice among HIV-positive couples?
column2: Some couples choose permanent methods like sterilization, but the number is lower compared to condom users.

column1: Do people’s beliefs about HIV affect their use of family planning?
column2: Yes, some people believe that if both partners are HIV positive, they don’t need family planning, which reduces their use of contraception.

column1: Can family planning improve the quality of life for people living with HIV?
column2: Yes, using family planning helps couples make safe reproductive choices, which improves their physical and emotional well-being.

column1: Do most people living with HIV in Nepal share their HIV status with their spouse?
column2: Yes, the majority tell their spouse about their HIV status, which supports mutual decision-making on family planning.

column1: Does sharing HIV status with a partner make it easier to use family planning?
column2: Yes, when both partners know each other's HIV status, they are more likely to agree on and use a family planning method.

column1: Do people living with HIV prefer short-term or long-term family planning methods?
column2: After diagnosis, most people prefer short-term methods like condoms instead of long-term methods such as IUCDs or implants.

column1: Are people with higher CD4 counts more likely to use family planning?
column2: No clear pattern was found between CD4 count levels and the use of family planning methods.

column1: Do family planning habits change after starting Antiretroviral Therapy?
column2: No major change was found in family planning habits after starting therapy, but consistent condom use became more common.

column1: Does early marriage affect people’s use of family planning later in life?
column2: Early marriage was not directly linked to higher or lower use of family planning among people living with HIV.

column1: Do most people living with HIV in Nepal have access to family planning services?
column2: Yes, most of them receive family planning counseling and services through ART clinics and government health facilities.

column1: Why do some people not know which family planning method to use?
column2: Some people lack proper information about which methods are safe and effective for those living with HIV.

column1: Do people who want more children use family planning too?
column2: Yes, some use temporary methods like condoms to plan pregnancy at a safer time.

column1: Do both men and women discuss family planning equally?
column2: In many cases, men are more likely to decide about family planning, especially when condom use is involved.

column1: Can couples use more than one method of family planning at the same time?
column2: Yes, using condoms along with another method, such as pills or injections, gives extra protection against pregnancy and infections.

column1: Why is consistent condom use important for people living with HIV?
column2: Consistent condom use protects against both pregnancy and the transmission of HIV and other sexually transmitted infections.

column1: Is condom use among people living with HIV reliable?
column2: Yes, most people who use condoms report that they use them consistently and correctly.

column1: Do women living with HIV face more barriers in using family planning?
column2: Yes, women may face challenges such as partner refusal, fear of side effects, or lack of decision-making power.

column1: Are men more open to using condoms after HIV diagnosis?
column2: Yes, after diagnosis, men are more likely to accept and use condoms regularly.

column1: Why do some couples stop using family planning when both partners have HIV?
column2: Some couples think that if both already have HIV, pregnancy will not increase health risks, so they stop using contraception.

column1: Do people who have not tested their spouse for HIV use family planning less?
column2: Yes, those who do not know their spouse’s HIV status are less likely to use family planning methods.

column1: Do religious beliefs stop people living with HIV from using family planning?
column2: No, religion did not have a strong effect on whether people used family planning methods.

column1: Is family planning use higher among middle-aged people living with HIV?
column2: Yes, people between 20 and 39 years of age are more likely to use family planning compared to other age groups.

column1: Can family planning help reduce mother-to-child HIV transmission?
column2: Yes, by preventing unintended pregnancies, family planning helps lower the chances of transmitting HIV from mother to child.

column1: Why do healthcare workers recommend condom use even for married couples with HIV?
column2: Because condoms prevent reinfection and protect against other sexually transmitted infections, even in married couples who both have HIV.

column1: Are people in urban areas more likely to use family planning than those in rural areas?
column2: Yes, people in urban areas often have better access to health facilities and information, so they are more likely to use family planning.

column1: Do most people living with HIV receive education about family planning at ART clinics?
column2: Yes, most ART clinics include family planning counseling as part of their services.

column1: Does family planning reduce stress for couples living with HIV?
column2: Yes, it helps couples feel more in control of their reproductive choices, which reduces anxiety and stress.

column1: Do people who disclose their HIV status feel more comfortable discussing family planning?
column2: Yes, being open about their HIV status helps couples communicate better and make shared family planning decisions.

column1: Is lack of information still a challenge for people living with HIV regarding family planning?
column2: Yes, a small number of people still do not know which family planning methods are suitable for them.

column1: Do most people living with HIV want more children after starting ART?
column2: Some do, but many choose to delay or avoid pregnancy even after starting Antiretroviral Therapy.

column1: Can HIV-positive couples use permanent methods of contraception?
column2: Yes, HIV-positive couples can safely use permanent methods like male or female sterilization if they do not want any more children.

column1: Do people living with HIV find it difficult to talk about family planning with their partner?
column2: Yes, some people find it hard to discuss family planning because of fear, stigma, or lack of communication.

column2: 28.2% were not using any family planning method.

column1: What was the most common reason for not using family planning?
column2: The most common reason was irregular sexual activity in the past 6 months (48%).

column1: What were other reasons for not using family planning methods?
column2: Other reasons included both partners being HIV positive (18%), fear of side effects (13%), spouse’s denial (10%), and lack of knowledge of appropriate family planning for people living with HIV (11%).

column1: Which factors were found to be associated with the use of family planning methods?
column2: Sex, caste, educational status, spouse’s education, and spouse’s HIV status were found to be associated with use of family planning.

column1: Which age groups were more likely to use family planning methods?
column2: Individuals aged 20–29 and 30–39 years were more likely to use family planning compared to other age groups.

column1: Which factors were not associated with family planning use?
column2: Age at marriage, religion, ethnicity, time since HIV diagnosis, use of ART, duration on ART, disclosure to spouse, latest CD4 count, HIV status of youngest child, desire for children, past childbirth, and intention for future childbearing were not associated.

column1: Who was more likely to use modern contraceptives?
column2: Modern contraceptive use was more likely among men compared to women (AOR = 2.48, p = 0.01).

column1: How did education level affect modern contraceptive use?
column2: Individuals with higher education levels were more likely to use modern contraceptives (AOR = 3.27, p < 0.01).

column1: How did knowing a spouse’s HIV status influence contraceptive use?
column2: Those who knew their spouse’s HIV status were more likely to use modern contraceptives (AOR = 4.70, p = 0.01).

column1: What is the current use of modern family planning methods compared to the general population?
column2: The current use of modern methods is 68%, higher than the 43% in the general population.

column1: How is contraceptive prevalence measured differently here compared to NDHS?
column2: NDHS measured contraceptive prevalence by asking only women, whereas both men and women are considered here.

column1: How does the rate of modern family planning use compare to other regions?
column2: It is similar to Kaski, Nepal (70%), lower than among HIV-infected individuals in India (92%), and higher than in some African nations.

column1: What happens to modern family planning rates when condom use is excluded?
column2: Excluding condom use, the current use of modern methods drops to 17%, suggesting possible overestimation of family planning utilization.

column1: How does HIV infection affect the use of non-condom contraceptives?
column2: There is a noticeable decline in use of non-condom contraceptives after HIV infection.

column1: What are the reasons for low use of non-condom contraceptives?
column2: Reasons include lack of discussion by healthcare providers, fear of side effects from pills or injectables, cost of implants or IUDs, and programmatic focus on condoms.

column1: Why is relying only on condoms a concern?
column2: Condoms have the highest failure rate among contraceptives, and women remain at potential risk of pregnancy from unprotected sex.

column1: What is recommended for better contraceptive protection for HIV-infected women?
column2: Women should use effective, women-controlled methods along with condoms, supported by counseling and training from healthcare providers to make informed choices.

column1: What is the most common reason for not using family planning methods?
column2: The most common reason is irregular sexual activity in the past 6 months.

column1: What are other reasons for non-utilization of family planning methods?
column2: Other reasons include fear of side effects, spouse refusal, lack of awareness regarding proper family planning methods, and both partners being HIV positive.

column1: What does the non-utilization of family planning indicate?
column2: It reflects a need for proper counseling and awareness on all methods of family planning.

column1: What percentage desired children or more children in the near future?
column2: Only about 20% desired children or more children, with an even smaller percentage planning pregnancy in the next six months.

column1: How does fertility desire relate to cultural and societal factors?
column2: Cultural and societal factors, including marriage and parenthood expectations, influence fertility desire. In Nepal, HIV status negatively impacts fertility desire despite societal value placed on childbearing.

column1: What is the average number of children and total fertility rate (TFR)?
column2: The mean number of children is 1.96 and the TFR in Nepal is 2.17.

column1: How does the number of existing children affect fertility desire?
column2: Fertility desire is lower among individuals with one to two children compared to those with no children.

column1: Is fertility desire associated with the use of family planning methods?
column2: In this context, fertility desire is not significantly associated with the use of family planning methods.

column1: Why might family planning use be low despite fertility desire?
column2: HIV-infected individuals may avoid initiating pregnancy and sexual intercourse due to concern about mother-to-child transmission, leading to low use of family planning methods.

column1: What is recommended to ensure safe pregnancy and prevent mother-to-child transmission?
column2: Proper counseling and effective use of family planning methods are needed to reduce mother-to-child transmission to zero.

column1: How are family planning services provided across Nepal?
column2: Family planning services in Nepal are delivered through government health facilities, private hospitals, and social marketing outlets. Public health facilities provide these services free of cost, while private and NGO-run clinics offer them either free or at subsidized rates.

column1: Which family planning methods are commonly available in Nepal?
column2: Temporary methods like condoms, pills, and injectables are available at health posts and through outreach clinics. Long-term methods like IUCDs and implants are offered at selected hospitals and primary health centers where trained staff are available.

column1: How are sterilization services delivered in Nepal?
column2: Depending on the district, sterilization services are offered either at static sites or through scheduled mobile and seasonal outreach programs.

column1: What are the main goals of Nepal’s family planning program under the Ministry of Health and Population?
column2: The Ministry aims to reduce the total fertility rate (TFR) to 2.5, lower the adolescent fertility rate (AFR) to 70 per 1,000 adolescents, and increase the contraceptive prevalence rate (CPR) to 67%.

column1: Has Nepal made progress in reducing fertility rates?
column2: Yes, the total fertility rate declined from 5.09 in 1991 to 2.6 in 2011, showing Nepal was close to achieving its national target of 2.5 by 2015.

column1: What changes have been observed in adolescent fertility in Nepal?
column2: The adolescent fertility rate dropped from 145 per 1,000 in 1976 to 81 per 1,000 in 2011, showing steady progress toward the national goal.

column1: What is the current status of contraceptive use in Nepal?
column2: The contraceptive prevalence rate increased from 3% in 1976 to about 50% in 2011, but progress has slowed in recent years, making it difficult to reach the target of 67%.

column1: What trend has been seen in permanent versus spacing methods?
column2: In 1986, permanent methods like sterilization dominated, with a ratio of 84% to 16% for spacing methods. By 2011, this shifted to 46% permanent and 54% spacing, showing growing interest in temporary methods.

column1: Which family planning method remains the most common in Nepal?
column2: Female sterilization is still the most widely used method, even though the use of IUCDs and implants remains low.

column1: How many pregnancies in Nepal are planned?
column2: According to national data, about three out of four births (74%) in recent years were planned, while 12% were mistimed and 13% were unwanted.

column1: Is knowledge about family planning common among Nepali people?
column2: Yes, almost all men and women in Nepal know at least one modern family planning method, though deeper understanding about specific methods is still limited.

column1: How has the desired number of children changed in Nepal over time?
column2: The average ideal number of children among married women fell from 2.9 in 1996 to 2.1 in 2011, showing a growing preference for smaller families.

column1: What changes have occurred in teenage pregnancy rates in Nepal?
column2: Teenage pregnancies declined from 24% in 1996 to 17% in 2011, indicating greater awareness and access to family planning.

column1: What is the current trend in birth spacing in Nepal?
column2: The average birth interval increased from 32 months in 1996 to 36 months in 2011, meaning couples are waiting longer between pregnancies.

column1: Has the unmet need for family planning decreased in Nepal?
column2: Unmet need dropped from 31% in 1996 to 25% in 2006, but slightly rose again to 27% in 2011, showing mixed progress.

column1: How does migration affect family planning use in Nepal?
column2: High male migration has caused many couples to live apart. About one-third of couples are separated, which affects contraceptive use and makes traditional indicators like CPR less accurate.

column1: What happens to contraceptive use when husbands migrate abroad?
column2: Many wives stop using family planning methods when their husbands are away to avoid social suspicion of infidelity. Data shows that 'husband living away' is the most common reason for discontinuing contraceptive use.

column1: What challenges do wives of migrant men face in using family planning?
column2: They often hesitate to ask for family planning services due to fear of judgment or denial by providers, and few make prior arrangements before their husbands return home.

column1: How has traditional method use changed in Nepal?
column2: Traditional methods like withdrawal and rhythm have increased from just 1% in 1991 to 6.5% in 2011, even though they are less effective than modern methods.

column1: Why is the increase in traditional method use a concern?
column2: It may indicate limited access to or trust in modern contraceptives, which can contribute to lower overall contraceptive effectiveness and higher unintended pregnancies.

column1: How has access to abortion services changed in Nepal?
column2: Since 2004, abortion services have expanded across all 75 districts, reaching even primary health centers. The introduction of medical abortion has made services more available in both public and private facilities.

column1: Why are more women seeking abortions in Nepal?
column2: Easier access to abortion and lack of consistent contraceptive use have led to more women seeking abortion services, even though many abortions could be avoided with effective contraception.

column1: What proportion of abortion clients were married and living with their spouse?
column2: Studies at Maternity Hospital in Kathmandu found that 97% of abortion clients were married and living with their spouse, with most having two children.

column1: What does the rise in abortion and emergency contraception indicate?
column2: It suggests gaps in regular family planning use and the need for better awareness so that abortion and emergency contraception are not used as substitutes for planned family planning.

column1: What strategies are recommended to strengthen family planning in Nepal?
column2: The program should focus on underserved groups like migrants, postpartum women, married adolescents, and rural communities through better coordination and integration with maternal, child health, and HIV services.

column1: How can family planning messages be made more effective?
column2: Messages about healthy timing and spacing of pregnancies should reach communities through strong behavior change communication and awareness campaigns.

column1: Why is integrating family planning with other health services important?
column2: Linking family planning with services like antenatal care, immunization, HIV treatment, and post-abortion care ensures more opportunities to counsel and reach women of reproductive age.

column1: What is the ideal approach to improving Nepal’s family planning program?
column2: Combining better data analysis, community-level advocacy, and inclusive service delivery can close the gaps in contraceptive use and unmet need, ensuring equitable access for all groups.

column2: The Government of Nepal provides family planning services through public health facilities

column1: What is comprehensive abortion care?

column1: Why is it important to talk about healthy spacing between pregnancies?
column2: Healthy spacing improves the health of mothers and babies and allows families to plan better lives.

column1: How can the government increase awareness about healthy timing and spacing?
column2: By spreading information through community-level campaigns and behavior change communication programs.

column1: Why is increased use of emergency contraception and abortion a concern?
column2: Because it shows that regular family planning methods are not being used effectively to prevent unwanted pregnancies.

column1: What should be done to discourage over-reliance on emergency contraception?

column1: Why is it difficult to measure family planning performance in Nepal accurately?

column1: What is suggested to better measure contraceptive use in Nepal?
