column1: When was the PPIUD intervention in Nepal carried out?
column2: The intervention was conducted between 2015 and 2017 across six tertiary hospitals in Nepal.

column1: What was the sample size of healthcare providers included in the study?
column2: A total of 96 trained healthcare providers were included in the final analysis who completed baseline, 6-month, and 24-month follow-up interviews.

column1: What was the average age of healthcare providers at baseline?
column2: The average age of healthcare providers at baseline was 37.1 years with an average of 11.8 years of professional experience.

column1: What percentage of providers were female?
column2: Approximately 81.3% of the healthcare providers who participated in the study were female.

column1: What were the main cadres of health professionals involved in the study?
column2: The study included obstetricians/gynecologists (34.4%), medical officers (1%), and nurses or midwives (62.5%).

column1: What is a PPIUD?
column2: A postpartum intrauterine device (PPIUD) is an intrauterine contraceptive inserted within 48 hours after childbirth to prevent unintended pregnancies and promote optimal birth spacing.

column1: Why is postpartum family planning (PPFP) important?
column2: Postpartum family planning helps women avoid closely spaced pregnancies, reducing risks of maternal, neonatal, and child mortality and morbidity.

column1: What was the baseline knowledge score among providers regarding PPIUDs?
column2: At baseline, providers scored an average of 2.9 out of 4 on the PPIUD knowledge index.

column1: How did the knowledge score change after 6 months of the intervention?
column2: After six months, the mean knowledge score increased significantly from 2.9 to 3.5 (p < 0.001).

column1: What was the knowledge score after 24 months?
column2: At 24 months, the mean knowledge score slightly decreased to 3.3 out of 4, though the change was not statistically significant.

column1: What was the mean attitude score at baseline?
column2: The mean attitude score at baseline was 4.0 out of 7.

column1: How did the attitude score change over time?
column2: It improved significantly to 5.3 after 6 months and further to 6.0 after 24 months (p < 0.001).

column1: What was the mean practice score at baseline?
column2: At baseline, the mean practice score was 0.9 out of 3, showing limited engagement in PPIUD counseling and provision.

column1: How did the practice score improve by 24 months?
column2: The mean practice score improved significantly to 3.0 after 24 months (p = 0.002).

column1: What percentage of providers offered general family planning counseling before the intervention?
column2: At baseline, 70.8% of providers offered general family planning counseling.

column1: How many providers offered PPIUD counseling before the intervention?
column2: Only 10.4% of providers offered PPIUD counseling before the intervention.

column1: What percentage of providers offered PPIUD insertion or removal before the intervention?
column2: At baseline, 9.4% of providers were involved in PPIUD insertion or removal.

column1: How did the proportion of providers offering PPIUD counseling change after 6 months?
column2: The percentage of providers offering PPIUD counseling rose significantly to 94.8% after six months (p < 0.001).

column1: How many providers offered PPIUD insertion by 24 months?
column2: By 24 months, 99% of providers were performing PPIUD insertions or removals.

column1: How did training affect providers’ knowledge of PPIUDs?
column2: Training substantially improved providers’ knowledge, particularly regarding correct IUD duration and immediate fertility after removal.

column1: What percentage of providers correctly knew that copper IUDs prevent pregnancy in less than 1% of cases at baseline?
column2: At baseline, 45.8% of providers knew that less than 1% of women get pregnant while using a copper IUD.

column1: Did this knowledge improve over time?
column2: Yes, it increased to 59.4% at six months but later declined to 38.5% at 24 months (p < 0.05).

column1: What percentage of providers knew that a copper IUD can be used for up to 12 years at baseline?
column2: 78.1% of providers knew the correct duration at baseline, rising to 100% by 24 months (p < 0.001).

column1: How many providers knew that a woman can conceive immediately after IUD removal?
column2: 63.5% knew this at baseline, 92.7% at six months, and 95.8% at 24 months.

column1: What percentage of providers correctly stated that IUDs do not protect against STIs?
column2: Almost all providers (99% at baseline, 100% at six months, and 99% at 24 months) knew this fact.

column1: Which groups of women were least likely to be recommended a PPIUD by providers at baseline?
column2: Unmarried women and women with a history of ectopic pregnancy were least likely to be recommended a PPIUD.

column1: How did attitudes towards recommending PPIUDs to unmarried women change?
column2: It rose from 17.7% at baseline to 77.1% at 24 months (p < 0.001).

column1: How did attitudes towards recommending PPIUDs to women with ectopic pregnancies change?
column2: The proportion increased from 8.3% at baseline to 45.8% at 24 months (p < 0.001).

column1: What percentage of providers recommended PPIUDs to women under 20 years old at baseline?
column2: At baseline, 61.5% of providers would recommend PPIUDs to women under 20.

column1: What percentage recommended PPIUDs to women over 40 years old at baseline?
column2: Only 34.4% would recommend PPIUDs to women aged 40 and above, but this rose to 86.5% by 24 months.

column1: How many providers viewed IUDs as the best family planning method after childbirth?
column2: 79.2% at baseline, increasing to 99% at 24 months (p < 0.001).

column1: What was the percentage of providers who believed it is important to protect women from pregnancy in the first postpartum year?
column2: Only around one-third (33.3%) believed it was important, with little change over time.

column1: What was one major barrier to IUD use among women in Nepal?
column2: Barriers included limited access in rural areas, lack of provider training, misconceptions, and social stigma surrounding IUD use.

column1: Why was the PPIUD intervention necessary in Nepal?
column2: Because of low IUD uptake (only 1.4% of married women used IUDs in 2016) and high unmet need for postpartum family planning.

column1: Which organization implemented the PPIUD intervention in Nepal?
column2: The Nepal Society of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (NESOG) implemented the intervention.

column1: Who conducted provider training for the PPIUD program?
column2: Training was conducted by the Nepal Health Training Center (NHTC) under the Ministry of Health and Population.

column1: How long was the provider training program?
column2: The training lasted three days and covered PPFP counseling, PPIUD insertion, infection prevention, and client management.

column1: What was the source of funding for the study?
column2: The study was funded by a grant to the Harvard T. H. Chan School of Public Health from an anonymous donor.

column1: How many providers in total were trained during the PPIUD project (2015–2019)?
column2: A total of 570 healthcare providers were trained during the FIGO PPIUD project period.

column1: What statistical tests were used to analyze KAP changes?
column2: The McNemar test and the Wilcoxon signed-rank test were used to evaluate differences over time.

column1: How did providers' practice change between baseline and 24 months?
column2: Practice improved dramatically, with PPIUD counseling rising from 10.4% to 99% and insertions from 9.4% to 99%.

column1: What was the key finding regarding provider bias?
column2: Despite improvement, provider bias persisted against recommending PPIUDs to unmarried women and those with ectopic pregnancies.

column1: How did untrained providers' attitudes change during the intervention?
column2: Untrained providers showed spillover effects, with improved attitudes towards recommending PPIUDs to younger and unmarried women.

column1: What did the study recommend for improving future interventions?
column2: It recommended ongoing refresher training, inclusion of social and medical eligibility in training, and emphasis on birth spacing.

column1: What limitation did the study acknowledge?
column2: The study had a small sample size and limited number of KAP survey questions, restricting detailed analysis.

column1: How does the study contribute to global health research?
column2: It provides two-year follow-up data, adding rare long-term evidence on PPIUD provider KAP improvements in low-income settings.

column1: What is the significance of ongoing training according to the study?
column2: Ongoing training ensures providers maintain accurate knowledge, reduce bias, and sustain quality postpartum family planning services.

column1: What is the overall conclusion of the study?
column2: The PPIUD intervention significantly improved provider knowledge, attitudes, and practices, though continued training is needed for sustained progress.

column1: What determines women's empowerment?
column2: Women's empowerment is determined by self-worth, ability to make choices, access to opportunities and resources, power to control their own lives, and ability to influence social change.

column1: What international commitments has Nepal made regarding women's empowerment?
column2: Nepal signed the ICPD in 1994, has incorporated women's empowerment in MDG 3, and continues to pursue SDG 5, which ensures equal access to education, healthcare, decent work, and representation in political and economic decision-making.

column1: How does NDHS measure women's empowerment?
column2: NDHS measures employment, earnings and control over earnings, participation in household decision-making, and attitudes towards intimate partner violence (IPV).

column1: Why is including Dalit women important for Nepal's family planning goals?
column2: Dalit women face caste-based discrimination and social stigma. Including them is essential to achieve global family planning commitments and Nepal's target of a 52% modern contraceptive prevalence rate by 2020.

column1: How does women's empowerment affect maternal and child health?
column2: Improving women's welfare and closing inequality gaps can improve maternal and child health, reduce mortality, and contribute to socioeconomic development.

column1: How are women's empowerment, abortion, and family planning related?
column2: Empowered women can exercise free choice, control fertility, make autonomous healthcare decisions, own assets, participate socially, and increase awareness, which improves safe abortion access and family planning uptake.

column1: What is the impact of easy access to contraceptive devices?
column2: Easy access to contraceptives reduces unsafe abortion, unintended pregnancies, and maternal and child health morbidity and mortality.

column1: Why is women's empowerment essential for decision-making in reproductive health?
column2: Empowerment is a precondition for women to have decision-making power over abortion, family planning, and broader life opportunities beyond traditional roles.

column1: Why is studying the association of women's empowerment with abortion and family planning important?
column2: Understanding this association is crucial to reduce morbidity and mortality related to unsafe abortion and to increase access to family planning services among marginalized women.

column1: What was the age distribution in the group studied?
column2: The majority (40.2%) were aged 20–24 years with a mean age of 25.68 years.

column1: What proportion belonged to the Dalit community?
column2: Almost 73% belonged to the Dalit community.

column1: What was the education and occupation status?
column2: 38.3% had informal education and 88.6% were homemakers.

column1: What was the family type distribution?
column2: Most (67.1%) belonged to nuclear families.

column1: How did women's empowerment relate to contraceptive use?
column2: Current use of modern contraceptives was higher among women with below-average empowerment (p=0.041, OR=0.593).

column1: Was there an association between women's empowerment and abortion or family planning knowledge?
column2: No significant differences were found for abortion knowledge (p=0.549), family planning knowledge (p=0.495), or decision for future use of modern contraceptives (p=0.977).

column1: What are the reasons and circumstances for abortion?
column2: Abortion occurs among women aged 20–35, sometimes illegally after sex determination at 3–4 months; causes include unwanted pregnancy, unmet family planning needs, and default of Depo-Provera. Health centers provide medical abortion and pregnancy test services.

column1: How was reproductive healthcare decision-making handled?
column2: 83.7% of couples decided jointly on contraception, 61.1% of women could refuse sexual intercourse, 50.8% could ask their husbands to use condoms, 88.9% had joint healthcare decisions, and 90.5% jointly decided on using income.

column1: How did women's empowerment relate to contraceptive use?
column2: Current use of modern contraceptives was higher among women with below-average empowerment (p=0.041, OR=0.593).

column1: What was the knowledge on fertility and abortion?
column2: 27.8% had knowledge on fertile period, 2.5% had knowledge on legal abortion provisions.

column1: What was the prevalence of abortion and post-abortion care?
column2: 14% had a history of abortion; among them, one did not receive post-abortion care and family planning services.

column1: What was the knowledge and use of modern contraceptive methods?
column2: 77% had knowledge of modern contraceptive methods; 63.84% were currently using contraception, with 41.6% using Depo-Provera, 39.3% sterilisation, and 47.4% considering use in the near future.

column1: What was the main focus of the study 'Men on the move and the wives left behind'?
column2: The study explored how male migration from Nepal affects family planning, fertility awareness, decision-making, and reproductive health among wives left behind.

column1: When was the study conducted?
column2: Data were collected between August and September 2016, as part of the Fertility Awareness Community Transformation (FACT) Project.

column1: Which organization funded the study?
column2: The study was funded by the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) under the FACT Project.

column1: How many women participated in the survey?
column2: A total of 2,430 women aged 15–24 years participated across five districts in Nepal.

column1: How many of the surveyed women were married?
column2: Out of the 2,430 women surveyed, 1,123 were married.

column1: What percentage of married women had migrant husbands?
column2: 43.2% of the married women reported having husbands working abroad for more than six months.

column1: What was the average age of married women in the study?
column2: The mean age of married women was 21.5 years across both groups of women with and without migrant husbands.

column1: Which regions had the highest share of migrant husbands?
column2: The Hill region had the highest proportion of women with migrant husbands (48.5%), followed by the Terai region (32%) and the Mountain region (19.5%).

column1: What percentage of married women had husbands working within Nepal but outside their community?
column2: About 5.3% of married women had husbands working within Nepal but away from home for more than three months.

column1: What was the dominant religion among women with migrant husbands?
column2: A majority, 91.1%, of women with migrant husbands identified as Hindu.

column1: Which ethnic groups had the highest migration rates?
column2: Dalits (52%), Brahman/Chhetri (42.5%), and Muslims (41.7%) had the highest rates of male migration.

column1: What percentage of women visited a health clinic recently?
column2: About 69% of all married women had visited a health clinic recently.

column1: How many women received family planning counselling at a clinic?
column2: Less than one-third (around 30%) of those who visited clinics received family planning counselling.

column1: Who are the main providers of family planning services in Nepal?
column2: Female Community Health Volunteers (FCHVs) and clinic staff provide family planning counselling, condoms, contraceptive pills, and referrals for other services.

column1: Were women with migrant husbands more or less likely to receive counselling?
column2: Women with migrant husbands were less likely to receive counselling or outreach services from FCHVs compared to other married women.

column1: What is fertility awareness as defined in the study?
column2: Fertility awareness refers to actionable knowledge about fertility throughout life and the ability to apply this knowledge to personal reproductive decisions.

column1: How did fertility awareness scores compare between the two groups?
column2: Women with migrant husbands scored significantly lower on fertility awareness (p = 0.02) than women with resident husbands.

column1: How many women correctly understood the menstrual cycle?
column2: Around 75% of women knew what menstruation was, but only 20% accurately identified the fertile window.

column1: How many women discussed family planning with their husbands?
column2: Only 37.7% of women with migrant husbands had ever discussed family planning with their spouse, compared to 53.5% of non-migrant wives.

column1: What percentage of women with migrant husbands discussed pregnancy timing?
column2: 64.5% of wives with migrant husbands discussed timing of pregnancy compared to 74% of women with resident husbands (p < 0.01).

column1: How many women described their marriage as 'strong' or 'good'?
column2: Over 80% of women rated their marriage as 'strong' or 'good', but more wives of migrants reported their relationship as 'fair' or 'poor' (11.4%, p < 0.01).

column1: How many women reported having autonomy in decision-making?
column2: Across all topics, about 60% of women reported having no autonomy, meaning that decisions were made by husbands or other family members.

column1: Did wives of migrants have more autonomy?
column2: Yes, wives of migrant husbands were 3.6–5.5 times more likely to have full autonomy in household and reproductive decisions.

column1: Who usually made decisions for women with no autonomy?
column2: For women with no autonomy, in-laws, especially mothers-in-law and fathers-in-law, often made health and mobility decisions.

column1: What was the main barrier to family planning among women with migrant husbands?
column2: Limited counselling access, reduced communication with absent spouses, and fear of social stigma were key barriers.

column1: What proportion of women intended to become pregnant in the next year?
column2: 36.5% of wives with migrant husbands intended to become pregnant within a year, compared to 26.1% of other married women.

column1: What percentage of all married women used modern family planning methods?
column2: About 20.4% of all married women reported using modern family planning methods.

column1: Were wives of migrants more or less likely to use family planning?
column2: They were 80% less likely to use modern family planning compared to wives with resident husbands (OR = 0.2, p < 0.001).

column1: Did husbands support family planning?
column2: Yes, 94% of all women said their husbands supported family planning use.

column1: What was the most important predictor of family planning intention?
column2: Couple communication was the strongest predictor—women who discussed FP were 4 times more likely to intend to use it (p < 0.001).

column1: What percentage of women had high fertility awareness?
column2: Less than half had high fertility awareness; women with migrant husbands scored significantly lower than others.

column1: Did women with migrant husbands feel pressure to have children immediately?
column2: They were 1.5 times more likely not to feel pressure to conceive immediately after marriage (p < 0.01).

column1: How did son preference differ between groups?
column2: Women with migrant husbands were 1.5 times less likely to feel pressure to have sons compared to others (p < 0.01).

column1: Did social norms affect family planning behaviour?
column2: Yes, women with migrant husbands perceived family planning as less acceptable in their communities (p < 0.01).

column1: What was the average number of pregnancies among married women?
column2: The mean number of pregnancies was 1.1, lower than Nepal’s national average of 2.3 children per woman.

column1: Why did some women avoid using contraceptives?
column2: Some avoided contraceptives to prevent rumours of infidelity while their husbands were abroad.

column1: How did migration impact access to reproductive health services?
column2: Wives of migrants were less likely to visit clinics or receive FP counselling, partly due to lower autonomy and mobility restrictions.

column1: What program implemented the survey?
column2: The Fertility Awareness Community Transformation (FACT) Project, led by the Institute of Reproductive Health at Georgetown University in collaboration with Save the Children.

column1: What was the purpose of the FACT project?
column2: It aimed to increase fertility awareness, educate on fertility-based methods, and improve access to and uptake of modern family planning in Nepal.

column1: How were the study areas selected?
column2: Three clusters of three Village Development Committees (VDCs) within five districts—Bajura, Pyuthan, Nuwakot, Rupandehi, and Siraha—were randomly assigned to study arms.

column1: How was data collected?
column2: Data were collected digitally using Android smartphones and the REMO program, with ethical approval from Georgetown University and the Nepal Health Research Council.

column1: What types of autonomy were measured?
column2: Five types: visiting family or friends, managing finances, seeking health care, spending on health, and deciding when to get pregnant.

column1: What percentage of women visited a clinic in the last six months?
column2: Around 69% had visited a clinic, but counselling coverage remained low, especially among wives of migrants.

column1: What does the study suggest about fertility awareness education?
column2: Improving fertility knowledge could help women plan pregnancies and use family planning more effectively, especially among those with migrant husbands.

column1: What interventions could benefit women with migrant husbands?
column2: Preconception counselling, improved spousal communication, and family-inclusive programs involving in-laws could improve outcomes.

column1: How might migration affect mental health?
column2: Wives of migrants often report loneliness, isolation, and depressive symptoms, especially when decision-making is controlled by in-laws.

column1: What positive effects can migration have on families?
column2: Remittances may increase household income and women’s financial decision-making power but also increase responsibilities.

column1: What proportion of households in Nepal are female-headed?
column2: Female-headed households nearly doubled from 16% in 2011 to 31% in 2016, largely due to male migration.

column1: Why is couple communication important for reproductive health?
column2: Open communication improves trust, joint decision-making, and family planning use among couples, especially when separated by migration.

column1: What are the study’s key recommendations?
column2: Design interventions that improve fertility knowledge, promote preconception health, and strengthen couple communication across distances.

column1: How can Female Community Health Volunteers support left-behind wives?
column2: FCHVs can offer nutrition counselling, preconception advice, and family planning guidance before husbands return from abroad.

column1: Why is autonomy important for women’s health?
column2: Autonomy enables women to seek care, make informed reproductive decisions, and maintain their health despite social constraints.

column1: What is the global implication of this study?
column2: The findings reflect how migration affects reproductive autonomy and FP use, offering lessons for other South Asian migrant-sending countries.

column1: What were the main limitations of the study?
column2: The study covered only five districts, included mainly young married women, and may reflect seasonal biases during the festival period.

column1: What is the overall conclusion of the study?
column2: Wives of migrant husbands form a vulnerable group with lower FP use, weaker spousal communication, and unique reproductive needs. Targeted interventions can improve their health and autonomy.

column1: Why are shorter interpregnancy intervals common in Nepal despite known health risks?
column2: Because of limited awareness about the risks
column4: and cultural pressures that prioritize frequent childbirth.

column1: What does the 28% rate of pregnancies within 24 months suggest about the effectiveness of postpartum family planning programs?
column2: It indicates that postpartum family planning interventions are not reaching or effectively influencing a significant portion of women soon after childbirth.

column1: Why are younger women more likely to experience shorter pregnancy intervals?
column2: Younger women often face social expectations to prove fertility early
column3: have limited access to contraceptive information
column4: and possess lower decision-making autonomy.

column1: How does education influence the length of the interval between births?
column2: Higher education improves knowledge and access to family planning services
column3: reducing the likelihood of short birth intervals.

column1: Why is the pregnancy interval shorter among poorer women?
column2: Economic disadvantage limits access to contraceptives and counselling
column3: and financial dependency reduces women’s agency in reproductive decisions.

column1: What do differences between ethnic groups (e.g.
column2: Muslims vs. Newars) indicate about family planning equity?
column4: religious
column5: and access-based disparities in reproductive health awareness and service utilization.

column1: Why might rural women have shorter intervals between births than urban women?
column2: Because rural women face geographic barriers to services
column4: and stronger traditional norms favoring large families.

column1: What does the low rate of postpartum counselling (9%) reveal about healthcare delivery in Nepal?
column2: It shows significant missed opportunities within the health system to integrate family planning counselling into routine maternal and child health services.

column1: Why does high sexual activity and menstruation within 12–23 months postpartum not translate into higher contraceptive use?
column2: Because awareness of fertility return is low and postpartum women underestimate their risk of pregnancy after delivery.

column1: What does the 52% unmet need for contraception among postpartum women imply about system gaps?
column2: It reflects both demand-side barriers (knowledge
column4: provider bias) in family planning programs.

column1: Why is unmet need for limiting greater than for spacing after 12 months postpartum?
column2: Because many women have achieved their desired family size but lack access or confidence in methods for permanent or long-term contraception.

column1: How does reliance on traditional methods affect unintended pregnancy rates?
column2: Traditional methods are less effective
column3: leading to higher risks of unintended pregnancies
column4: which can result in repeat abortions or short birth intervals.

column1: What explains the high initial uptake of modern methods (mainly LAM) within 0–5 months postpartum?
column2: Because breastfeeding mothers rely on LAM early on
column3: but many do not transition to other modern methods once fertility resumes.

column1: Why does contraceptive use decline sharply after 5 months postpartum?
column2: Due to waning use of LAM without timely adoption of alternative methods and lack of follow-up counselling from health workers.

column1: What are the implications of short birth intervals for maternal and child health?
column2: They increase the risk of maternal depletion
column4: low birth weight
column5: and higher infant mortality.

column1: Why do socioeconomic and educational disparities mirror each other in contraceptive uptake?
column2: Because education is closely tied to income
column4: and autonomy—factors that collectively shape reproductive health behaviors.

column1: What does the variation by caste and ethnicity reveal about cultural determinants of family planning?
column2: It underscores the influence of religion
column4: and community attitudes on contraceptive use and pregnancy spacing.

column1: How does the low transition from traditional to modern methods affect national reproductive health goals?
column2: It slows progress toward reducing unintended pregnancies and undermines maternal and child health targets.

column1: Why might healthcare providers miss opportunities for counselling postpartum women?
column2: Due to workload pressures
column3: lack of integration between maternal and family planning services
column4: and insufficient provider training.

column1: What does the difference in spacing among education levels suggest about intergenerational health outcomes?
column2: Educated women are more likely to plan pregnancies
column3: resulting in healthier mothers and children and better long-term socioeconomic outcomes.

column1: Why is it critical to integrate PPFP into existing maternal health programs?
column2: Because childbirth provides a key contact point for health workers to counsel women when motivation and need for contraception are highest.

column1: How might strengthening community-based counselling improve PPFP uptake?
column2: It ensures culturally sensitive
column4: especially in rural areas where facility-based counselling is rare.

column1: What are the policy implications of 52% unmet need within two years postpartum?
column2: There is an urgent need to expand access to quality PPFP counselling
column4: and promote timely transitions from LAM.

column1: How does the observed pattern of fertility return highlight the gap between knowledge and behavior?
column2: Although most women resume menstruation
column4: showing a disconnection between awareness and perceived risk.

column1: What strategies could reduce short interpregnancy intervals in Nepal?
column2: Expanding postpartum counselling
column4: and improving rural access to affordable and acceptable contraceptive methods.

column1: Why are short birth-to-pregnancy intervals considered a public health risk?
column2: Because intervals shorter than 24 months increase the risk of maternal mortality
column4: low birth weight
column5: and neonatal and perinatal mortality.

column1: What does the 24-month median interval in Nepal suggest about national progress on birth spacing?
column2: It suggests moderate success in promoting healthy spacing but highlights that a significant proportion of women still conceive too early after birth.

column1: How do Nepal’s short birth intervals compare to other developing countries?
column2: Nepal’s rate is similar to several African and Asian countries
column3: indicating that short spacing is a widespread issue across low- and middle-income contexts.

column1: Why are women who gave birth before age 20 more likely to have shorter pregnancy intervals?
column2: Younger mothers often face social and familial pressure to prove fertility early
column4: and possess limited access to family planning information.

column1: How does rural residence contribute to shorter pregnancy intervals?
column2: Rural women often lack access to health facilities
column4: and contraceptives
column5: resulting in higher rates of closely spaced pregnancies.

column1: What is the role of religion in determining birth spacing practices?
column2: Religious beliefs
column3: such as those within Muslim communities
column4: can influence contraceptive attitudes and limit acceptance or use of modern methods.

column1: How does poverty amplify the risk of short interpregnancy intervals?
column2: Poorer women face affordability barriers
column4: and limited access to private providers
column5: reducing their ability to practice planned spacing.

column1: What does the study suggest about targeting family planning education?
column2: It recommends prioritizing high-risk groups—rural
column4: uneducated
column5: young
column6: and Muslim women—through tailored counselling and community-based outreach.

column1: How does breastfeeding affect the return of fertility?
column2: Exclusive breastfeeding can delay ovulation for up to six months
column3: but fertility may return unpredictably once feeding frequency decreases or menstruation resumes.

column1: Why is counselling on fertility return critical during postpartum care?
column2: Because many women underestimate how soon fertility can return
column3: leading to unintended pregnancies within months after delivery.

column1: What systemic issue causes many postpartum women to neglect contraception?
column2: Weak integration between maternal health services and family planning counselling leads to missed opportunities during antenatal care (ANC) and postnatal care (PNC) visits.

column1: Why is unmet need for family planning higher among postpartum women than among all married women?
column2: Postpartum women are often excluded from standard family planning initiatives and lack follow-up after delivery.

column1: What policy implications arise from higher unmet need for limiting than spacing?
column2: It indicates the need to expand long-acting and permanent contraceptive options during postpartum and infant care services.

column1: How could integration of postpartum family planning (PPFP) with the Expanded Programme on Immunization (EPI) improve contraceptive uptake?
column2: By using immunization visits as contact points for counselling
column4: and transition from the Lactational Amenorrhea Method (LAM) to other modern contraceptive methods.

column1: Why is the promotion of the Lactational Amenorrhea Method (LAM) a key opportunity in Nepal’s postpartum programs?
column2: Because the majority of mothers breastfeed exclusively
column3: making LAM a practical entry point for promoting family planning within six months postpartum.

column1: What challenges do stockouts in public facilities create for family planning equity?
column2: They force poor women—who cannot afford private care—to face higher unmet need and unintended pregnancies.

column1: Why do mountain areas show higher fertility and lower contraceptive prevalence than Terai and hill regions?
column2: Geographical isolation and weaker service infrastructure reduce access to family planning and health education in mountain regions.

column1: How do demographic and socioeconomic disparities affect postpartum contraceptive uptake?
column2: They lead to unequal access and outcomes
column4: urban
column5: and educated women better able to space or limit births.

column1: What limitation of the Nepal Demographic and Health Survey (NDHS) dataset constrains understanding of postpartum family planning?
column2: The lack of service-level data prevents analysis of counselling quality
column4: and provider competency.

column1: Why is qualitative research important for understanding postpartum family planning barriers?
column2: Because it can reveal cultural norms
column4: and behavioral factors not captured in quantitative surveys.

column1: What kind of programmatic coordination is needed to improve postpartum family planning?
column2: Closer collaboration between safe motherhood
column4: and family planning programs to ensure counselling at every maternal care contact.

column1: How can routine institutional deliveries be leveraged to improve family planning uptake?
column2: By offering predischarge counselling and services like Postpartum Intrauterine Copper Device (PPIUCD) insertion before women leave health facilities.

column1: What broader socioeconomic benefits can family planning provide beyond health outcomes?
column2: It contributes to women’s education
column4: and empowerment
column5: improving overall family and community well-being.

column1: Why is it essential to address inequalities in postpartum contraception access?
column2: Because persistent gaps among poor
column4: and minority women undermine national progress toward maternal and child health goals.

column1: How can future research build on this study’s findings?
column2: By combining quantitative and qualitative methods to explore provider behavior
column4: and women’s decision-making processes.

column1: What is the relationship between communication and decision-making in family planning?
column2: Open and frequent communication between partners helps in better joint decision-making about family planning, ensuring both understand and agree on their reproductive choices.

column1: Why is spousal communication important in family planning?
column2: Spousal communication allows couples to share their views, plan together, and make informed choices about when or whether to have children.

column1: What factors influence how couples communicate about family planning in Nepal?
column2: Age, education level, cultural background, and whether they live in rural or urban areas can all influence how couples communicate about family planning.

column1: Do most Nepali couples discuss family planning together?
column2: Many couples do, but not all. Around half of couples report open discussions about family planning, while others may avoid or disagree on whether such discussions occurred.

column1: How often do husbands and wives agree on whether they discussed family planning?
column2: Agreement between husbands and wives varies, with around 41% to 54% of couples reporting similar views on whether they discussed family planning topics.

column1: What are some challenges couples face in discussing family planning?
column2: Some couples face barriers such as cultural expectations, gender norms, or lack of confidence to discuss sensitive topics openly.

column1: How does location affect communication about family planning?
column2: Couples in rural areas may have less access to information or support for open discussion compared to those in urban areas, though this is changing over time.

column1: How many children do most couples in Nepal have?
column2: The majority of Nepali couples tend to have one or two children, reflecting a gradual shift toward smaller family sizes.

column1: What is the significance of joint decision-making in family planning?
column2: Joint decision-making ensures that both partners’ views are respected, leading to healthier relationships and more consistent use of family planning methods.

column1: How can improving communication benefit family planning outcomes?
column2: Better communication helps couples understand their needs and options, reduces misunderstandings, and supports mutual agreement on the use of family planning methods.

column1: How common is communication about family planning among couples?
column2: Many couples openly talk about family planning topics such as family size, contraception, and methods to use. These conversations are often seen as positive and important for mutual happiness and understanding.

column1: Why is it important for couples to discuss family planning together?
column2: Discussing family planning helps couples make thoughtful decisions about their future, strengthens trust, and promotes love and coordination between partners.

column1: Do most couples feel comfortable talking about family planning?
column2: Yes, most couples report feeling comfortable discussing these topics, especially about family size and contraception, as it helps them manage their family life better.

column1: Who usually starts the conversation about family planning?
column2: Women are often more likely to start discussions about family size or contraception, though many men also engage openly when the topic is brought up.

column1: How do couples describe their comfort level discussing contraception?
column2: Many couples, especially those who are educated or have strong mutual understanding, say they feel very comfortable discussing contraception methods without hesitation.

column1: What helps couples feel more at ease talking about family planning?
column2: Mutual respect, education, and emotional closeness make it easier for partners to discuss family planning freely and without discomfort.

column1: Are there couples who still find it difficult to talk about contraception?
column2: Yes, some couples—both men and women—still feel shy or uncomfortable discussing contraception, though they acknowledge that such conversations are necessary.

column1: What role does respect play in family planning communication?
column2: Respect helps both partners share opinions equally, listen to each other, and make decisions together without fear or hesitation.

column1: What do some men believe about women’s roles in family decisions?
column2: Many men believe women should have equal rights in decision-making and opportunities, not just limited to household or childcare duties.

column1: What are some reasons a husband might avoid using modern contraceptives?
column2: Some husbands worry about the side effects of contraceptive medicines on their wives’ health, and in such cases, they take personal responsibility to prevent unwanted pregnancies.

column1: How do couples usually make decisions about which family planning method to use?
column2: Most couples decide together which method is suitable, with about 87% of couples reporting joint decision-making on family planning choices.

column1: Why is joint decision-making important in family planning?
column2: When both partners decide together, it leads to better understanding, shared responsibility, and a stronger emotional bond in the relationship.

column1: What connection exists between shared decision-making and relationship closeness?
column2: Couples who make family planning decisions together often report feeling closer, more coordinated, and more supported by each other.

column1: Why do some people hesitate to discuss contraception even though they know it’s important?
column2: Cultural norms, shyness, or fear of judgment can make it hard for some people to start such conversations, even when they understand their importance.

column1: How can couples improve their communication about family planning?
column2: By being open, patient, and supportive with each other, and by understanding that discussing these topics leads to a healthier and happier family life.

column1: How are communication and decision-making related in family planning?
column2: Couples who communicate openly about family planning are much more likely to make joint decisions together about their reproductive choices.

column1: Why does good communication lead to better decision-making in family planning?
column2: When partners talk about family planning topics, they build understanding and trust, which helps them reach mutual decisions that suit both of their needs.

column1: What happens when couples discuss several topics related to family planning?
column2: Couples who talk about multiple aspects of family planning—such as timing, number of children, and contraceptive methods—are more likely to agree and make shared decisions.

column1: Are couples who talk more about family planning more likely to agree on decisions?
column2: Yes, couples who frequently discuss family planning are over twice as likely to make joint, consistent decisions compared to those who don’t communicate as much.

column1: Does discussing only one family planning topic have the same impact as discussing several?
column2: No, discussing only one topic doesn’t have a strong effect. Couples who talk about several topics tend to have better agreement and shared decision-making.

column1: What is the overall message about communication and family planning decisions?
column2: Open and honest communication between partners is key to ensuring both agree and actively participate in family planning choices, leading to healthier and happier relationships.

column1: Why is it important to study how communication and decision-making about family planning are connected?
column2: Understanding how couples communicate and make joint decisions helps improve family planning programs and ensures both partners’ needs and opinions are respected.

column1: Do communication and decision-making always go hand in hand?
column2: Not always. While open communication often supports shared decision-making, the two don’t always move together in a simple or linear way.

column1: What other factors can influence how couples communicate and decide about family planning?
column2: Gender roles, cultural beliefs, family expectations, and migration experiences can all shape how couples discuss and decide on family planning.

column1: Why should family planning be studied in different communities and countries?
column2: Studying various social and cultural settings helps reveal how context affects communication, decision-making, and family planning practices, leading to more effective solutions.

column1: How can better research improve family planning outcomes?
column2: By combining both numbers (quantitative data) and stories (qualitative data), researchers can understand the real reasons behind how couples communicate and decide, helping design programs that better support families.

column1: What does this mean for family planning education and awareness programs?
column2: Programs should encourage open discussion, mutual respect, and shared responsibility between partners to achieve healthier and more satisfying family planning outcomes.

column1: Why should communication and decision-making be viewed together rather than separately?
column2: Because how couples talk and how they decide are deeply connected—understanding both gives a clearer picture of what helps families make the best choices.

column1: What is the broader goal of studying communication and decision-making in family planning?
column2: The goal is to create practical strategies and education programs that help couples work together, improve reproductive health, and strengthen family well-being.

column1: Which South Asian countries have a high rate of male sterilization?
column2: Nepal and Bhutan are among the South Asian countries with the highest rates of male sterilization.

column1: What is the current pattern of contraceptive use in Nepal?
column2: Contraceptive use in Nepal is more common among women, but a significant number of men also choose sterilization, making up about one-third of all sterilized couples.

column1: What does 'unmet need for limiting fertility' mean in Nepal's context?
column2: It refers to couples who wish to stop having children but are not using any contraceptive method. In Nepal, this group represents more than two-thirds of the total unmet need for family planning.

column1: What are the goals of Nepal’s National Family Planning Program?
column2: The program aims to increase access to modern contraception, especially for poor and socially excluded communities in remote and underserved areas.

column1: How are family planning services delivered in Nepal?
column2: Services are provided through hospitals, health posts, primary health care centers, private clinics, pharmacies, NGOs, and mobile family planning camps.

column1: Which organizations are involved in family planning in Nepal?
column2: Key organizations include the Family Planning Association of Nepal (FPAN), Marie Stopes Nepal, and the Nepal Red Cross, along with government health services.

column1: Are family planning services free in Nepal?
column2: Yes, most family planning services offered through government and some NGO programs are free of charge.

column1: What are mobile sterilization camps and why are they important?
column2: Mobile sterilization camps are temporary community-based clinics that bring reproductive health services to remote areas with limited health facilities. They’ve been active in Nepal for over 30 years.

column1: Who usually provides sterilization services in these mobile camps?
column2: Medical teams, including gynecological surgeons, travel to remote areas—especially during the dry season—to offer procedures such as vasectomy and laparoscopic sterilization.

column1: Why do many women in remote areas choose sterilization?
column2: Many women in rural or poor households opt for sterilization because they lack access to other contraceptives or fear losing financial support if their husbands undergo vasectomy.

column1: How does geography affect access to family planning services in Nepal?
column2: The mountain and hill regions often have poor access to health facilities and higher fertility rates, while the terai plains have better transportation and service availability.

column1: How are people informed about mobile family planning camps?
column2: Community health volunteers and female health workers often go door-to-door to inform families about upcoming mobile camps and available services.

column1: What role do men play in family planning in Nepal?
column2: Men sometimes attend mobile family planning camps, seek contraception voluntarily, or participate through encouragement from their spouses or peers.

column1: What factors influence whether men or women choose sterilization?
column2: Education, cultural beliefs, financial incentives, gender norms, and service accessibility all play roles in determining who opts for sterilization.

column1: Why do some people hesitate about vasectomy?
column2: There is a belief that vasectomy may make men physically weak or unable to support their families, which discourages some from choosing it.

column1: Why are mobile clinics important for men’s participation in family planning?
column2: Mobile clinics provide accessible and confidential services that encourage men to take part in family planning, especially in areas with limited health facilities.

column1: What overall impact do mobile family planning clinics have in Nepal?
column2: They help reach remote communities, promote awareness, and provide both men and women with access to long-term family planning options, supporting more balanced participation.

column1: How does the use of mobile clinics affect male sterilization rates in Nepal?
column2: Men are more likely to choose vasectomy in mobile clinics compared to government hospitals, showing that mobile services play a key role in encouraging male participation.

column1: Why are vasectomy rates higher in mobile clinics?
column2: Mobile clinics make services more accessible, especially in remote areas, and provide a comfortable environment for men to seek family planning options.

column1: Which regions of Nepal show higher vasectomy use through mobile clinics?
column2: Vasectomy use is notably higher in the hill and mountain regions where health facilities are limited and mobile clinics are often the main source of family planning services.

column1: How does family composition affect vasectomy decisions?
column2: Men with three or more sons or only daughters are more likely to choose vasectomy, often because they feel their desired family size has been reached.

column1: What does the difference between clinics and hospitals suggest?
column2: It shows that bringing services closer to communities through mobile clinics reduces barriers such as travel distance, cost, and stigma, increasing male participation in family planning.

column1: Why are mobile family planning clinics important for gender equity?
column2: They encourage men to take active responsibility in reproductive health, balancing the burden of contraception that often falls on women.

column1: How do mobile clinics improve access to family planning in remote areas?
column2: By traveling to villages and hard-to-reach communities, mobile clinics ensure that both men and women can access safe and modern contraceptive methods without needing to visit distant hospitals.

column1: What should future reproductive health programs consider based on these findings?
column2: Programs should include more mobile clinics as part of their strategy to reach rural populations and promote male involvement in family planning.

column1: What is the overall benefit of mobile family planning clinics?
column2: They increase the use of male-based methods like vasectomy, improve accessibility for remote populations, and promote shared responsibility between partners in reproductive health.

column1: What is the main goal of Nepal’s national family planning program?
column2: The main goal of Nepal’s national family planning program is to improve the health and overall quality of life of families by increasing access to and use of modern contraceptive services as part of essential health care.

column1: Which sectors provide family planning services in Nepal?
column2: Family planning services in Nepal are provided through government health facilities
column4: non-governmental organizations
column5: and social marketing networks.

column1: Which modern contraceptive methods are commonly provided through Nepal’s public health system?
column2: The public health system provides male condoms
column4: injectables
column5: implants
column6: and intrauterine contraceptive devices depending on the level of the health facility and the availability of trained personnel.

column1: Who are female community health volunteers and what is their role in family planning?
column2: Female community health volunteers are local women trained to provide family planning information and distribute basic contraceptives like condoms and pills in their communities.

column1: How has Nepal’s fertility rate changed over the past decades?
column2: Nepal’s total fertility rate decreased significantly from 5.1 children per woman in 1991 to 2.6 in 2011
column3: showing progress in family planning efforts.

column1: What does contraceptive prevalence rate mean and how has it changed in Nepal?
column2: The contraceptive prevalence rate measures the percentage of women using any form of contraception; in Nepal it rose from 28.5 percent in 1996 to nearly 50 percent in 2011.

column1: Why is it important to promote family planning in Nepal beyond reducing family size?
column2: Family planning should focus on improving women’s and children’s health and preventing unintended pregnancies that pose physical
column4: and economic risks for families and society.

column1: Why is there a disparity in contraceptive use between different ethnic groups in Nepal?
column2: Differences in education
column4: and religious interpretations contribute to varying rates of contraceptive use
column5: with Muslim women having much lower usage compared to Brahmin and Chhetri women.

column1: How does poverty relate to family size in Nepal?
column2: Larger families are associated with higher levels of poverty; households with three or more children experience poverty rates nearly four times higher than those without children.

column1: What were some key demographic characteristics of Muslim women surveyed in Nepal regarding family planning?
column2: Most Muslim women surveyed were aged 20 to 30
column3: had little or no formal education
column4: were housewives
column5: and had an average of four children.

column1: How do religious beliefs influence family planning practices among Muslim women in Nepal?
column2: Religious beliefs play a major role
column3: as some interpret Islam as permitting contraception for health or financial reasons
column4: while others believe preventing birth is against divine will.

column1: How do community norms affect women’s willingness to discuss or use contraceptives?
column2: Strong social norms and fear of judgment often lead women to use family planning methods secretly
column3: avoiding open discussion even with close relatives.

column1: Why do many women prefer seeking family planning services far from home?
column2: Women often prefer distant health centers or private clinics to maintain privacy and avoid being recognized by community members.

column1: Who has the most influence on women’s decisions about family planning in Muslim communities in Nepal?
column2: Husbands are the primary decision-makers for most women regarding family planning
column3: with about three-quarters of women saying their husbands make the final decision.

column1: What impact does husband involvement have on contraceptive use?
column2: When husbands are involved in decision-making
column3: women are significantly more likely to use contraceptives
column4: showing that spousal communication is a strong determinant of adoption.

column1: Why is secrecy important for women using contraceptives in conservative communities?
column2: Secrecy protects women from social stigma
column4: or disapproval from elders and religious leaders
column5: allowing them to manage fertility discreetly.

column1: What are the most commonly preferred contraceptive methods among Muslim women in Nepal?
column2: Injectable contraceptives such as Depo-Provera are most preferred
column3: followed by oral contraceptive pills and condoms.

column1: Why do many Muslim women choose private facilities for family planning services?
column2: They prefer private providers because of better privacy
column4: and reduced fear of exposure within their community.

column1: What are the main reasons women discontinue using contraceptives?
column2: Side effects such as heavy bleeding
column4: and fear of long-term health problems like cancer often lead women to stop using contraception.

column1: How do myths and misconceptions affect family planning use?
column2: False beliefs
column3: such as the idea that contraceptive pills cause infertility or cancer
column4: discourage many women from starting or continuing contraceptive use.

column1: What role do religious leaders play in shaping community attitudes toward family planning?
column2: Religious leaders strongly influence community attitudes and can either support or discourage family planning depending on how they interpret religious texts.

column1: How can religious leaders be engaged to promote family planning?
column2: By encouraging them to highlight religious teachings that support responsible parenthood and emphasize the health benefits of birth spacing.

column1: Why is it important to involve husbands in family planning programs?
column2: Involving husbands fosters mutual understanding
column4: and increases the likelihood that couples will adopt and continue using family planning methods.

column1: What policy change could improve access to family planning for marginalized communities?
column2: Policies should prioritize culturally sensitive approaches that respect local values while ensuring women have access to accurate information and voluntary choices.

column1: Why do some women secretly use contraception even when it is socially discouraged?
column2: Because they recognize the personal health and economic benefits of spacing or limiting births
column3: even when social norms oppose such practices.

column1: What strategies can improve contraceptive use among Muslim women in Nepal?
column2: Providing accurate health information
column4: involving husbands and religious leaders
column5: and offering a variety of contraceptive choices can all increase use.

column1: Why is family planning considered an investment for a country’s future?
column2: It helps reduce poverty
column4: and support women’s education and economic participation
column5: leading to stronger and more resilient communities.

column1: How can the government make family planning programs more effective?
column2: By ensuring a consistent supply of contraceptives
column4: training providers
column5: collecting better data from private sectors
column6: and promoting family planning as a health measure rather than just population control.

column1: Why should family planning be promoted as a tool for healthy birth spacing rather than limiting births?
column2: Focusing on birth spacing respects cultural and religious values while still protecting maternal and child health and gaining broader community acceptance.

column1: What communication approach is most effective for promoting family planning in conservative communities?
column2: Using culturally appropriate language
column4: and providing one-on-one counseling in private or home-based settings are most effective.

column1: How can integrating family planning with other health programs improve outcomes?
column2: Combining family planning with maternal and child health services ensures women receive consistent information and access during antenatal and postnatal visits.

column1: Why do some women lack information about family planning despite national programs?
column2: Limited outreach
column4: and inadequate communication from health workers contribute to poor awareness
column5: especially in marginalized and rural groups.

column1: What are the key lessons for policymakers from Nepal’s experience with family planning in Muslim communities?
column2: Policies must account for cultural sensitivity
column4: spousal dynamics
column5: and the need for education and outreach through trusted community figures to ensure equitable access to contraception.
